description: The Implementing Cisco IP Switched Networks exam is the second of three exams required to obtain the Cisco Certified Network Professional certification. This exam focuses on Cisco switch implementation in medium and large environment. The topics covered range from HSRP, STP, VTP to Etherchannel and how and why we use them.. The typical viewer would be anyone responsible for the maintenance and implementation of Cisco Switches in a large or enterprise organization. This SWITCH Â emphasizes planning, configuring, and verifying the implementation of complex enterprise switching solutions that use the Cisco Enterprise Campus Architecture.
name: CCNP Routing and Switching - SWITCH
subtitle: Implementing Cisco IP Switched Networks

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.906
[SOUND] Hello and thank you for

2
00:00:04.906 --> 00:00:08.368
choosing ITProTV.

3
00:00:08.368 --> 00:00:11.246
We're talking about
Cisco Switch with Don Pezet.

4
00:00:11.246 --> 00:00:13.435
Don, could you tell us a little
bit about Cisco Switch?

5
00:00:13.435 --> 00:00:17.989
>> All right, the Cisco Switch series
is part of our Cisco Track that focuses

6
00:00:17.989 --> 00:00:22.486
specifically on, well yeah,
as the name implies, switches, right?

7
00:00:22.486 --> 00:00:25.479
In the Cisco world, a lot of times we
think about routers because that's where

8
00:00:25.479 --> 00:00:26.622
they have a really big focus.

9
00:00:26.622 --> 00:00:30.067
But their switching platform is actually
massive, amazing, they have a lot

10
00:00:30.067 --> 00:00:33.200
of technology in there, and
this course focuses specifically on it.

11
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:36.532
Now we refer to the course as
Cisco Switch, a lot of people do.

12
00:00:36.532 --> 00:00:40.281
The actual official name of the course,
a little more involved,

13
00:00:40.281 --> 00:00:44.985
is the Implementing Cisco IP Switch
Networks Course., A nice long title there,

14
00:00:44.985 --> 00:00:48.940
but basically what it's hinting at
is that switches do a lot more than

15
00:00:48.940 --> 00:00:50.674
just basic frame switching.

16
00:00:50.674 --> 00:00:54.383
Now they actually get involved with IP
networks in a lot more complexity and so

17
00:00:54.383 --> 00:00:58.102
that's all some of the stuff that we're
gonna see right here in this series.

18
00:00:58.102 --> 00:00:59.811
>> So Don,
who is this show targeted towards?

19
00:00:59.811 --> 00:01:02.651
>> It's targeted to a couple
of different people.

20
00:01:02.651 --> 00:01:05.431
So people that are trying to
pass Cisco exams, right, and

21
00:01:05.431 --> 00:01:08.723
it's gonna be one of them, but
really anybody whose responsible for

22
00:01:08.723 --> 00:01:11.187
supporting Cisco switches
out there in the field.

23
00:01:11.187 --> 00:01:14.118
And that means that you might be
a help desk or network engineer,

24
00:01:14.118 --> 00:01:17.918
even the junior network engineers, the
people are just getting started in network

25
00:01:17.918 --> 00:01:20.546
administration are usually responsible for
switches.

26
00:01:20.546 --> 00:01:23.105
Layer twos is where we'll
typically cut our teeth.

27
00:01:23.105 --> 00:01:26.521
Now, if you've done the CCNA andn some
of the earlier Cisco certifications,

28
00:01:26.521 --> 00:01:29.317
you already learned a bit about switches,
and really enough for

29
00:01:29.317 --> 00:01:30.580
a junior engineer, right?

30
00:01:30.580 --> 00:01:34.944
Those are focusing on small deployments,
a handful of switches.

31
00:01:34.944 --> 00:01:40.486
In the CCNP track, we take that and
we scale it up much, much larger.

32
00:01:40.486 --> 00:01:44.430
And so here, we're talking about not
just people that support Cisco switches,

33
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:47.910
the people that support hundreds,
even thousands of Cisco switches,

34
00:01:47.910 --> 00:01:51.115
cuz the technologies change when
you have a network of that size.

35
00:01:51.115 --> 00:01:53.641
That's all stuff we take into
account right here in this course.

36
00:01:53.641 --> 00:01:56.213
>> Is certification available for
the course?

37
00:01:56.213 --> 00:01:57.856
>> Absolutely, and
you don't have to do it,

38
00:01:57.856 --> 00:02:00.835
if you just wanna learn about Cisco
switches, this course is great for that.

39
00:02:00.835 --> 00:02:03.314
We really going into some of the advanced
features on what you can do.

40
00:02:03.314 --> 00:02:07.340
But most of the people that watch this
show are people that are seeking out

41
00:02:07.340 --> 00:02:11.105
the Cisco Certified Network
Professional Routing and Switching,

42
00:02:11.105 --> 00:02:12.639
CCNP R&S Certification.

43
00:02:12.639 --> 00:02:15.689
This is one of three exams
to get that CCNP R&S,

44
00:02:15.689 --> 00:02:18.677
in fact let me bring up
Cisco's website here.

45
00:02:18.677 --> 00:02:22.307
And I've got there the page for
the CCNP Routing and Switching and

46
00:02:22.307 --> 00:02:25.879
in order to get this certification
you have to pass three exams.

47
00:02:25.879 --> 00:02:29.725
The three exams are the 300-101 Route,

48
00:02:29.725 --> 00:02:33.481
which focuses just on
routing technologies.

49
00:02:33.481 --> 00:02:35.343
And granted,
some switches are layer three switches,

50
00:02:35.343 --> 00:02:36.779
that means that the switch can do routing.

51
00:02:36.779 --> 00:02:38.393
So it's a bit of overlap between the two.

52
00:02:38.393 --> 00:02:42.605
Then there's 300-1155 switch,
that's what this one is based on.

53
00:02:42.605 --> 00:02:45.736
This course is focused
on that particular exam.

54
00:02:45.736 --> 00:02:49.849
And then there's a 300-135 TSHOOT,
which is troubleshooting, and

55
00:02:49.849 --> 00:02:53.276
your troubleshooting not just routers,
but switches as well.

56
00:02:53.276 --> 00:02:57.104
So there's a little bit of switching
technology in all three of these, but

57
00:02:57.104 --> 00:03:00.649
this course, Switch is the only one
that focuses on just switching.

58
00:03:00.649 --> 00:03:03.839
So if you are looking to get your CCNP and
you're studying for this exam,

59
00:03:03.839 --> 00:03:06.001
that's exactly what this
is targeted towards.

60
00:03:06.001 --> 00:03:08.645
It's the only certification
that this exam counts towards.

61
00:03:08.645 --> 00:03:11.730
Cisco has a bunch of other
certifications with different exams.

62
00:03:11.730 --> 00:03:14.750
This one just counts towards
CCNP routing and switches.

63
00:03:14.750 --> 00:03:18.478
>> Don, that sounds great, now what
topics are covered in Cisco Switch?

64
00:03:18.478 --> 00:03:22.230
If you wanna see the actual topics that
are on the exam, you can go to CISCO's

65
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:24.880
website and they've got where you can
download the exam objectives right there.

66
00:03:24.880 --> 00:03:27.570
And they lay it all out piece by piece,
every individual technology.

67
00:03:27.570 --> 00:03:30.760
When we built this course, we actually
structured it around those exam objectives

68
00:03:30.760 --> 00:03:32.230
to make sure we covered every single one.

69
00:03:32.230 --> 00:03:34.940
But we did rearrange them a little bit.

70
00:03:34.940 --> 00:03:37.980
We put them in a slightly different
order to make it a little more logical,

71
00:03:37.980 --> 00:03:39.690
get a little more flow.

72
00:03:39.690 --> 00:03:42.836
Basically the course is divided into
three sections, and in the first section,

73
00:03:42.836 --> 00:03:46.200
we're focusing on what's kinda generally
called layer two technologies.

74
00:03:46.200 --> 00:03:50.280
And what we really do is, we take
everything that you learned about switches

75
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:55.720
in the CCNA and we blow it up on scale,
and we see what it's like when we have far

76
00:03:55.720 --> 00:04:00.030
more greater amount of systems involved
and we also learn a lot more detail.

77
00:04:00.030 --> 00:04:01.740
So we take things like VLANS,

78
00:04:01.740 --> 00:04:06.320
expanding tree protocol, we take trunking,
like 802.1Q trunking, and

79
00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:10.380
those technologies, and we go a lot
more in depth, into how they work,

80
00:04:10.380 --> 00:04:13.580
how they can be optimized and how they
can handle large scale networking.

81
00:04:13.580 --> 00:04:15.740
So that's where we start this series and

82
00:04:15.740 --> 00:04:19.900
where really, about half the content
falls is right inside of there.

83
00:04:19.900 --> 00:04:22.480
The other half of the course
is spent on two other areas.

84
00:04:22.480 --> 00:04:25.363
We've got switch security,
Cisco levels infrastructure security, but

85
00:04:25.363 --> 00:04:28.340
we're really talking about security
on the switches themselves.

86
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:33.190
There are some amazing security features
that are included on every Cisco switch

87
00:04:33.190 --> 00:04:35.240
and they're all turned off by default.

88
00:04:35.240 --> 00:04:36.663
So ifyou don't know they're there,

89
00:04:36.663 --> 00:04:38.714
your switch is actually
running in a pretty open mode.

90
00:04:38.714 --> 00:04:40.981
So you get in there and
you lock it down and

91
00:04:40.981 --> 00:04:45.250
there are a ton of network attacks
that you can kill right on the switch.

92
00:04:45.250 --> 00:04:48.100
So your workstations, your servers,
they never even see that attack,

93
00:04:48.100 --> 00:04:50.920
they're completely unaffected,
cuz the switch protects them.

94
00:04:50.920 --> 00:04:52.480
So we take a look at some
of those features and

95
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:55.070
how they can be implemented and
what you can do with them.

96
00:04:55.070 --> 00:04:58.580
And then we wrap up the series by
talking about infrastructure services.

97
00:04:58.580 --> 00:05:02.590
And these are other things that we can run
on our switches to improve our network.

98
00:05:02.590 --> 00:05:07.300
One of my favorite shows is in that
section, it's the first-hop redundancy.

99
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:10.280
When you have a router that's critical
to your network and that router fails,

100
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:11.120
what happens?

101
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:13.923
Well, you lose remote connectivity.

102
00:05:13.923 --> 00:05:18.046
But if I'm using my switches to do layer
three switching, I can actually create

103
00:05:18.046 --> 00:05:22.354
many, many virtual routers and have it
where entire switches, entire portions of

104
00:05:22.354 --> 00:05:26.433
my networking fail, and we'll just route
right around it and get on through.

105
00:05:26.433 --> 00:05:30.194
So that's a technology that's really easy
to do on switches if we plan for and so

106
00:05:30.194 --> 00:05:32.943
we take a look at how to do that and
get a chance to see that and

107
00:05:32.943 --> 00:05:35.378
we learn about configuring
layer three switches.

108
00:05:35.378 --> 00:05:38.256
So we're not just focused on the layer
two side, although that's where

109
00:05:38.256 --> 00:05:41.037
the bulk of the exam is, we do learn
about the layer three side as well,

110
00:05:41.037 --> 00:05:43.561
and see how we can merge routing
functionality right in there.

111
00:05:43.561 --> 00:05:46.570
So that's kind of a quick overview of all
the topics that we're gonna cover right

112
00:05:46.570 --> 00:05:47.379
here in this series.

113
00:05:47.379 --> 00:05:50.703
>> Well thank you so much Don,
Cisco Switch sounds like an amazing show.

114
00:05:50.703 --> 00:05:54.799
And you wanna catch all the episodes in
our course library, and thank you for

115
00:05:54.799 --> 00:05:55.887
watching ITProTV.

116
00:05:55.887 --> 00:05:59.865
Remember, ITProTV is binge-worthy.

117
00:05:59.865 --> 00:06:02.338
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain how to configure and verify some switch administration tasks. Watch as they detail the Ternary Content Addressable Memory (TCAM) table and how to use it to optimize switch functionality. Other topics include MAC address tables administration and troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Switch Administration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.596 --> 00:00:12.780
All right.

3
00:00:12.780 --> 00:00:16.211
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.211 --> 00:00:17.744
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.744 --> 00:00:20.480
Here with me today,
the illustrious Don Pezet.

6
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:21.560
How's it going, Don?

7
00:00:21.560 --> 00:00:23.770
>> Well, now I feel like I should
be wearing fancier clothes.

8
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:24.670
>> Well, you should.

9
00:00:24.670 --> 00:00:26.850
>> Well, I'm excited to be
back on the show, Daniel, and

10
00:00:26.850 --> 00:00:28.690
excited to kick off another series.

11
00:00:28.690 --> 00:00:32.400
We're diving into the world
of CCNP switch today,

12
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:36.360
and this is a fun one, cuz we'll
really get a chance to take a look at

13
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:38.640
what's normally a pretty simple device,
right?

14
00:00:38.640 --> 00:00:40.800
A layer two switch,
not a whole lot to them.

15
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:43.810
So you think you just throw them
on the network and you're done,

16
00:00:43.810 --> 00:00:46.390
but there's a lot of cool stuff in there.

17
00:00:46.390 --> 00:00:49.470
We're gonna run through all the various
features, and we gotta get started

18
00:00:49.470 --> 00:00:52.470
somewhere, so today we're gonna be
jumping into just switch administration.

19
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:56.920
These are gonna be the things your switch
does every single day that we just need to

20
00:00:56.920 --> 00:01:00.650
be aware of, and sometimes
influences we work with the device.

21
00:01:00.650 --> 00:01:03.760
>> Yeah, now Don,
we've learned in CCNA all about switching.

22
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:05.500
Well, at least we thought we did anyway.

23
00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:08.760
Basically layer two device,
working with MAC addresses, and

24
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:10.890
that was kind of about
where they go us though.

25
00:01:10.890 --> 00:01:13.000
But in CCNP, we gotta dive deeper, right?

26
00:01:13.000 --> 00:01:14.520
And that's what you're
gonna show us today.

27
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:18.650
>> Absolutely, yeah, and
just as an example, in the CCNA,

28
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:23.450
you learn enough to implement switches in
really in any small, medium environment.

29
00:01:23.450 --> 00:01:25.260
Even in some enterprise environments,

30
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:27.910
what's covered under CCNA
is enough to get you by.

31
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:31.380
But there are some interesting things
that happen in the background that,

32
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:36.730
as your network gets bigger and
bigger and bigger, your switch just can't

33
00:01:36.730 --> 00:01:39.290
keep up unless you understand
what's going on behind the scenes.

34
00:01:39.290 --> 00:01:43.480
And so that's one of the topics
that I wanna lead off with today

35
00:01:43.480 --> 00:01:46.490
is our good friend, the MAC address table.

36
00:01:46.490 --> 00:01:48.500
And Daniel, you know all about
the MAC address table, right?

37
00:01:48.500 --> 00:01:51.216
>> Every last stitch of that MAC,
I've got it down.

38
00:01:51.216 --> 00:01:52.048
Sure, yeah.

39
00:01:52.048 --> 00:01:55.810
>> [LAUGH] Now, we learned under
the CCNA that the MAC address table, or

40
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:59.110
the media access control address,
the MAC address table,

41
00:01:59.110 --> 00:02:01.826
it's the primary function of a switch,
right?

42
00:02:01.826 --> 00:02:05.460
A switch is a layer two device,
the MAC address is your layer two address.

43
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:09.910
So everything that plugs into your
network, every router, every PC,

44
00:02:09.910 --> 00:02:14.410
every laptop, every television,
printer, whatever it is

45
00:02:14.410 --> 00:02:19.110
that has a network jack on it Is gonna
have a MAC address on your network.

46
00:02:19.110 --> 00:02:22.690
And what your switch is doing,
deep down in its little layer two heart,

47
00:02:22.690 --> 00:02:26.460
is it's watching for
your frames to go across the network.

48
00:02:26.460 --> 00:02:31.060
It looks at the layer two header to find
the source and destination MAC address.

49
00:02:31.060 --> 00:02:35.270
It then looks at the source MAC address
and says, what port did this come in on?

50
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:39.100
All right, well,
that is where that MAC address lives.

51
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:43.390
And it maps the source MAC address to
the port that that traffic came in on.

52
00:02:43.390 --> 00:02:46.570
And then it finds the destination, right,
the destination MAC address that you're

53
00:02:46.570 --> 00:02:50.300
going to, and it hopefully already
knows what port that one's on so

54
00:02:50.300 --> 00:02:54.610
we can send it right to that interface and
not bother anybody else on the switch.

55
00:02:54.610 --> 00:02:59.630
That is the basic layer two functionality
that every switch performs, and

56
00:02:59.630 --> 00:03:03.080
the MAC address table
is a key piece of that.

57
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:05.930
You can view the MAC address
table on any switch.

58
00:03:05.930 --> 00:03:11.140
The command, if you think back to the old

59
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:15.219
it's just show mac address-table.

60
00:03:15.219 --> 00:03:16.735
There we go,
gotta remember where my hyphen is.

61
00:03:16.735 --> 00:03:17.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

62
00:03:17.400 --> 00:03:21.240
it'll give you a list of all the MAC
addresses that it's learned and

63
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:22.610
the interfaces that it's learned them.

64
00:03:22.610 --> 00:03:27.920
So you'll see my switch has learned
a handful here, and the ports they're tied

65
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:33.958
to, so for example, the MAC ending in
0417 is plugged into Fa1/0/22, right?

66
00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:34.709
That's the port it's on.

67
00:03:34.709 --> 00:03:37.128
All right.
This is a key piece of what's going on in

68
00:03:37.128 --> 00:03:38.830
the background.

69
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:44.070
But what a lot of people don't realize is
the MAC address table is just one table,

70
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:47.720
and it's actually nested
inside of another table.

71
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:50.760
This is where things get
really kinda squirrely.

72
00:03:50.760 --> 00:03:54.790
Sometimes, as you study for Cisco,
you hear about the MAC table.

73
00:03:54.790 --> 00:03:58.030
And then other times you hear
people talk about the CAM table.

74
00:03:58.030 --> 00:03:59.760
And you're like,
wait a minute, the CAM table?

75
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:01.430
Are they writing MAC backwards?

76
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:03.300
>> I just thought it was
dyslexic Cisco people.

77
00:04:03.300 --> 00:04:06.744
>> Yeah, and you won't find a lot
of information on it, that's what

78
00:04:06.744 --> 00:04:10.820
makes it even harder, so if you go to
look it up, Google will autocorrect you.

79
00:04:10.820 --> 00:04:12.353
Did you mean MAC table?

80
00:04:12.353 --> 00:04:13.713
>> No. [LAUGH] >> No, I typed CAM!

81
00:04:13.713 --> 00:04:18.330
So, when you talk about the CAM table,
it's a bit different, right?

82
00:04:18.330 --> 00:04:22.570
The CAM table is talking about the
hardware memory, the actual memory that's

83
00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:25.930
on the motherboard where the MAC
address table is stored.

84
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:30.310
And the CAM is actually
arranged as a table itself, and

85
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:33.560
it's got several things that
are tucked away inside of it.

86
00:04:33.560 --> 00:04:37.460
And so the thing as a whole,
it gets a little weird.

87
00:04:37.460 --> 00:04:40.840
There's actually five
different sets of data

88
00:04:40.840 --> 00:04:44.510
that are collected into
what's called your TCAM.

89
00:04:44.510 --> 00:04:48.922
And TCAM, I'm just gonna throw out as
many acronyms as I can this episode,

90
00:04:48.922 --> 00:04:53.845
we're gonna go crazy, TCAM, it stands for
ternary content addressable memory.

91
00:04:53.845 --> 00:04:57.992
Now, when you talk about
your regular CAM table,

92
00:04:57.992 --> 00:05:04.460
you run a query against it and you say,
is this Mac address on this port?

93
00:05:04.460 --> 00:05:06.130
You get a true or a false back.

94
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:07.300
That's the way that hardware works.

95

00:16:54.690 --> 00:16:58.870

00:16:58.870 --> 00:17:01.820

00:17:01.820 --> 00:17:03.440

00:17:03.440 --> 00:17:07.120

00:17:07.120 --> 00:17:08.380

00:17:08.380 --> 00:17:12.870

00:17:17.620 --> 00:17:20.360

00:17:42.840 --> 00:17:44.070

00:17:45.150 --> 00:17:48.890

00:17:54.930 --> 00:17:57.670

00:18:11.510 --> 00:18:13.630

00:22:07.870 --> 00:22:11.690

00:22:15.510 --> 00:22:20.080

00:22:20.080 --> 00:22:23.520

00:22:23.520 --> 00:22:26.895

00:22:26.895 --> 00:22:29.590

So when we look down here, we'll start

00:22:41.160 --> 00:22:44.431

448
00:22:52.552 --> 00:22:55.253
>> Now Don, we've going over this

00:22:55.253 --> 00:22:58.130
this is something that we

450
00:22:58.130 --> 00:23:01.180
One of the things that I've realized
in my career is that a lot of switch

00:23:01.180 --> 00:23:05.960
administration comes down to, I've got
a device plugged in, it's turned on, and

00:23:05.960 --> 00:23:08.110
it's not showing up in the table.

453
00:23:08.110 --> 00:23:10.430
And that can be extremely frustrating.

454
00:23:10.430 --> 00:23:12.050
You had to do a lot of troubleshooting.

455
00:23:12.050 --> 00:23:12.890
You're going to help us out with this.

00:23:12.890 --> 00:23:15.730
You're going to give us some
nice things to follow, right?

457
00:23:15.730 --> 00:23:19.690
>> Yeah, normally if you plug
a device in and it gets a link light,

458
00:23:19.690 --> 00:23:22.820
then usually that means your MAC
address is going to be detected.

459
00:23:22.820 --> 00:23:25.110
You're going to be in the MAC table,
right?

460
00:23:25.110 --> 00:23:27.040
The link light is all you need.

461
00:23:27.040 --> 00:23:29.990
But there is a certain condition that
can happen on a Cisco switch that

462
00:23:29.990 --> 00:23:33.530
can cause you to have a link light and
not show up in the Mac table,

463
00:23:33.530 --> 00:23:35.180
not be able to communicate, all right?

464
00:23:35.180 --> 00:23:37.407
It's called err-disable, right?

465
00:23:37.407 --> 00:23:40.290
E-R-R-disable, err-disable.

466
00:23:40.290 --> 00:23:42.630
And err-disable is a status.

467
00:23:42.630 --> 00:23:45.000
It's just short for error disabled.

468
00:23:45.000 --> 00:23:48.820
And it means that the interface might
look like it's functioning, but

469
00:23:48.820 --> 00:23:52.340
an error occurred that
made the switch disabled.

470
00:23:52.340 --> 00:23:55.530
And oftentimes this can cause
the link light to turn off, so

471
00:23:55.530 --> 00:23:57.130
you don't get a link light at all.

472
00:23:57.130 --> 00:24:00.990
But there are times when the link light
stays on, and you just can communicate,

473
00:24:00.990 --> 00:24:02.980
it creates a really tricky situation.

474
00:24:02.980 --> 00:24:06.374
So, if you have a client plugged in and
you're just not learning their Mac

475
00:24:06.374 --> 00:24:09.127
address, it's a good idea to
see if the port got disabled.

476
00:24:09.127 --> 00:24:11.826
I know, I said there's a couple of
situations that can cause this.

477
00:24:11.826 --> 00:24:16.230
There's actually a lot of
situations that can cause it.

478
00:24:16.230 --> 00:24:21.120
Ranging from bad cabling,
unidirectional links,

479
00:24:21.120 --> 00:24:24.120
maybe you've got eight wires
inside of a cat five cable and

480
00:24:24.120 --> 00:24:26.660
maybe one of them is loose,
that can cause error disabled.

481
00:24:26.660 --> 00:24:31.160
You could have a duplex mismatch that's
significant and that could cause it.

482
00:24:31.160 --> 00:24:34.940
That's not so common anymore but

00:24:34.940 --> 00:24:37.240
We can have security violations.

484
00:24:37.240 --> 00:24:39.440
If you've configured port security, and

00:24:39.440 --> 00:24:42.150

00:24:42.150 --> 00:24:45.620
And you plug in somebody else's

487
00:24:45.620 --> 00:24:46.870
it's gonna trigger port security, right?

488
00:24:46.870 --> 00:24:51.230
We saw that in the CCNA Well,
when port security locks down a port,

489
00:24:51.230 --> 00:24:52.260
that's air disabled.

490
00:24:52.260 --> 00:24:53.560
That's another one.

491
00:24:53.560 --> 00:24:55.960
And when a port goes air disabled,
it's going to lock it, and

492
00:24:55.960 --> 00:24:59.020
it's going to stay locked
forever by default.

493
00:24:59.020 --> 00:25:01.100
Until one of two things happens.

494
00:25:01.100 --> 00:25:04.440
Either one, an administrator shuts
the port down and turns it back on.

495
00:25:04.440 --> 00:25:05.660
That resets it.

496
00:25:05.660 --> 00:25:07.490
Or two, somebody reboots the switch.

497
00:25:07.490 --> 00:25:09.350
Which hopefully you never do.

498
00:25:09.350 --> 00:25:11.940
So, those are the two conditions
that'll bring that port back up, but

499
00:25:11.940 --> 00:25:15.740
if the error condition still exists it's
just going to go error disabled again,

500
00:25:15.740 --> 00:25:17.740
it's not going to help anything.

501
00:25:17.740 --> 00:25:20.706
So you normally need to
resolve the issue first and

502
00:25:20.706 --> 00:25:22.832
then resolve it by doing shut down.

503
00:25:22.832 --> 00:25:25.510
Now I've had these happen

00:25:25.510 --> 00:25:28.000
I'll give you one that happened to me.

00:25:28.000 --> 00:25:32.190
Is what if you're doing span,

00:25:32.190 --> 00:25:34.590

00:25:41.580 --> 00:25:42.750
What's gonna happen?

00:25:42.750 --> 00:25:44.060

00:25:44.060 --> 00:25:46.260
And when that happens, they're disabled.

00:25:46.260 --> 00:25:48.320
And it's beautiful because

00:25:48.320 --> 00:25:49.280
>> Oh, that's amazing.

00:25:49.280 --> 00:25:50.660
>> It doesn't just take
the 100 meg one down.

00:25:50.660 --> 00:25:52.344
That would be too convenient.

00:25:52.344 --> 00:25:53.683
>> If we're gonna fail,
we're gonna fail epically.

517
00:25:53.683 --> 00:25:55.450
[LAUGH]
>> That's right, it goes all out.

518
00:25:55.450 --> 00:25:57.520
So you know it can really
put you in a bind.

519
00:25:57.520 --> 00:26:01.140
So you always wanna remember that
there's a special error status

520
00:26:01.140 --> 00:26:03.780
that's not necessarily reflected
on the front of the switch.

00:26:03.780 --> 00:26:06.830
If you have a Syslog set up,

522
00:26:06.830 --> 00:26:10.750
You will see that unless the error's

523
00:26:10.750 --> 00:26:16.030
the Syslog Server, so there's potential

00:26:16.030 --> 00:26:17.580

00:26:17.580 --> 00:26:19.650
And now, you've gotta get a console

00:26:19.650 --> 00:26:20.668
So it's a pretty deal.

00:26:20.668 --> 00:26:22.346
It's definitely something

is a great way to quickly see if

550
00:27:34.125 --> 00:27:36.995
ports are healthy or if they're in
an error disabled state like that.

551
00:27:38.265 --> 00:27:41.130
You can then do show interface and

552
00:27:41.130 --> 00:27:44.110
specify the interface that's
your problem child, right?

553
00:27:45.180 --> 00:27:47.766
So I'll point it right at fa1/0/12.

554
00:27:47.766 --> 00:27:50.109
And we're gonna get a lot of data here,

555
00:27:50.109 --> 00:27:53.800
a lot of which we don't
necessarily care about, right?

556
00:27:53.800 --> 00:27:57.180
But some of it can give us
hints as to what our error is.

557
00:27:57.180 --> 00:27:59.520
And so what I'm looking for
is right here on this first line,

558
00:27:59.520 --> 00:28:02.380
where it says that it's down,
and that it's air disabled.

559
00:28:02.380 --> 00:28:04.120
All right.
Well I kind of already knew that,

560
00:28:04.120 --> 00:28:05.350
but now I can see it.

561
00:28:05.350 --> 00:28:08.810
Maybe I skipped that show interface status
and I knew this was my problem port, so

562
00:28:08.810 --> 00:28:11.370
I just ran show interface on that one.

563
00:28:11.370 --> 00:28:13.950
But what I'm really looking for
is that move down a little bit.

564
00:28:13.950 --> 00:28:18.060
Right down here is where you start
to get your port statistics.

565
00:28:18.060 --> 00:28:21.220
And this is where we can start to look for
things like errors.

566
00:28:21.220 --> 00:28:25.430
So I've got output errors, collisions,
interface resets, these things.

567
00:28:25.430 --> 00:28:26.020
Right?

568
00:28:26.020 --> 00:28:31.120
These are great indicators of
bad cabling or failing NICs.

569
00:28:31.120 --> 00:28:32.540
Network interface cards, they do fail.

570
00:28:32.540 --> 00:28:35.230
It happens, and you get all sorts
of craziness when that occurs.

571
00:28:35.230 --> 00:28:38.050
So we definitely wanna keep an eye out for
that.

572
00:28:38.050 --> 00:28:43.210
If you see things like collisions,
collisions shouldn't happen on a switch.

573
00:28:43.210 --> 00:28:45.730
Each port is its own collision domain.

574
00:28:45.730 --> 00:28:48.640
It's just the switch and
the client that's on that port.

575
00:28:48.640 --> 00:28:50.230
You shouldn't have collisions.

576
00:28:50.230 --> 00:28:53.440
If you do,
that's an indicator of a problem, right.

577
00:28:53.440 --> 00:28:57.220
But on mine, I don't have any of those so
I'm actually looking okay here.

578
00:28:57.220 --> 00:28:58.830
I've got an interface reset.

579
00:28:58.830 --> 00:29:02.450
That just means I maybe rebooted the
computer on the other side, or plugged and

580
00:29:02.450 --> 00:29:03.270
unplugged the cable.

581
00:29:03.270 --> 00:29:05.000
That doesn't necessarily mean a problem.

582
00:29:05.000 --> 00:29:09.000
But all my error stuff,
my buffer failures, all that.

583
00:29:09.000 --> 00:29:09.930
It's all clear.

584
00:29:09.930 --> 00:29:12.590
So I'm pretty sure I don't
have a hardware error here.

585
00:29:12.590 --> 00:29:16.520
If I do have a hardware error, then it's
probably time to call system attack and

586
00:29:16.520 --> 00:29:19.190
start going through that process
because you've got to figure out

587
00:29:19.190 --> 00:29:22.580
is it the client that's the problem or
is it your switch or is it the cable?

588
00:29:22.580 --> 00:29:24.000
Well, you can replace a cable.

589
00:29:24.000 --> 00:29:25.730
You can try another client.

590
00:29:25.730 --> 00:29:28.130
But if it's the switch,
you're gonna have to get Cisco involved.

591
00:29:29.400 --> 00:29:32.320
All right, now, in my case I still
don't know what the problem is.

592
00:29:32.320 --> 00:29:33.560
So I need to go a little bit further.

593
00:29:33.560 --> 00:29:37.640
Well, now I need to start thinking about
all the different things that can cause

594
00:29:37.640 --> 00:29:39.320
an error disabled state.

595
00:29:39.320 --> 00:29:44.780
So I mentioned doing monitoring,
the span monitoring.

596
00:29:44.780 --> 00:29:47.120
So I might look and
see if I've got any of those configured.

597
00:29:47.120 --> 00:29:50.850
But I know that I have port
security turned on in this switch.

598
00:29:50.850 --> 00:29:53.667
So I might just want to check the security
state of this particular port.

599
00:29:53.667 --> 00:29:58.197
So I could do a show, port dash security,
I could just run the whole thing, or

600
00:29:58.197 --> 00:30:02.450
I could point it to an interface,
and just look at that one interface,

601
00:30:02.450 --> 00:30:06.821
which was what was it 12,
something it was 12, that sounds right.

602
00:30:06.821 --> 00:30:09.398
So we can take a look at it and
sure enough,

603
00:30:09.398 --> 00:30:14.640
right here I see port security is enabled,
port status, secure shutdown.

604
00:30:14.640 --> 00:30:19.450
That means that it violated the
limitations, and now we have a violation.

605
00:30:19.450 --> 00:30:22.760
So I can see the last source
address on this particular MAC.

606
00:30:22.760 --> 00:30:25.650
So this is the MAC that's
on that port right now.

607
00:30:25.650 --> 00:30:28.130
This guy right here.

608
00:30:28.130 --> 00:30:31.412
If I check the port's configuration,

609
00:30:31.412 --> 00:30:35.887
let's go see what its actually
set to on that one, and

610
00:30:35.887 --> 00:30:42.269
I can see that it's set with port
security limited, it's one MAC address.

611
00:30:42.269 --> 00:30:44.780
This Mac address right here doesn't match.

612
00:30:44.780 --> 00:30:49.715
So now I know I either need to change
this MAC address, update it to reflect

613
00:30:49.715 --> 00:30:55.128
the existing one, or I could go and take
this rogue machine off of my network, but

614
00:30:55.128 --> 00:31:00.569
in my case I'll just go and change the MAC
address so we can get that back in there.

615
00:31:00.569 --> 00:31:05.553
And so I'll just say switchport
port-security mac-address and

616
00:31:05.553 --> 00:31:08.850
then I'm gonna punch
in the one from above.

617
00:31:08.850 --> 00:31:10.902
Which is kind of nice to
have it on the screen.

618
00:31:10.902 --> 00:31:13.364
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it makes it a little easier to type.

619
00:31:13.364 --> 00:31:15.200
All right, so I'm go ahead and
punch that one in.

620
00:31:15.200 --> 00:31:19.150
So that's gonna update it and
oh, shoot, I've hit my maximum so

621
00:31:19.150 --> 00:31:21.060
I need to do a switchport.

622
00:31:22.310 --> 00:31:23.810
Actually, here we need to do a shutdown.

623
00:31:23.810 --> 00:31:29.470
Let's take that down, and we'll re-run
that command and oh, you know what?

624
00:31:29.470 --> 00:31:33.080
I need to clear the address
that was in there first.

625
00:31:33.080 --> 00:31:37.190
So let me do a no switchport port-securty.

626
00:31:37.190 --> 00:31:40.469
Probably just been easier to disable the
whole thing, but we'll do it the hard way.

627
00:31:42.460 --> 00:31:44.310
So I'm just gonna MAC address off.

628
00:31:44.310 --> 00:31:45.800
I guess I could have raised the maximum.

629
00:31:45.800 --> 00:31:48.815
I could have said, switchport
port-security maximum 2, and bumped it up.

630
00:31:48.815 --> 00:31:50.075
That would have worked also.

631
00:31:50.075 --> 00:31:52.160
But, I'm just gonna tack this one on.

632
00:31:52.160 --> 00:31:55.430
I did a shutdown on the port,
so that turned it off, and

633
00:31:55.430 --> 00:31:57.980
now when I do a no shutdown,
it's gonna bring it back up.

634
00:31:57.980 --> 00:32:02.700
Now, if I didn't fix the problem,
it's just gonna go error, disabled again.

635
00:32:02.700 --> 00:32:05.189
But I did fix my problem,
so it should come up.

636
00:32:06.720 --> 00:32:09.656
Once it comes up it should no
longer show as error disabled.

637
00:32:09.656 --> 00:32:14.530
So there it goes,
it's a POE phone on the other side, so

638
00:32:14.530 --> 00:32:17.850
that's power over ethernet
kicking into the phone there.

639
00:32:17.850 --> 00:32:23.630
So just grant it a power, interface came
up, and if I do a show interface status

640
00:32:23.630 --> 00:32:29.470
I should be able to see that port,
right there, is now connected.

641
00:32:29.470 --> 00:32:32.340
It's got full duplex,
and it's up and happy.

642
00:32:32.340 --> 00:32:36.650
So that's another thing to keep an eye
out for on the back end of the switch.

643
00:32:36.650 --> 00:32:39.822
These are things that
happen every single day.

644
00:32:39.822 --> 00:32:44.340
This isn't magic, this is not high-end
stuff that you do not have to worry about.

645
00:32:44.340 --> 00:32:45.510
If you are a small business,

646
00:32:45.510 --> 00:32:49.290
medium business, enterprise,
you potentially run into these.

647
00:32:49.290 --> 00:32:50.970
You could get air-disabled ports,

648
00:32:50.970 --> 00:32:54.850
you could exceed the amount of mac
addresses in your mac address table.

649
00:32:54.850 --> 00:32:59.510
You could, have the configured wrong
to not allow certain features to work.

650
00:32:59.510 --> 00:33:03.010
I see this with policy based routing
a lot, is where people will call me and

651
00:33:03.010 --> 00:33:06.840
say, well Don,
you showed how I could use PBR,

652
00:33:06.840 --> 00:33:09.010
policy based routing on
a layer three switch.

653
00:33:09.010 --> 00:33:10.500
And I tried, and it doesn't work.

654
00:33:10.500 --> 00:33:13.710
If you did something special on a switch,
you didn't show us.

655
00:33:13.710 --> 00:33:17.270
And in a way they're wong,
in a way they're right.

656
00:33:17.270 --> 00:33:19.910
In a lot of switches they
ship from the factory,

657
00:33:19.910 --> 00:33:23.830
on the PBR table is allocated zero memory.

658
00:33:23.830 --> 00:33:27.330
And so unless you change your template it
has no memory to use and it can't get out.

659
00:33:27.330 --> 00:33:31.420
Right so I probably did, either my
switch shipped with that as a default or

660
00:33:31.420 --> 00:33:33.080
I did modify the template to account for

661
00:33:33.080 --> 00:33:35.690
that and this is that missing
piece of knowledge right there.

662
00:33:35.690 --> 00:33:38.450
Right, so these are all things we
need to be aware of on our switches.

663
00:33:38.450 --> 00:33:39.830
>> Well very very cool, Don.

664
00:33:39.830 --> 00:33:41.140
Switch administration?

665
00:33:41.140 --> 00:33:44.680
Definitely a bulk of what we can be doing
inside of an enterprising environment.

666
00:33:44.680 --> 00:33:47.720
I know I've done plenty of these
Mac addresses not show showing.

667
00:33:47.720 --> 00:33:50.060
They're not, I know it's connected and
it's not working.

668
00:33:50.060 --> 00:33:53.610
Had to do a little bit of that
sometimes it, Nick going crazy.

669
00:33:53.610 --> 00:33:55.810
Lot of times it's the cable,
other times it's other things.

670
00:33:55.810 --> 00:33:58.470
So gotta be aware of how to
take care of those problems.

671
00:33:58.470 --> 00:34:00.740
Don, great demonstrations for us today.

672
00:34:00.740 --> 00:34:02.180
Hopefully you guys have
enjoyed it as well.

673
00:34:02.180 --> 00:34:05.470
Looks like we've come to the end of
another great episode here at ITProTV, so

674
00:34:05.470 --> 00:34:07.080
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

675
00:34:07.080 --> 00:34:08.610
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

676
00:34:08.610 --> 00:34:09.407
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

677
00:34:09.407 --> 00:34:11.179
>> And we'll see you next time.

678
00:34:11.179 --> 00:34:16.800
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel discuss a few Layer 2 protocols that are supported by Cisco switches. They begin the show by explaining the Cisco Discovery Protocol, then contrast CDP to LLDP (Link-Layer Discovery Protocol). Lastly, they cover Unidirectional Link Detection (UDLD) used to verify failed links.
episodes.title: Layer 2 Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.791 --> 00:00:13.461
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.461 --> 00:00:15.870
Welcome to another great episode ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:17.360
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:20.100
Here with me today,
it is the nefarious Don Pezet.

6
00:00:20.100 --> 00:00:20.940
How's it going today, Don?

7
00:00:20.940 --> 00:00:22.195
>> Wanted in seven states.

8
00:00:22.195 --> 00:00:24.043
>> [LAUGH]
>> I ordered the seven star system.

9
00:00:24.043 --> 00:00:26.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, well ladies and gentlemen,

10
00:00:26.470 --> 00:00:27.580
I am glad to be back on the show.

11
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:31.160
We're continuing on with
our CCNP switch adventure.

12
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:35.070
And today we're gonna be taking a look
at some of the layer two protocols,

13
00:00:35.070 --> 00:00:38.600
which I know what you're thinking, come
on Don a switch is a layer two device,

14
00:00:38.600 --> 00:00:40.070
what do we need to know there?

15
00:00:40.070 --> 00:00:41.720
Well there's actually some

16
00:00:42.890 --> 00:00:46.810
mysterious kind of hidden protocols
that run in the background on a switch.

17
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:51.700
That can operate even If your layer
three network isn't even configured.

18
00:00:51.700 --> 00:00:55.330
Your things like IP,
IPX, SPF3, those guys.

19
00:00:55.330 --> 00:00:58.840
If they are not even functioning, there
are some layer 2 protocols that run in

20
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:02.420
the background that do
some pretty neat stuff.

21
00:01:02.420 --> 00:01:04.950
At a minimum, we need to be aware of them,
because they're running, and

22
00:01:04.950 --> 00:01:05.910
you should know it.

23
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:08.650
But also because we might want
to manipulate them, change them,

24
00:01:08.650 --> 00:01:09.500
disable them, and so on.

25
00:01:09.500 --> 00:01:11.990
So that's what we're gonna
take a look at today.

26
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:14.480
>> Now, Don, because we wanna
do that voodoo that you do,

27
00:01:14.480 --> 00:01:18.150
where do we begin with these
mysterious liturgy protocol?

28
00:01:18.150 --> 00:01:18.810
>> All right.

29
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:22.095
Let's take a trip down memory
lane back to the CCNA.

30
00:01:22.095 --> 00:01:25.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> And back when you needed the CCNT and

31
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:26.760
CCNA certifications.

32
00:01:26.760 --> 00:01:30.230
You learned about CDP,
the Cisco Discovery Protocol.

33
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:34.700
CDP is on by default on
almost every Cisco switch.

34
00:01:34.700 --> 00:01:36.840
And what it is, is a layer 2 protocol.

35
00:01:36.840 --> 00:01:40.800
It runs regardless of whether you even
have IP addresses in your network.

36
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:45.460
And it will help to find
direct attach hardware.

37
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:49.060
If I've two switches plugged into each
other, right, cross over cable or

38
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:50.420
whatever between them.

39
00:01:50.420 --> 00:01:51.700
They'll actually see each other and

40
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:54.320
know that there's a Cisco switch
on the other side of that link.

41
00:01:54.320 --> 00:01:55.990
And that's what CDP does.

42
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:57.370
Cisco Discovery Protocol.

43
00:01:57.370 --> 00:02:01.310
It's a broadcast-based protocol,
so it doesn't need addresses.

44
00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:04.230
It just sends out a broadcast.

45
00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:06.480
And I don't mean like an IP broadcast,
255.255.255.255.

46
00:02:06.480 --> 00:02:08.730
It's a Mac addressed broadcast.

47
00:02:08.730 --> 00:02:10.390
So it uses the Mac address of all apps.

48
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:12.900
And as a switch will receive that,
and, and

49
00:02:12.900 --> 00:02:14.750
know to kind of send it
out of all its ports.

50
00:02:14.750 --> 00:02:17.810
Now, CDP is just looking for
who else is out there.

51
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:19.910
And this can be a good thing.

52
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:23.740
I know I, I've gone to networks where,
somebody called me and

53
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.040
said Don we've got a real problem.

54
00:02:25.040 --> 00:02:26.070
Stuff just isn't working.

55
00:02:26.070 --> 00:02:27.180
You need to come out and help.

56
00:02:27.180 --> 00:02:28.770
And I say, all right,
well, let me swing on by.

57
00:02:28.770 --> 00:02:31.920
So, I drive over there or fly or
however it is that I get there.

58
00:02:31.920 --> 00:02:35.730
And I get there, and I say, okay,
can you give me a topology diagram?

59
00:02:36.780 --> 00:02:38.882
And they say, boy,
we would really love to do that.

60
00:02:38.882 --> 00:02:42.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, yeah, we don't have one.

61
00:02:42.470 --> 00:02:47.180
Or, here's the topology diagram from seven
years ago, and it just doesn't help you.

62
00:02:47.180 --> 00:02:51.810
So now you're staring at this network and
you could start tracing cables, or

63
00:02:51.810 --> 00:02:54.020
you could use something like
CDP to learn the network,

64
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:55.860
to find how the devices are plugged in.

65
00:02:55.860 --> 00:02:58.510
And it'll tell you exactly what port
you're connected to on both ends

66
00:02:58.510 --> 00:02:59.470
of the cable.

67
00:02:59.470 --> 00:03:03.670
So your switch might have another
switch plugged into it and it'll show.

68
00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:04.790
Let me show you on one of these.

69
00:03:04.790 --> 00:03:08.680
So I got a switch fired up right here.

70
00:03:08.680 --> 00:03:15.470
And if I do a show CDP neighbors, right,
I can run that and I'm in core 1.

71
00:03:15.470 --> 00:03:19.210
And I can see that I've got
two connections to core 2.

72
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:21.910
And I've got one connection to access one.

73
00:03:21.910 --> 00:03:23.840
And I can see my local interface.

74
00:03:23.840 --> 00:03:26.355
So on this switch, port 22.

75
00:03:26.355 --> 00:03:32.000
Is connected way over here on the side
to port 24 on the other switch,

76
00:03:32.000 --> 00:03:33.190
I don't have to go trace a cable.

77
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:34.440
I know.
I know exactly what

78
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:35.710
port I'm in on both sides.

79
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:36.820
That's what CDP does.

80
00:03:38.410 --> 00:03:42.040
All right but
there's two problems with CDP.

81
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:44.050
Two reasons why most people don't use it.

82
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:45.220
>> Say it ain't so, Don.

83
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:45.900
>> I know, it's crazy.

84
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:47.920
Like if Cisco made this, isn't it great?

85
00:03:47.920 --> 00:03:49.500
Well, it does have some problems.

86
00:03:49.500 --> 00:03:51.160
First off, Cisco made this.

87
00:03:51.160 --> 00:03:52.510
Exactly what I said a second ago.

88
00:03:52.510 --> 00:03:54.900
Not that Cisco makes bad, well, all right.

89
00:03:54.900 --> 00:03:58.580
So, but the problem here is
it's Cisco proprietary, right.

90
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:00.710
Only Cisco supports CDP.

91
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:05.190
So when I run show CDP neighbor, I'm only
seeing other Cisco devices out there.

92
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:06.830
And it might be switches like this,

93
00:04:06.830 --> 00:04:12.450
or, let me see, I think I have a VoIP
phone plugged into somebody somewhere.

94
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:16.340
So if I do a show cdp neighbor,
let's see if I got a VoIP phone.

95
00:04:16.340 --> 00:04:21.280
Yeah, I got a VoIP phone on this one so
I can see its little zip ID or whatever.

96
00:04:21.280 --> 00:04:24.720
The MAC address is part of its name,
and I can spot that phone.

97
00:04:24.720 --> 00:04:26.180

00:19:02.500 --> 00:19:06.120

00:19:08.820 --> 00:19:12.000
Well, it is possible,
whether you're half or

full duplex,

00:19:14.650 --> 00:19:15.970
Usually something wrong with the cable.

00:19:15.970 --> 00:19:18.990
This is usually a physical

00:19:18.990 --> 00:19:21.850
Something go wrong with the physical
cable and you plug it in, and

00:19:21.850 --> 00:19:25.570

00:19:25.570 --> 00:19:27.820
Maybe you're able to receive,

00:19:29.080 --> 00:19:32.630
Now, on a workstation, it's going

00:19:32.630 --> 00:19:34.960
So, it's pretty recognizable.

00:19:34.960 --> 00:19:40.030

00:19:40.030 --> 00:19:44.440

00:19:44.440 --> 00:19:46.070

00:19:46.070 --> 00:19:49.220

00:19:49.220 --> 00:19:53.210
With spanning tree protocol,

00:19:53.210 --> 00:19:57.780

00:19:57.780 --> 00:20:00.300

00:20:00.300 --> 00:20:04.400

00:20:05.830 --> 00:20:07.510
You'd think there was nothing on there.

00:20:07.510 --> 00:20:12.130
But if we keep one end of the link up and
the other end is down, the switch that's

00:20:12.130 --> 00:20:15.830
holding it down will know that link

418
00:20:15.830 --> 00:20:17.210
It'll know it's there.

419
00:20:17.210 --> 00:20:19.870
And it's not sending any data,

00:20:19.870 --> 00:20:23.130
But it's receiving data, and

421
00:20:23.130 --> 00:20:27.460
Well, imagine if you will,

00:20:27.460 --> 00:20:32.260

00:20:32.260 --> 00:20:35.540

And all of a sudden,

And I say boy I could

00:20:40.540 --> 00:20:42.300
Right?
That's what spanning tree protocol does.

00:20:42.300 --> 00:20:46.870
I'm going to bring that link up and

00:20:46.870 --> 00:20:49.320
I'm receiving the BPDUs

00:20:49.320 --> 00:20:53.730

00:20:53.730 --> 00:20:55.190

00:20:55.190 --> 00:20:56.370
What's going on?

00:20:56.370 --> 00:20:59.060
There could be problems with the cable

00:20:59.060 --> 00:21:00.890

00:21:00.890 --> 00:21:02.510

00:21:12.860 --> 00:21:15.460
You could have several cables

00:21:21.720 --> 00:21:25.930

555
00:26:59.040 --> 00:27:05.000
In normal mode, if we don't get a message
back, we go into a warning status, right?

556
00:27:05.000 --> 00:27:08.140
But a warning status doesn't
take the port offline.

557
00:27:08.140 --> 00:27:11.040
It just generates a sys log message and
so now you've got in your logs,

558
00:27:11.040 --> 00:27:12.140
and you know about it.

559
00:27:12.140 --> 00:27:14.650
But it doesn't actually
do anything about it.

560
00:27:14.650 --> 00:27:16.230
Aggressive mode is different.

561
00:27:16.230 --> 00:27:19.200
Aggressive mode waits for eight failures.

562
00:27:19.200 --> 00:27:23.905
If it gets eight failures in a row,
it puts the port into err-disabled.

563
00:27:23.905 --> 00:27:25.565
Moves it into that disabled state.

564
00:27:25.565 --> 00:27:26.655
So now the port's out.

565
00:27:26.655 --> 00:27:29.425
We know it's damaged and
we have to take action on it.

566
00:27:29.425 --> 00:27:31.255
But it's eight attempts.

567
00:27:32.305 --> 00:27:35.795
And these little broadcast messages
they're being sent out every so often.

568
00:27:35.795 --> 00:27:36.935
There's a little timer that runs.

569
00:27:36.935 --> 00:27:38.015
And you can adjust the timer.

570
00:27:38.015 --> 00:27:41.615
If you're really worried about that
time and you want this to happen fast,

571
00:27:41.615 --> 00:27:45.610
you can adjust the timer for it and
shrink that down if you need to.

572
00:27:45.610 --> 00:27:48.150
You can leave it at its
default if you want.

573
00:27:48.150 --> 00:27:49.760
That's what a lot of people do.

574
00:27:49.760 --> 00:27:52.070
But you can kind of manipulate
it a few different ways.

575
00:27:52.070 --> 00:27:56.450
And we actually have, if I get out of my
config here, a couple of show commands

576
00:27:56.450 --> 00:28:02.020
built around UDLD, where you can pull it
up and look at the individual interfaces

577
00:28:02.020 --> 00:28:07.060
and see what their current configuration
is and you can see UDLD neighbors.

578
00:28:07.060 --> 00:28:10.860
So for the person on the other end,
they gotta be replying back, right,

579
00:28:10.860 --> 00:28:12.570
so they're your UDLD neighbor.

580
00:28:12.570 --> 00:28:15.166
And you'll see that and
get that information and

581
00:28:15.166 --> 00:28:17.133
see what's going on there, right.

582
00:28:17.133 --> 00:28:20.030
So if I run show UDLD,
it's gonna give me all the interfaces,

583
00:28:20.030 --> 00:28:21.662
which is a little more than I want.

584
00:28:21.662 --> 00:28:26.009
But right here is Fa1/0/2,
and I can see that it is and

585
00:28:26.009 --> 00:28:28.600
I'm in aggressive mode, right.

586
00:28:28.600 --> 00:28:30.480
So it's up and it's doing its job.

587
00:28:30.480 --> 00:28:33.220
Current by directional state, unknown.

588
00:28:33.220 --> 00:28:35.330
Why's it unknown?
The switch on the other side is

00:28:35.330 --> 00:28:36.070
not running UDLD.

590
00:28:36.070 --> 00:28:36.890
Right.
We ought to be able to

591
00:28:36.890 --> 00:28:37.850
talk back and forth.

592
00:28:37.850 --> 00:28:40.680
The other side doesn't know to
reflect these messages back to me.

593
00:28:40.680 --> 00:28:42.960
But here's where I can
see the message interval.

594
00:28:42.960 --> 00:28:46.830
Right now and in seven seconds and
I've got a time out interval of

595
00:28:46.830 --> 00:28:51.140
five seconds which is smaller so
if i miss just one I'm going to time out.

596
00:28:51.140 --> 00:28:55.257
So it's going to keep an eye on that and
right now it's just running and waiting.

597
00:28:55.257 --> 00:28:56.553
And then we can go in and

598
00:28:56.553 --> 00:29:00.247
kind of customize that on the interface
some more if we need too.

599
00:29:00.247 --> 00:29:02.380
Actually, this switch might not allow me.

00:29:02.380 --> 00:29:05.490
When I looked in there
I didn't see any other,

601
00:29:05.490 --> 00:29:07.450
let's see if they give
me any other settings.

00:29:07.450 --> 00:29:11.660
Not every switch has the full
features set of UDLD, and

00:29:11.660 --> 00:29:15.490
it kind of goes back to that whole design

604
00:29:15.490 --> 00:29:20.330
ports that just don't
have that functionality.

605
00:29:20.330 --> 00:29:21.400
The fiber was what?

606
00:29:21.400 --> 00:29:24.760
2/0/1, whoops.

607
00:29:24.760 --> 00:29:26.810
My typing skills are gonna

Now it's just gonna kill me if

609
00:29:31.415 --> 00:29:35.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is gonna be how many bad commands

00:29:35.260 --> 00:29:37.565
can I type in a row, and

611
00:29:37.565 --> 00:29:38.355
There we go.

612
00:29:38.355 --> 00:29:40.905
So if I jump into one of these other ones,
I'm pretty sure they're copper too.

613
00:29:40.905 --> 00:29:43.475
I'm almost positive.

614
00:29:43.475 --> 00:29:46.115
Let's just go take a look at that.

615
00:29:46.115 --> 00:29:47.855
And yeah, so these are the same.

616
00:29:47.855 --> 00:29:49.655
So yeah, nothing special there.

617
00:29:49.655 --> 00:29:53.167
So if If we jump in, some switches will
have addition options in there where

618
00:29:53.167 --> 00:29:54.987
you can kind of tweak some of that.

619
00:29:54.987 --> 00:29:57.507
Some actually have global options,
well this one does,

620
00:29:57.507 --> 00:30:00.897
UDLD enable just to turn it
on on all fiber ports, right?

621
00:30:00.897 --> 00:30:03.470
There's that UDLD enable
that I was talking about.

622
00:30:03.470 --> 00:30:04.740
And UDLD aggressive, so

623
00:30:04.740 --> 00:30:07.790
you can have it default to aggressive
mode instead of normal mode.

624
00:30:07.790 --> 00:30:12.220
And then we can say UDLD message,
and there's our timer.

625
00:30:12.220 --> 00:30:15.470
And so we can jump in and
set that timer for how many seconds.

626
00:30:15.470 --> 00:30:18.720
If this is a mission critical link,
I might want to monitor it once a second,

627
00:30:18.720 --> 00:30:20.220
set it to the lowest.

628
00:30:20.220 --> 00:30:22.350
I might want to go 90 seconds,
just every minute and a half.

629
00:30:22.350 --> 00:30:23.960
I don't need to go crazy on it.

630
00:30:23.960 --> 00:30:25.840
Or middle of the road,
which is 45 seconds,

631
00:30:25.840 --> 00:30:28.890
which I believe is what the default
is on most of these switches.

632
00:30:28.890 --> 00:30:29.500
All right?

633
00:30:29.500 --> 00:30:31.830
So, we can get that configured and
put in place.

634
00:30:31.830 --> 00:30:38.045
Now, for me, if I do a,
oh we turned off CDP.

635
00:30:38.045 --> 00:30:42.765
If I do a show LDP neighbor,
who is plugged in on port two for me?

636
00:30:42.765 --> 00:30:43.525
Not a switch.

637
00:30:43.525 --> 00:30:44.845
So that's gonna be a problem too.

638
00:30:44.845 --> 00:30:47.875
My UDLD status will never be happy if
it's turned on on a port that's not

639
00:30:47.875 --> 00:30:49.190

640
00:30:49.190 --> 00:30:54.660
So I would need to turn it on actually
somewhere else like my connection to core

641
00:30:54.660 --> 00:30:58.810
two and you know what,

00:30:58.810 --> 00:31:01.400
Right, so I'm gonna turn it on for

I'll just come in here and

644

and we'll turn it on globally too to just.

645
00:31:11.500 --> 00:31:12.730
For giggles.

646
00:31:12.730 --> 00:31:14.060
So there we go.
We're up and we're running.

647
00:31:14.060 --> 00:31:16.178
Right?
So we're running UDLD, and

648
00:31:16.178 --> 00:31:19.622
if I do a show UDLD, and
look at those interfaces,

649
00:31:19.622 --> 00:31:23.322
actually let me just jump
ahead to those interfaces.

650
00:31:26.571 --> 00:31:28.059
And take a look at, whoops.

651
00:31:32.288 --> 00:31:35.660
Sorry, I don't need the interface command
there, so let me just take that out.

652
00:31:35.660 --> 00:31:37.840
And we take a look at
one of those interfaces.

653
00:31:37.840 --> 00:31:38.630
I'll see it is running.

654
00:31:38.630 --> 00:31:39.330
I'm in aggressive mode.

655
00:31:39.330 --> 00:31:42.470
It's unknown, but now I can jump
over to my other core switch and

656
00:31:42.470 --> 00:31:46.800
I can get it turned on over here too and
get the same basic effect, right?

657
00:31:46.800 --> 00:31:51.160
Same configuration, and so I'm just
gonna jump in here and do a range and,

658
00:31:51.160 --> 00:31:54.570
oh, you know what?

659
00:31:54.570 --> 00:31:55.670
I'm gonna do a bad thing, Daniel.

660
00:31:55.670 --> 00:31:58.690
I'm gonna assume that it's
the same port numbers.

661
00:31:58.690 --> 00:32:00.055
>> Well,
that'll be interesting if it's not.

662
00:32:00.055 --> 00:32:02.900
[LAUGH]
>> And, yeah, we'll find out.

663
00:32:02.900 --> 00:32:04.640
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
hit enable these.

664
00:32:04.640 --> 00:32:08.820
So I'm doing UDLD port aggressive on the
port, and really, that's all I need to do.

665
00:32:08.820 --> 00:32:13.330
But I'm also doing a UDLD enable globally,

666
00:32:14.550 --> 00:32:17.630
But once that's done,
it's gonna start sending those messages.

667
00:32:17.630 --> 00:32:21.300
Now, based on the timer, I might have to
wait up to 90 seconds before I actually

668
00:32:21.300 --> 00:32:23.330
start getting information back.

669
00:32:23.330 --> 00:32:26.250
So I might have to be
a little patient here.

670
00:32:26.250 --> 00:32:28.620
But assuming I got my port numbers right.

00:32:28.620 --> 00:32:30.500
Which, oh they're all the same, good.

672
00:32:30.500 --> 00:32:36.300
So I should be able to
run show UDLD FA1/0/23,

673
00:32:36.300 --> 00:32:41.900
and we should see, there we go,
current neighbor state, bidirectional.

674
00:32:41.900 --> 00:32:45.410
I sent my broadcast, I got it back
from them, and we're sending and

675
00:32:45.410 --> 00:32:49.090
communicating back and forth and
we can see that device is out there.

676
00:32:49.090 --> 00:32:51.260
And it's up, and it's happy.

677
00:32:51.260 --> 00:32:54.010
And my message interval right now has
actually dropped down to 15 seconds.

678
00:32:54.010 --> 00:32:56.060
I thought it was 45 to the default.

679
00:32:56.060 --> 00:32:57.390
This one is pretty low.

00:32:57.390 --> 00:32:59.410
And my timeout interval is set to 5.

00:32:59.410 --> 00:33:01.880
So, if we have 5 failures,

682
00:33:01.880 --> 00:33:05.010
then it is going to identify that
as a failure and take it out.

683
00:33:05.010 --> 00:33:09.470
So it's up, it's going, and now we're
running unidirectional link detection.

684
00:33:09.470 --> 00:33:11.460
This is one of those set it and
forget it protocols.

685
00:33:11.460 --> 00:33:13.670
You turn it on, you put it in place, and

686
00:33:13.670 --> 00:33:16.620
you never worry about it again until
you have a physical cable failure.

687
00:33:16.620 --> 00:33:19.000
I know a lot of you guys
are probably out there saying, boy,

688
00:33:19.000 --> 00:33:21.430
I've worked with fiber and
never had a problem with it.

689
00:33:21.430 --> 00:33:22.820
Well, one day you will.

690
00:33:22.820 --> 00:33:24.480
And this is how you'll know.

00:33:24.480 --> 00:33:26.840
>> Just a matter of time before
those failures start to happen.

692
00:33:26.840 --> 00:33:28.940
It's nice to be able to
know things like this so

693
00:33:28.940 --> 00:33:31.360
that you can troubleshoot those issues.

694
00:33:31.360 --> 00:33:32.580
Great demonstrations, Don,

695
00:33:32.580 --> 00:33:37.660
it's really taken us into becoming
CCMP wizards such as yourself who'll

696
00:33:37.660 --> 00:33:42.100
be talking about the magical little layer
two protocols that we're using today.

00:33:42.100 --> 00:33:42.841
Very cool stuff.

00:33:42.841 --> 00:33:44.606
>> Yeah,
it's not crazy unattainable stuff,

it's just knowing a little

00:33:46.835 --> 00:33:49.760
a little bit more about the protocols and

00:33:49.760 --> 00:33:52.892
otherwise it's actually very parallel
to what you guys have already learned.

00:33:52.892 --> 00:33:53.800
>> That's right.

00:33:53.800 --> 00:33:56.190
Well everyone, it looks like we've
