episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explore the exciting world of Virtual Local Area Networks or VLANs. Here they describe VLAN details such as the VLAN database, default ranges, and how to crate and name a VLAN. They also show you some VLAN options when dealing with VoIP traffic.
episodes.title: VLANs and Trunking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.850 --> 00:00:16.645
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.645 --> 00:00:21.250
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and here with
me today is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

4
00:00:21.250 --> 00:00:22.220
How's it going Don?

5
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:23.320
>> It is going great, Daniel.

6
00:00:23.320 --> 00:00:24.870
I'm glad to be back on the show.

7
00:00:24.870 --> 00:00:29.310
And today we're going to be jumping into
a pretty neat topic which are VLANs or

8
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:31.856
Virtual Local Area Networks.

9
00:00:31.856 --> 00:00:34.310
Now VLANS are one of those topics.

10
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:36.525
Again, we learned about them in the CCNA.

11
00:00:36.525 --> 00:00:39.483
But we're gonna go a little more in depth
on here in this series to make sure we've

12
00:00:39.483 --> 00:00:42.110
got a really good understanding of
what's going on behind the scenes.

13
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:46.380
And some of the things that we might bump
into as we implement them on the network.

14
00:00:46.380 --> 00:00:48.220
Now, let's start with a real,

15
00:00:48.220 --> 00:00:53.420
just kind of basic refresher over what
a VLAN is, because maybe you've forgotten.

16
00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:56.689
It's not something you necessarily
work with every single day.

17
00:00:56.689 --> 00:01:00.507
When you buy a Cisco switch, a Cisco
switch is actually ready to be deployed in

18
00:01:00.507 --> 00:01:02.166
production right out of the box.

19
00:01:02.166 --> 00:01:05.383
You can cut open the box,
take that switch, throw it in your rack,

20
00:01:05.383 --> 00:01:06.484
plug devices into it.

21
00:01:06.484 --> 00:01:09.549
And if you plug two devices into it
they' ll be able to see each other.

22
00:01:09.549 --> 00:01:11.443
Right?
That's the basic layer two

23
00:01:11.443 --> 00:01:12.869
switch functionality.

24
00:01:12.869 --> 00:01:17.079
But what we can do is take
that physical switch and

25
00:01:17.079 --> 00:01:21.398
we can divide it into
multiple virtual switches.

26
00:01:21.398 --> 00:01:23.962
Right?
Think of it, it's like virtualization,

27
00:01:23.962 --> 00:01:27.830
like hyper V, or VM ware, or any kind
of operating system virtualization.

28
00:01:27.830 --> 00:01:30.651
VLANs are like that for your switch.

29
00:01:30.651 --> 00:01:34.309
So I might have a 48-port switch,
but I divide it in half.

30
00:01:34.309 --> 00:01:40.060
And the first 24 ports are on one VLAN and
the other 24 ports are on a second VLAN.

31
00:01:40.060 --> 00:01:44.770
And when I plug my computers into it,
it's as if I had two 24-port switches.

32
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:46.090
And you don't have to divide it in half.

33
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:47.370
It doesn't have to be even.

34
00:01:47.370 --> 00:01:49.820
I could say these three
ports are in one VLAN,

35
00:01:49.820 --> 00:01:52.010
these seven ports are in another VLAN.

36
00:01:52.010 --> 00:01:56.055
And continue on like that creating as many
virtual local area networks as I need.

37
00:01:56.055 --> 00:01:57.030
Right?

38
00:01:57.030 --> 00:02:00.169
Now, what are some scenarios
where I need VLANs?

39
00:02:00.169 --> 00:02:02.371
There's a few reasons why
we might create these,

40
00:02:02.371 --> 00:02:05.265
one example might be I'm creating a DMZ,
a demilitarized zone.

41
00:02:05.265 --> 00:02:06.580
Right?
I need to have

42
00:02:06.580 --> 00:02:09.170
servers that are exposed to the Internet.

43
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:13.650
And I'm plugging them into a switch
that I have maybe workstations or

44
00:02:13.650 --> 00:02:16.570
other servers plugged into that
aren't exposed to the Internet.

45
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:18.710
Well, I don't wanna have
cross contamination.

46
00:02:18.710 --> 00:02:21.150
If somebody hacks into one
of my Internet servers,

47
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:24.290
I don't want them being able to
leapfrog into the rest of my network.

48
00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:29.880
So I might create a VLAN, a separate
DMZ VLAN to isolate those servers,

49
00:02:29.880 --> 00:02:33.190
and then a VLAN for all of my other
machines and it's nice and separate.

50
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:35.010
Right?
That's one scenario.

51
00:02:35.010 --> 00:02:36.580
Personally, I like to do
dedicated switches for

52
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:38.320
a DMZ just to be on
the absolute safe side.

53
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:40.960
But you don't necessarily have to.

54
00:02:40.960 --> 00:02:43.530
A VLAN is a true separation.

55
00:02:43.530 --> 00:02:49.030
When you do a VLAN, one VLAN cannot
see another VLAN by default.

56
00:02:49.030 --> 00:02:54.010
If you want traffic to move between VLANs,
you need, well there's two solutions I

57
00:02:54.010 --> 00:02:57.610
guess, one's kinda ridiculous, which
is you can take a crossover cable and

58
00:02:57.610 --> 00:02:59.980
you can plug one end into
a port on one VLAN and

59
00:02:59.980 --> 00:03:03.960
another end into a port on a second
VLAN and now it merges them together.

60
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:04.611
>> That's how I do it.

61
00:03:04.611 --> 00:03:06.450
[LAUGH] That's the fun one.

62
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:09.830
>> And I say it's ridiculous because it
kinda negates the whole point of having

63
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:10.340
the VLAN.

64
00:03:10.340 --> 00:03:11.350
>> So what are you doing.

65
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:13.870
>> Yeah, it's basically just bonding those
switches there's not really a whole lot

66
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:15.110
of point in doing that.

67
00:03:15.110 --> 00:03:16.940
The other solution is to put in a router.

68
00:03:16.940 --> 00:03:21.370
I can have have a router with an interface
on one VLAN an interface on another VLAN

69
00:03:21.370 --> 00:03:22.960
and now I can route traffic between them.

70
00:03:22.960 --> 00:03:25.140
All right,
now you might be thinking again,

71
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:28.020
well doesn't that kinda defeat
the purpose I got that connectivity?

72
00:03:28.020 --> 00:03:31.330
Well you actually get a few different
benefits by doing these things.

73
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:35.371
The first benefit is when traffic passes
through a router, we can filter it.

74
00:03:35.371 --> 00:03:35.923
Right?

75
00:03:35.923 --> 00:03:39.008
Or that router might be a firewall,
we always say router these days but

76
00:03:39.008 --> 00:03:40.330
most firewalls are routers.

77
00:03:40.330 --> 00:03:44.255
So, we could actually be filtering traffic
as it passes between those VLANS because

78
00:03:44.255 --> 00:03:46.148
it goes through an intelligent engine.

79
00:03:46.148 --> 00:03:46.705
Right?

80
00:03:46.705 --> 00:03:48.329
router or a layer three or higher device.

81
00:03:49.410 --> 00:03:52.350
Or another benefit even if we don't route

82
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:56.020
is that what you're doing is you're
creating separate broadcast domains.

83
00:03:56.020 --> 00:04:00.130
Remember when a work station sends out a
broadcast, which they do all the time, or

84
00:04:00.130 --> 00:04:01.860
a server, a printer, whatever.

85
00:04:01.860 --> 00:04:05.700
When they send out a broadcast it goes
to everybody on the whole network

86
00:04:05.700 --> 00:04:07.540
until it hits the edge of the network.

87
00:04:07.540 --> 00:04:09.080
And where's that edge?

88
00:04:09.080 --> 00:04:09.730
Your router.

89
00:04:09.730 --> 00:04:12.130
If you've got one your router
is the edge of your network.

90
00:04:12.130 --> 00:04:13.700
That's the end of that broadcast.

91
00:04:13.700 --> 00:04:16.020
Your broadcast says within your subnet.

92
00:04:16.020 --> 00:04:19.730
If I have more than one VLAN,
I've now got more than one subnet.

93
00:04:19.730 --> 00:04:22.830
And broadcasts on one don't
make it to the other.

94
00:04:22.830 --> 00:04:24.820
And if I have a router in between it,

95
00:04:24.820 --> 00:04:28.620
only unicast traffic will pass
from one VLAN to the other.

96
00:04:28.620 --> 00:04:30.790
So if you've got a massive network.

97
00:04:30.790 --> 00:04:34.450
Let's say you have 10,000 workstations,
and maybe you're

98
00:04:34.450 --> 00:04:38.690
some kind of corporate campus,
factory environment, a large college and

99
00:04:38.690 --> 00:04:42.008
you've got 10,000 computers and
you don't want those all on one segment.

100
00:04:42.008 --> 00:04:45.895
Imagine having 10,000 computers all
just doing their regular chatter,

101
00:04:45.895 --> 00:04:47.236
their regular broadcast.

102
00:04:47.236 --> 00:04:48.340
Right?

103
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:50.000
Windows machines can be
pretty bad about it,

104
00:04:50.000 --> 00:04:51.650
Linux machines are pretty good about it.

105
00:04:51.650 --> 00:04:54.170
Macs are the worst,
they broadcast all the time.

106
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:57.360
And that's because of the convenience of
the auto configuring protocols they have.

107
00:04:57.360 --> 00:04:58.730
It's a lot of chatter.

108
00:04:58.730 --> 00:05:02.760
But even firewalls are sending
out broadcasts, that's how they

109
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:06.590
find things on the network at a minimum
Address Resolution Protocol, ARP.

110
00:05:06.590 --> 00:05:07.400
So when I'm looking for

111
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:11.316
what IP is tied to a MAC address,
I send out an ARP broadcast.

112
00:05:11.316 --> 00:05:13.980
And every computer is gonna
do that at least once when it

113
00:05:13.980 --> 00:05:18.790
boots up to find its default gateway, or
DNS servers, or other entries like that.

114
00:05:18.790 --> 00:05:21.510
And those broadcasts will be
constant on your network.

115
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:24.000
If you have 10,000
computers there's too much.

116
00:05:24.000 --> 00:05:25.561
Right?
It's a ton of chatter.

117
00:05:25.561 --> 00:05:27.695
So we use VLANs to divide
that network up and

118
00:05:27.695 --> 00:05:29.960
maybe I'll divide it up into 50 networks.

119
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:31.380
So we've got 10,000 computers,

120
00:05:31.380 --> 00:05:32.910
you should have picked easier math
>> [LAUGH]

121
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:34.729
>> If I divide it into 50 networks,

122
00:05:34.729 --> 00:05:39.137
now things start to get a little crazy and
we end up with, I don't know what is that?

123
00:05:39.137 --> 00:05:39.799
>> 8 million.

124
00:05:39.799 --> 00:05:41.342
Yeah, something like that [LAUGH].

125
00:05:41.342 --> 00:05:44.335
[CROSSTALK]
>> If I have 10,000 computers and

126
00:05:44.335 --> 00:05:46.726
I divide it into, say, 100 networks.

127
00:05:46.726 --> 00:05:47.330
Right?

128
00:05:47.330 --> 00:05:50.840
Now we end up with 100
computers on each segment.

129
00:05:50.840 --> 00:05:52.550
And that's a much more manageable number,

130
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:56.009
a much smaller number, and
things usually work out better that way.

131
00:05:56.009 --> 00:05:58.290
Right?
So those are some of the uses for VLANs.

132
00:05:58.290 --> 00:05:59.200
There's others.

133
00:05:59.200 --> 00:06:00.730
Right?
You may have other reasons for

134
00:06:00.730 --> 00:06:03.690
using VLANs on your network, but
those are two of the big ones.

135
00:06:03.690 --> 00:06:05.559
Right?
Implementing security,

136
00:06:05.559 --> 00:06:09.987
as we filter traffic going between VLANs,
and minimizing your broadcast domain.

137
00:06:09.987 --> 00:06:11.379
So those are the two big ones.

138
00:06:11.379 --> 00:06:14.490
All right,
I guess I could throw out some other uses.

139
00:06:14.490 --> 00:06:17.560
It might be things like isolating clients.

140
00:06:17.560 --> 00:06:20.600
If you're a service provider you
might have multiple customers and

141
00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:24.120
you wanna separate the customers from each
other so you can use VLANs for that too,

142
00:06:24.120 --> 00:06:25.710
assigning a VLAN to each customer.

143
00:06:25.710 --> 00:06:27.770
It does all sorts of neat
stuff you can do with VLANs.

144
00:06:27.770 --> 00:06:31.317
>> So Don, it's just all about segregating
the networks apart from each other.

145
00:06:31.317 --> 00:06:33.795
That broadcast domain stuff,
that's basically the whole,

146
00:06:33.795 --> 00:06:35.519
well one of the major
purposes of a router.

147
00:06:35.519 --> 00:06:36.481
Right?
Is to say we

148
00:06:36.481 --> 00:06:38.353
are separating these broadcast domains.

149
00:06:38.353 --> 00:06:41.627
I don't want this traffic from this
network to go to this network,

150
00:06:41.627 --> 00:06:44.030
well at least the broadcast
traffic [INAUDIBLE].

151
00:06:44.030 --> 00:06:45.457
>> Yeah, that is basically it.

152
00:06:45.457 --> 00:06:47.534
I mean that's kind of
the nature of the design and

153
00:06:47.534 --> 00:06:49.015
this really solves that problem.

154
00:06:49.015 --> 00:06:52.710
So, remember that a lot of these
networks and the ethernet itself

155
00:06:52.710 --> 00:06:56.740
were all designed back in the 70s and
80s, when networks were very small.

156
00:06:56.740 --> 00:07:00.550
And now networks are massive, way beyond
what they even envisioned back then.

157
00:07:00.550 --> 00:07:02.977
And so we've got to have tools
like this to make that work.

158
00:07:02.977 --> 00:07:07.610
All right, now on your switch,
when you go in and start to configure it.

159
00:07:07.610 --> 00:07:10.250
We need to think about what
that switch is being used for.

160
00:07:10.250 --> 00:07:11.100
And let me give you an example.

161
00:07:11.100 --> 00:07:15.569
I've got a diagram pulled up here of kind
of the topology that I'm working with.

162
00:07:15.569 --> 00:07:20.221
And so what you can kind of see
here is I've got a few switches

163
00:07:20.221 --> 00:07:22.466
that are in my environment.

164
00:07:22.466 --> 00:07:26.732
And I've got, I kinda,
I call them my core and access switches,

165
00:07:26.732 --> 00:07:29.610
they're really all kind of the same.

166
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:34.380
But when you have core switches, core
switches are focused on moving data from

167
00:07:34.380 --> 00:07:36.760
point A to point B as fast as possible.

168
00:07:36.760 --> 00:07:40.160
They're all about moving data,
and moving it quickly.

169
00:07:40.160 --> 00:07:45.035
We don't normally do VLANs up here at the
core because their just moving data fast.

170
00:07:45.035 --> 00:07:47.295
And so
these might me layer three switches,

171
00:07:47.295 --> 00:07:49.685
they might be routers instead of switches.

172
00:07:49.685 --> 00:07:51.766
Sometimes your core you just have routers.

173
00:07:51.766 --> 00:07:53.746
Then you may have a separate
distribution layer and

174
00:07:53.746 --> 00:07:55.505
I don't have a distribution
layer in my lab.

175
00:07:55.505 --> 00:07:57.825
I've kinda merged my core distribution.

176
00:07:57.825 --> 00:08:00.404
Your distribution layers almost
always layer three switches.

177
00:08:00.404 --> 00:08:04.255
They're switches that act as routers and
so they see more than one VLAN, and

178
00:08:04.255 --> 00:08:08.250
they control access between them,
that's kind of their purpose.

179
00:08:08.250 --> 00:08:12.188
But where VLANs are really prevalent
is down here at the access layer,

180
00:08:12.188 --> 00:08:15.602
where we actually plug our
workstations into that network.

181
00:08:15.602 --> 00:08:20.413
So I've got PCs, I've got laptops,
printers, whatever devices that I have,

182
00:08:20.413 --> 00:08:22.554
I plug into these access switches.

183
00:08:22.554 --> 00:08:27.994
And an access switch might be
a 24-port 2950 or 2960, right?

184
00:08:27.994 --> 00:08:29.119
A really low end switch.

185
00:08:29.119 --> 00:08:36.080
Or it might be a massive
6512 with 288 ports on it.

186
00:08:36.080 --> 00:08:40.420
It could be insanely large if I
want it to be or really small.

187
00:08:40.420 --> 00:08:44.190
But those ports can easily be divided up

188
00:08:44.190 --> 00:08:46.250
into VLANs to create
those virtual networks.

189
00:08:47.610 --> 00:08:50.355
Now, when we go and start creating
these virtual networks, well,

190
00:08:50.355 --> 00:08:53.230
you've actually already got the first one.

191
00:08:53.230 --> 00:08:55.752
Remember how I said we could take
a Cisco switch out of the box and

192
00:08:55.752 --> 00:08:56.711
plug it in and it works.

193
00:08:56.711 --> 00:09:01.110
Well all the ports are in the same VLAN.

194
00:09:01.110 --> 00:09:04.500
You've got one VLAN,
VLAN 1, VLAN number one.

195
00:09:04.500 --> 00:09:06.540
And that's what all
the ports are in by default.

196
00:09:06.540 --> 00:09:11.253
So, if I were to take one of my switches,
like if I were to jump back to this guy

197
00:09:11.253 --> 00:09:14.218
here and
take a look at its VLAN configuration.

198
00:09:14.218 --> 00:09:18.790
So, if I jump into its config,
I do a show vlan.

199
00:09:18.790 --> 00:09:21.670
It's gonna show me all
the VLANs on this system and

200
00:09:21.670 --> 00:09:23.570
I've got one VLAN in particular.

201
00:09:23.570 --> 00:09:26.038
VLAN 1 is my default VLAN.

202
00:09:26.038 --> 00:09:30.348
And if I look at my port list,
all my ports are right there, right?

203
00:09:30.348 --> 00:09:33.726
So I got a bunch of ports,
port 1 through 24, and then my gig ports,

204
00:09:33.726 --> 00:09:35.518
my uplinks at the end of this switch.

205
00:09:35.518 --> 00:09:36.778
And they're all in VLAN 1.

206
00:09:36.778 --> 00:09:41.352
And that's why, when I plug a computer in,
well it's gonna be able to see anybody

207
00:09:41.352 --> 00:09:44.885
else's plugin cuz they're all
in that same virtual network.

208
00:09:44.885 --> 00:09:48.085
>> Now Don,
you said there's one VLAN on this switch,

209
00:09:48.085 --> 00:09:50.975
but I don't mean to be corrective or
anything, but

210
00:09:50.975 --> 00:09:55.900
it seems like there might be more than
one VLAN on this switch by default here.

211
00:09:55.900 --> 00:09:57.740
>> Damn you, Daniel,
[INAUDIBLE] your ability to read.

212
00:09:57.740 --> 00:09:58.938
>> [LAUGH]
>> So-

213
00:09:58.938 --> 00:10:00.341
>> [LAUGH] Stinking school!

214
00:10:00.341 --> 00:10:01.154
[LAUGH]
>> So

215
00:10:01.154 --> 00:10:03.890
right here on the screen you can see,
there is one VLAN.

216
00:10:03.890 --> 00:10:07.027
It is called default, and
that's where all of my ports are.

217
00:10:07.027 --> 00:10:08.967
But there's a few more VLANs
on this screen, right?

218
00:10:08.967 --> 00:10:11.126
There's 1,002 through 1,005.

219
00:10:11.126 --> 00:10:12.560
What are these guys all about?

220
00:10:12.560 --> 00:10:13.260
Right?

221
00:10:13.260 --> 00:10:17.340
Well on a brand new Cisco switch, and it
really doesn't matter what model you get.

222
00:10:17.340 --> 00:10:18.700
They're all the same.

223
00:10:18.700 --> 00:10:20.530
You actually do have
five VLANs by default.

224
00:10:20.530 --> 00:10:21.610
All right?

225
00:10:21.610 --> 00:10:24.600
There's four more VLANs that are created,
but

226
00:10:24.600 --> 00:10:29.450
you'll notice their status
is active/unsupported.

227
00:10:29.450 --> 00:10:29.990
All right?

228
00:10:29.990 --> 00:10:33.425
That's kind of an odd little thing to say
unsupported when they're right here on

229
00:10:33.425 --> 00:10:35.052
the screen like they're supported.

230
00:10:35.052 --> 00:10:37.048
And there's no port assigned to them.

231
00:10:37.048 --> 00:10:38.802
See how the port area over here is empty.

232
00:10:38.802 --> 00:10:41.427
So, why are these guys even here?

233
00:10:41.427 --> 00:10:44.011
Well, the reason they're
here is these are VLANs,

234
00:10:44.011 --> 00:10:46.890
special VLANs that were created
by Cisco back in the day.

235
00:10:46.890 --> 00:10:50.340
Back in the early 1990s, so
we're talking 20 years ago.

236
00:10:50.340 --> 00:10:52.910
And it was to support
particular technologies.

237
00:10:52.910 --> 00:10:54.705
And you can kinda see
the technologies here.

238
00:10:54.705 --> 00:10:57.566
Token-ring and fddi, fiberoptics.

239
00:10:57.566 --> 00:11:01.490
And fddi and token-ring are kind of,

240
00:11:01.490 --> 00:11:05.330
I know there's still some people
that use fddi today, but not many.

241
00:11:05.330 --> 00:11:09.260
And token-ring is by and
large completely dead in today's world.

242
00:11:09.260 --> 00:11:12.670
So these are really designed
to support older technologies.

243
00:11:12.670 --> 00:11:17.500
My switch, the switch that I'm on,
doesn't have any fddi ports.

244
00:11:17.500 --> 00:11:19.540
In fact, I don't think you
can even buy those anymore.

245
00:11:19.540 --> 00:11:22.880
I could be wrong, but on normal switches,
I'm not aware of any.

246
00:11:22.880 --> 00:11:25.630
And then token-ring, my switch
definitely doesn't support token-ring.

247
00:11:25.630 --> 00:11:29.680
So Cisco reserved these VLANs and
now they're not used.

248
00:11:29.680 --> 00:11:31.340
They're unsupported.

249
00:11:31.340 --> 00:11:34.260
But if this switch doesn't support it,

250
00:11:34.260 --> 00:11:36.430
what if I still have an old
switch on my network?

251
00:11:36.430 --> 00:11:39.990
I might have an old switch on my network
somewhere that's still using these.

252
00:11:39.990 --> 00:11:42.690
And so what Cisco does is they
say better safe than sorry.

253
00:11:42.690 --> 00:11:46.255
We're just gonna reserve those VLANs and
block them off on all of our switches.

254
00:11:46.255 --> 00:11:48.055
And that way if you've
still got the old stuff,

255
00:11:48.055 --> 00:11:51.110
you'll be okay we won't
overlap our VLAN numbers.

256
00:11:51.110 --> 00:11:52.860
And if you don't have the old stuff,

257
00:11:52.860 --> 00:11:55.630
there's plenty of other numbers
out there for us to use, right.

258
00:11:55.630 --> 00:12:00.527
I'm using VLAN 1 and then we skip
all the way to 1002 through 1005.

259
00:12:00.527 --> 00:12:04.136
I still have VLAN 2, VLAN 3, VLAN 4,

260
00:12:04.136 --> 00:12:08.603
all the way up to VLAN 1000 and then 1001.

261
00:12:08.603 --> 00:12:11.040
I've got a ton of VLAN numbers.

262
00:12:11.040 --> 00:12:13.310
And they're all available for me to use.

263
00:12:13.310 --> 00:12:17.750
Now, you might be thinking how many
VLANs am I actually going to use?

264
00:12:17.750 --> 00:12:20.000
How many times do I need
to divide my network?

265
00:12:20.000 --> 00:12:22.210
And there's no good clean answer for that.

266
00:12:22.210 --> 00:12:23.670
It's kinda up to you.

267
00:12:23.670 --> 00:12:27.940
Cisco has this kinda like rule of thumb
that no one switch should really have more

268
00:12:27.940 --> 00:12:31.590
than 16 VLANs on it, but
it's not gonna stop you from doing it.

269
00:12:31.590 --> 00:12:35.770
And, when I say 16 VLANs, I mean VLANs
that you actually have ports assigned to,

270
00:12:35.770 --> 00:12:37.620
and that is just a rule of thumb.

271
00:12:37.620 --> 00:12:41.890
It's not a set fast rule I've used
switches with over a hundred VLANs with

272
00:12:41.890 --> 00:12:43.250
port assignments on them.

273
00:12:43.250 --> 00:12:45.126
The Cisco switches handle it great.

274
00:12:45.126 --> 00:12:46.785
It's really more of
a management side of things.

275
00:12:46.785 --> 00:12:49.629
Gets kind of confusing remembering
what ports are in what VLANs.

276
00:12:49.629 --> 00:12:51.847
And that's why we have output like this.

277
00:12:51.847 --> 00:12:54.561
But, I know one of
the things that was hard for

278
00:12:54.561 --> 00:12:59.350
me when I was learning this was, all
right, well, if I have a 48 port switch,

279
00:12:59.350 --> 00:13:01.949
why would I ever need more than 24 VLANs?

280
00:13:01.949 --> 00:13:03.368
If you think about it,

281
00:13:03.368 --> 00:13:07.498
what good is a VLAN if there's
only one computer plugged into it?

282
00:13:07.498 --> 00:13:09.055
Not much good, right?

283
00:13:09.055 --> 00:13:10.169
You're trying to gather computers.

284
00:13:10.169 --> 00:13:12.801
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, we might have a VLAN with two

285
00:13:12.801 --> 00:13:16.509
ports, so we isolate these two computers
so they can talk to each other privately

286
00:13:16.509 --> 00:13:19.029
but it's pretty rare that
they have a VLAN of one port.

287
00:13:19.029 --> 00:13:23.672
I mean maybe you got some super
risky computer, a honey pot, right?

288
00:13:23.672 --> 00:13:26.723
And you want to expose that to
the Internet and keep it isolated,

289
00:13:26.723 --> 00:13:29.562
so you put one computer in that VLAN and
that's what you do.

290
00:13:29.562 --> 00:13:32.276
So, even going with that model,
if I have a 48-port switch,

291
00:13:32.276 --> 00:13:33.904
why would I need more than 48 VLANs?

292
00:13:33.904 --> 00:13:37.231
Well, I might have 48 VLANs on one switch,
but

293
00:13:37.231 --> 00:13:41.100
I might have other switches
in my organization.

294
00:13:41.100 --> 00:13:45.970
And I might not want to reuse VLAN
numbers, to keep things straight.

295
00:13:45.970 --> 00:13:49.117
So, on this switch,
I might have VLANs 1 through 48.

296
00:13:49.117 --> 00:13:52.171
And then on the next switch,
I might go 49 through 98.

297
00:13:52.171 --> 00:13:54.760
And then on the next switch
I go 99 through whatever,

298
00:13:54.760 --> 00:13:56.190
my math starts to breakdown.

299
00:13:56.190 --> 00:13:59.163
But, just kind of assigning out
48 ports to each switch and

300
00:13:59.163 --> 00:14:00.971
never reusing the same VLAN number,

301
00:14:00.971 --> 00:14:04.553
that way in my documentation I can
keep it straight and kind of remember.

302
00:14:04.553 --> 00:14:08.403
So, that's why we have such a big
space here to use VLANs and

303
00:14:08.403 --> 00:14:10.564
we got a thousand numbers there.

00:16:04.168 --> 00:16:05.411
So 1518.

321
00:16:05.411 --> 00:16:10.168
And that's kinda your maximum MTU, but if
you look on a computer like on workstation

322
00:16:10.168 --> 00:16:13.124
or even your router what's
the default MTU set too?

323
00:16:13.124 --> 00:16:14.691
Usually 1500.

324
00:16:14.691 --> 00:16:19.630
Why 1500 if I can go even
bigger to 1518 or even 1524?

325
00:16:19.630 --> 00:16:23.560
Well, the reason is we need extra room for
things like these VLAN tags, and

326
00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:24.770
quality of service.

327
00:16:24.770 --> 00:16:27.990
That stuff where we add data to
the header to identify traffic.

328
00:16:27.990 --> 00:16:32.960
So these VLAN tags, remember your VLAN
number, it could be one through 4,094, and

329
00:16:32.960 --> 00:16:37.260
that we need a couple of bytes
to be able to write that.

330
00:16:37.260 --> 00:16:41.030
And so, that's why our MTU sizes are a
little bit smaller, to leave that room.

331
00:16:41.030 --> 00:16:45.625
But when the switch injects that
tag number into the header,

332
00:16:45.625 --> 00:16:47.635
it changes the length of the frame.

333
00:16:47.635 --> 00:16:50.305
And every frame has
a checksum attached to it.

334
00:16:50.305 --> 00:16:53.546
And the checksum is the result of
a mathematical equation that's running

335
00:16:53.546 --> 00:16:57.615
against the data, and you can use it to
see if the frame has gotten corrupted.

336
00:16:57.615 --> 00:17:01.840
If you run the formula and get a different
number then what's stored in the checksum,

337
00:17:01.840 --> 00:17:03.556
then that means the data changed.

338
00:17:03.556 --> 00:17:06.342
Well, when we inject a tag,
what happens to the checksum?

339
00:17:06.342 --> 00:17:08.580
It's bad, it invalidates it.

340
00:17:08.580 --> 00:17:12.641
So the switch has to recalculate that
checksum every time it injects a tag.

341
00:17:12.641 --> 00:17:15.495
And then, on the other side
it's gonna take the tag off and

342
00:17:15.495 --> 00:17:18.364
recalculate the checksums and
stick it on the right VLAN.

343
00:17:18.364 --> 00:17:20.240
With no tag anymore.

344
00:17:20.240 --> 00:17:22.940
So we're having to constantly
recalculate checksums.

345
00:17:22.940 --> 00:17:26.980
And Cisco switches have dedicated hardware
specifically to handle that, and so

346
00:17:26.980 --> 00:17:29.550
they do it at near wired speed,
we don't even notice.

347
00:17:29.550 --> 00:17:32.010
But on older switches
that was a real problem.

348
00:17:32.010 --> 00:17:34.590
It kinda created a bit
of a performance hit.

349
00:17:34.590 --> 00:17:38.750
And so, 802.1Q VLAN tagging got off
to a bit of a rocky start back in

00:17:38.750 --> 00:17:39.510

00:17:39.510 --> 00:17:42.930
But now it's widely accepted, it's used by

00:17:42.930 --> 00:17:44.250
that's basically the way

00:27:16.740 --> 00:27:21.010
to not send it, to save a little bit of
ban wave then kind of optimize that link.

548
00:27:21.010 --> 00:27:22.860
So, we can control that too.

549
00:27:22.860 --> 00:27:25.850
That's just a extra
setting here in our trunk.

550
00:27:25.850 --> 00:27:29.345
So the default is to carry everything and
then we can go and modify that.

551
00:27:29.345 --> 00:27:32.226
It's not on the interface, so you go
into the interface like I am right here.

552
00:27:32.226 --> 00:27:35.797
And, I've been in the range command this
whole time, which is making sure that I'm

553
00:27:35.797 --> 00:27:38.380
doing the same configuration
on these two different ports.

554
00:27:38.380 --> 00:27:41.206
If you ever want to configure common
ports It's a great way to do it so.

555
00:27:41.206 --> 00:27:46.570
So I'm gonna set it here and I just
wanna change what VLANs are present,

556
00:27:46.570 --> 00:27:52.390
and so I'm gonna say switch
port trunk allowed and

557
00:27:52.390 --> 00:27:57.700
now we can specify the VLANs that
we want to allow on the link, okay?

558
00:27:57.700 --> 00:28:00.540
And, you can add and
remove them several different ways.

559
00:28:00.540 --> 00:28:03.710
You'll see we've got the add and
remove commands, so that's a start,

560
00:28:03.710 --> 00:28:07.500
and then you can specify
entire ranges if you want.

561
00:28:07.500 --> 00:28:13.629
So I might come in and say,
like, allowed VLAN 1-3 and

562
00:28:13.629 --> 00:28:19.906
comma, I don't know, 1,000 through 4,094.

563
00:28:19.906 --> 00:28:22.080
Right, and when I do that,

564
00:28:22.080 --> 00:28:25.788
now there's this nice big range
of stuff that I'm approving.

565
00:28:25.788 --> 00:28:30.880
And I used a comma kind of format
there to separate those ranges and

566
00:28:30.880 --> 00:28:33.960
specify them, and
you can remove them the same way.

567
00:28:33.960 --> 00:28:39.096
So for example if I had said the default
is switchport trunk allowed VLAN,

568
00:28:39.096 --> 00:28:41.780
one through 4,094, right?

569
00:28:41.780 --> 00:28:46.995
By default we allow the whole thing and
we saw that in our output up here, right?

570
00:28:46.995 --> 00:28:50.340
VLAN allowed on trunk and
here's that nice big list.

571
00:28:50.340 --> 00:28:55.650
Well what I did here was I
excluded four through 999.

572
00:28:55.650 --> 00:29:02.930
I could've done the same thing by saying,
switchport trunk allowed VLAN,

573
00:29:02.930 --> 00:29:07.960
and instead of adding the VLAN,
we could've done a remove

574
00:29:09.000 --> 00:29:12.320
and specified the range, and
my head is going this up a little bit.

575
00:29:12.320 --> 00:29:15.970
But if I do a remove,
I can specify, what did I do?

576
00:29:15.970 --> 00:29:21.219
It was like 4 through 999, right, and
it's gonna remove that from that list.

577
00:29:21.219 --> 00:29:24.161
So now when I do that
show interface trunk,

578
00:29:24.161 --> 00:29:28.251
I'll see that one through
4,094 allowed by default,

579
00:29:28.251 --> 00:29:33.180
but now I'm only allowing 1-3 and
1,000-4094, right?

580
00:29:33.180 --> 00:29:35.190
That's what I'm allowing, and

581
00:29:35.190 --> 00:29:38.860
down here see how the VLANs
active drop to one through three.

582
00:29:38.860 --> 00:29:42.910
And that's because four and
five are being trimmed off of that link.

583
00:29:42.910 --> 00:29:46.465
That's called pruning a VLAN, and what I
just did there is a manual prune to take

584
00:29:46.465 --> 00:29:48.389
those off and just save bandwidth of link.

585
00:29:48.389 --> 00:29:50.316
Don't bother sending VLAN
traffic to that switch,

586
00:29:50.316 --> 00:29:51.943
cuz it doesn't have any
ports in that VLAN.

587
00:29:51.943 --> 00:29:52.964
You're just wasting time.

588
00:29:52.964 --> 00:29:54.734
All right, so
that's a way that we can do it by hand.

589
00:29:54.734 --> 00:29:56.397
Just kind of an additional trump command.

590
00:29:56.397 --> 00:29:59.406
>> Well Don, we love having control
over our switches saying hey,

591
00:29:59.406 --> 00:30:03.080
this is the traffic I wanna allow,
this is the traffic I wanna disallow.

592
00:30:03.080 --> 00:30:06.570
Because there are some security
issues when it comes to the VLAN

593
00:30:06.570 --> 00:30:07.335
tagging specifically.

594
00:30:07.335 --> 00:30:11.220
We want to avoid those like
the black death, that is for sure.

595
00:30:11.220 --> 00:30:13.195
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don, anything else we need to add for

596
00:30:13.195 --> 00:30:13.745
this episode?

597
00:30:13.745 --> 00:30:16.415
>> You know,
I actually have quite a bit more to add so

598
00:30:16.415 --> 00:30:18.835
I think we're gonna have to move onto
a part three on this one, Daniel.

599
00:30:18.835 --> 00:30:20.535
>> Yeah, well you know,
it's one of those days.

600
00:30:20.535 --> 00:30:21.700
We're feeling good about it.

601
00:30:21.700 --> 00:30:24.170
Hopefully we'll see everybody
out there in part three.

602
00:30:24.170 --> 00:30:26.490
As for this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

603
00:30:26.490 --> 00:30:27.230
Thanks for watching.

604
00:30:27.230 --> 00:30:28.740
I've been your host Daniel Lowrey.

605
00:30:28.740 --> 00:30:29.340
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

606
00:30:29.340 --> 00:30:32.172
>> And we'll see you next time.

607
00:30:32.172 --> 00:30:36.740
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish up by explaining about Native VLANs and then discussing how to setup the VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP). They go in depth about the different versions of VTP and then walk you through setting up VTP to automatically propagate VLAN information between trunked switches.
episodes.title: VLANs and Trunking Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.723 --> 00:00:12.880
>> All right.

3
00:00:12.880 --> 00:00:16.420
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:16.420 --> 00:00:17.850
I'm your host Daniel Lowry, and

5
00:00:17.850 --> 00:00:21.780
here with me today is, well, I think
we all know who we have here today.

6
00:00:21.780 --> 00:00:22.490
Mr Don Pezet.

7
00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:23.400
How's it going Don?

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.525
>> The random stranger
has entered the studio.

9
00:00:25.525 --> 00:00:26.882
>> That's right [LAUGH].
Who are you again, sir?

10
00:00:26.882 --> 00:00:27.860
[LAUGH]
>> Do you have a badge, or did you just,

11
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:29.280
tailgated in?

12
00:00:29.280 --> 00:00:33.860
Glad to be back on the show, Daniel,
and excited to wrap up our what's

13
00:00:33.860 --> 00:00:38.300
now turned into a three part
series on VLANs and VLAN Trunking.

14
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:40.930
Now, in the last episode,
if you haven't watched already,

15
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:43.780
we kinda left off with getting
some trunks up and going and

16
00:00:43.780 --> 00:00:46.610
looking at dynamic trunking protocol and
how it works.

17
00:00:46.610 --> 00:00:50.248
And now we're gonna switch, well, actually
we're not gonna switch gears quite yet

18
00:00:50.248 --> 00:00:51.800
cuz there is one thing I left out.

19
00:00:51.800 --> 00:00:54.684
I had a good question in between
the episodes from a viewer about

20
00:00:54.684 --> 00:00:56.010
802.1q tagging.

21
00:00:56.010 --> 00:01:00.150
And I made the comment in
the last episode about how we're

22
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:01.980
injecting a tag into a frame.

23
00:01:01.980 --> 00:01:05.000
And that means the CRC has
to be recalculated, right?

24
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:06.830
So, we have to do
a mathematical operation and

25
00:01:06.830 --> 00:01:09.925
that doesn't necessarily make
things go as smooth as possible.

26
00:01:09.925 --> 00:01:13.345
And so, one of the viewers had asked if
there is anything that can help that.

27
00:01:13.345 --> 00:01:17.021
And there actually is one way and
this used to be a big deal.

28
00:01:17.021 --> 00:01:19.965
Now it isn't anymore, so
we don't really worry about it.

29
00:01:19.965 --> 00:01:25.050
But if you've got one VLAN in
particular that's pushing tons of data,

30
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:27.830
maybe you've got iSCSI equipment, right?

31
00:01:27.830 --> 00:01:31.110
And so, you're pushing storage data across
the network and it's just tons of it.

32
00:01:31.110 --> 00:01:32.560
And you're doing superframes, so

33
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:36.960
they're like 9,000 bytes instead of 1,500
bytes, and it's just huge amounts of data.

34
00:01:36.960 --> 00:01:38.350
And you don't wanna calculate CRCs.

35
00:01:38.350 --> 00:01:40.610
You don't want to recalculate CRCs.

36
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:46.740
If you are doing 802.12q VLAN tagging,
there is one VLAN that's special.

37
00:01:46.740 --> 00:01:48.040
There's a VLAN that's
called the native VLAN.

38
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:52.870
And the native VLAN is untagged traffic.

39
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:55.500
It's the only VLAN that doesn't get a tag.

40
00:01:55.500 --> 00:02:01.229
Normally, it injects a tag that says
I'm on VLAN7, or VLAN700, or VLAN2000.

41
00:02:01.229 --> 00:02:03.804
It designates that.
But with the native VLAN it just leaves it

42
00:02:03.804 --> 00:02:04.550
untagged.

43
00:02:05.810 --> 00:02:09.880
So there's a nice little benefit
there in that and since it's untagged

44
00:02:09.880 --> 00:02:13.580
it doesn't have to recalculate the CRC and
you get a little bit better performance.

45
00:02:13.580 --> 00:02:15.912
Now, that used to be absolutely true.

46
00:02:15.912 --> 00:02:18.300
In fact, back in the 1990s,
and even the early 2000s,

47
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:20.560
I used to plan networks around that.

48
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:22.460
Like, all right,
which one's gonna be my native VLAN?

49
00:02:22.460 --> 00:02:23.100
Right?

50
00:02:23.100 --> 00:02:26.660
But in today's world the hardware
acceleration in CISCO switches is so

51
00:02:26.660 --> 00:02:30.020
great that the CRC calculation
is next to nothing.

52
00:02:30.020 --> 00:02:33.120
And so,
we typically don't use the native VLAN.

53
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:36.620
And the reason we don't is
because it's untagged traffic.

54
00:02:36.620 --> 00:02:40.220
There's a few types of attacks
that a hacker can try and

55
00:02:40.220 --> 00:02:45.900
pull off where they can malform a tag so
that the packet,

56
00:02:45.900 --> 00:02:50.700
or the frame, is admitted into a switch
and then it jumps to the native VLAN.

57
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:53.300
And one of the problems of the native
VLAN is if that's where you're

58
00:02:53.300 --> 00:02:56.680
putting your sensitive data,
your stuff that needs to move fast,

59
00:02:56.680 --> 00:02:59.680
that just became an attack target and
that's not normally what we want.

60
00:02:59.680 --> 00:03:03.370
So, a lot of people will set that native
VLAN to be some useless number they never

61
00:03:03.370 --> 00:03:05.380
use and it just sits there empty.

62
00:03:05.380 --> 00:03:06.750
But we need to be aware of that,

63
00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:10.910
that in 802.1Q VLAN tagging,
you can define a native VLAN.

64
00:03:10.910 --> 00:03:11.999
The default is VLAN1.

65
00:03:11.999 --> 00:03:16.000
Right?
Now VLAN1 is also your management VLAN

66
00:03:16.000 --> 00:03:16.640
by default.

67
00:03:16.640 --> 00:03:20.730
If you're gonna into a switch,
it's usually the IP assigned to VLAN1.

68
00:03:20.730 --> 00:03:23.900
But it could be the IP assigned to other
VLANs if you wanna set it up that way.

69
00:03:23.900 --> 00:03:28.500
So, the native VLAN kind of has a purpose,
but it's not required.

70
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:29.880
We can always switch it to something else.

71
00:03:29.880 --> 00:03:32.760
So let me show you real quick
how we would switch that.

72
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:35.816
In the last episode, I took my core
switch here and I set up some trunks.

73
00:03:35.816 --> 00:03:40.133
And if I do a show interface trunk, we can
see those trunks are still up and running,

74
00:03:40.133 --> 00:03:43.850
that I've got that FA1/0/23 port and
/24 that are trunking.

75
00:03:43.850 --> 00:03:50.320
They're doing 802.1q and, hang on let
me get this where we can all see it.

76
00:03:50.320 --> 00:03:50.880
There we go.

77
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.850
And way over here we've
got this native VLAN.

78
00:03:53.850 --> 00:03:55.730
And the native VLAN for

79
00:03:55.730 --> 00:03:59.250
all of my trunks right now is 1 because
they're all set to the default.

80
00:03:59.250 --> 00:04:03.440
But I can change that to
a different native VLAN if I want.

81
00:04:03.440 --> 00:04:05.116
But I've gotta be really careful.

82
00:04:05.116 --> 00:04:05.749
All right?

83
00:04:05.749 --> 00:04:12.350
The reason I've gotta be careful is
because this switch, my core one switch,

84
00:04:12.350 --> 00:04:16.150
it's gonna receive untagged traffic and
say this is on VLAN 1.

85
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:19.460
And it's gonna send it untagged
to the other end of the trunk.

86
00:04:19.460 --> 00:04:22.480
At the other end, it's gonna receive it
and say, oh, this doesn't have a tag,

87
00:04:22.480 --> 00:04:23.460
it must be on VLAN 1.

88
00:04:23.460 --> 00:04:25.770
So, they both know it's on VLAN 1.

89
00:04:25.770 --> 00:04:30.270
But what happens if I change one side and
not the other?

90
00:04:30.270 --> 00:04:31.150
Well, let me show you.

91
00:04:31.150 --> 00:04:35.820
So here on CORE1, I've got my
native VLAN is VLAN 1 on all these.

92
00:04:35.820 --> 00:04:39.750
If I jump over to CORE2 and look for
that same information, right?.

93
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:43.450
So I'm just going to do
a show interface trunk, and

94
00:04:43.450 --> 00:04:47.330
I'll see those same trunks over here,
and they're native VLAN 1.

95
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:50.610
So, both sides know if traffic
is not tagged put it on VLAN 1.

96
00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:52.090
They both know that.

97
00:04:52.090 --> 00:04:52.950
All right?

98
00:04:52.950 --> 00:04:58.360
But if I take CORE2 and
I jump into its configuration and

99
00:04:58.360 --> 00:05:01.860
I modify, or
here I'll just do one of the ports.

100
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:06.890
So I'll take one of the ports, port 23,
and I'm gonna change it's native VLAN.

101
00:05:06.890 --> 00:05:11.610
I'm gonna come in here and
just say switchport trunk native VLAN,

102
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:14.755
and I'm gonna set it to 5.

103
00:05:14.755 --> 00:05:15.554
Right?

104
00:05:15.554 --> 00:05:18.050
VLAN 5 was my voiceover IP VLAN.

105
00:05:18.050 --> 00:05:22.260
And so,
I'm gonna set that as my new native VLAN.

106
00:05:22.260 --> 00:05:23.030
Okay?

107
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:27.520
And if I take a look at my
interface trunk information,

108
00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:30.640
I can see right here my
native VLAN is VLAN 5.

109
00:05:30.640 --> 00:05:33.100
So now when I send data over that link,

110
00:05:33.100 --> 00:05:36.860
if I have traffic on VLAN 5 I'll
send it untagged over that link.

111
00:05:36.860 --> 00:05:41.090
And then that's gonna go to
my other switch over here,

112
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:45.130
and it's gonna come in
untagged on this port.

113
00:05:45.130 --> 00:05:47.055
And it's going to say, oh,
it's untagged, I'll put it on VLAN 1.

114
00:05:48.090 --> 00:05:50.540
I just bridged VLAN 1 and VLAN 5.

115
00:05:50.540 --> 00:05:53.080
And that's bad, right?

116
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:54.810
It's bad if it's sensitive data,
if it's private data,

117
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:56.520
if I don't want people
jumping that border.

118
00:05:56.520 --> 00:05:57.850
Broadcasts are going between them.

119
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:01.590
They're effectively linked now,
VLAN 1 and VLAN 5 are effectively linked.

120
00:06:01.590 --> 00:06:02.850
That's a problem.

121
00:06:02.850 --> 00:06:05.930
So, if you ever adjust your native VLAN,

122
00:06:05.930 --> 00:06:10.950
you gotta do it on both ends of the line,
otherwise you end up with VLAN jumping and

123
00:06:10.950 --> 00:06:13.620
you're jumping from one VLAN to
the next and that's not a good thing.

124
00:06:13.620 --> 00:06:15.700
So, always double check, all right?

125
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:19.360
It's a good idea to look in the show
interface trunk output to make sure you've

126
00:06:19.360 --> 00:06:21.970
got the native VLAN defined
on both ends correctly.

127
00:06:21.970 --> 00:06:23.860
Or just look at
the interface configuration.

128
00:06:23.860 --> 00:06:25.370
It just needs to be the same on both ends.

129
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:29.330
You can pick whatever VLAN you want,
but it needs to be the same.

130
00:06:29.330 --> 00:06:33.040
And I mentioned how a lot of people pick
a dummy VLAN, a VLAN that's not in use.

131
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:35.140
Well, that's an easy way to do it,

132
00:06:35.140 --> 00:06:38.270
is just set it to some high number that
you're not gonna use as a port anywhere.

133
00:06:38.270 --> 00:06:42.920
And now, if somebody tries to do an attack
to strip off their tag, well, they're

134
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:45.840
gonna end up on this dummy VLAN that has
no ports, and so they didn't get anywhere.

135
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:47.569
It's a great way to get
around that attack.

136
00:06:47.569 --> 00:06:48.270
All right?

137
00:06:48.270 --> 00:06:52.470
Now, if you're running CVP
you will get status messages.

138
00:06:52.470 --> 00:06:55.310
See my status message is coming up
here letting me know there's a native

139
00:06:55.310 --> 00:06:56.740
VLAN mismatch.

140
00:06:56.740 --> 00:07:00.040
But if I'm not running CVP,
I'm not gonna get these messages.

141
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:01.500
And so, I might not see that.

142
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:03.570
And also, I need to be logged
into the switch to see it.

143
00:07:03.570 --> 00:07:05.300
I might not be logged
into the switch at all.

144
00:07:05.300 --> 00:07:07.510
So, these types of things
can go unnoticed for

145
00:07:07.510 --> 00:07:08.980
a little while and
really cause some problems.

146
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:10.020
All right.

147
00:07:10.020 --> 00:07:13.620
So, I'm gonna set my native VLAN
to one of those kind of random

148
00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:15.100
high number type things.

149
00:07:15.100 --> 00:07:18.280
So, one of the ones I like to use is 999,
right?

150
00:07:18.280 --> 00:07:21.520
It's just an odd number that
most people never make use of.

151
00:07:21.520 --> 00:07:23.340
It's a good one to use for a dummy VLAN.

152
00:07:23.340 --> 00:07:30.900
And so we can get into an interface and we
can say switchport trunk native VLAN 999.

153
00:07:30.900 --> 00:07:31.400
Okay.

154
00:07:32.540 --> 00:07:36.220
Now, I never created VLAN 999.

155
00:07:36.220 --> 00:07:37.280
But I'm okay with that.

156
00:07:37.280 --> 00:07:38.700
Because I don't actually
care about this traffic.

157
00:07:38.700 --> 00:07:40.270
I'm just trying to make
the native VLAN nothing.

158
00:07:40.270 --> 00:07:42.580
And that way, if somebody attacks
it they get into nothing.

159
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:45.090
So, I don't really care if
the VLAN exists or not.

160
00:07:45.090 --> 00:07:46.770
I'm just gonna designate it.

161

00:51:12.540 --> 00:51:15.240
So if I go to Core 2 and I pick a port.

1049
00:51:16.400 --> 00:51:18.428
Do I have any?

1050
00:51:18.428 --> 00:51:20.830
Let's see if I have any
other ports that are up.

1051
00:51:20.830 --> 00:51:24.070
It's kind of important for the port to
actually be up too, it looks at that.

1052
00:51:24.070 --> 00:51:28.490
So, if I assign a port that's down to
a VLAN, it's not gonna bring it in.

1053
00:51:28.490 --> 00:51:29.703
So, let's see.

1054
00:51:29.703 --> 00:51:34.122
Port 12 is up, and 23 and 24, great.

1055
00:51:34.122 --> 00:51:38.075
So I don't have any other ports that
are kind of ready for me to use.

1056
00:51:38.075 --> 00:51:40.440
I guess I could falsify Port 22.

1057
00:51:40.440 --> 00:51:41.400
Let's do that.

1058
00:51:43.110 --> 00:51:46.400
So if I take this guy and
just switch port mode access.

1059
00:51:46.400 --> 00:51:48.368
I'm gonna hard set it to an access port.

1060
00:51:50.646 --> 00:51:54.860
And I'll set it to vlan 5.

1061
00:51:54.860 --> 00:51:57.660
I'm only getting VLAN 1 and
12 across the link, but

1062
00:51:57.660 --> 00:52:01.450
I'm gonna set this one to VLAN 5 and
bring that up.

1063
00:52:01.450 --> 00:52:02.720
Actually, I'm gonna kill cdp on it too.

1064
00:52:02.720 --> 00:52:04.070
Otherwise, I'm gonna get
a bunch of errors there.

1065
00:52:06.260 --> 00:52:10.152
And so, we'll kill that off,
and then we'll bring it online.

1066
00:52:10.152 --> 00:52:12.327
All right?
And I don't know if we have LLDP running

1067
00:52:12.327 --> 00:52:13.096
on this thing.

1068
00:52:13.096 --> 00:52:16.280
But, we'll kill that off too just in case.

1069
00:52:16.280 --> 00:52:17.879
All right.
So, that interface is going to come up.

1070
00:52:17.879 --> 00:52:21.928
And so now, when I do a show vlan br,
I've got a port that's up and

1071
00:52:21.928 --> 00:52:26.165
active in VLAN 5 and that voiceover
IP network that I made earlier.

1072
00:52:26.165 --> 00:52:27.330
Right?

1073
00:52:27.330 --> 00:52:30.680
But, I'm not getting VLAN 5
traffic cuz it's being pruned off.

1074
00:52:30.680 --> 00:52:33.360
The VTP should learn that and
correct it for me.

1075
00:52:33.360 --> 00:52:36.240
So if I jump back to my core over here,

1076
00:52:36.240 --> 00:52:39.620
I can see in my history where
I was just getting 1 and 12.

1077
00:52:39.620 --> 00:52:43.430
And lets see if this patience pays off.

1078
00:52:43.430 --> 00:52:45.430
Now, 1, 5, and 12.

1079
00:52:45.430 --> 00:52:48.260
So VTP pruning is nice
because it's automatic.

1080
00:52:48.260 --> 00:52:50.710
We can just turn these things on and
it fixes it, and

1081
00:52:50.710 --> 00:52:51.960
it fixes it across our network.

1082
00:52:51.960 --> 00:52:54.180
It's really, pretty slick stuff.

1083
00:52:54.180 --> 00:52:58.138
But if you jump switches with a VLAN,
so I have VLAN 5 on Switch 1.

1084
00:52:58.138 --> 00:53:02.083
No VLAN 5 on Switch 2, and
then VLAN 5 on Switch 3,

1085
00:53:02.083 --> 00:53:06.838
switch three can't communicate
all the way back to switch one.

1086
00:53:06.838 --> 00:53:08.982
You only talk to your neighbors,
and it's getting pruned.

1087
00:53:08.982 --> 00:53:10.427
So we just have to be careful with that.

1088
00:53:10.427 --> 00:53:12.617
But otherwise, it works pretty well.

1089
00:53:12.617 --> 00:53:14.343
>> Don, this is fascinating stuff.

1090
00:53:14.343 --> 00:53:18.731
I thoroughly enjoy getting behind the CLI
of a switch or a router from Cisco, and

1091
00:53:18.731 --> 00:53:22.153
playing around trying to get
things to work as they need to be.

1092
00:53:22.153 --> 00:53:24.658
Don, that was actually
some pretty amazing stuff.

1093
00:53:24.658 --> 00:53:29.029
I have to be honest, I'm sure our viewers
are just riveted to their seats as we are.

1094
00:53:29.029 --> 00:53:32.530
And is there anything else we need to talk
about before we close this here episode?

1095
00:53:32.530 --> 00:53:33.340
>> That's about it.

1096
00:53:33.340 --> 00:53:35.694
Just remember the secret
of VTP is patience.

1097
00:53:35.694 --> 00:53:37.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's supposed to be a simple protocol,

1098
00:53:37.700 --> 00:53:39.390
you turn it on, it just does its thing.

1099
00:53:39.390 --> 00:53:41.130
But, you do have to verify.

1100
00:53:41.130 --> 00:53:42.380
Always verify your configuration.

1101
00:53:42.380 --> 00:53:43.680
Do that on the exam too.

1102
00:53:43.680 --> 00:53:46.580
Make sure that you put the commands in,
make sure that they're actually

1103
00:53:46.580 --> 00:53:48.890
working because sometimes they
don't like you saw with mine.

1104
00:53:48.890 --> 00:53:51.470
>> Yeah,
you'd hate to lose that exam just because

1105
00:53:51.470 --> 00:53:52.782
well you didn't verify your own work.

1106
00:53:52.782 --> 00:53:53.453
All right.

1107
00:53:53.453 --> 00:53:56.930
tTat being said, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

1108
00:53:56.930 --> 00:53:57.760
Thanks for watching.

1109
00:53:57.760 --> 00:53:59.280
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

1110
00:53:59.280 --> 00:54:00.110
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

1111
00:54:00.110 --> 00:54:02.014
We'll see you next time.

1112
00:54:02.014 --> 00:54:08.190
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe how to configure and verify Etherchannel in Cisco switches. They start off with a quick overview of what Etherchannel is and what its used for and then jump into configuring a switch using Etherchannel protocols such as LACP, PAgP, and the Etherchannel protocol itself.
episodes.title: Ether Channel
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.813 --> 00:00:13.617
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.617 --> 00:00:16.790
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.790 --> 00:00:18.130
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:18.130 --> 00:00:21.032
Here with me today is
the illustrious Don Pezet.

6
00:00:21.032 --> 00:00:22.310
How's it going today Don?

7
00:00:22.310 --> 00:00:24.600
>> [LAUGH] I am doing great Daniel,
glad to be back on this show.

8
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:27.860
And we're gonna be jumping into
a neat topic today as we take a look

9
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:29.812
at Cisco EtherChannel.

10
00:00:29.812 --> 00:00:33.080
And EtherChannel's one of those
neat features that's built into

11
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:35.220
darn near every Cisco switch.

12
00:00:35.220 --> 00:00:38.480
And it's something that a lot of people
don't take advantage of cuz it's

13
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:41.350
not one of those
automatically enable things.

14
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:44.920
So it's another one of those great
technologies where if you know about it,

15
00:00:44.920 --> 00:00:46.020
you can jump in.

16
00:00:46.020 --> 00:00:49.260
You can configure it and you can really
change the performance of your network.

17
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:52.715
If you don't know about it, you can
actually be running in a sub optimal

18
00:00:52.715 --> 00:00:54.973
network and not even know it,
not realize it.

19
00:00:54.973 --> 00:00:58.660
And so, it's a pretty cool technology and
we want to take a look at it today.

20
00:00:58.660 --> 00:01:00.540
>> Yeah, definitely want
to optimize my network Don.

21
00:01:00.540 --> 00:01:01.711
Teach me, oh great one.

22
00:01:01.711 --> 00:01:04.960
[LAUGH]
>> Let me show you one of the common

23
00:01:04.960 --> 00:01:09.580
things that happens in a switch network
is that as we start to build out our

24
00:01:09.580 --> 00:01:14.560
topology, it's not uncommon to
have loops in your network.

25
00:01:14.560 --> 00:01:16.840
But they're loops that we
don't think of as loops.

26
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:19.550
They're loops that we
think of as redundancy.

27
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:20.760
And so let me show you what I mean.

28
00:01:20.760 --> 00:01:24.000
So I've got a little topology right
here that I wanna show you guys, and

29
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:25.248
I've got three switches.

30
00:01:25.248 --> 00:01:27.196
So I've got some core
switches up at the top.

31
00:01:27.196 --> 00:01:29.767
I've got an access switch
down here at the bottom.

32
00:01:29.767 --> 00:01:35.872
And if you look at these switches they've
got cabling that forms a triangle.

33
00:01:35.872 --> 00:01:37.414
It forms a circle.

34
00:01:37.414 --> 00:01:41.565
If the switch at the top left were to send
out a broadcast it's gonna broadcast over

35
00:01:41.565 --> 00:01:42.490
to this switch.

36
00:01:42.490 --> 00:01:46.460
It's gonna broadcast down to this switch
and it's gonna broadcast back to core one

37
00:01:46.460 --> 00:01:49.730
again, back to this other switch and it's
just gonna keep going in a circle over and

38
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:51.360
over and over again, and that's bad.

39
00:01:51.360 --> 00:01:54.630
And so we have a protocol called
spanning tree that we'll talk about in

40
00:01:54.630 --> 00:01:58.390
another episode that blocks that loop and
it fixes that problem for us.

41
00:01:58.390 --> 00:01:59.274
It's great.

42
00:01:59.274 --> 00:02:02.672
We don't even have to configure that,
it does it automatically.

43
00:02:02.672 --> 00:02:05.700
Now that's normally a good thing but
sometimes it's not.

44
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:06.960
My two core switches.

45
00:02:06.960 --> 00:02:08.030
These guys up here.

46
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:09.321
So I've got NewYork CORE1 and

47
00:02:09.321 --> 00:02:12.870
New York CORE2, see how I've got
two links running between them?

48
00:02:12.870 --> 00:02:16.380
Well, why do I have two links
running between two switches?

49
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:17.680
It could be bad design.

50
00:02:17.680 --> 00:02:19.210
I could have where these aren't trunks.

51
00:02:19.210 --> 00:02:23.005
One's carrying VLAN 1, the other one's
carrying VLAN 2 and those are my uplinks.

52
00:02:23.005 --> 00:02:26.585
Kind of waste of ports,
I could chunk those on a single line.

53
00:02:26.585 --> 00:02:29.135
It could be that I've done it for
redundancy.

54
00:02:29.135 --> 00:02:33.415
I run two cables so that if one fails,
the other can kick on,

55
00:02:33.415 --> 00:02:35.790
the other one can take over.

56
00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:36.720
It could be that I've done it for

57
00:02:36.720 --> 00:02:39.350
extra bandwidth,
maybe these are gigabyte length here.

58
00:02:39.350 --> 00:02:40.097
Here they're 100 megabit.

59
00:02:40.097 --> 00:02:41.840
So they're 100 megabit links.

60
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:44.750
If I've got two of them,
I wanna get 200 megabit of bandwidth.

61
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:46.436
Maybe that's what I want.

62
00:02:46.436 --> 00:02:49.848
Well it doesn't really matter which
scenario that we kind of fall under,

63
00:02:49.848 --> 00:02:52.070
because the end result is the same.

64
00:02:52.070 --> 00:02:53.200
This creates a loop.

65
00:02:53.200 --> 00:02:56.230
A loop right between these two switches.

66
00:02:56.230 --> 00:02:59.920
And so in the background,
spanning tree protocol's gonna kick in.

67
00:02:59.920 --> 00:03:01.510
And what's it gonna do?

68
00:03:01.510 --> 00:03:03.500
It's gonna shut one of those ports off.

69
00:03:03.500 --> 00:03:07.740
It's gonna make it not function and
that's to block the loop.

70
00:03:07.740 --> 00:03:11.340
So even though I've got two links,
I only end up with one.

71
00:03:11.340 --> 00:03:14.400
Now if my goal was redundancy, I got it.

72
00:03:14.400 --> 00:03:18.980
If one link fails the loop is gone,
so the other link comes back up and

73
00:03:18.980 --> 00:03:23.880
now I've got my redundancy so if that's
what I've set out to do, I've achieved it.

74
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:28.850
But if my goal was to get 200 megabits
of bandwidth, I haven't done that.

75
00:03:28.850 --> 00:03:31.390
The second link is gonna be
sitting there doing nothing.

76
00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:36.190
And even in the redundancy model one link
goes down, it takes a little while for

77
00:03:36.190 --> 00:03:38.520
Spanning Tree Protocol to
recognize the loop is gone and

78
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:39.480
bring the other link back up.

79
00:03:39.480 --> 00:03:41.390
So it's not instantaneous.

80
00:03:41.390 --> 00:03:45.782
So while this works, this does achieve
what a lot of people want it to achieve,

81
00:03:45.782 --> 00:03:46.926
it's not optimal.

82
00:03:46.926 --> 00:03:49.485
Fail over is slow,
you don't get the extra bandwidth and

83
00:03:49.485 --> 00:03:51.150
it's kinda some wasted resources.

84
00:03:52.440 --> 00:03:54.630
What if we could take advantage of that?

85
00:03:54.630 --> 00:03:58.270
What if we could bring that second
link up, double up our bandwidth.

86
00:03:58.270 --> 00:04:00.560
Make it where they're both running, so

87
00:04:00.560 --> 00:04:02.680
if one fail the other one's
already running and we go?

88
00:04:02.680 --> 00:04:05.154
That would be great but
that's not the default.

89
00:04:05.154 --> 00:04:08.859
Let's verify the default on our
actual equipment here just to see,

90
00:04:08.859 --> 00:04:12.240
so I'm gonna jump back here and
I'm on core two.

91
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:16.990
And the two links between those switches,
if I just look at that configuration.

92
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:22.980
If I look at fa1/0/23 and 24.

93
00:04:22.980 --> 00:04:25.170
I got them configured to
just access ports right now.

94
00:04:25.170 --> 00:04:28.060
They're just pushing VLAN 1 and
that's it and that's fine.

95
00:04:28.060 --> 00:04:30.570
I got these two links and there they are.

96
00:04:30.570 --> 00:04:32.189
You see nothing special.

97
00:04:32.189 --> 00:04:34.079
No cards up my sleeves or anything.

98
00:04:34.079 --> 00:04:37.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just regular basic configuration there.

99
00:04:37.440 --> 00:04:40.390
And those interfaces
are more than likely up.

100
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:45.430
If we just take a look at
our interface output here.

101
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:48.347
And find 23 and 24.

102
00:04:48.347 --> 00:04:52.780
I can see those two guys right here,
and they're both up, up.

103
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:55.630
So those links are up,
they're happy and we're good.

104
00:04:55.630 --> 00:04:59.920
And if I jump over to CORE1,
I should basically see the same thing.

105
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:05.313
So in CORE1, if I come in here and
I do a show ip interface brief and

106
00:05:05.313 --> 00:05:09.152
I'll just jump down and look at 23 and 24.

107
00:05:09.152 --> 00:05:12.496
I should see that they are up,
up, which sure enough I do.

108
00:05:12.496 --> 00:05:13.890
So those guys are up.

109
00:05:13.890 --> 00:05:19.830
And if I do a show run for
interface fa1/0/23 and

110
00:05:19.830 --> 00:05:22.720
24 again, same basic configuration
nothing special here.

111
00:05:23.850 --> 00:05:26.480
Now, it looks like both
those links are up.

112
00:05:26.480 --> 00:05:29.810
They're both up,
up in the show ip interface brief output.

113
00:05:29.810 --> 00:05:32.820
But one of them is
actually not gonna be up.

114
00:05:32.820 --> 00:05:36.940
One of them is going to be off, and it's
spanning tree that's shutting that off.

115
00:05:36.940 --> 00:05:41.890
If I d o a show spanning-tree and
take a look at my spanning tree

116
00:05:41.890 --> 00:05:47.044
configuration, I've got fa1/0/23 and
1/0/24.

117
00:05:47.044 --> 00:05:49.490
And see how they both show as forwarding?

118
00:05:49.490 --> 00:05:51.625
You might be thinking oh we've got them,
we've got Don, he's wrong!

119
00:05:51.625 --> 00:05:53.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well no they are both forwarding so

120
00:05:53.850 --> 00:05:58.190
both of these ports are up, but
if I go take a look at the other switch,

121
00:05:58.190 --> 00:06:03.010
I jump over to the other core switch
here and do a quick show spanning tree.

122
00:06:04.340 --> 00:06:10.903
On this one, I can see 23 and
24 and look at port 24.

123
00:06:10.903 --> 00:06:13.281
It's an alternate and it's blocking.

124
00:06:13.281 --> 00:06:15.975
That status of BLK,
that lets me know it's blocking.

125
00:06:15.975 --> 00:06:18.472
Spanning tree is shut
off one of the ports.

126
00:06:18.472 --> 00:06:22.144
Now, if I kill one of the other ports,
if I kill port 23.

127
00:06:22.144 --> 00:06:28.850
So if I jump in to fa1/0/23 and
I shut that one down, it's gonna go away.

128
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:30.180
That kills the loop.

129
00:06:30.180 --> 00:06:35.320
And now the other port can come back up
and so that's where I get my redundancy.

130
00:06:35.320 --> 00:06:38.610
So if I watch my statuses
here I get that link down.

131
00:06:38.610 --> 00:06:45.340
And then if I do a show spanning tree
I can see that 24 is now in listening.

132
00:06:45.340 --> 00:06:47.720
And it's gonna do listening and
then learning and

133
00:06:47.720 --> 00:06:49.150
then it's gonna go to forwarding.

134
00:06:49.150 --> 00:06:51.350
Listening and
learning take 15 seconds each.

135
00:06:51.350 --> 00:06:53.980
So after 30 seconds,
it's gonna fail over and come up.

136
00:06:55.260 --> 00:06:59.910
Well that means that I've got redundancy,
but I got a 30 second down time.

137
00:06:59.910 --> 00:07:03.310
Now in our spanning tree episodes we're
gonna see how we can optimize that and

138
00:07:03.310 --> 00:07:04.700
make it much, much shorter.

139
00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:07.590
But just with the default configuration
of a Cisco switch which was

140
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:09.580
unfortunately what a lot
of people are running.

141
00:07:09.580 --> 00:07:11.310
Expect a 30 second down time.

142
00:07:11.310 --> 00:07:16.570
So if I run two links, I only get the band
length of one link cuz only one is active

143
00:07:16.570 --> 00:07:20.220
and if it fails, I've got a 30 second
delay before the other one kicks in.

144
00:07:20.220 --> 00:07:25.800
So I get redundancy but it's not optimal,
EtherChannel can fix that.

145
00:07:25.800 --> 00:07:29.992
It can solve that problem, because what
EtherChannel does is it takes the two

146
00:07:29.992 --> 00:07:33.680
network cards or network interfaces,
and it bonds them together.

147
00:07:33.680 --> 00:07:35.550
That's why they call it a channel.

148
00:07:35.550 --> 00:07:37.640
You hear them described as
a few different things,

149
00:07:37.640 --> 00:07:42.080
you'll hear them called Channel groups,
you'll hear them called port groups and

150
00:07:42.080 --> 00:07:45.090
you'll hear them called bonds and bundles.

151
00:07:45.090 --> 00:07:48.000
And it just depends on which
Cisco document you're reading,

152
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:49.630
which one they decide to call them.

153
00:07:49.630 --> 00:07:50.800
You'll see several of the terms here.

154
00:07:50.800 --> 00:07:53.315
But the official standard
name is a bundle.

155
00:07:53.315 --> 00:07:56.263
So it bundles the two
interfaces together so

156
00:07:56.263 --> 00:07:59.537
that spanning tree will
see it as one interface.

157
00:07:59.537 --> 00:08:01.418
Can one interface make a loop?

158
00:08:01.418 --> 00:08:02.173
No.

159
00:08:02.173 --> 00:08:03.473
The loop goes away.

160
00:08:03.473 --> 00:08:06.073
It's so both interfaces come up.

161
00:08:06.073 --> 00:08:09.830
And the cool part about that is I'm
now getting 200 megabits of bandwidth.

162

00:10:19.684 --> 00:10:24.911

00:10:24.911 --> 00:10:29.230

00:10:29.230 --> 00:10:30.230

00:10:30.230 --> 00:10:32.760

00:21:41.820 --> 00:21:45.010

00:22:12.560 --> 00:22:13.108

00:22:15.065 --> 00:22:19.656
I mentioned that when we do EtherChannel

00:22:22.651 --> 00:22:27.394

00:22:33.850 --> 00:22:35.170

00:23:04.830 --> 00:23:06.890

00:23:12.550 --> 00:23:14.360

00:23:14.360 --> 00:23:19.290

00:23:19.290 --> 00:23:24.970
So when traffic hits the EtherChannel,

00:23:24.970 --> 00:23:27.210

00:23:27.210 --> 00:23:31.580
