I'm being tied to one.

485
00:24:11.930 --> 00:24:13.950
My source MAC address is
being tied to one link.

486
00:24:13.950 --> 00:24:14.580
Unless that link fails.

487
00:24:15.730 --> 00:24:19.020
But on a good side it means that one
person can't monopolize the whole channel

488
00:24:19.020 --> 00:24:20.590
and everybody else gets
the other bandwidth.

489
00:24:20.590 --> 00:24:23.040
So that's an interesting way for
that to behave.

490
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:26.070
Now, different switches
have different defaults and

491
00:24:26.070 --> 00:24:28.280
I've seen some that have
slightly different defaults.

492
00:24:28.280 --> 00:24:30.850
And there's other modes we can switch to.

493
00:24:30.850 --> 00:24:34.500
Most switches will support at least 4
modes, if you get to like the 6,500,

494
00:24:34.500 --> 00:24:37.060
the really big switches,
they've got something like 8

495
00:24:37.060 --> 00:24:40.340
different modes you can go to,
some that are really advanced.

496
00:24:40.340 --> 00:24:43.260
Some that actually do create
a bit of a processor hit.

497
00:24:43.260 --> 00:24:45.240
If you don't have the right
hardware to support it.

498
00:24:45.240 --> 00:24:48.004
And that's why some of the lower end
switches only have four to pick from,

499
00:24:48.004 --> 00:24:49.936
cuz they just can't handle
some of the other ones.

500
00:24:49.936 --> 00:24:51.870
Let me show you how to change it.

501
00:24:51.870 --> 00:24:55.180
So the way we change it is,
you jump in your configuration,

502
00:24:55.180 --> 00:24:56.950
and it's a global command.

503
00:24:56.950 --> 00:24:58.550
It changes for all your port channels.

504
00:24:58.550 --> 00:25:00.750
You can't change it for
just one port channel or another.

505
00:25:00.750 --> 00:25:03.290
So you jump in your config and

506
00:25:03.290 --> 00:25:08.590
you do port-channel load-balance, and then

507
00:25:08.590 --> 00:25:11.550
it's always a good idea to do a question
mark here to see what's supported.

508
00:25:11.550 --> 00:25:13.780
You do a question mark and
it'll show you the modes.

509
00:25:13.780 --> 00:25:14.680
I've only got six here.

510
00:25:15.780 --> 00:25:19.440
Now, I know for a fact there's at least
eight different ones that Cisco supports.

511
00:25:19.440 --> 00:25:21.710
My switch doesn't support all of them.

512
00:25:21.710 --> 00:25:23.915
This is a, actually what is this.

513
00:25:23.915 --> 00:25:25.203
This is a 3750, I think.

514
00:25:25.203 --> 00:25:27.120
So [LAUGH] I should know that.

515
00:25:27.120 --> 00:25:28.000
>> What am I working with here?

516
00:25:28.000 --> 00:25:28.720
>> I know. [LAUGH] >> [LAUGH].

517
00:25:28.720 --> 00:25:30.750
>> So
let me take a look at what this switch is.

518
00:25:30.750 --> 00:25:32.520
I'm pretty sure, yeah, it's a 3750.

519
00:25:32.520 --> 00:25:36.790
And I've got IP services, so
I've got the full feature set on this one.

520
00:25:36.790 --> 00:25:42.040
And it by all means should support
a number of different ones.

521
00:25:42.040 --> 00:25:44.280
And I see six,
which is more than a lot of switches.

522
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:46.960
Your 2960s, they usually only have 4.

523
00:25:46.960 --> 00:25:50.025
Your higher end switches
are gonna have other ones.

524
00:25:50.025 --> 00:25:52.796
But for me,
I do port-channel load-balance,

525
00:25:52.796 --> 00:25:55.980
and a question mark,
and here's my choices.

526
00:25:55.980 --> 00:26:01.140
I've got source MAC address, I can also do
destination MAC address, but that means

527
00:26:01.140 --> 00:26:04.390
going that destination, the destination
would always be tied to that one gig max.

528
00:26:05.540 --> 00:26:10.420
I can also do source and
destination MAC address.

529
00:26:10.420 --> 00:26:11.180
Now, that's different.

530
00:26:12.720 --> 00:26:17.076
Now, when I talk to any one host,
yes I'm gonna be held to one link.

531
00:26:17.076 --> 00:26:21.335
But if I start talking to a second host at
the same time, I can jump to another link.

532
00:26:21.335 --> 00:26:26.425
Now, one laptop could potentially use all
eight gigs of bandwidth on that eight

533
00:26:26.425 --> 00:26:28.705
gig link that I've created.

534
00:26:28.705 --> 00:26:31.685
So that gives me more flexibility and it's
still just looking at MAC addresses that

535
00:26:31.685 --> 00:26:34.522
your switch is already
gonna be looking at anyway.

536
00:26:34.522 --> 00:26:36.082
So that might be a good switch for me.

537
00:26:37.212 --> 00:26:39.232
You can even go more advanced.

538
00:26:39.232 --> 00:26:42.744
Source IP Address and
Destination IP Address and

539
00:26:42.744 --> 00:26:45.747
both Source and Destination IP Address.

540
00:26:45.747 --> 00:26:47.722
Now, that's more advanced.

541
00:26:47.722 --> 00:26:50.622
If you're a Layer 2 switch,
are you looking at IPs?

542
00:26:50.622 --> 00:26:51.702
Not normally.

543
00:26:51.702 --> 00:26:55.560
So if I'm a Layer 3 switch,
I am looking at it, it's not a big deal.

544
00:26:55.560 --> 00:26:57.930
If I'm not a Layer 3 switch,
I'm not looking at that.

545
00:26:57.930 --> 00:26:59.620
This is gonna create a processor burden.

546
00:26:59.620 --> 00:27:00.860
So I probably don't wanna
go with one of those.

547
00:27:02.510 --> 00:27:05.180
On other switches,
you might see even other options.

548
00:27:05.180 --> 00:27:08.740
You might see things like source and
destination port.

549
00:27:08.740 --> 00:27:10.660
That's when you have some real fun.

550
00:27:10.660 --> 00:27:14.621
If you do source port I might have five
connections to the same server but

551
00:27:14.621 --> 00:27:16.746
they're on different port numbers.

552
00:27:16.746 --> 00:27:20.655
If I open up five webpages and
I point them all at ITPro.TV, I'm actually

553
00:27:20.655 --> 00:27:25.620
gonna be using five different ports, it's
gotta tell my tabs apart from each other.

554
00:27:25.620 --> 00:27:28.520
And so, I could be getting a gig
on each one of those tabs,

555
00:27:28.520 --> 00:27:30.110
you really optimize things.

556
00:27:30.110 --> 00:27:31.560
But now I got to look at port number.

557
00:27:31.560 --> 00:27:35.150
That's like layer four, layer five in the
OSI model, we're starting to get up there.

558
00:27:35.150 --> 00:27:40.800
My switch doesn't normally look at that
and that's where if you got a 6500 with

559
00:27:40.800 --> 00:27:45.260
the filtering module or VPM modules and
stuff that are in there and it's actually

560
00:27:45.260 --> 00:27:48.410
looking at that higher data already,
you can get some real performance.

561
00:27:48.410 --> 00:27:51.850
If you're on a 3750 like me, that's not
something we're normally looking at.

562
00:27:51.850 --> 00:27:55.850
It's the equivalent of creating an ACL and
you access control is where we're starting

563
00:27:55.850 --> 00:27:57.940
to look at port numbers and
the switch has to interpret that, so

564
00:27:57.940 --> 00:28:00.350
it's the same type of performance
hit as we'd see on an ACL.

565
00:28:01.620 --> 00:28:03.090
But we can come in and change it.

566
00:28:03.090 --> 00:28:07.381
Now, it's a good idea to change it on both
ends of the link so they're the same,

567
00:28:07.381 --> 00:28:08.679
but you don't have to.

568
00:28:08.679 --> 00:28:10.167
They don't have to match, but

569
00:28:10.167 --> 00:28:14.580
you generally don't want the two
sides load balancing different ways.

570
00:28:14.580 --> 00:28:18.120
So normally we configure it
the same on both ends of the link.

571
00:28:18.120 --> 00:28:19.800
But it will let you do differently.

572
00:28:19.800 --> 00:28:21.160
And so, you just come in here and
you specify.

573
00:28:21.160 --> 00:28:26.101
So I wanna do, maybe Source and
Destination MAC, I could come in and

574
00:28:26.101 --> 00:28:26.890
add that.

575
00:28:28.200 --> 00:28:31.458
And now, my port channel's gonna switch
over to load balancing that way.

576
00:28:31.458 --> 00:28:33.770
And I can jump over to my other switch and
do the same thing and

577
00:28:33.770 --> 00:28:35.501
now I'll be [INAUDIBLE]
a different method.

578
00:28:35.501 --> 00:28:38.555
So just another way to handle how we look.

579
00:28:38.555 --> 00:28:40.425
>> And Don, you were mentioning,

580
00:28:40.425 --> 00:28:44.065
make it sure you do things the right way
and if you make a change on one side,

581
00:28:44.065 --> 00:28:45.960
you should go to the other
>> Make the same change there.

582
00:28:45.960 --> 00:28:48.690
Even though it would still work,
we like to be consistent.

583
00:28:48.690 --> 00:28:52.040
Just like Tak likes to call me
Daniel the human error Lawry,

584
00:28:52.040 --> 00:28:54.787
[LAUGH] so
a lot of times you're looking through my

585
00:28:54.787 --> 00:28:58.271
configuration you'll see I've
made a misconfiguration and

586
00:28:58.271 --> 00:29:02.563
is there anything that we can do to help
guide us and not make those mistakes?

587
00:29:02.563 --> 00:29:04.699
>> Now, if you're like me-
>> [LAUGH]

588
00:29:04.699 --> 00:29:06.606
>> Then you statically set your

589
00:29:06.606 --> 00:29:07.745
EtherChannel.

590
00:29:07.745 --> 00:29:09.085
So you don't use LACP or PAgP.

591
00:29:09.085 --> 00:29:10.848
You just statically set it and
you know it's on.

592
00:29:10.848 --> 00:29:13.102
And if something goes wrong, what happens?

593
00:29:13.102 --> 00:29:15.052
It goes down and the ports don't work,
and that's the end of the story.

594
00:29:16.182 --> 00:29:21.132
But if you are using LACP and PAgP, either
one, if something is wrong with your

595
00:29:21.132 --> 00:29:23.330
configuration, your ports don't go down,
do they?

596
00:29:23.330 --> 00:29:25.520
They just flip back to
being regular access ports.

597
00:29:25.520 --> 00:29:29.878
Now, that can be tough because if they
flip back to being regular ports,

598
00:29:29.878 --> 00:29:33.028
you might have connectivity but
just over one link.

599
00:29:33.028 --> 00:29:35.332
And the other link spanning
tree shutting them off.

600
00:29:35.332 --> 00:29:38.960
And if that happens you might
not notice the failure.

601
00:29:38.960 --> 00:29:40.040
That this happened.

602
00:29:40.040 --> 00:29:41.062
You've got a problem.

603
00:29:41.062 --> 00:29:43.465
There's an issue with the configuration
but you don't know it,

604
00:29:43.465 --> 00:29:44.810
cuz traffic is flowing.

605
00:29:44.810 --> 00:29:47.600
You've got to run a bandwidth test to see
that you're not hitting all the links.

606
00:29:47.600 --> 00:29:49.060
You've got to log into
the switch to see it.

607
00:29:49.060 --> 00:29:51.880
And so, there's an extra feature

608
00:29:51.880 --> 00:29:56.452
in a Cisco switch that's called
EtherChannel Misconfiguration Guard.

609
00:29:56.452 --> 00:29:58.720
And [LAUGH] it's a nice long name.

610
00:29:58.720 --> 00:30:01.000
Misconfiguration Guard and
just like its name implies,

611
00:30:01.000 --> 00:30:03.590
it guards you from misconfiguring things.

612
00:30:03.590 --> 00:30:08.580
What it does is it says, if I'm using LACP
or PAgP and the connection doesn't quite

613
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:13.380
work out instead of dropping down to our
regular port let's make it air disabled.

614
00:30:13.380 --> 00:30:15.214
Let's go ahead and just disable the ports.

615
00:30:15.214 --> 00:30:17.370
It's pretty hard to ignore that one.

616
00:30:17.370 --> 00:30:19.560
It's gonna shut the ports off and
stop them.

617
00:30:19.560 --> 00:30:22.530
So it ensure that it works
the way that you want it to work.

618
00:30:22.530 --> 00:30:24.410
It's not on by default,
cuz most people don't need it.

619
00:30:24.410 --> 00:30:25.482
These are controlled links.

620
00:30:25.482 --> 00:30:26.460
They're your trunks.

621
00:30:26.460 --> 00:30:27.520
Right.
It's not stuff you really mess

622
00:30:27.520 --> 00:30:28.520
around with a lot.

623
00:30:28.520 --> 00:30:29.500
So most people don't worry about it.

624
00:30:29.500 --> 00:30:31.060
It is off by default.

625
00:30:31.060 --> 00:30:34.540
But we can turn it on if we want and
it will help us kinda protect from that.

626
00:30:34.540 --> 00:30:37.706
So if you hire Daniel, for example, and
you just don't know what's gonna happen,

627
00:30:37.706 --> 00:30:40.103
yeah, and here's your chance-
>> It's a crap shoot.

628
00:30:40.103 --> 00:30:43.069
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Turning it on is a little bit

629
00:30:43.069 --> 00:30:48.880
of work, because it's actually
not a part of EtherChannel.

630
00:30:48.880 --> 00:30:50.480
It's actually a part of Spanning Tree.

631
00:30:50.480 --> 00:30:54.433
Spanning Tree can watch your EtherChannel
to see when things are misconfigured and

632
00:30:54.433 --> 00:30:55.515
drop back to regular.

633
00:30:55.515 --> 00:30:59.080
And normally it's gonna see that and
block off the loops.

634
00:30:59.080 --> 00:31:00.260
But this time we can tell statement chain,

635
00:31:00.260 --> 00:31:03.590
hey, don't block off the loops,
just turn the ports off.

636
00:31:03.590 --> 00:31:08.676
So what we do is, we get into our switch,
and the command, it's one of

637
00:31:08.676 --> 00:31:14.801
the kinda longer ones, is we can just say
spanning-tree, and then etherchannel,

638
00:31:14.801 --> 00:31:20.264
so this is where we link the two
technologies together, guard misconfig.

639
00:31:20.264 --> 00:31:23.048
That command right there's gonna turn
that misconfiguration guard on, so

640
00:31:23.048 --> 00:31:24.786
now it's gonna see that
we have a port channel,

641
00:31:24.786 --> 00:31:26.810
it's gonna see that we
have these interfaces.

642
00:31:26.810 --> 00:31:30.450
And if the port channel doesn't work out,
it'll just block the ports and stop it.

643
00:31:30.450 --> 00:31:32.200
And that'll be the end of it.

644
00:31:32.200 --> 00:31:33.940
And so, we can turn that on.

645
00:31:33.940 --> 00:31:36.330
You usually would wanna turn this
on across your environment, so

646
00:31:36.330 --> 00:31:38.430
you have consistent behavior but
you don't have to.

647
00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:42.300
If it's on on this end and
the other end causes the problem,

648
00:31:42.300 --> 00:31:44.120
the end's gonna drop and
will block it here too.

649
00:31:44.120 --> 00:31:46.260
So I don't technically have
to turn it on everywhere.

650
00:31:46.260 --> 00:31:48.755
But it's usually a good idea so
you have consistent behavior.

651
00:31:48.755 --> 00:31:51.231
But in this scenario
I've got it turned off.

652
00:31:51.231 --> 00:31:54.203
There are some people out there who will
tell you it's not a good idea to turn it

653
00:31:54.203 --> 00:31:56.940
on on both ends, and
I understand why they're saying that.

654
00:31:56.940 --> 00:32:02.620
Because if I disable the ports here, and
the ports gets disabled on the other side,

655
00:32:02.620 --> 00:32:06.320
when I fix one end,
the other end is still disabled.

656
00:32:06.320 --> 00:32:08.020
It doesn't know we fixed the problem.

657
00:32:08.020 --> 00:32:11.700
So if we leave one end not configured,
when I fix the first end,

658
00:32:11.700 --> 00:32:14.580
the second end can see it and
it can come back up.

659
00:32:15.600 --> 00:32:19.033
But it just kinda depends on your
own opinion how you want to.

660
00:32:19.033 --> 00:32:20.978
My opinion is don't use it at all,
just go and hard set stuff and

661
00:32:20.978 --> 00:32:22.440
you don't have to worry about it.

662
00:32:22.440 --> 00:32:23.555
But not everybody agreed.

663
00:32:23.555 --> 00:32:26.715
So just keep that in mind.

664
00:32:26.715 --> 00:32:29.425
Once we have that turned on, now spanning
tree is gonna behave differently, and

665
00:32:29.425 --> 00:32:31.365
it's that extra little
added layer of protection.

666
00:32:31.365 --> 00:32:33.835
Now, we talk about a lot
of commands on the show,

667
00:32:33.835 --> 00:32:37.615
the bulk of which I can assure you guys
I've used many times in production.

668
00:32:37.615 --> 00:32:39.265
I've never once turned
this on in production, and

669
00:32:39.265 --> 00:32:41.888
it's just because of how
I normally set things up.

670
00:32:41.888 --> 00:32:45.230
But you wanna know this one because it
is specifically in the exam objective.

671
00:32:45.230 --> 00:32:47.655
So good chance it's gonna
show up on the exam.

672
00:32:47.655 --> 00:32:48.456
>> Yeah, great stuff Don.

673
00:32:48.456 --> 00:32:49.942
Let's me see, just one second.

674
00:32:49.942 --> 00:32:51.381
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

675
00:32:51.381 --> 00:32:52.169
>> Put that in real quick.

676
00:32:52.169 --> 00:32:55.922
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't mind me Don,

677
00:32:55.922 --> 00:32:57.615
just making a config change.

678
00:32:57.615 --> 00:32:59.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> Episode to stop, that's it.

679
00:32:59.640 --> 00:33:01.525
>> That's it.
The end of the show.

680
00:33:01.525 --> 00:33:03.400
Great stuff though,
excellent demonstrations.

681
00:33:03.400 --> 00:33:06.010
Is there anything else we need to
know about this wonderful technology?

682
00:33:06.010 --> 00:33:07.950
>> I think we are ether channeled out.

683
00:33:07.950 --> 00:33:08.474
That's it.

684
00:33:08.474 --> 00:33:11.287
>> I think our good viewers
out there now know that, hey,

685
00:33:11.287 --> 00:33:14.897
if you do have some of these links
that you're setting up to have that,

686
00:33:14.897 --> 00:33:18.870
we want that redundancy, we also
want that aggregation of link speed.

687
00:33:18.870 --> 00:33:20.140
This is definitely the way to go.

688
00:33:20.140 --> 00:33:24.010
So now you know how to set that up,
I know I'm gonna start employing this in

689
00:33:24.010 --> 00:33:27.560
all of my trunk links that's
a great place to put that.

690
00:33:27.560 --> 00:33:30.150
But Don I say we'll go ahead and
call this an episode.

691
00:33:30.150 --> 00:33:30.900
>> That's a good spot.

692
00:33:30.900 --> 00:33:32.164
>> All right.
Signing off for

693
00:33:32.164 --> 00:33:34.707
ITProTV, I've been your
host Daniel Lowrie.

694
00:33:34.707 --> 00:33:35.531
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:33:35.531 --> 00:33:37.412
We will see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) switch loop prevention system found in Cisco switches. They start with a quick review of STP functions and then get right to explaining how exactly it goes about keeping a switched network loop-free. Specifically here they cover the STP processes of Root Bridge election as well as the 5 STP port states.

Now if you've forgotten

So for example the topology I've

28
00:01:29.655 --> 00:01:33.335

>> All right,
well let's start with the root bridge.

73
00:03:27.910 --> 00:03:30.420
I mentioned that with
Spanning Tree Protocol,

74
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:35.120
it picks somebody to be the head honcho,
to be the center of the network.

75
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:37.310
And a lot of people think
of this as a server.

76
00:03:37.310 --> 00:03:38.660
It's not really a server.

77
00:03:38.660 --> 00:03:43.560
And in the standards, they'll even say it
acts as like the center of the network.

78
00:03:43.560 --> 00:03:45.100
It doesn't necessarily have to
be the center of the network,

79
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:48.100
it can be any switch in your entire
environment can act as what's called

80
00:03:48.100 --> 00:03:48.950
the root bridge.

81
00:03:50.100 --> 00:03:53.240
But the root bridge is pretty
important because it's sending out

82
00:03:53.240 --> 00:03:53.930
announcements, right.

83
00:03:53.930 --> 00:03:55.600
It's announcing that it's on the network.

84
00:03:56.710 --> 00:04:02.140
In spanning tree protocol we use these
BPDUs, these bridge protocol data units,

85
00:04:02.140 --> 00:04:05.000
and the BPDUs are just little
announcements that says, hey,

86
00:04:05.000 --> 00:04:06.920
I'm a switch, and I'm here.

87
00:04:06.920 --> 00:04:11.230
So the root bridge sends out
BPDUs out of all of its ports.

88
00:04:11.230 --> 00:04:13.140
Every single port on the switch,
it sends out a BPDU.

89
00:04:14.540 --> 00:04:17.810
If another switch receives it,
It looks at it and

90
00:04:17.810 --> 00:04:21.400
it says, oh, that guy's the head honcho,
he's the root.

91
00:04:21.400 --> 00:04:24.810
This interface that I just received the
BPDU on, that's a connection to the root.

92
00:04:25.910 --> 00:04:31.280
If it sees a BPDU from the root
come in on two different lengths,

93
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:32.710
it knows there's a loop.

94
00:04:32.710 --> 00:04:33.840
It says wait a minute.

95
00:04:33.840 --> 00:04:38.120
I've got two ways to get to the root,
there's a loop on this network.

96
00:04:38.120 --> 00:04:41.380
So as simple as that,
we can figure out where the loop is.

97
00:04:41.380 --> 00:04:43.870
So using my topology as an example.

98
00:04:43.870 --> 00:04:47.660
Let's just pretend,
that Core 1 is the root.

99
00:04:49.110 --> 00:04:52.520
It's gonna send out BPDUs at
all three of these interfaces.

100
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:56.220
Well one BPDU is gonna come down
this link on interface 22 down to

101
00:04:56.220 --> 00:04:57.830
this access switch and
is gonna receive it.

102
00:04:57.830 --> 00:05:00.207
So the access switch says,
hey I can get to the root right here.

103
00:05:00.207 --> 00:05:05.030
That's a good port but the BPU's
are gonna out these two links also and

104
00:05:05.030 --> 00:05:07.160
those two links are gonna
come over here to CORE 2 and

105
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:11.590
CORE 2's gonna say wait a minute, I've
got two different ways to get to CORE 1.

106
00:05:11.590 --> 00:05:12.780
There's a loop.

107
00:05:12.780 --> 00:05:16.690
I need to do something
about that to fix the loop.

108
00:05:16.690 --> 00:05:20.770
Meanwhile, it takes that root BPU and
forwards it along.

109
00:05:22.070 --> 00:05:28.190
All the child switches in spanning tree
protocol forward along the root BPDU.

110
00:05:28.190 --> 00:05:31.730
So it's receiving the root
BPDU right here in Core 2, and

111
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:34.290
then it sends it down to Access 1.

112
00:05:34.290 --> 00:05:35.820
And so Access 1 is going to say,

113
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:39.280
wait a minute,
I can get to the route two different ways.

114
00:05:39.280 --> 00:05:42.170
I can get to the route this way and
I can get to the route this way.

115
00:05:42.170 --> 00:05:44.220
I have two different paths to take.

116
00:05:44.220 --> 00:05:46.490
And so which one is better?

117
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:47.410
I know I've got a loop.

118
00:05:47.410 --> 00:05:49.100
I've got two ways to get there.

119
00:05:49.100 --> 00:05:51.910
I need to pick the better one and
shut off the bad one.

120
00:05:53.100 --> 00:05:56.260
And that stops the loop and ensures that
we've got the good connection going.

121
00:05:56.260 --> 00:05:57.720
So there's a lot that
comes into play here.

122
00:05:57.720 --> 00:06:01.010
Think about all the different
things I just mentioned,

123
00:06:01.010 --> 00:06:04.460
we have to have a root bridge, so
somebody's got to be the head honcho.

124
00:06:04.460 --> 00:06:07.300
Everybody else has to be
looking at these BPDUs and

125
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:11.420
kind of building their infrastructure, so
they have know which is their best port.

126
00:06:11.420 --> 00:06:14.420
And then somehow, they have to make
a decision over which ports to shut off.

127
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:19.750
So for the CCNA exam, we didn't really
have to know that all that well, but for

128
00:06:19.750 --> 00:06:20.910
the CCNP, you really do.

129
00:06:20.910 --> 00:06:24.720
We need to fully understand exactly
how these decisions get made.

130
00:06:24.720 --> 00:06:27.420
And depending on how much information we

131
00:06:27.420 --> 00:06:30.200
have is going to determine if we can
figure this out on our own or not.

132
00:06:31.620 --> 00:06:33.010
Let's start with that root bridge.

133
00:06:33.010 --> 00:06:34.880
Who becomes the root.

134
00:06:34.880 --> 00:06:39.450
Well if you've only got one switch and
you just turned it on, congratulations,

135
00:06:39.450 --> 00:06:41.540
it's the root, that makes it easy.

136
00:06:41.540 --> 00:06:44.720
But if you have one switch do
you have a loop, probably not,

137
00:06:44.720 --> 00:06:46.710
I guess you could have
a cable running out.

138
00:06:46.710 --> 00:06:47.450
>> Looped to yourself.

139
00:06:47.450 --> 00:06:48.910
>> You can loop to yourself, it happens.

140
00:06:50.010 --> 00:06:51.370
It shouldn't happen, but it does.

141
00:06:52.380 --> 00:06:57.570
But if you have more than one switch, the
odds of creating a loop start to increase.

142
00:06:57.570 --> 00:06:59.690
And sometimes we create loops on purpose.

143
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:02.170
If you watched our ether channel episode,

144
00:07:02.170 --> 00:07:05.520
we had two links running between
a switch for redundancy purposes.

145
00:07:05.520 --> 00:07:08.950
And that was a loop and
we did it on purpose for redundancy.

146
00:07:08.950 --> 00:07:11.530
Well, Spinning Tree solves that problem,
but

147
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:14.120
keeps the other cable available to
bring it back up if we need it.

148
00:07:14.120 --> 00:07:16.620
We can use either channel to
fix that between two switches.

149
00:07:16.620 --> 00:07:18.280
But if you have more than
two switches in the loop,

150
00:07:18.280 --> 00:07:21.630
like what we've got here with Core1,
Core2 and this access switch.

151
00:07:21.630 --> 00:07:25.890
You've got more than two switches here,
ether channel can't solve that problem.

152
00:07:25.890 --> 00:07:28.770
I've got this triangle, or
it might be a square or an octagon or

153
00:07:28.770 --> 00:07:31.420
whatever that creates
a giant loop in my network.

154
00:07:31.420 --> 00:07:32.560
I need a way to fix that.

155
00:07:32.560 --> 00:07:35.160
So we have to elect somebody at the root.

156
00:07:35.160 --> 00:07:37.290
And, assuming that all of
the switches are already up and

157
00:07:37.290 --> 00:07:41.700
running, it could be just whatever
switch came up first is the root.

158
00:07:41.700 --> 00:07:46.180
But if that switch goes off,
an election happens.

159
00:07:46.180 --> 00:07:49.030
It's election day on the old network.

160
00:07:49.030 --> 00:07:52.570
And so some switch has to
basically get elected as the root.

161
00:07:52.570 --> 00:07:54.793
And it boils down to
a few different factors.

162
00:07:54.793 --> 00:07:57.584
In Spanning Tree,
you have what's called a priority.

163
00:07:57.584 --> 00:08:00.751
And the priority is really what
determines who becomes the root.

164
00:08:00.751 --> 00:08:05.833
Priority's a number.
Zero through 65,534.

165
00:08:05.833 --> 00:08:08.770
It's one of those,
what is that 16 bit number?

166
00:08:08.770 --> 00:08:11.260
>> Yeah.
>> 65,000, yeah I think it's 16 bits.

167
00:08:11.260 --> 00:08:14.990
So, that's why the number stops at 65,534.

168
00:08:14.990 --> 00:08:18.210
So, every switch has a priority number.

169
00:08:18.210 --> 00:08:19.720
And it's gonna be between those.

170
00:08:19.720 --> 00:08:23.110
If you make it a zero, that tells
the switch hey, you need to be the root.

171
00:08:23.110 --> 00:08:26.010
If you make it 65,534 that says,
you're not gonna be the root unless

172
00:08:26.010 --> 00:08:30.240
everybody else is turned off,
then you're not gonna be the root.

173
00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:32.240
So we influence that priority.

174
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:34.790
Remember, this is where
it's really challenging.

175
00:08:34.790 --> 00:08:37.120
Lower priority is better.

176
00:08:37.120 --> 00:08:38.920
Right?
The lower the priority number,

177
00:08:38.920 --> 00:08:41.460
the more likely you are to become a root.

178
00:08:41.460 --> 00:08:47.870
Well, on Cisco switches,
the default is 32,768.

179
00:08:47.870 --> 00:08:49.050
Now it's a weird number.

180
00:08:49.050 --> 00:08:51.997
Right?
Why do they pick 32,768?

181
00:08:51.997 --> 00:08:58.545
It's smack in the middle of zero and
65,534.

182
00:08:58.545 --> 00:08:59.101
So it's right in the middle.

183
00:08:59.101 --> 00:09:03.572
32,768, so if I have all Cisco equipment,

184
00:09:03.572 --> 00:09:08.047
they all default to 32,768 and it's a tie.

185
00:09:08.047 --> 00:09:09.767
It's a tie across all my equipment.

186
00:09:09.767 --> 00:09:13.960
If I have third party equipment,
who know what they're set to.

187
00:09:13.960 --> 00:09:20.388
Spanning tree protocol is an open
standard, it's 802.1D, I 802.1D.

188
00:09:20.388 --> 00:09:22.614
And it defines the way
spanning tree works so

189
00:09:22.614 --> 00:09:26.225
you can have third parties and
they might have a lower priority number,

190
00:09:26.225 --> 00:09:29.140
or they might have a higher
priority number who knows.

191
00:09:29.140 --> 00:09:31.080
You'd need to read their manual and
check it.

192
00:09:31.080 --> 00:09:34.540
But if it's all Cisco,
it's one big fat tie.

193
00:09:34.540 --> 00:09:36.890
So I got two choices, all right?

194
00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:40.580
One, I can go and adjust the priority
to dictate who's gonna be the root.

195
00:09:41.650 --> 00:09:44.280
Or two, I can leave it to chance.

196
00:09:44.280 --> 00:09:46.950
Right?
There is a tie-breaker mechanism.

197
00:09:46.950 --> 00:09:50.900
If the priority is equal
on all the switches

198
00:09:50.900 --> 00:09:52.970
then it goes to what's
called the bridge ID.

199
00:09:52.970 --> 00:09:56.800
Now the bridge ID is technically
made up of the port number,

200
00:09:56.800 --> 00:09:58.230
I mean the priority number.

201
00:09:58.230 --> 00:10:02.350
But it's the priority number and
the MAC address, okay.

202
00:10:02.350 --> 00:10:05.550
Every switch has a MAC address, every
switch has a lot of MAC addresses, right.

203
00:10:05.550 --> 00:10:07.755
But it has one that's its
primary MAC address for

204
00:10:07.755 --> 00:10:11.300
its management interface and
it's gonna use that MAC address.

205
00:10:11.300 --> 00:10:13.560
And so when I create that switch,

206
00:10:13.560 --> 00:10:18.520
it's got a priority that might be equal,
but its MAC address is not gonna be equal.

207
00:10:18.520 --> 00:10:23.740
And so it looks at the MAC address and,
whoever has the lowest MAC address, wins.

208
00:10:23.740 --> 00:10:24.600
Just like priority,

209
00:10:24.600 --> 00:10:28.020
the lower the number the better,
the lower the MAC address, the better.

210
00:10:28.020 --> 00:10:32.230
And so priority combined with
MAC address is the bridge ID.

211
00:10:32.230 --> 00:10:36.010
That's what identifies that bridge, and
that's gonna be the tiebreaker for us.

212
00:10:36.010 --> 00:10:38.450
Now here's the problem
with that as a tiebreaker.

213
00:10:38.450 --> 00:10:42.070
When Cisco manufactures a switch
they assign to the MAC address.

214
00:10:42.070 --> 00:10:44.530
And they don't use that
MAC address any more.

215
00:10:44.530 --> 00:10:47.080
So if it gives a switch a MAC
address that ends in five,

216
00:10:47.080 --> 00:10:49.950
the next switch they
manufacture ends in six,

217
00:10:49.950 --> 00:10:53.570
and the next one is seven, and
then seven, and it goes up, like that.

218
00:10:53.570 --> 00:10:54.400
All right.

219
00:10:54.400 --> 00:10:58.040
That means a switch that
I bought ten years ago

220
00:10:58.040 --> 00:11:02.170
is gonna have a lower MAC address
then a switch I buy today.

221
00:11:02.170 --> 00:11:08.075
So I might have this bright shiny 6500
series switch that cost 100 grand,

222
00:11:08.075 --> 00:11:11.415
and I just put it in my network, and
I want this to be that root bridge.

223
00:11:13.425 --> 00:11:16.595
But I got this old, crusty 1900
that's sitting in some lab somewhere.

224
00:11:16.595 --> 00:11:19.445
It's 10 megabit and its MAC address is so

225
00:11:19.445 --> 00:11:22.725
low that it becomes the root
on my network, right?

226
00:11:22.725 --> 00:11:25.533
So if you don't want to leave it
to chance you'll want to go and

227
00:11:25.533 --> 00:11:28.460
adjust your priority to dictate
who's gonna become that root.

228
00:11:28.460 --> 00:11:30.929
All right in my network I'm
leaving it up to chance.

229
00:11:30.929 --> 00:11:33.721
So let's go into it and
we're gonna see who is the root.

230
00:11:33.721 --> 00:11:38.677
Now to me I'm thinking New York core
one should be the root it's a core

231
00:11:38.677 --> 00:11:42.189
right at least core two maybe but
I want core one.

232
00:11:42.189 --> 00:11:47.406
So I want it to be the root,
well if I jump into core one and

233
00:11:47.406 --> 00:11:54.340
I do a show stunning dash tree I can
see that I'm running spanning-tree.

234
00:11:54.340 --> 00:11:58.500
And right here at the very beginning,
it's gonna tell me what my ID is.

235
00:11:59.930 --> 00:12:01.230
And I can see my priority.

236
00:12:01.230 --> 00:12:06.445
Now, my priority is not set
to the default, it's 24577.

237
00:12:06.445 --> 00:12:09.230
And my address, that's my MAC address.

238
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:14.950
And so those two combined, my priority and
my address combine to make my bridge ID.

239
00:12:14.950 --> 00:12:16.520
Now here it's saying the root ID.

240
00:12:16.520 --> 00:12:19.360
This is whoever is the root.

241
00:12:19.360 --> 00:12:20.030

00:24:06.617 --> 00:24:10.710
And when you plug in that computer,
a new port comes up and

464
00:24:10.710 --> 00:24:13.710
a new potential for a loop comes up.

465
00:24:13.710 --> 00:24:15.450
All right,
now if I'm plugging in a laptop or

466
00:24:15.450 --> 00:24:18.880
if I'm plugging in a PC,
I'm not creating a loop there am I?

467
00:24:18.880 --> 00:24:23.162
But if I'm plugging in a switch,
I could create a loop.

468
00:24:23.162 --> 00:24:27.390
So spanning-tree has to watch every
single port on your switch, and

469
00:24:27.390 --> 00:24:30.230
when that port state changes,
when it come to a up,

470
00:24:30.230 --> 00:24:33.255
up status, spanning-tree has
to run to check it for a loop.

471
00:24:33.255 --> 00:24:36.690
All right, and the default behavior
is a little bit odd, especially for

472
00:24:36.690 --> 00:24:39.110
people that haven't worked with
higher end switches before.

473
00:24:39.110 --> 00:24:42.040
If you've only worked with low
end switches, you plug a PC in

474
00:24:42.040 --> 00:24:45.600
that switch port, the port comes up and
you're communicating right then.

475
00:24:46.760 --> 00:24:47.920
But if you take a laptop and

476
00:24:47.920 --> 00:24:51.750
you plug it into a brand new Cisco switch,
you don't communicate.

477
00:24:51.750 --> 00:24:53.170
It sits there and
you're not on the network and

478
00:24:53.170 --> 00:24:54.450
you're like what the heck's going on?

479
00:24:54.450 --> 00:24:56.120
You start running IPConfig.

480
00:24:56.120 --> 00:24:58.420
You start trying to ping or IFConfig.

481
00:24:58.420 --> 00:24:59.490
You start troubleshooting.

482
00:24:59.490 --> 00:25:01.274
And all of the student it just
magically starts working.

483
00:25:01.274 --> 00:25:01.958
All right,

484
00:25:01.958 --> 00:25:07.000
what happens is the default configuration
of spanning-tree does a hold down.

485
00:25:07.000 --> 00:25:10.900
When you plug in a new port it
holds it down for 30 seconds, and

486
00:25:10.900 --> 00:25:14.747
during that 30 second period,
it's checking to see if you're a loop.

487
00:25:14.747 --> 00:25:15.350
Right?

488
00:25:15.350 --> 00:25:19.050
What it's doing is it says if this is
a loop I should be getting BPDUs from

489
00:25:19.050 --> 00:25:20.330
the root switch on it.

490
00:25:20.330 --> 00:25:22.530
So am I seeing any BPDUs?

491
00:25:22.530 --> 00:25:24.660
If I do, I might have a loop.

492
00:25:24.660 --> 00:25:28.220
If I don't, then it's just a PC,
or a laptop, or a printer, or

493
00:25:28.220 --> 00:25:30.759
something like that or
they're not sending me BPDUs.

494
00:25:30.759 --> 00:25:33.300
So, if not a loop,
I can let the port communicate.

495
00:25:33.300 --> 00:25:36.210
But it'll hold it down for 30 seconds,
you gotta wait for that to happen.

496
00:25:36.210 --> 00:25:37.270
All right?

497
00:25:37.270 --> 00:25:39.790
And there's actually a good bit
going on behind the scenes there.

498
00:25:39.790 --> 00:25:40.440
Right?

499
00:25:40.440 --> 00:25:44.226
There's five steps to
spanning-tree protocol by default.

500
00:25:44.226 --> 00:25:49.072
All right, and different text books kinda
refer to this different ways depending on

501
00:25:49.072 --> 00:25:50.720
how they want to arrange it.

502
00:25:50.720 --> 00:25:54.335
Cuz one of the states is
that the port is disabled.

503
00:25:54.335 --> 00:25:57.383
Okay, and that usually means
the port is either unplugged or

504
00:25:57.383 --> 00:25:58.953
administratively shut down.

505
00:25:58.953 --> 00:25:59.470
Right?

506
00:25:59.470 --> 00:26:01.930
So it's not really
participating in spanning-tree.

507
00:26:01.930 --> 00:26:04.830
Some people count that as the first phase,
some people count that as the last phase.

508
00:26:04.830 --> 00:26:06.480
So it kinda changes the numbers a bit, but

509
00:26:06.480 --> 00:26:08.750
the other four phases
are all pretty set in stone.

510
00:26:08.750 --> 00:26:13.006
But just remember, a port doesn't have to
participate in spanning-tree, it could be

511
00:26:13.006 --> 00:26:16.571
disabled for the port, and that is
even though it's not participating,

512
00:26:16.571 --> 00:26:20.044
that is kind of a state of spanning-tree,
not being spanning-tree.

513
00:26:20.044 --> 00:26:21.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's kinda weird.

514
00:26:21.140 --> 00:26:23.510
>> It's a non state of
spanning tree [LAUGH]

515
00:26:23.510 --> 00:26:25.080
>> Choosing not to be a part

516
00:26:25.080 --> 00:26:27.440
is being a part, so, that's what happens.

517
00:26:27.440 --> 00:26:29.690
But the other states
are pretty straightforward.

518
00:26:29.690 --> 00:26:31.550
Right?
So as we move through the states,

519
00:26:32.600 --> 00:26:36.840
the very first state you have
is what's called Blocking.

520
00:26:36.840 --> 00:26:39.700
Blocking means,
it's a valid port, it works but

521
00:26:39.700 --> 00:26:41.182
I gotta block it cuz this created a loop.

522
00:26:41.182 --> 00:26:44.966
All right, if it's not a loop then I'm not
gonna block, but if the port is up and

523
00:26:44.966 --> 00:26:48.375
I just haven't checked it or
anything like that yet then its blocking.

524
00:26:48.375 --> 00:26:49.681
So, blocking is the default.

525
00:26:49.681 --> 00:26:50.990
Right?

526
00:26:50.990 --> 00:26:53.892
We wanna protect ourselves from loops by
default, so blocking is where we start.

527
00:26:53.892 --> 00:26:56.770
All right, but
when you plug in a new PC and

528
00:26:56.770 --> 00:27:00.770
that link comes up, then we move
in to what's called Listening.

529
00:27:00.770 --> 00:27:03.650
For 15 seconds we just listen.

530
00:27:04.762 --> 00:27:07.350
Whatever is on the other end, whatever
you just plugged in is gonna be talking.

531
00:27:07.350 --> 00:27:08.810
It's gonna be saying,
please give me a DHCP address.

532
00:27:08.810 --> 00:27:11.350
And we're just gonna ignore that,
we're gonna listen.

533
00:27:11.350 --> 00:27:13.799
And what we're doing is
we're listening for BPDUs.

534
00:27:13.799 --> 00:27:18.774
And we listen for 15 seconds because most
switches defaults every ten seconds for

535
00:27:18.774 --> 00:27:19.277
BPDUs.

536
00:27:19.277 --> 00:27:22.737
All right, but some go a little bit
longer, so we listen for 15 seconds and

537
00:27:22.737 --> 00:27:24.154
we wait to see if we hear a BPDU.

538
00:27:24.154 --> 00:27:29.445
Okay, if we hear a BPDU, now we've gotta
look at our network and see whether

539
00:27:29.445 --> 00:27:34.920
this is a loop and we need to block it, or
if it's a better way to get to the root.

540
00:27:34.920 --> 00:27:37.380
This might be a better connection and
I wanna block my other one.

541
00:27:37.380 --> 00:27:38.428
We have to make that decision.

542
00:27:38.428 --> 00:27:41.100
All right, that happens during listening.

543
00:27:41.100 --> 00:27:46.600
If 15 seconds pass and I don't see
any BPDUs, then we move to learning.

544
00:27:46.600 --> 00:27:48.405
In the learning stage
we're still listening for

545
00:27:48.405 --> 00:27:50.110
BPDUs cuz it could be they're just late.

546
00:27:50.110 --> 00:27:51.980
Right?
Someone may have a really long timer.

547
00:27:51.980 --> 00:27:55.040
So we keep listening,
but now we're learning.

548
00:27:55.040 --> 00:27:57.550
We're learning the MAC address on
the other end of the link, and

549
00:27:57.550 --> 00:28:01.070
we take that MAC address and
we stick it in our arc table.

550
00:28:01.070 --> 00:28:03.088
Right?
Because people are not, well, and

551
00:28:03.088 --> 00:28:06.492
it does into arc cable at some point but
it goes in our Mac address table first.

552
00:28:06.492 --> 00:28:07.100
Right?

553
00:28:07.100 --> 00:28:09.930
So it goes in the Mac address
cable because as a switch,

554
00:28:09.930 --> 00:28:12.010
how do I move traffic from port to port?

555
00:28:12.010 --> 00:28:13.370
By knowing the Mac addresses.

556
00:28:13.370 --> 00:28:15.115
So here's a great chance for

557
00:28:15.115 --> 00:28:17.265
me to pre-populate it in
order to be ready to rock.

558
00:28:17.265 --> 00:28:17.895
Right?

559
00:28:17.895 --> 00:28:21.215
And so, we get that loaded in,
that happens during the learning phase.

560
00:28:21.215 --> 00:28:22.993
And the learning phase
takes another 15 seconds.

561
00:28:22.993 --> 00:28:23.558
Right?

562
00:28:23.558 --> 00:28:26.858
So for 30 seconds, listening and
learning, that device,

563
00:28:26.858 --> 00:28:29.913
whatever it is I just plugged in,
is not allowed to talk.

564
00:28:29.913 --> 00:28:32.775
So it looks like the network's down for
30 seconds.

565
00:28:32.775 --> 00:28:36.080
And then we move into the last stage,
which is Forwarding.

566
00:28:36.080 --> 00:28:40.908
When we get to forwarding, now we
allow traffic to flow over the port.

567
00:28:40.908 --> 00:28:44.811
All right, and it can send and receive and
the MAC address is already in our MAC

568
00:28:44.811 --> 00:28:47.590
address table and
it's a good port, it's good to go.

569
00:28:47.590 --> 00:28:51.566
All right, so spanning-tree is doing that
and it's by default on every Cisco switch.

570
00:28:51.566 --> 00:28:54.005
When you take that brand new
switch out of the box and

571
00:28:54.005 --> 00:28:55.775
plug in you have a 30 second delay.

572
00:28:55.775 --> 00:28:58.920
All right, now later,
I've already rambled on too long.

573
00:28:58.920 --> 00:29:01.540
But later on, I wanna show you guys some
techniques we can use to make that a heck

574
00:29:01.540 --> 00:29:02.630
of a lot faster.

575
00:29:02.630 --> 00:29:04.780
We've got a few different ways to do that.

576
00:29:04.780 --> 00:29:05.420
But for right now,

577
00:29:05.420 --> 00:29:08.750
I'm just kinda describing the default
way that spanning-tree works.

578
00:29:08.750 --> 00:29:12.634
So on the exam, if they show you
a picture like my triangle topology, and

579
00:29:12.634 --> 00:29:14.683
they ask you who's gonna be the root?

580
00:29:14.683 --> 00:29:16.140
You need to be able to figure that out.

581
00:29:16.140 --> 00:29:20.430
And if they ask you, you plug in a PC and
it holds you down for 30 seconds,

582
00:29:20.430 --> 00:29:21.710
what's going on there?

583
00:29:21.710 --> 00:29:24.185
Then you know that's the standard
spanning-tree listening and

584
00:29:24.185 --> 00:29:26.621
learning interval, and
that's kinda what's going on there.

585
00:29:26.621 --> 00:29:27.264
All right, so

586
00:29:27.264 --> 00:29:31.370
that's the basic process, and that's what
happens when we plug in a new device.

587
00:29:31.370 --> 00:29:32.960
>> Awesome.
Well obviously spanning-tree

588
00:29:32.960 --> 00:29:36.480
is something we need to know a little
bit about, because it can't help us out.

589
00:29:36.480 --> 00:29:38.483
We definitely wanna avoid those loops.

590
00:29:38.483 --> 00:29:41.972
But Don, we got plenty more to talk about,
yet so little time.

591
00:29:41.972 --> 00:29:43.471
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

592
00:29:43.471 --> 00:29:45.195
>> Well, let's break this one up.

593
00:29:45.195 --> 00:29:47.523
This is gonna be our new standard plan.

594
00:29:47.523 --> 00:29:49.209
Right?
We'll just go into part two.

595
00:29:49.209 --> 00:29:52.001
>> That's right,
part two mode, the STPing.

596
00:29:52.001 --> 00:29:53.081
>> And we have a lot of spanning-trees.

597
00:29:53.081 --> 00:29:54.352
>> We do.
>> So I imagine we're going to have

598
00:29:54.352 --> 00:29:54.900
a part three.

599
00:29:54.900 --> 00:29:56.154
>> Maybe.
>> And who knows we might go crazy and

600
00:29:56.154 --> 00:29:56.720
do a part four.

601
00:29:56.720 --> 00:29:57.542
>> That's right.
This guy right here,

602
00:29:57.542 --> 00:29:58.264
he loves to talk about this stuff.

603
00:29:58.264 --> 00:30:00.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, that is very, very likely.

604
00:30:00.900 --> 00:30:02.970
Hopefully we'll see you
guys in those episodes.

605
00:30:02.970 --> 00:30:05.068
That's where this one,
we're going to call it a close.

606
00:30:05.068 --> 00:30:08.049
Thanks for watching today,
signing off for ITProTV.

607
00:30:08.049 --> 00:30:09.357
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

608
00:30:09.357 --> 00:30:10.384
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

609
00:30:10.384 --> 00:30:11.597
>> And we'll see you next time.

610
00:30:11.597 --> 00:30:18.450

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue explaining the switch loop prevention system called Spanning Tree Protocol found in Cisco switches. They pick back up exploring the topic of ports; root ports, designated ports, and non-designated ports and their timers. How and why they are utilized in STP is covered and then they show STP ports and timers in action.
episodes.title: Spanning Tree Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.708 --> 00:00:16.570
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another greet episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.570 --> 00:00:17.710
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.710 --> 00:00:20.320
Here with me today none other than Mr.
Don Pezet.

5
00:00:20.320 --> 00:00:21.130
How's it going, Don?

6
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:21.969
>> It's going great.

7
00:00:21.969 --> 00:00:25.294
I'm excited to be back on the show and
ready to continue on with our

8
00:00:25.294 --> 00:00:28.747
Spanning Tree Protocol adventure
that we started back in part one.

9
00:00:28.747 --> 00:00:32.220
If you're watching the shows in series,
then you're in the right place.

10
00:00:32.220 --> 00:00:34.690
But if you're just starting out,
definitely check out part one because

11
00:00:34.690 --> 00:00:37.990
that's where we introduced you guys to
spanning tree protocol and kinda how it

12
00:00:37.990 --> 00:00:42.010
functions, what it does or how it
kinda works with this loop prevention.

13
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:44.440
Now, we left off with
the episode yesterday,

14
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:47.560
we had talked about how
a root bridge is selected.

15
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:50.290
And that's one of the first things
that Spanning Tree Protocol does.

16
00:00:50.290 --> 00:00:55.550
It's gotta pick somebody, it's gotta
pick a switch to be the guy in charge.

17
00:00:55.550 --> 00:01:00.310
And then, after that, all the other
switches are gonna form up in line against

18
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.600
that main controlling switch,
and they're gonna detect loops.

19
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:08.840
And once they spot the loops,
they gotta shut off ports to fix that.

20
00:01:08.840 --> 00:01:12.070
And I made a comment on the last show,
I said, the root bridge,

21
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:16.680
that guy never shuts off a port, unless
you run a cable from it right back to it.

22
00:01:16.680 --> 00:01:18.940
It would have to be a direct
loop on the root bridge.

23
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:21.950
But otherwise the root bridge
never shuts off a port.

24
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:22.760
Everybody else has to.

25
00:01:23.810 --> 00:01:27.300
So there's obviously winners and
losers in this equation and

26
00:01:27.300 --> 00:01:33.010
I always think of that Mel Brooks film
where he says, it's good to be the king.

27
00:01:33.010 --> 00:01:34.400
Well, that's how it is
with the root bridge.

28
00:01:34.400 --> 00:01:35.830
It's good to be the root bridge.

29
00:01:35.830 --> 00:01:37.050
He never makes a mistake.

30
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:37.985
Don't show off any ports.

31
00:01:37.985 --> 00:01:40.528
>> [LAUGH]
>> But all the other guys have to, and

32
00:01:40.528 --> 00:01:43.752
so we need to understand the mechanism
that's in use to figure out

33
00:01:43.752 --> 00:01:46.460
which ports get left on and
which ports get turned off.

34
00:01:47.620 --> 00:01:52.210
Now, looking at my topology,
let me bring up my topology diagram again.

35
00:01:52.210 --> 00:01:55.920
And when we look at my topology
here I've got three switches.

36
00:01:55.920 --> 00:01:57.970
And I've got two different
loops that are involved here.

37
00:01:59.020 --> 00:02:03.912
I've got New York Core 1 has two links
to New York Core 2, and those 2 links,

38
00:02:03.912 --> 00:02:06.050
they are gonna create a loop.

39
00:02:06.050 --> 00:02:08.930
So there's one loop that's
gonna have to be resolved.

40
00:02:08.930 --> 00:02:13.170
And then, I've got a bigger loop right
here running as a triangle between

41
00:02:13.170 --> 00:02:14.980
the three switches that's a loop too.

42
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:16.940
That's gonna have to be resolved.

43
00:02:16.940 --> 00:02:23.410
Now, if New York Core 1, if that's my root
bridge he's not gonna show off any ports.

44
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:29.418
He's got three ports,
two of which are involved in a loop.

45
00:02:29.418 --> 00:02:33.750
We don't necessarily know which two, but
at least two are involved in a loop.

46
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:36.630
And something's gotta be turned off,
it's not gonna do it.

47
00:02:36.630 --> 00:02:39.530
So these other switches are gonna
have to make some decisions.

48
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:44.300
Now, technically, New York Core 2
here could solve all my problems.

49
00:02:44.300 --> 00:02:48.790
This one switch could turn off
one of these two ports here.

50
00:02:48.790 --> 00:02:52.413
And it can turn off this port
running down to New York Access 1.

51
00:02:52.413 --> 00:02:55.774
It would still have one link to the core,
so it would still be able to communicate,

52
00:02:55.774 --> 00:02:57.340
and the loop would be gone.

53
00:02:57.340 --> 00:02:59.230
One switch could solve my problem.

54
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:01.412
But that's not how it always works.

55
00:03:01.412 --> 00:03:03.665
Because there's a lot of criteria
that goes into figuring out

56
00:03:03.665 --> 00:03:05.330
what ports to shut off.

57
00:03:05.330 --> 00:03:09.940
So when spanning tree fires up step one,
reelect a route bridge, step two,

58
00:03:09.940 --> 00:03:16.600
all the other bridges figure out what
is their best connection to the root.

59
00:03:16.600 --> 00:03:18.320
They have to know the best
connection to the root,

60
00:03:18.320 --> 00:03:19.272
cuz they don't wanna shut that off.

61
00:03:19.272 --> 00:03:22.230
We wanna keep that best link.

62
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:26.970
Technically New York Core 2 can get to
New York Core 1 via 3 different links.

63
00:03:26.970 --> 00:03:28.530
It can jump over port 23, port 24, or

64
00:03:28.530 --> 00:03:32.910
it can go over port 22
through this other switch.

65
00:03:32.910 --> 00:03:35.300
So how does it know which one is better?

66
00:03:35.300 --> 00:03:37.880
Well, it uses a couple
of different things, but

67
00:03:37.880 --> 00:03:40.050
the main thing it uses is
what's called a port cost.

68
00:03:41.130 --> 00:03:45.150
Spanning tree protocol assigns
a cost to every single interface.

69
00:03:45.150 --> 00:03:48.960
And despite what you'll find in some
places out there on the Internet,

70
00:03:48.960 --> 00:03:51.390
the cost number is actually arbitrary.

71
00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:55.050
If you ever get bored and you go and
crack open IEEE 802.1D and

72
00:03:55.050 --> 00:03:59.760
start reading through the standard,
it's really super mega boring.

73
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:03.400
But in there you'll find where
they give you recommendations for

74
00:04:03.400 --> 00:04:05.470
how the cost should be measured.

75
00:04:05.470 --> 00:04:06.930
But they're not rules.

76
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:07.980
They're not being forced on you.

77
00:04:07.980 --> 00:04:09.467
They're a recommendation.

78
00:04:09.467 --> 00:04:13.364
And so, vendors like Cisco and
HP and Extreme Networks, those guys,

79
00:04:13.364 --> 00:04:15.742
they might choose to

you're going to have a four-digit number.

529
00:27:37.971 --> 00:27:40.496
This were different
types of spanning tree.

530
00:27:40.496 --> 00:27:42.760
And there's other types of spanning
tree that are much faster.

531
00:27:42.760 --> 00:27:43.930
And we'll see later in the series,

532
00:27:43.930 --> 00:27:45.927
there are other ways to treat
this which make it much faster.

533
00:27:45.927 --> 00:27:49.228
But if I want to adjust the timers I can,
I just encourage you not to do it.

534
00:27:49.228 --> 00:27:50.935
But let me show you how it would be done.

535
00:27:50.935 --> 00:27:53.157
Let's say, I jump over here to core two.

536
00:27:53.157 --> 00:27:58.251
And on this switch, I decide that I
know more than Cisco and the IEEE.

537
00:27:58.251 --> 00:28:01.224
So I want to, somebody's gonna
edit that sound byte out and

538
00:28:01.224 --> 00:28:03.375
I'm gonna regret that the rest of my life.

539
00:28:03.375 --> 00:28:04.633
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I wanna go in here and

540
00:28:04.633 --> 00:28:05.533
tweak these timers.

541
00:28:05.533 --> 00:28:06.368
Okay.

542
00:28:06.368 --> 00:28:10.427
So if I wanna tweak them, we can jump in,
we can start to mess with that.

543
00:28:10.427 --> 00:28:13.714
And it's a few different
ways we can do it.

544
00:28:13.714 --> 00:28:16.135
If you do, before I even get started here,

545
00:28:16.135 --> 00:28:18.974
I'm just gonna do a show
spanning-tree vlan 1.

546
00:28:18.974 --> 00:28:21.777
And I'm gonna take a look at that output.

547
00:28:21.777 --> 00:28:26.000
And in here, you can see your hello timer.

548
00:28:26.000 --> 00:28:27.960
That's how often your sending BPDU's.

549
00:28:27.960 --> 00:28:30.270
This one's sending BPDU's
every two seconds.

550
00:28:30.270 --> 00:28:32.840
Maximum age, 20 seconds.

551
00:28:32.840 --> 00:28:34.567
That's where our blocking comes in.

552
00:28:34.567 --> 00:28:36.922
We're not gonna stay blocking for
more than 20 seconds.

553
00:28:36.922 --> 00:28:40.359
And then we get forwarding delay,
15 seconds.

554
00:28:40.359 --> 00:28:43.000
That's where my listening and
learning timers are coming from.

555
00:28:43.000 --> 00:28:46.630
So it's telling me the times
that it's using right there.

556
00:28:46.630 --> 00:28:50.094
And if I don't hear BPDU's from somebody,
but the link is still up and healthy.

557
00:28:50.094 --> 00:28:52.914
Well, I need to get a BPDU
within a certain amount of time.

558
00:28:52.914 --> 00:28:55.460
I get this aging of five minutes.

559
00:28:55.460 --> 00:28:56.939
And so I need to hear from them.

560
00:28:56.939 --> 00:28:59.699
If I don't, I'm gonna assume
that they're a dead link now and

561
00:28:59.699 --> 00:29:01.230
I need to pull them out.

562
00:29:01.230 --> 00:29:01.750
Okay.

563
00:29:01.750 --> 00:29:06.390
So these are some of the timers that are
being put in use, and we can tweak those.

564
00:29:06.390 --> 00:29:08.828
If we jump in and if we want to do that.

565
00:29:08.828 --> 00:29:10.168
Again, I don't encourage you to do it.

566
00:29:10.168 --> 00:29:15.180
But if you do, it's actually set as
part of the global configuration.

567
00:29:15.180 --> 00:29:19.718
So we say spanning- tree, and
then it's on a per vlan basis.

568
00:29:19.718 --> 00:29:22.890
So I'm gonna say per vlan 1,
I want to adjust the timer.

569
00:29:22.890 --> 00:29:27.930
So spanning-tree vlan 1, and
if you do a question mark, let's see.

570
00:29:27.930 --> 00:29:31.306
If you spell spanning tree right,
then you can do a question mark and

571
00:29:31.306 --> 00:29:33.807
you'll see the different
timers right in there.

572
00:29:33.807 --> 00:29:36.090
You've got, there we go.

573
00:29:36.090 --> 00:29:39.817
Your maximum age or
hello time, your forward time.

574
00:29:39.817 --> 00:29:41.570
There's those three timers.

575
00:29:41.570 --> 00:29:42.661
And so you can come in and
you can adjust them.

576
00:29:42.661 --> 00:29:47.306
You can set a shorter age,
you can set a faster forward time and

577
00:29:47.306 --> 00:29:49.770
speed that process up.

578
00:29:49.770 --> 00:29:50.894
But there's better ways to do it.

579
00:29:50.894 --> 00:29:54.293
So if they ask you on the exam
to adjust the timers, you can.

580
00:29:54.293 --> 00:29:55.292
Here's how you do it.

581
00:29:55.292 --> 00:29:57.069
But there's better ways.

582
00:29:57.069 --> 00:29:57.986
>> Not best practice.

583
00:29:57.986 --> 00:29:59.691
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> [LAUGH] All right, Don.

584
00:29:59.691 --> 00:30:02.885
Well, I know we have a lot more to
cover when it comes to spanning tree.

585
00:30:02.885 --> 00:30:07.160
It's quite a lengthy bit of a dialogue for
us to go through.

586
00:30:07.160 --> 00:30:09.940
And looking at the time where we have
completely exhausted our time for

587
00:30:09.940 --> 00:30:10.890
this episode.

588
00:30:10.890 --> 00:30:12.648
So we're gonna have to make a part three,
and

589
00:30:12.648 --> 00:30:15.438
hopefully we'll see everybody out there,
as well, in that episode.

590
00:30:15.438 --> 00:30:17.127
As for this one,
we're gonna call it a close.

591
00:30:17.127 --> 00:30:18.570
Thanks for watching.

592
00:30:18.570 --> 00:30:19.497
Signing off for IT-Pro TV.

593
00:30:19.497 --> 00:30:20.937
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

00:30:20.937 --> 00:30:22.075

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the switch loop prevention system called Spanning Tree Protocol found in Cisco switches. Specifically called out in this episode is the different versions of Spanning Tree; explaining the why and how you might employ one over the other. They go into great detail describing PVST+, RPVST+, and MST.
episodes.title: Spanning Tree Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.914 --> 00:00:12.940
All right.

3
00:00:12.940 --> 00:00:16.990
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.990 --> 00:00:18.310
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:18.310 --> 00:00:21.020
Here with me yet again today,
is Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:21.020 --> 00:00:22.430
How's it going, Don?

7
00:00:22.430 --> 00:00:23.320
>> It is going well Daniel.

8
00:00:23.320 --> 00:00:26.030
I'm always surprised you
maintain that happy demeanour.

9
00:00:26.030 --> 00:00:28.850
We're on part three of this show and
so its starting to run on.

10
00:00:28.850 --> 00:00:31.640
But it's really important that we have
that in-depth knowledge of spanning tree

11
00:00:31.640 --> 00:00:35.780
protocol for the exam and
we're gonna be continuing with it today.

12
00:00:35.780 --> 00:00:40.286
We're on part three, we've already
done two episodes on this, but

13
00:00:40.286 --> 00:00:44.949
those two episodes we focused on
the original spanning tree protocol,

14
00:00:44.949 --> 00:00:48.385
which is IEEE802.1D
spanning tree protocol.

15
00:00:48.385 --> 00:00:53.066
Real important to understand the original
because there's actually four other

16
00:00:53.066 --> 00:00:58.440
versions of spanning tree protocol that
are out there that we need to be aware of.

17
00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:02.860
There's several different implementations
of spanning tree protocol and

18
00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:04.290
they serve different purposes.

19
00:01:04.290 --> 00:01:05.730
They have different uses.

20
00:01:05.730 --> 00:01:11.176
We need to understand each so
we know when to use one versus the other.

21
00:01:11.176 --> 00:01:16.610
Now the original IEEE802.1D spanning tree
protocol is supported by darn near every

22
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:21.730
piece of equipment in the planet, and with
each additional version of spanning tree

23
00:01:21.730 --> 00:01:26.400
protocol, they've done a really good job
of maintaining backwards compatibility.

24
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:30.660
So as we go through this episode,
understand that you can configure

25
00:01:30.660 --> 00:01:33.910
different versions of spanning tree
protocol in different devices and

26
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:35.300
they'll still work.

27
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:36.590
It just won't work well.

28
00:01:36.590 --> 00:01:39.660
If you wanna get the optimum
results out of your network,

29
00:01:39.660 --> 00:01:44.050
you need to run the same type of spanning
tree across all of your equipment.

30
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:45.520
Now if you have all Cisco equipment,

31
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:47.340
you'll be able to choose
from any one of these.

32
00:01:47.340 --> 00:01:51.280
But if you don't have Cisco equipment,
if you've got third-party

33
00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:54.750
vendors kinda in the mix, you might be
limited in the ones you can choose.

34
00:01:54.750 --> 00:01:57.540
Always remember that when you go and
implement this in real life land.

35
00:01:57.540 --> 00:01:59.720
On the exam, it's all Cisco, so
we don't have to worry about it there,

36
00:01:59.720 --> 00:02:02.310
but in real life land,
we do have to worry about it.

37
00:02:02.310 --> 00:02:02.850
All right.

38
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:08.840
Now let's talk about the original
spanning tree protocol, IEE802.1D.

39
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:12.680
We know that basically
it lacks a root bridge.

40
00:02:12.680 --> 00:02:16.060
We know that it then
allows the other bridges,

41
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:20.090
the non-root bridges to do designated and
non-designated ports to block loops.

42
00:02:20.090 --> 00:02:21.560
We know it uses priority.

43
00:02:21.560 --> 00:02:23.950
These are all things we've seen
in the first couple episodes.

44
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:26.220
And it does a pretty good job of it.

45
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:27.630
It blocks loops.

46
00:02:27.630 --> 00:02:29.500
It's really only got a couple of faults.

47
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:32.000
One fault is that it's slow.

48
00:02:32.000 --> 00:02:33.700
We've talked about that a little bit.

49
00:02:33.700 --> 00:02:38.230
And then the other fault it that,
it doesn't necessarily play nice with

50
00:02:38.230 --> 00:02:41.400
super complex networks,
which we'll see here in a minute.

51
00:02:41.400 --> 00:02:44.660
But it does work, and it is on by default.

52
00:02:44.660 --> 00:02:47.820
When I take a look at old
new york core one here,

53
00:02:47.820 --> 00:02:51.780
if I take a look at this switch and
I do a show spanning tree, and I go in and

54
00:02:51.780 --> 00:02:54.730
I look at it, I haven't configured
span tree on this switch.

55
00:02:54.730 --> 00:02:58.580
Actually before I even get into that,
let me just show a running dash config and

56
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:02.810
I'm gonna filter it for
any line including spanning tree.

57
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:07.747
I'm not in config so
I don't need the old do command there.

58
00:03:07.747 --> 00:03:09.320
Let me just just get rid of that.

59
00:03:09.320 --> 00:03:10.680
There we go and I'm looking for

60
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:15.060
any command with spanning tree and there's
a couple of command's here default.

61
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:18.980
These are once that expect to see in
to switch to switch put these in here.

62
00:03:18.980 --> 00:03:24.810
So with my default configuration,
if I do a show spanning-tree,

63
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:30.260
well I'm running right here,
spanning tree enabled protocol ieee.

64
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:33.900
When they say ieee,
what they're talking about is ieee 801.d,

65
00:03:33.900 --> 00:03:35.880
the original spanning tree protocol.

66
00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:41.310
It does have another name,
you'll hear it called CST sometimes,

67
00:03:41.310 --> 00:03:42.900
or just Common Spanning Tree.

68
00:03:44.180 --> 00:03:47.680
Just remember you probably won't see it
that way on the exam, but in real life,

69
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:50.200
if you hear someone talking
about Common Spanning Tree,

70
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:53.569
they're really just talking about
regular Spanning Tree 802.2.1 D,

71
00:03:53.569 --> 00:03:56.330
but because there's more than one type of
spanning tree, it gets a little confusing.

72
00:03:56.330 --> 00:03:58.710
So that's why some people refer
to it as common spanning tree.

73
00:03:58.710 --> 00:04:01.830
But it's not a separate protocol,
it's just this one right here.

74
00:04:01.830 --> 00:04:04.820
>> Now Don, I don't wanna derail
your little loveliness about

75
00:04:04.820 --> 00:04:07.420
spanning tree here, but
take a look at your output, and

76
00:04:07.420 --> 00:04:09.810
there's some interesting
things that I'm seeing there.

77
00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:13.980
And one of them is the fact that there's a
VLAN ID there, it's talking about VLAN 1,

78
00:04:13.980 --> 00:04:17.600
and the other is the fact
that the priority,

79
00:04:17.600 --> 00:04:19.120
we talked about the priority
in the other show.

80
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:23.380
The priority there is, and
I wrote it down, is 32769.

81
00:04:23.380 --> 00:04:30.250
I could've swore you said that
the default priority is 32768.

82
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:33.070
What's with the discrepancy and
why is that VLAN layer?

83
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:36.870
>> Both of those questions are actually
answered by the same problem.

84
00:04:36.870 --> 00:04:42.630
So I did I said that default priority is
32,768 and if you look at my screen, every

85
00:04:42.630 --> 00:04:48.670
time I said that I pointed right here to
this little block where it says 32,768.

86
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:53.330
But if you're astute like Daniel or
bored like Daniel, then you can look and

87
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:55.910
you can see,
I mean it's plastered all over the place.

88
00:04:55.910 --> 00:05:00.704
Bridge ID priority 32769 and then right
up here Root ID, well I'm the root so

89
00:05:00.704 --> 00:05:01.616
that's mine.

90
00:05:01.616 --> 00:05:02.640
But you know if there
was a different root.

91
00:05:02.640 --> 00:05:06.160
32769, so what the heck is going on there?

92
00:05:06.160 --> 00:05:10.950
And why does it say VLAN 1 up here,
what does it care what VLAN I'm on.

93
00:05:10.950 --> 00:05:15.050
Well, the funny story
there is that IEEE 802.1b,

94
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:20.440
spanning tree protocol,
was written before VLANs were popular.

95
00:05:20.440 --> 00:05:25.420
And at the time, VLANs were only
really implemented by Cisco and

96
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:27.100
a few other experimental vendors.

97
00:05:27.100 --> 00:05:29.370
But nobody was really pushing
any commercial products.

98
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:34.860
So the original Spanning Tree Protocol
doesn't understand VLANs.

99
00:05:34.860 --> 00:05:38.020
Now you might not think that matters,
and maybe it doesn't.

100
00:05:38.020 --> 00:05:40.250
If you've only got one VLAN,
it doesn't matter.

101
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:43.570
If you're not using VLANs, technically
your whole network is one big VLAN.

102
00:05:43.570 --> 00:05:48.310
Or if you're taking Cisco's switches out
of the box, how many VLANs do they have?

103
00:05:48.310 --> 00:05:48.850
One.
VLAN 1.

104
00:05:48.850 --> 00:05:50.760
And that's why I see that
note right there, VLAN001.

105
00:05:50.760 --> 00:05:54.550
All my stuff's in VLAN001, and here's
spanning-tree protocol up and running for

106
00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:57.530
that, very exciting.

107
00:05:57.530 --> 00:06:00.810
But let me kind of paint a picture for
you here.

108
00:06:00.810 --> 00:06:02.410
This is my topology.

109
00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:05.860
And I've got a very obvious
loop between CORE1 and CORE2.

110
00:06:06.930 --> 00:06:10.760
Traffic can go across port 23 and
come right back across port 24.

111
00:06:10.760 --> 00:06:13.270
In fact any broadcast I send
would actually do both.

112
00:06:13.270 --> 00:06:14.648
It'd be looping in both directions.

113
00:06:14.648 --> 00:06:17.210
So that's bad.

114
00:06:17.210 --> 00:06:20.570
Spanning tree protocol spots that and
it shuts one of them off.

115
00:06:20.570 --> 00:06:28.120
But what if the first link, what if port
23 was on VLAN1 and port 24 was on VLAN2?

116
00:06:28.120 --> 00:06:32.500
If those two interfaces were on
different VLANS, do I have loop?

117
00:06:33.850 --> 00:06:35.200
No.
They're different VLANS.

118
00:06:35.200 --> 00:06:38.660
Different broadcast domains,
they're separate segments on my network,

119
00:06:38.660 --> 00:06:42.800
it's not a loop anymore cuz I've
created two virtual switches.

120
00:06:42.800 --> 00:06:44.600
But spanning tree doesn't know that.

121
00:06:44.600 --> 00:06:48.380
Spanning tree protocol is called
common spanning tree protocol, because

122
00:06:48.380 --> 00:06:53.680
you have one common instance of spanning
tree that runs for that whole switch.

123
00:06:53.680 --> 00:06:58.650
So this whole switch, regardless of VLAN
is only running one copy of Spanning Tree.

124
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:01.910
And even though one link is on VLAN2 and
the other link is on VLAN1,

125
00:07:01.910 --> 00:07:06.380
it's still gonna see it as a loop and
it's still gonna shut off a port.

126
00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:07.300
And that's not good.

127
00:07:07.300 --> 00:07:09.860
Because that means whichever
VLAN gets shut off,

128
00:07:09.860 --> 00:07:13.190
it all goes back to priority and
port number and all that good stuff.

129
00:07:13.190 --> 00:07:18.400
Whichever one gets shut off, that's the
one that's gonna kill one of those VLANs.

130
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:20.932
If VLAN3 is only on this bottom link and

131
00:07:20.932 --> 00:07:25.530
the bottom link is shut off
VLAN3's not dead, it's isolated.

132
00:07:25.530 --> 00:07:26.570
We don't want that.

133
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:28.680
Tha's a flaw in
the original spanning tree.

134
00:07:29.730 --> 00:07:32.987
Cisco was one of the early
proponents of VLAN,

135
00:07:32.987 --> 00:07:38.416
they really pushed that technology
forward and so early on, and by early on,

136
00:07:38.416 --> 00:07:42.939
we're talking the early 1990s,
kind of, 20 years ago.

137
00:07:42.939 --> 00:07:44.726
>> Back when dinosaurs run the earth.

138
00:07:44.726 --> 00:07:45.303
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

139
00:07:45.303 --> 00:07:48.150
[LAUGH] Back when television
sitcoms were actually funny.

140
00:07:48.150 --> 00:07:53.786
So back then they said, all right, we need
Spanning Tree protocol to run different,

141
00:07:53.786 --> 00:07:57.098
but we don't wanna break
our existing networks.

142
00:07:57.098 --> 00:08:00.460
And so, what Cisco did is,
they created their own protocol.

143
00:08:00.460 --> 00:08:04.721
They create a protocol called PVST+,
right.

144
00:08:04.721 --> 00:08:08.830
Which is Per VLAN Spanning Tree Plus.

145
00:08:10.050 --> 00:08:12.950
It's kind of an extension
of Spanning tree protocol.

146
00:08:12.950 --> 00:08:17.260
And I hate to call PVST+ a protocol,
cuz it really isn't.

147
00:08:17.260 --> 00:08:19.920
All PVST+ is, is really a policy.

148
00:08:19.920 --> 00:08:25.340
And it says hey, instead of running
one copy of Spanning tree for

149
00:08:25.340 --> 00:08:32.530
all of my VLANs, let's let each VLAN
maintain its own copy of Spanning tree.

150
00:08:32.530 --> 00:08:35.990
And by doing that, they're now separate.

151
00:08:35.990 --> 00:08:39.210
And so, it can recognize that
when we look at my topology,

152
00:08:39.210 --> 00:08:42.165
if I've got one link on VLAN 2 and
one link on VLAN 3,

153
00:08:42.165 --> 00:08:46.960
they're separate copies of Spanning
tree protocol, it's not a loop.

00:26:22.827 --> 00:26:27.740

00:26:27.740 --> 00:26:29.060

00:26:29.060 --> 00:26:33.085

00:26:33.085 --> 00:26:36.300

00:26:36.300 --> 00:26:39.290

00:26:39.290 --> 00:26:41.370

00:26:41.370 --> 00:26:45.100
it really just has discarding,

00:26:46.140 --> 00:26:50.540

00:26:50.540 --> 00:26:51.970

00:26:51.970 --> 00:26:55.240

00:26:55.240 --> 00:26:57.890

00:27:05.310 --> 00:27:09.320

00:27:11.840 --> 00:27:15.580
