I need to make sure that's a do.

603
00:32:18.970 --> 00:32:21.860
Oh, it's capital F,
case sensitive searches.

604
00:32:21.860 --> 00:32:22.600
There we go.

605
00:32:22.600 --> 00:32:25.400
All right, so
I can see that it's blocking, all right.

606
00:32:25.400 --> 00:32:31.356
If I get into fa1/0/23, this is
the one that's not blocking, right.

607
00:32:31.356 --> 00:32:35.163
So I guess we could do it this way and
see, whoops [LAUGH],

608
00:32:35.163 --> 00:32:37.550
that's not what I wanted.

609
00:32:37.550 --> 00:32:38.810
If we get in here, and

610
00:32:38.810 --> 00:32:43.470
we get it to show us all of the ports,
I say, let's do it this way.

611
00:32:43.470 --> 00:32:49.730
I want it to show me the root port and
any alternate ports.

612
00:32:49.730 --> 00:32:50.390
There we go.

613
00:32:50.390 --> 00:32:54.210
I can see ports 23 and
24, 23 is forwarding.

614
00:32:54.210 --> 00:32:55.060
24 is blocking.

615
00:32:56.290 --> 00:32:57.760
I'm in 23.
I'm gonna do a shutdown.

616
00:32:58.990 --> 00:33:00.970
So the root port just went down.

617
00:33:00.970 --> 00:33:04.120
And now, I'm gonna watch
what spanning-tree is doing.

618
00:33:04.120 --> 00:33:04.800
Okay?

619
00:33:04.800 --> 00:33:09.317
And what you can see is that 23 is gone,
24 is already forwarding.

620
00:33:09.317 --> 00:33:12.590
Didn't go to listening,
didn't go to learning, right?

621
00:33:12.590 --> 00:33:15.801
We don't have listening so
it just skipped the learning phase and

622
00:33:15.801 --> 00:33:17.312
went immediately to forwarding.

623
00:33:17.312 --> 00:33:21.981
It knew this was a good port and
it just held it down and said I'm.

624
00:33:21.981 --> 00:33:24.770
That's the big advantage of
rapid spanning tree protocol.

625
00:33:24.770 --> 00:33:26.280
And so we normally want that, right?

626
00:33:26.280 --> 00:33:28.460
That's a good thing,
if your switches support it.

627
00:33:28.460 --> 00:33:32.550
But if some switches do and some switches
don't, you can end up with some trouble.

628
00:33:32.550 --> 00:33:34.730
And so you might not be able
to use it in your environment.

629
00:33:34.730 --> 00:33:37.400
But given a choice,
I usually run rapid spanning tree,

630
00:33:37.400 --> 00:33:38.650
this is the one that you want.

631
00:33:38.650 --> 00:33:42.750
And on a Cisco switch it's
per-VLAN rapid spanning-tree that

632
00:33:42.750 --> 00:33:45.630
you're actually running, so PVRST-plus.

633
00:33:45.630 --> 00:33:50.090
>> Yeah, I wouldn't want to have rapid
spanning-tree running on just one VLAN.

634
00:33:50.090 --> 00:33:54.395
I've probably got multiple running, so
that PVST is nice in those Cisco switches.

635
00:33:54.395 --> 00:33:54.895
All right, Don.

636
00:33:54.895 --> 00:33:57.555
Now I know we still have more to cover.

637
00:33:57.555 --> 00:34:02.335
We got some enhancements to Spanning Tree
that we need to get through but again,

638
00:34:02.335 --> 00:34:05.420
we have eliminated all of our time for
this episode.

639
00:34:05.420 --> 00:34:07.720
So we're gonna have to make a part four.

640
00:34:07.720 --> 00:34:10.940
That's right,
we're getting into the bad sequels area.

641
00:34:10.940 --> 00:34:11.910
It's like Jaws part 4.

642
00:34:11.910 --> 00:34:14.290
I'm going to break the rule and
kill that timer.

643
00:34:14.290 --> 00:34:16.430
So I got two things I want to add.

644
00:34:16.430 --> 00:34:17.790
We had a good question in the chat room.

645
00:34:17.790 --> 00:34:20.947
Doug was asked about, what is the cost?

646
00:34:20.947 --> 00:34:23.570
200,000, right?

647
00:34:23.570 --> 00:34:27.140
I mentioned earlier that cost
is fairly small number, right?

648
00:34:27.140 --> 00:34:32.439
The cost is actually 0, which you'll
never see, so 1 through 65,555, right?

649
00:34:32.439 --> 00:34:34.310
That's what the cost is.

650
00:34:34.310 --> 00:34:39.570
But there is a special new cost mode
you can use called the long mode.

651
00:34:39.570 --> 00:34:43.130
If you're in the long mode it
bumps it up to a 32 bit number but

652
00:34:43.130 --> 00:34:44.700
it doesn't truly use it.

653
00:34:44.700 --> 00:34:48.030
I believe it has
the maximum of 200 million.

654
00:34:48.030 --> 00:34:51.140
With a 32 bit number you should be
able to go to like 4.3 billion.

655
00:34:51.140 --> 00:34:53.910
But you can actually have a cost
that goes as high as $200 million.

656
00:34:53.910 --> 00:34:55.570
If you switch to the long mode,

657
00:34:55.570 --> 00:34:57.050
what you're doing is you're
basically saying, all right.

658
00:34:57.050 --> 00:34:59.950
From now on, I'm gonna control the cost
myself and I'm gonna set it to whatever I

659
00:34:59.950 --> 00:35:03.920
want now I've got this huge
number range to be able to use.

660
00:35:03.920 --> 00:35:05.700
All the Cisco net switches support it.

661
00:35:06.850 --> 00:35:08.023
Some of the catalysts support.

662
00:35:08.023 --> 00:35:11.420
The 4500s, the 6500s, right?

663
00:35:11.420 --> 00:35:17.650
Those guys do, on a 3750 like mine,
you know if I look at my hardware here.

664
00:35:17.650 --> 00:35:20.490
I don't know if I support it,
let's find out if we do.

665
00:35:20.490 --> 00:35:21.920
It's kinda easy to find out.

666
00:35:21.920 --> 00:35:28.525
If you go into config, and
you do a spanning-tree cost,

667
00:35:28.525 --> 00:35:32.939
oops, all right I may not support it.

668
00:35:32.939 --> 00:35:39.830
It's, oh wait it's not cost,
it's path cost.

669
00:35:39.830 --> 00:35:43.050
If you have the spanning-tree
path cost command then that

670
00:35:43.050 --> 00:35:44.840
means you support that new format.

671
00:35:44.840 --> 00:35:50.210
And so you could come in here and you
could say, spanning-tree pathcost method.

672
00:35:50.210 --> 00:35:52.700
And then there's long and short, right?

673
00:35:52.700 --> 00:35:54.550
Short's the old method, 16-bit number,

674
00:35:54.550 --> 00:35:57.870
it will be 1 to 65,535,
long is the new method.

675
00:35:57.870 --> 00:36:00.490
It can go as high as 200 million, right?

676
00:36:00.490 --> 00:36:02.860
Way bigger cost number to be able to use.

677
00:36:02.860 --> 00:36:06.720
And so, if I flip that,
now I'm running in long mode.

678
00:36:06.720 --> 00:36:08.620
And the switch should support it.

679
00:36:08.620 --> 00:36:12.130
So, if I do a show spanning-tree.

680
00:36:12.130 --> 00:36:14.760
Now my costs are gonna look
a bit different aren't they.

681
00:36:14.760 --> 00:36:18.980
There's that cost, 200,000 creeping in.

682
00:36:18.980 --> 00:36:21.790
What used to be a 19 is now a 200,000.

683
00:36:21.790 --> 00:36:26.450
And I can go in and start to manipulate
the cost of my interfaces to change that,

684
00:36:26.450 --> 00:36:32.150
so I could jump into Fa1/0/24,
there we go.

685
00:36:32.150 --> 00:36:38.000
And I could say spanning-tree and you'll
see right here we can set that cost.

686
00:36:38.000 --> 00:36:41.522
And the cost would
normally be one to 65,535.

687
00:36:41.522 --> 00:36:44.353
But here you can see I can go all
the way up to, is it two million,

688
00:36:44.353 --> 00:36:45.647
two hundred million right.

689
00:36:45.647 --> 00:36:50.604
Let's see whatever are thousands
are hundred thousands,

690
00:36:50.604 --> 00:36:54.766
two hundred thousand I guess
this is the highest so

691
00:36:54.766 --> 00:36:57.960
we can set it to one hundred thousand.

692
00:36:57.960 --> 00:37:00.230
>> That's two hundred million.

693
00:37:00.230 --> 00:37:01.140
>> Is it two hundred million,
am I screwing it up?

694
00:37:01.140 --> 00:37:03.420
So it's three right two hundred million.

695
00:37:03.420 --> 00:37:05.280
Big number, I was right the first time.

696
00:37:05.280 --> 00:37:06.670
So anyway,
now we can adjust that cost, and

697
00:37:06.670 --> 00:37:08.610
you can set it to any arbitrary numbers.

698
00:37:08.610 --> 00:37:11.660
And that helps to solve the number we
talked about earlier when you have

699
00:37:11.660 --> 00:37:12.830
either channels and stuff.

700
00:37:12.830 --> 00:37:17.055
And you end up with these numbers that are
really weird, here we can override that.

701
00:37:17.055 --> 00:37:19.605
And now when we take a look
at our spanning tree,

702
00:37:19.605 --> 00:37:22.095
you'll see that custom
cost stuck in there and

703
00:37:22.095 --> 00:37:25.535
see how that port flipped to blocking
cuz I gave it a high cost, right.

704
00:37:25.535 --> 00:37:28.125
Versus before, I think it was forwarding
before I messed with it, yeah.

705
00:37:28.125 --> 00:37:31.453
That was my root port until I
messed with it and now, you know,

706
00:37:31.453 --> 00:37:34.731
it was a root port with
a forwarding cost of 200,000.

707
00:37:34.731 --> 00:37:38.865
Now I made it a, what did I gave it a
million, ten million, something like that.

708
00:37:38.865 --> 00:37:39.875
So, it's pretty high.

709
00:37:39.875 --> 00:37:41.710
So that's where you see those longer ones.

710
00:37:41.710 --> 00:37:45.160
With normal Spanning Tree and your
normal cost you don't see that, right?

711
00:37:45.160 --> 00:37:46.430
But if you're in that long form.

712
00:37:46.430 --> 00:37:49.280
And just to refresh there,
that command that I used

713
00:37:49.280 --> 00:37:54.420
was spanning-tree pathcost method long.

714
00:37:54.420 --> 00:37:56.981
That's what got that in place and
got that working.

715
00:37:56.981 --> 00:37:59.059
So, the other thing I wanna mention here,

716
00:37:59.059 --> 00:38:01.497
just cuz obviously I don't
care about the timer.

717
00:38:01.497 --> 00:38:04.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Is I just want to do a real

718
00:38:04.170 --> 00:38:07.430
quick review of the different protocols
we talked about because there

719
00:38:07.430 --> 00:38:08.170
were a bunch of them right?

720
00:38:08.170 --> 00:38:11.180
We started with regular
spanning tree protocol,

721
00:38:11.180 --> 00:38:14.216
which is also called common
spanning tree protocol.

722
00:38:14.216 --> 00:38:18.680
Then we talked about per
VLAN Spanning Tree Plus, PVST plus,

723
00:38:18.680 --> 00:38:20.140
which is Cisco proprietary.

724
00:38:20.140 --> 00:38:22.220
Right?
No I Triple E number there.

725
00:38:22.220 --> 00:38:27.924
Then we talked about rapid spanning
tree protocol, which is a 802.1W and

726
00:38:27.924 --> 00:38:35.300
Cisco's Per VLAN rapid spanning tree plus,
or P VRST+, Cisco proprietary.

727
00:38:35.300 --> 00:38:42.564
And we also talk about MST, multiple
spanning tree protocol, which was 802.1S.

728
00:38:42.564 --> 00:38:43.689
Yes, 802.1S.

729
00:38:43.689 --> 00:38:44.280
>> Yes.

730
00:38:44.280 --> 00:38:45.820
>> And that was the last one.

731
00:38:45.820 --> 00:38:48.730
So those are the five different
spanning tree protocols

732
00:38:48.730 --> 00:38:50.910
we talked about in this episode.

733
00:38:50.910 --> 00:38:52.940
And they're all on the table,

734
00:38:52.940 --> 00:38:55.870
you have to decide which one is
the best for your environment.

735
00:38:55.870 --> 00:38:58.210
>> All right, well Don,
we have definitely,

736
00:38:58.210 --> 00:39:01.450
this is the show to end all shows,
even though we have part four coming.

737
00:39:01.450 --> 00:39:04.040
You would think that that would be
the end of spanning tree, it's not.

738
00:39:04.040 --> 00:39:06.110
We have plenty more to cover.

739
00:39:06.110 --> 00:39:08.760
But for this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

740
00:39:08.760 --> 00:39:12.540
Hopefully we will see you in part four,
The Reckoning of Spanning Tree.

741
00:39:12.540 --> 00:39:17.190
You guys have a good day signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

742
00:39:17.190 --> 00:39:17.850
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel go over some of the enhancements to the Spanning Tree Protocol. They walk you through technologies like PortFast, BPDUguard and BPDUfilter, LoopGuard, and RootGuard. All of these technologies can help you optimize and/or secure your switched network running STP.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.949 --> 00:00:16.680
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:21.240
I'm your host Daniel Lowery, here with
me yet again today is Mr. Don Pezet.

4
00:00:21.240 --> 00:00:22.150
How's it going, Don?

5
00:00:22.150 --> 00:00:23.340
>> It is going great, Daniel.

6
00:00:23.340 --> 00:00:24.520
I'm glad to be back on the show for

7
00:00:24.520 --> 00:00:28.200
our, I promise, our final episode
on spanning tree protocol.

8
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:32.540
We've got, just got a mixed bag of
advance features that Cisco gives us with

9
00:00:32.540 --> 00:00:34.730
spanning that we can
modify the way it behaves.

10
00:00:34.730 --> 00:00:36.850
And so we're going to be tackling those,
here in this episode.

11
00:00:36.850 --> 00:00:39.650
Now just quick kind of caveat
right at the beginning.

12
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:42.840
The majority of these are Cisco
proprietary, they're things that Cisco did

13
00:00:42.840 --> 00:00:45.700
on their equipment to try and
make Spanning Tree more reliable or

14
00:00:45.700 --> 00:00:48.520
behave a little bit more efficiently
in certain environments.

15
00:00:48.520 --> 00:00:49.650
You don't have to use any of these.

16
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:53.140
All of the features we talk about in
this episode are completely optional.

17
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:56.300
And most of them, I think actually
all of them, are off by default.

18
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:58.390
So we actually have to go and
turn them on if we want them.

19
00:00:58.390 --> 00:01:02.400
But your third-party equipment might have
something similar, but will typically not

20
00:01:02.400 --> 00:01:05.440
use the same name as there's no iTripoli
standards to throw out in this episode.

21
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:08.030
It's just kind of a mixed bag of stuff.

22
00:01:08.030 --> 00:01:12.030
>> Yeah, Don, we did talk a lot about
a lot of good stuff when it comes to

23
00:01:12.030 --> 00:01:13.430
Spanning Tree protocol stuff.

24
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:17.890
We even talked about a rapid Spanning Tree
and a per-VLAN rapid spanning tree and

25
00:01:17.890 --> 00:01:19.245
how we can speed things up.

26
00:01:19.245 --> 00:01:21.260
But, But you know what,
I'm the kind of guy, I like speed.

27
00:01:21.260 --> 00:01:25.140
I like demon speed,
I like greasy, fast speed.

28
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:27.135
Is there any way we can speed this up?

29
00:01:27.135 --> 00:01:28.700
[LAUGH]
>> All right, so speed.

30
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:32.430
It's best measured from
an end users perspective.

31
00:01:32.430 --> 00:01:34.620
When we talked about speed in the earlier
episode we talked about rapid

32
00:01:34.620 --> 00:01:39.020
Spanning Tree and I showed how quickly
it could fail over to another port.

33
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:42.500
It had that alternate root port that it
could flip over to it at a moments notice.

34
00:01:42.500 --> 00:01:44.830
That's great on you uplink's,
on your trunks.

35
00:01:44.830 --> 00:01:47.590
Right, or they don't have to be a trunk
just whatever your link is between

36
00:01:47.590 --> 00:01:49.220
the switches.

37
00:01:49.220 --> 00:01:50.550
That's nice and fast.

38
00:01:50.550 --> 00:01:53.130
But that doesn't help an end user.

39
00:01:53.130 --> 00:01:56.780
When you plug in a device,
when a port comes up the first time,

40
00:01:56.780 --> 00:02:00.640
even rapid Spanning Tree still
does it's learning phase.

41
00:02:00.640 --> 00:02:02.940
So you have listening and
learning under regular spanning.

42
00:02:02.940 --> 00:02:05.930
You have learning under rapid,
but it's still there.

43
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:07.430
The reason that alternate fails over so

44
00:02:07.430 --> 00:02:09.400
fast is that the ports
technically are already up.

45
00:02:09.400 --> 00:02:12.090
It's being blocked, but it's already up
it's already happy we already know it's

46
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:13.960
good, we could flip over to it right away.

47
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:18.170
But when a user plugs in their laptop or
turns on their computer,

48
00:02:18.170 --> 00:02:22.570
there's gonna be a 30 second or
a 15 second window where they can't talk.

49
00:02:22.570 --> 00:02:24.700
And they see that as slow and
they get frustrated.

50
00:02:24.700 --> 00:02:27.870
If it's 30 seconds, then maybe they, maybe
they dont' get a dhcp request done in

51
00:02:27.870 --> 00:02:30.950
time, they don't get an address, now they
can't communicate and they get frustrated.

52
00:02:30.950 --> 00:02:36.200
So one great way to improve speed is
not to mess with Spannng Tree itself,

53
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:37.540
not to mess with our trunks.

54
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:40.250
But to mess with our client access ports.

55
00:02:40.250 --> 00:02:43.920
When I plug in a laptop can I
create a loop with my laptop?

56
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:44.870
No, it's a single net.

57
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:48.250
I mean you can do crazy things,
but functioning normally,

58
00:02:48.250 --> 00:02:50.830
a laptop can't create a loo,
neither can a desktop.

59
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:53.030
You plug it in and that's it, right.

60
00:02:53.030 --> 00:02:56.160
So do we really need to do all the checks?

61
00:02:56.160 --> 00:03:00.340
The watching for BPDU's and
loop detection and all that.

62
00:03:00.340 --> 00:03:05.060
Couldn't we give it the benefit of the
doubt and say alright it's an access port.

63
00:03:05.060 --> 00:03:07.100
You're plugging in the work
stations whatever.

64
00:03:07.100 --> 00:03:08.490
Let's just bring the port up.

65
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:11.980
And we'll keep an ear out, we'll
listen to see if there is a loop, but

66
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:14.080
we're going to give you the benefit of
the doubt and just come up right away.

67
00:03:14.080 --> 00:03:19.500
All right, that function in a Cisco
switch is called port fast.

68
00:03:19.500 --> 00:03:24.090
Port fast should only be used on access
ports not on trunk ports, right.

69
00:03:24.090 --> 00:03:26.470
Because a trunk,
you very well could have a loop on that or

70
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:28.860
an uplink between switches,
you could have a loop there.

71
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:32.390
On a port that's connected to an end-user
station, you're not normally gonna have

72
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:35.580
a loop, so we can tell it to
bring it up first by default.

73
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:37.420
There's two ways to do it.

74
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:41.640
Method one is to turn it on globally,
you can turn it on for the whole switch.

75
00:03:41.640 --> 00:03:44.750
All right, but then you need to go and
turn it off for

76
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:46.120
the individual ports that are up links.

77
00:03:47.160 --> 00:03:51.740
Option two is to just turn it
on on the ports themselves, and

78
00:03:51.740 --> 00:03:54.270
then you just don't turn it on on
your uplinks and that's that, right.

79
00:03:54.270 --> 00:03:57.340
So it really boils down to what
you're going to need to do more of.

80
00:03:57.340 --> 00:04:01.140
If you've got more access
ports than uplinks

81
00:04:01.140 --> 00:04:03.430
then you usually wanna

00:15:16.830 --> 00:15:20.570

00:15:20.570 --> 00:15:26.290

00:15:26.290 --> 00:15:27.540

00:15:27.540 --> 00:15:29.972

314
00:15:29.972 --> 00:15:30.707

00:15:30.707 --> 00:15:32.193

00:15:32.193 --> 00:15:35.610

00:15:35.610 --> 00:15:39.545

00:15:39.545 --> 00:15:43.576

00:15:43.576 --> 00:15:47.828

00:15:47.828 --> 00:15:52.232

00:15:52.232 --> 00:15:54.512

00:15:54.512 --> 00:15:58.567

00:15:58.567 --> 00:16:02.804

00:16:02.804 --> 00:16:05.544

00:16:05.544 --> 00:16:10.370

00:16:10.370 --> 00:16:11.830

00:16:11.830 --> 00:16:13.317
And so loopguard is doing a double check.

00:16:13.317 --> 00:16:15.734

00:16:19.555 --> 00:16:23.358

get our optimized networks.

535
00:26:12.180 --> 00:26:13.330
That's the way we like them.

536
00:26:13.330 --> 00:26:14.980
Now, is there anything else
that we need to cover, or

537
00:26:14.980 --> 00:26:17.760
have we finally reached
the end of spanning tree?

538
00:26:17.760 --> 00:26:18.910
>> I do wanna mention one more,

539
00:26:18.910 --> 00:26:22.780
this was one that was asked about
during the break, which is UplinkFast.

540
00:26:22.780 --> 00:26:25.450
It's not on the exam objectives,
and I'm not a big fan of it,

541
00:26:25.450 --> 00:26:26.619
I never use it myself.

542
00:26:27.720 --> 00:26:30.480
PortFast, when you plug in a new PC,

543
00:26:30.480 --> 00:26:35.660
it gives that port the benefit of
the doubt and it brings it up, right?

544
00:26:35.660 --> 00:26:38.720
UplinkFast does the same thing for
your uplinks.

545
00:26:38.720 --> 00:26:40.650
So if you've got trunks,
it's basically saying,

546
00:26:40.650 --> 00:26:43.090
if you've got a trunk
that's an important line.

547
00:26:43.090 --> 00:26:45.030
We need it to come up fast, all right?

548
00:26:45.030 --> 00:26:48.300
Now, that sounds like a good thing
at first, and you can turn it on,

549
00:26:48.300 --> 00:26:50.690
it's just kind of an addition to PortFast,

550
00:26:50.690 --> 00:26:54.410
but, there's a reason why we
don't do PortFast on trunks.

551
00:26:54.410 --> 00:26:56.460
If you're gonna have a loop,
where's your loop gonna be?

552
00:26:56.460 --> 00:26:58.010
It's gonna be on the trunks, right?

553
00:26:58.010 --> 00:27:00.050
Your uplinks between the switch,
that's where your loops come from,

554
00:27:00.050 --> 00:27:02.090
that's where your loop
protection needs to be.

555
00:27:02.090 --> 00:27:03.910
If you give it the benefit of
the doubt and bring it up,

556
00:27:03.910 --> 00:27:06.400
you're gonna have a loop for
a few moments.

557
00:27:06.400 --> 00:27:10.410
And that loop could be 15 seconds,
it could be 30 seconds.

558
00:27:10.410 --> 00:27:13.510
But if it's a high traffic network,

559
00:27:13.510 --> 00:27:16.220
your network can crawl to a halt
while that loop is there.

560
00:27:16.220 --> 00:27:17.960
And granted,
it resolves itself in 30 seconds,

561
00:27:17.960 --> 00:27:21.340
but if you've got critical software,
you don't want 30 seconds of downtime.

562
00:27:21.340 --> 00:27:25.060
You would have been better off
to have not done UplinkFast,

563
00:27:25.060 --> 00:27:30.385
to have held that link down, because if
we've got other paths to follow, then

564
00:27:30.385 --> 00:27:33.770
we'll just keep you using those until this
one is clear, then we bring it up, right?

565
00:27:33.770 --> 00:27:35.790
So when you've got a triangle like mine,

566
00:27:35.790 --> 00:27:38.528
you've got another way to go while
waiting on this first one to come up.

567
00:27:38.528 --> 00:27:43.414
So UplinkFast is really only good
when you have a single way in and

568
00:27:43.414 --> 00:27:45.100
a single way out, all right?

569
00:27:45.100 --> 00:27:48.410
But I always look at it this way,
I think about what's happening here.

570
00:27:48.410 --> 00:27:51.377
If you got a single way in and
a single way out, and you're worried about

571
00:27:51.377 --> 00:27:55.030
UplinkFast, how fast the link comes up,
that means your link was down, right?

572
00:27:55.030 --> 00:27:57.080
So you've already got a downtime.

573
00:27:57.080 --> 00:28:01.028
And so really all you're doing is shaving
off a few seconds on that downtime.

574
00:28:01.028 --> 00:28:03.170
And the trade-off is not worth it,
to me and

575
00:28:03.170 --> 00:28:04.480
to a lot of network
professionals out there.

576
00:28:04.480 --> 00:28:08.320
So, most people don't use UplinkFast
in production, but it does exist,

577
00:28:08.320 --> 00:28:12.674
it is there, you can use it, if you want
those uplinks to come up super mega fast,

578
00:28:12.674 --> 00:28:13.550
so you can turn that on.

579
00:28:13.550 --> 00:28:16.620
>> Well, very cool Don, thanks for
that info there on the UplinkFast, and

580
00:28:16.620 --> 00:28:18.400
everything you've done today is great.

581
00:28:18.400 --> 00:28:19.700
Awesome demonstrations.

582
00:28:19.700 --> 00:28:22.560
Hopefully everybody out there has
followed along, enjoyed the show.

583
00:28:22.560 --> 00:28:26.330
I know I certainly have, but
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

584
00:28:26.330 --> 00:28:27.220
Thanks for watching.

585
00:28:27.220 --> 00:28:30.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

586
00:28:30.400 --> 00:28:31.070
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

587
00:28:31.070 --> 00:28:31.970
>> And we'll see you next time.

588
00:28:31.970 --> 00:28:32.876
>> In part five.

589
00:28:32.876 --> 00:28:34.932
[LAUGH] thousand.

590
00:28:34.932 --> 00:28:39.440
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate how to monitor a switched network using Switch Port ANalyzer (SPAN). Here they detail reasons why you may wish to monitor network traffic and then walk you through configuring SPAN on a Cisco switch for those very reasons.
episodes.title: SPAN and RSPAN
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.730 --> 00:00:16.500
All right, greetings everyone and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:17.663
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.663 --> 00:00:21.195
Here with me in the studio today
is none other than Don Pezet.

5
00:00:21.195 --> 00:00:21.987
How's it going today, Don?

6
00:00:21.987 --> 00:00:23.310
>> It is going great, Daniel.

7
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:27.220
Excited to be back on this show, and
jumping into a pretty neat topic.

8
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:29.760
It's going to be one of those things
that your end users will never see,

9
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:32.670
but you as an administrator
make a lot of use of, and

10
00:00:32.670 --> 00:00:37.030
what I'm talking about is Span and R-Span,
some great port monitoring technologies.

11
00:00:37.030 --> 00:00:38.270
So it'll be a pretty good time.

12
00:00:38.270 --> 00:00:40.240
>> Yeah, I'm looking forward to this one.

13
00:00:40.240 --> 00:00:44.392
We were talking about this a little while
ago and I was like, Span and R-Span, not

14
00:00:44.392 --> 00:00:48.555
really ringing any bells on there Don, and
he was like oh yeah, you know what it is.

15
00:00:48.555 --> 00:00:50.225
It's basically port right?

16
00:00:50.225 --> 00:00:53.465
>> That's exactly it, and I run into it
all the time where I tell people about

17
00:00:53.465 --> 00:00:56.635
the span which is switch,
port, analyzer, right?

18
00:00:56.635 --> 00:00:58.890
So, on a Cisco system you got Span.

19
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:02.400
And people say I've never
heard of that and they have.

20
00:01:02.400 --> 00:01:04.130
It's just cuz the only
one they call is a Span.

21
00:01:04.130 --> 00:01:08.020
Everybody else calls it port mirroring and
it's where we take the traffic on

22
00:01:08.020 --> 00:01:11.510
one switchboard and
we copy it to another port.

23
00:01:11.510 --> 00:01:16.080
So the switch has this hardware logic
where as traffic comes in it looks at

24
00:01:16.080 --> 00:01:20.640
the frame, every frame is a source MAC
address and a destination MAC address.

25
00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:22.750
And it looks at the destination
MAC address, and

26
00:01:22.750 --> 00:01:27.550
it says let me look at my MAC address
table and oh I see that MAC on port seven.

27
00:01:27.550 --> 00:01:30.650
So it sends the frames to port seven,
and off it goes right?

28
00:01:30.650 --> 00:01:32.320
That's what a switch does.

29
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:37.190
When you use Span,
you say anytime I send traffic to

30
00:01:37.190 --> 00:01:40.940
Port 7 also send a copy to Port 9.

31
00:01:40.940 --> 00:01:41.540
Right?

32
00:01:41.540 --> 00:01:43.740
We just send another copy somewhere else.

33
00:01:43.740 --> 00:01:45.320
Pretty straight forward technology.

34
00:01:45.320 --> 00:01:48.350
Now you might ask yourself,
why do I use that?

35
00:01:48.350 --> 00:01:51.490
And I can give you couple of great
examples of how you'd use it.

36
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:53.410
And the two most common
that I can think of,

37
00:01:53.410 --> 00:01:57.230
well let's start with the one that I
use the most, network troubleshooting.

38
00:01:57.230 --> 00:02:01.270
If you're troubling shooting your
network you want to have a good view

39
00:02:01.270 --> 00:02:05.020
of what's going on in there, what kind
of traffic is moving across the network?

40
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:06.140
And in an earlier episode,

41
00:02:06.140 --> 00:02:09.560
actually it might even been part of the
route show where we talked about net flow,

42
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:13.440
net flow is the system that works on
the switches and routers themselves.

43
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:15.770
And it monitors the communications
that are happening.

44
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:17.700
And it can report that
to a reporting server.

45
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:20.370
You can have third party monitoring
software that'll give you pie charts

46
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:20.970
and graphs.

47
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:24.768
And so, if your network is slow,
you can look at your bandwidth.

48
00:02:24.768 --> 00:02:28.431
And you can say, all right,
I've gotta 20MB Internet connection.

49
00:02:28.431 --> 00:02:30.630
And I'm using 19MB of it.

50
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:32.700
That's why my network's slow, right?

51
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:35.520
But what is using the 19MB?

52
00:02:35.520 --> 00:02:36.480
What protocols?

53
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:37.420
What workstations?

54
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:38.910
Who is it that's doing that?

55
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:40.710
The switch in the router can't tell you.

56
00:02:40.710 --> 00:02:42.020
Netflow can interpret it.

57
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:43.760
And it will show you, right?

58
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:46.480
But netflow is just looking
at the conversation.

59
00:02:46.480 --> 00:02:49.020
It doesn't actually carry any payload, so

60
00:02:49.020 --> 00:02:52.370
it's not recording the actual
packets that pass through.

61
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:55.420
So if I want a full vision of that data,

62
00:02:55.420 --> 00:02:59.120
including the payload,
that's where Span comes in.

63
00:02:59.120 --> 00:03:01.040
So if I get a call and they're saying,

64
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:05.120
look, this network
connection is really slow.

65
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:08.170
I might mirror the port for
the Internet router so

66
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:11.540
that way any traffic that's going to
the Internet also gets sent to my laptop.

67
00:03:12.570 --> 00:03:17.270
And then I can run a sniffer and protocol
analyzer and look at that data and

68
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:17.938
interpret it.

69
00:03:17.938 --> 00:03:21.190
All right now if you're not familiar with
those, you probably are if you're watching

70
00:03:21.190 --> 00:03:25.260
this show, but for those of you who aren't
when it comes to network troubleshooting,

71
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:28.840
there's two pieces of software that're
super handy to have on your laptop for

72
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:29.890
troubleshooting.

73
00:03:29.890 --> 00:03:32.390
One of them is what's
called a packet sniffer.

74
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:37.450
When you plug your laptop into a network,
your laptop has a MAC address.

75
00:03:37.450 --> 00:03:40.140
And when it received
communications on the network,

76
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:43.370
it looks at the destination MAC
address to see if it matches yours.

77
00:03:43.370 --> 00:03:45.790
And if it matches you receive the frame,
and if it doesn't match,

78
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:48.470
your network card will actually
discard the traffic, throws it away.

79
00:03:48.470 --> 00:03:54.020
All right, if you want a packet sniffer,
it can connect your network and

80
00:03:54.020 --> 00:03:56.530
move your network adapter into
what's called promiscuous mode,

81
00:03:56.530 --> 00:03:58.190
it's one of those funnier terms.

82
00:03:58.190 --> 00:04:00.825
So, we move it into promiscuous mode and
it basically tells your network.

83
00:04:00.825 --> 00:04:04.845
Hey don't through away traffic that's
destined for a different MAC address.

84
00:04:04.845 --> 00:04:07.175
Go ahead and
receive it because I want to record it.

85
00:04:07.175 --> 00:04:08.655
And then the packet snipper can record it.

86
00:04:08.655 --> 00:04:09.845
It will record that data.

87
00:04:09.845 --> 00:04:13.035
That's what a packet snipper does,
it just records.

88
00:04:13.035 --> 00:04:16.172
Now this might be third party
software you've installed like on,

89
00:04:16.172 --> 00:04:19.902
on Windows there's WIN P Cap, right,
that's the packet capture for Windows.

90
00:04:19.902 --> 00:04:24.692
In Linux, Unix, Mac, we have TCP dump,
that can just dump that data right out and

91
00:04:24.692 --> 00:04:26.406
that's actually built into the OS.

92
00:04:26.406 --> 00:04:29.016
So, the thing though is
it gathers that data,

93
00:04:29.016 --> 00:04:32.136
and then it's just raw data in a file.

94
00:04:32.136 --> 00:04:34.496
So then we combine that with
a second piece of software called

95
00:04:34.496 --> 00:04:35.936
a protocol analyzer.

96
00:04:35.936 --> 00:04:39.860
And a protocol analyzer can
take that dump of data and

97
00:04:39.860 --> 00:04:41.690
translate into something
that is more human readable,

98
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:44.480
where we can see the layer,
two layer, three layer, four headers.

99
00:04:44.480 --> 00:04:46.670
You can see the actual payload.

100
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:48.870
If it's encrypted, it doesn't help you,
but if it's unencrypted,

101
00:04:48.870 --> 00:04:52.030
you can actually see what was going on
in the network communication, right?

102
00:04:52.030 --> 00:04:53.750
And that's really handy for

103
00:04:53.750 --> 00:04:57.614
somebody who's a network admin who's
trying to troubleshoot a problem.

104
00:04:57.614 --> 00:04:59.370
Now, I used to do this in the past.

105
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:02.290
And Daniel, I worked with Daniel.

106
00:05:02.290 --> 00:05:03.450
Jeez, I don't know.

107
00:05:03.450 --> 00:05:04.428
Eight years ago,
ten [CROSSTALK] years ago?

108
00:05:04.428 --> 00:05:05.267
>> Something like that.

109
00:05:05.267 --> 00:05:08.224
>> And we were working at this
training school and every now and

110
00:05:08.224 --> 00:05:11.030
then a machine would get
infected with a virus.

111
00:05:11.030 --> 00:05:13.240
Or somebody would be running BitTorrent.

112
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:15.420
BitTorrent weren't as big,
it was more like Napster back then.

113
00:05:15.420 --> 00:05:18.420
And they'd be running something and
consuming our bandwidth and so.

114
00:05:18.420 --> 00:05:19.730
We'd get a report of that.

115
00:05:19.730 --> 00:05:21.690
People'd think, boy the network is slow.

116
00:05:21.690 --> 00:05:24.150
And, so, I'd breakout this hub.

117
00:05:24.150 --> 00:05:25.340
It had this little.

118
00:05:25.340 --> 00:05:25.950
You remember, Dan?

119
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:27.900
>> Oh yeah.
>> It was a little five port, tan,

120
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:29.280
piece of junk hub.

121
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:33.570
And I would unplug our
router from the switch.

122
00:05:33.570 --> 00:05:38.090
I'd plug the router into the hub and then
plug the hub into the switch, all right?

123
00:05:38.090 --> 00:05:42.258
And then I could plug my laptop into that
hub and intercept the communications.

124
00:05:42.258 --> 00:05:45.187
Now why did I do that?

125
00:05:45.187 --> 00:05:45.863
>> Cuz you're ghetto fabulous.

126
00:05:45.863 --> 00:05:46.583
>> I know.

127
00:05:46.583 --> 00:05:47.745
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

128
00:05:47.745 --> 00:05:50.870
it was cuz at the time we
didn't have a great switch.

129
00:05:50.870 --> 00:05:53.870
But the other thing was,
if you think about a switch network,

130
00:05:55.230 --> 00:05:58.480
when data is going from let's
say Daniel's laptop and

131
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:03.210
it's going to the router, well, his frames
that he builds up are gonna have a source

132
00:06:03.210 --> 00:06:07.250
MAC address of his laptop and
a destination MAC address of the router.

133
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:10.200
So when the switch receives that traffic,

134
00:06:10.200 --> 00:06:12.920
it's gonna forward it right
to the port with the router.

135
00:06:12.920 --> 00:06:16.350
If my laptop is plugged in
to say the very next port.

136
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:19.210
Maybe Daniel's plugged into port one,
I'm plugged into port two, and

137
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:21.110
the router's plugged into port three.

138
00:06:21.110 --> 00:06:25.540
Well, when Daniel communicates to the
router it will skip my port entirely and

139
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:26.980
go right to port three.

140
00:06:26.980 --> 00:06:28.980
I don't even see the communication.

141
00:06:28.980 --> 00:06:30.960
If I were to just plug my
laptop into the switch and

142
00:06:30.960 --> 00:06:34.140
start monitoring,
all I'm gonna see are broadcasts.

143
00:06:34.140 --> 00:06:36.010
Cuz those will send out to every part.

144
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:38.420
And unicasts destined for me.

145
00:06:38.420 --> 00:06:39.660
That's all I'm gonna see.

146
00:06:39.660 --> 00:06:41.618
I'm not gonna see Daniel's communications.

147
00:06:41.618 --> 00:06:43.061
So it's not a useful way to monitor.

148
00:06:43.061 --> 00:06:46.195
So that's why I had this
crappy hub that I'd plug in.

149
00:06:46.195 --> 00:06:49.385
And the worst part about it
was I had to unplug the router

150
00:06:49.385 --> 00:06:50.905
to plug this thing in to get it in line.

151
00:06:50.905 --> 00:06:53.425
I didn't wanna leave the hub in place all
the time cuz it was a cheap piece of junk.

152
00:06:53.425 --> 00:06:54.520
I knew it was gonna fail.

153
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:57.740
So, I had to create downtime to do this.

154
00:06:57.740 --> 00:07:01.950
Wouldn't it be nice if we could
monitor the network without downtime?

155
00:07:01.950 --> 00:07:03.210
And that's what Span lets us do.

156
00:07:03.210 --> 00:07:06.700
Span would let me say I'm gonna take
the port that Daniel is plugged into or

157
00:07:06.700 --> 00:07:08.980
I'm gonna take the port that
the router's plugged into, and

158
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:12.150
just send a copy of their traffic
over to my port, and I can see it.

159
00:07:12.150 --> 00:07:14.470
And, I didn't have to create any
downtime and I can turn it on and

160
00:07:14.470 --> 00:07:15.900
off whenever I want.

161
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:17.100
And, that's that, right?

162
00:07:17.100 --> 00:07:20.030
So, it's a great way to monitor and
troubleshoot the network.

163
00:07:20.030 --> 00:07:21.720
And that's what I'm gonna show
you guys in this episode today.

164
00:07:22.740 --> 00:07:24.860
Another use for Span, or

165
00:07:24.860 --> 00:07:29.410
the switchboard analyzer, is if you
have an intrusion detection system.

166
00:07:29.410 --> 00:07:30.920
IDS, right?

167
00:07:30.920 --> 00:07:33.530
Now, you'll hear these terms, IPS and IDS.

168
00:07:33.530 --> 00:07:37.000
Intrusion prevention system and
intrusion detection system.

169
00:07:37.000 --> 00:07:40.166
And you hear a lot of people use them
interchangeably because the hardware

170
00:07:40.166 --> 00:07:40.735
is the same.

171
00:07:40.735 --> 00:07:44.275
If you got to Cisco and you say, I want
an IPS or if you go to Cisco and say,

172
00:07:44.275 --> 00:07:47.120

00:07:47.120 --> 00:07:51.453

00:07:51.453 --> 00:07:54.178
a An ASA with the IPS module in it.

00:07:54.178 --> 00:07:57.440

00:07:57.440 --> 00:08:02.120

177
00:08:02.120 --> 00:08:06.838

is a piece of hardware that

00:08:06.838 --> 00:08:09.387

179
00:08:09.387 --> 00:08:13.574

00:08:13.574 --> 00:08:17.366

00:08:17.366 --> 00:08:19.928

will flow through the IPS.

182
00:08:19.928 --> 00:08:23.659
It's in line, and
it'll scan that traffic for attacks, and

183
00:08:23.659 --> 00:08:28.640
if it finds an attack, it stops it, and
it can stop it because it's in line.

184
00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:31.420
I don't need port mirroring or
anything for that, it's in line.

185
00:08:31.420 --> 00:08:32.850
These are physical connections, and

186
00:08:32.850 --> 00:08:37.320
it filters, but
it hurts performance a little bit.

187
00:08:37.320 --> 00:08:41.160
If you're doing things like voice over IP,
it's scanning those packets,

188
00:08:41.160 --> 00:08:42.870
it's looking for attacks, and

189
00:08:42.870 --> 00:08:47.000
that creates a little bit of lag while
that happens, and we might not want that.

190
00:08:47.000 --> 00:08:50.340
So the other option is to do an IDS,
an Intrusion Detection System.

191
00:08:51.440 --> 00:08:56.280

it doesn't do anything about it.

192
00:08:56.280 --> 00:09:00.090
If it spots an attack,
it just alerts us, and that's it, but

193
00:09:00.090 --> 00:09:01.810
it doesn't hurt performance.

194
00:09:01.810 --> 00:09:05.380
And the reason is, an IDS is not in line,
an IDS sits off to the side.

195
00:09:05.380 --> 00:09:10.580
And instead of the actual traffic going
through it, we just take the traffic and

196
00:09:10.580 --> 00:09:11.390

197
00:09:11.390 --> 00:09:13.920
We send a copy of the traffic to the IDS.

198
00:09:13.920 --> 00:09:16.590
So it can scan it and
it doesn't slow our traffic down at all.

199
00:09:16.590 --> 00:09:19.810
Your voice traffic, goes at nice

00:09:19.810 --> 00:09:21.360

00:09:21.360 --> 00:09:24.330

00:09:24.330 --> 00:09:28.950
cuz if it spots an attack, it stop

00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:32.690

00:09:32.690 --> 00:09:35.580

00:09:35.580 --> 00:09:39.200

00:30:24.640 --> 00:30:26.090
>> That's not what we got into this for.

626
00:30:26.090 --> 00:30:31.510
>> So there's a different form of span
that we can use, called Rspan, that

627
00:30:31.510 --> 00:30:34.600
let's you monitor ports on a different
switch, and so it's pretty awesome.

628
00:30:34.600 --> 00:30:35.350
We definitely want to see it.

629
00:30:35.350 --> 00:30:38.220
It's a little bit more complex to get
set up, which is why I definitely can't

630
00:30:38.220 --> 00:30:40.231
cram it in the one minute I see
we have left on the clock here.

631
00:30:40.231 --> 00:30:41.072
>> [LAUGH] You can do it.

632
00:30:41.072 --> 00:30:44.624
>> So let's go on to a part two and
we'll get a chance to see RSPAN, and

633
00:30:44.624 --> 00:30:48.250
how we can get that setup and
use it to monitor on multiple switches.

634
00:30:48.250 --> 00:30:49.070
Which is pretty awesome.

635
00:30:49.070 --> 00:30:49.740
>> Sounds good.

636
00:30:49.740 --> 00:30:50.380
All right everyone.

637
00:30:50.380 --> 00:30:52.340
We're going to go ahead and
close this episode out.

638
00:30:52.340 --> 00:30:54.470
Hopefully, we'll see you guys in part two.

639
00:30:54.470 --> 00:30:57.850
For signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

640
00:30:57.850 --> 00:30:58.520
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

641
00:30:58.520 --> 00:30:59.773
>> And we'll see you next time.

642
00:30:59.773 --> 00:31:06.980
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate how to monitor a switched network using Remote Switch Port Analyzer (RSPAN). Building upon SPAN, RSPAN enables you to monitor switches that you are not directly connected to. This episode covers how to configure RSPAN for the times when being physically connected to a switch that needs monitoring isn't feasible.
episodes.title: SPAN and RSPAN Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.280
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.280 --> 00:00:10.504
All right, greetings everyone and

3
00:00:10.504 --> 00:00:16.570
welcome to another great
episode of ITPro.tv.

4
00:00:16.570 --> 00:00:20.540
I'm your host Daniel Lowery,
joining me again today is Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:20.540 --> 00:00:21.380
How's it going today Don?

6
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:22.360
>> It is going great, Daniel.

7
00:00:22.360 --> 00:00:26.000
I'm glad to be back for
part two of our SPAN and RSPAN episode.

8
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:28.990
And if you didn't watch the first one
you really should because we tackled

9
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:31.680
the switch port analyzer and
what it does, how it works,

10
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:35.700
how we capture traffic on one port and
send a copy of it to another port.

11
00:00:35.700 --> 00:00:38.280
But we stopped short of something
that's kinda important.

12
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:40.800
Everything we showed you in
the first episode was true, right,

13
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:41.835
we're not doing a retraction.

14
00:00:41.835 --> 00:00:43.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> At least not yet.

15
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:47.180
It all worked great on a single switch.

16
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:50.130
But when you go into a multi-switch
environment we start to have some little

17
00:00:50.130 --> 00:00:51.200
problems.

18
00:00:51.200 --> 00:00:53.550
So let's kinda recap where
we were in the last episode.

19
00:00:53.550 --> 00:00:54.840
I whipped up a quick diagram.

20
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:56.310
Let me show you guys this.

21
00:00:56.310 --> 00:01:02.450
And basically, in the last episode I
had my laptop plugged into the switch.

22
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:06.700
And I was monitoring this
trunk port right here,

23
00:01:06.700 --> 00:01:09.100
that's where I was running span,
on that guy right there.

24
00:01:09.100 --> 00:01:14.540
And so when I took this switch and
I tel-netted into the other switch,

25
00:01:14.540 --> 00:01:18.890
so I did a telnet session across those,
I was passing through that port.

26
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:20.270
And I was capturing that traffic.

27
00:01:20.270 --> 00:01:22.870
It was being sent to my laptop and
we saw it right on screen.

28
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:23.560
That's what was happening.

29
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:30.100
That works great and if I monitor that
port and even if Daniel from his laptop

30
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:33.810
were to Telnet into that switch, I'd see
it because he's passing through that port.

31
00:01:35.460 --> 00:01:37.840
But not all traffic
passes through the port.

32
00:01:37.840 --> 00:01:42.070
So for example, if Daniel were to Telnet
from his laptop into this switch,

33
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:44.190
am I gonna see that?

34
00:01:44.190 --> 00:01:46.930
No, it never makes it to this trunk.

35
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:51.330
It sees his frames coming in with
a destination MAC address of this switch.

36
00:01:51.330 --> 00:01:54.410
It delivers it right to that
switches management port and

37
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:56.345
it never crosses the trunk.

38
00:01:56.345 --> 00:02:00.695
I might see his initial ARP broadcast as
he tries to find the Mac of the switch.

39
00:02:00.695 --> 00:02:02.375
Imagine his system would already know.

40
00:02:02.375 --> 00:02:04.625
But if it doesn't,
I'll see the ARP broadcast.

41
00:02:04.625 --> 00:02:09.065
But the actual Telnet session will
just go direct and I'll never see it.

42
00:02:09.065 --> 00:02:11.415
So I've got two choices, right?

43
00:02:11.415 --> 00:02:15.129
Choice one involves physical labor so
we'll throw that one out.

44
00:02:15.129 --> 00:02:19.570
>> [LAUGH] And then choice one, I unplug
my laptop and I plug it into this switch.

45
00:02:19.570 --> 00:02:22.510
And I configure SPAN over here
to be able to mirror him and

46
00:02:22.510 --> 00:02:23.610
I'm plugged in on the same switch.

47
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:24.170
That'll work.

48
00:02:24.170 --> 00:02:25.720
That's option one.

49
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:29.150
Option two is, we can use RSPAN.

50
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:33.980
And what RSPAN does is let me
monitor a port on one switch and

51
00:02:33.980 --> 00:02:37.780
send its traffic to
a port on another switch.

52
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:38.470
Okay.

53
00:02:38.470 --> 00:02:44.100
Now to do that is a lot more complex than
just grabbing traffic of a one switch and

54
00:02:44.100 --> 00:02:47.050
there's a lot of concerns we have to have.

55
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:49.920
There needs to be some
planning when you do RSpan.

56
00:02:49.920 --> 00:02:50.560
All right.

57
00:02:50.560 --> 00:02:54.560
The way RSPAN works is
normally with regular span,

58
00:02:54.560 --> 00:02:58.990
you grab traffic from one port, right, so
your source is one physical interface, and

59
00:02:58.990 --> 00:03:01.570
your destination is another
physical interface.

60
00:03:01.570 --> 00:03:03.950
And remember the warning I gave
you guys in the last episode,

61
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:08.695
was make sure that the destination
interface has equal the bandwidth or

62
00:03:08.695 --> 00:03:11.435
more than the source interface.

63
00:03:11.435 --> 00:03:14.185
You never want the source interface
to have more traffic than what

64
00:03:14.185 --> 00:03:17.235
the destination interface can handle,
cuz your ports will go the same,

65
00:03:17.235 --> 00:03:18.199
it'll turn them off.

66
00:03:18.199 --> 00:03:20.145
Right, so
that's definitely not what you want.

67
00:03:20.145 --> 00:03:23.569
Well, when we do our RSPAN,
you have a source and your source

68
00:03:23.569 --> 00:03:28.500
is a physical interface, so the traffic
on one of your physical interfaces.

69
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:32.560
And instead of sending the copy
to another physical interface,

70
00:03:32.560 --> 00:03:36.040
you send a copy of the data to a VLAN,
all right?

71
00:03:36.040 --> 00:03:38.690
What's called a remote SPAN VLAN.

72
00:03:38.690 --> 00:03:41.610
So you send that traffic to a VLAN, and

73
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:45.840
the VLAN can then cross
across many switches.

74
00:03:45.840 --> 00:03:47.890
Cross switch to switch to switch.

75
00:03:47.890 --> 00:03:52.450
And at another switch somewhere
else I configure a SPAN session

76
00:03:52.450 --> 00:03:57.015
where the source is not a physical
interface, but is instead the VLAN, so

77
00:03:57.015 --> 00:03:59.835
a source of whatever this magic VLAN is.

78
00:03:59.835 --> 00:04:02.965
And the destination would be
the physical interface on my own laptop.

79
00:04:04.145 --> 00:04:06.565
So there's a VLAN in the mix.

80
00:04:06.565 --> 00:04:10.455
And the warning here, the reason we need
so much planning, is that if we're gonna

81
00:04:10.455 --> 00:04:13.805
be sending VLANs across we usually don't
have dedicated interfaces for that, do we?

82
00:04:13.805 --> 00:04:15.185
We have trunks.

83
00:04:15.185 --> 00:04:17.425
And so now you've gotta
worry about trunk bandwidth.

84
00:04:17.425 --> 00:04:21.990
If we go back to my diagram, Daniel has
a 100 meg connection between himself and

85
00:04:21.990 --> 00:04:26.380
the switch and I have a 100 meg
connection between myself and the switch.

86
00:04:26.380 --> 00:04:31.870
But this trunk, it might be 100 megabit or
it might be a gigabit, it can be bigger.

87
00:04:31.870 --> 00:04:32.610
Right?

88
00:04:32.610 --> 00:04:35.080
And there's more than
one VLAN running on it.

89
00:04:35.080 --> 00:04:38.250
And so, I could end up with
some real problems there.

90
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:42.690
So, I need to do one of two things either
one, make sure that the bandwidth is equal

91
00:04:42.690 --> 00:04:45.735
that my monitoring station has at
least the same bandwidth as the trunk.

92
00:04:45.735 --> 00:04:51.650
Or two, do some kinda quality of
service rate limiting like ingress and

93
00:04:51.650 --> 00:04:56.620
egress filtering to hold that particular
VLAN down to below 100 megabit and

94
00:04:56.620 --> 00:05:01.460
to only be spamming just that
one VLAN using a VLAN filter.

95
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:03.390
So you gotta really plan for that.

96
00:05:03.390 --> 00:05:06.820
You gotta think about making sure your
infrastructure is stable enough for it.

97
00:05:06.820 --> 00:05:12.110
But assuming that it is, we can get
this set up and it worked great, okay.

98
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:18.010
So first, let's test what we've got
with just the regular network in place.

99
00:05:18.010 --> 00:05:24.660
So I'm gonna move that off and right now
I'm already monitoring here on switch one.

100
00:05:24.660 --> 00:05:31.323
If I take a look at switch one and
a I do a show monitor session.

101
00:05:31.323 --> 00:05:37.260
[LAUGH] If I look at my monitor sessions,
there we go,

102
00:05:37.260 --> 00:05:40.820
I can see that my laptop
is plugged into port 1.

103
00:05:40.820 --> 00:05:44.460
And I'm monitoring port 24 which is
the trunk between the two switches, so

104
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:46.480
I'm monitoring that and it's up and

105
00:05:46.480 --> 00:05:50.620
it's running right now so I am doing
exactly what I said here in the diagram.

106
00:05:50.620 --> 00:05:53.960
I am monitoring that port, all right.

107
00:05:53.960 --> 00:05:56.960
So I'm gonna start a capture and

108
00:05:56.960 --> 00:06:01.300
let me just get over to WireShark and
I'm gonna start an all new capture.

109
00:06:02.360 --> 00:06:03.790
And I'm gonna start
capturing that traffic and

110
00:06:03.790 --> 00:06:05.510
I'm gonna filter it down to just Telnet.

111
00:06:05.510 --> 00:06:07.000
So I'm just looking at the Telnet traffic.

112
00:06:07.000 --> 00:06:11.390
All right, now Daniel,
can you Telnet into my switch?

113
00:06:11.390 --> 00:06:12.537
So Telnet into 10.1.230.244.

114
00:06:12.537 --> 00:06:13.110
>> .244 no problem.

115
00:06:13.110 --> 00:06:14.440
Let's see here, Telnet.

116
00:06:14.440 --> 00:06:18.740
>> So let me get back to my diagram.

117
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:21.025
So he's tel-netting from his laptop.

118
00:06:21.025 --> 00:06:22.480
Into my switch over here.

119
00:06:22.480 --> 00:06:25.560
So he's gonna have to cross to
this band port to get there.

120
00:06:25.560 --> 00:06:28.290
And sure enough,
there's that Telnet traffic passing by.

121
00:06:28.290 --> 00:06:29.630
And he's logging in right now.

122
00:06:29.630 --> 00:06:31.905
So I see that traffic.

123
00:06:31.905 --> 00:06:35.970
Cuz he's passing through that port
right there that I'm monitoring.

124
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:37.136
And that's exactly what I want.

125
00:06:37.136 --> 00:06:38.668
All right?

126
00:06:38.668 --> 00:06:42.290
But I'm gonna stop this and
did you end your?

127
00:06:42.290 --> 00:06:45.050
>> Yes, I am done [LAUGH]
>> So let me start a new one.

128
00:06:45.050 --> 00:06:46.150
So we'll continue without saving.

129
00:06:46.150 --> 00:06:48.540
And here is all new filter, okay?

130
00:06:48.540 --> 00:06:52.762
And this time Daniel Telnet
into the 10.1.230.245.

131
00:06:52.762 --> 00:06:53.630
>> 45.

132
00:06:53.630 --> 00:06:56.060
Now 245 is his switch right here.

133
00:06:56.060 --> 00:06:57.770
He's tel-netting into that one.

134
00:06:57.770 --> 00:07:03.190
That traffic's not gonna hit the trunk and
so I'm not gonna see that.

135
00:07:03.190 --> 00:07:04.000
And so you're logged in?

136
00:07:04.000 --> 00:07:05.070
>> I'm logged in.

137
00:07:05.070 --> 00:07:06.400
>> And I don't see the traffic.

138
00:07:06.400 --> 00:07:06.990
Okay.

139
00:07:06.990 --> 00:07:10.320
So here we can see the situation.

140
00:07:10.320 --> 00:07:15.550
And I wanna get that data so I'm gonna go
and configure RSPAN to do it, all right.

141
00:07:15.550 --> 00:07:18.090
So let me stop this capture so its not
just running in the background filling up

142
00:07:18.090 --> 00:07:23.310
my hard drive and I will jump over to my
switches and we'll get this set up, okay.

143
00:07:23.310 --> 00:07:27.330
Now I'm gonna start on his switch so
over here on his switch.

144
00:07:27.330 --> 00:07:29.040
He's on switch two.

145
00:07:29.040 --> 00:07:31.990
And if I do a show monitor

146
00:07:31.990 --> 00:07:36.340
session actually here we'll just
take a look at the running config.

147
00:07:36.340 --> 00:07:39.780
And I don't have any spam ports
set up on his switch yet.

148
00:07:39.780 --> 00:07:42.310
So there's no monitor commands in there.

149
00:07:42.310 --> 00:07:44.260
And what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna set up a monitor.

150
00:07:44.260 --> 00:07:48.830
And I can monitor this different ways but
let's say his laptop is the problem.

151
00:07:48.830 --> 00:07:51.567
So I want to monitor his
laptop specifically.

152
00:07:51.567 --> 00:07:56.682
Well, he is plugged into, I believe he
is plugged into port one if I recall

153
00:07:56.682 --> 00:08:01.467
correctly, and so he's plugged into
port one, so I should be able to

154
00:08:01.467 --> 00:08:06.606
catch him right there on port one,
and intercept those communications.

155
00:08:06.606 --> 00:08:09.755
Now, if I want to be certain that he
is in port one, I could say, Daniel,

156
00:08:09.755 --> 00:08:11.320
do you know what your IP address is?

157
00:08:11.320 --> 00:08:13.071
>> No, but I can find out for
you in one second.

158
00:08:13.071 --> 00:08:17.014
>> So, we can quickly check by
looking at our arp table and

159
00:08:17.014 --> 00:08:20.369
our mac table and
figure out what port he is on.

160
00:08:20.369 --> 00:08:24.320
>> .15, 10.1.230.15.

161
00:08:24.320 --> 00:08:29.190
>> Okay, so if he's on 10.1.230.15,
right and I can ping him.

162
00:08:29.190 --> 00:08:34.410
I can do a show arp, and so there he
is and I can find his MAC address.

163
00:08:34.410 --> 00:08:36.290
There's his MAC address.

164
00:08:36.290 --> 00:08:41.559
And once I have his MAC address,
I can do a show mac address and

165
00:08:41.559 --> 00:08:45.320
I can look for his mac address and
there he is on port one.

166
00:08:45.320 --> 00:08:48.900
So if I didn't know what port he was on,
if this was a big 6500 series switch and

167
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:52.890
cables all over the place, we can
always hunt and find them pretty quick.

168
00:08:52.890 --> 00:08:56.320
And so, what I'm gonna do is,
that's gonna be my source.

169
00:08:56.320 --> 00:09:00.990
I wanna get the traffic on port one and
then I wanna send it to a VLAN.

170
00:09:00.990 --> 00:09:03.910
Now, for the VLAN I've got just one VLAN.

171
00:09:03.910 --> 00:09:07.150
Right now I've got VLAN 1 and that's it.

172
00:09:07.150 --> 00:09:09.220
I need to create, oh,
actually I've got VLAN 2 and 3.

173
00:09:09.220 --> 00:09:10.690
I got a couple of VLANs.

174
00:09:10.690 --> 00:09:16.610
But for our span we need to create
a special VLAN that is only used for

175
00:09:16.610 --> 00:09:18.030
RSPAN and nothing else.

176
00:09:18.030 --> 00:09:21.530
So you don't wanna reuse some other VLAN
that you might have workstations on.

177
00:09:21.530 --> 00:09:23.701
So I'm gonna create an all new VLAN.

178
00:09:23.701 --> 00:09:27.934
And I'll just give it a number like 999.

179
00:09:27.934 --> 00:09:30.550
Pick a number that you're
not using in your network.

180
00:09:30.550 --> 00:09:31.940
And so I'll give it a name.

181
00:09:31.940 --> 00:09:33.670
I'll call this one RSPAN.

182
00:09:33.670 --> 00:09:36.520
You can call it whatever you want,
all right?

183
00:09:36.520 --> 00:09:37.710
That part is not important.

184
00:09:37.710 --> 00:09:45.180
The part that is important is that we need
to come in here and say remote-span, okay?

185
00:09:45.180 --> 00:09:47.110
That command right there, remote-span,

186
00:09:47.110 --> 00:09:50.600
if we look at our help That
configures it as a Remote SPAN VLAN.

187
00:09:50.600 --> 00:09:52.151
You can't just use any old VLAN.

188
00:09:52.151 --> 00:09:54.411
That's why I'm not reusing
one of my other ones.

189
00:09:54.411 --> 00:09:57.390
The VLAN has to be flagged for RSPAN.

190
00:09:59.270 --> 00:10:05.480
Once that's done,
now if I do show VLAN and

191
00:10:05.480 --> 00:10:10.080
I take a look at my VLANs, I've got
this 99 VLAN that I've named RSPAN, and

192
00:10:10.080 --> 00:10:12.980
it shows up here in my VLAN output.

193
00:10:12.980 --> 00:10:13.670
Right?

194
00:10:13.670 --> 00:10:16.760
But when I take a look at
things like spanning tree.

195
00:10:18.740 --> 00:10:22.160
When I go and look at its config here's
the VLAN one and its information.

196
00:10:22.160 --> 00:10:24.948
And then the VLAN 2 and VLAN 3.

197
00:10:24.948 --> 00:10:29.052
And there's V VLAN 999,
it's actually up and

198
00:10:29.052 --> 00:10:32.680
working as a true VLAN, but RSPAN enabled.

199
00:10:34.380 --> 00:10:39.490
Now what I can do is I can say monitor
session and whatever number I want to use.

200
00:10:39.490 --> 00:10:43.030
I used 1 in the other episode,
so I'll use 2 this time.

201
00:10:43.030 --> 00:10:50.820
So I'll say monitor session 2,
source interface fa0/1, right?

202
00:10:50.820 --> 00:10:52.780
Then I want traffic going
in both directions, so

203
00:10:52.780 --> 00:10:54.560
I'm going to grab Daniel's traffic.

204
00:10:54.560 --> 00:10:57.090
He's on port one and
I want to capture all of that.

205
00:10:57.090 --> 00:11:01.700
So now, if I want to actually see
Daniel's traffic, I need to set up RSPAN.

206
00:11:01.700 --> 00:11:04.600
I need to be able to monitor that
connection on the other side.

207

00:22:15.000 --> 00:22:16.620
you can use that to hop
between the switches.

441
00:22:16.620 --> 00:22:19.770
Now, that works if you have two or
three switches but

442
00:22:19.770 --> 00:22:23.710
if you have 100 switches, it's a lot of
dedicated links that you're setting up and

443
00:22:23.710 --> 00:22:25.860
RSPAM becomes a lot less practical.

444
00:22:25.860 --> 00:22:29.850
And that's why I was hesitating to say
that is, it certainly can be done.

445
00:22:29.850 --> 00:22:36.250
You also could set up dedicated access
ports to try and move the traffic, too.

446
00:22:36.250 --> 00:22:40.180
That's a little bit flaky though, cuz your
switches start to get involved in layer 2

447
00:22:40.180 --> 00:22:43.280
headers and so
the packets aren't in their original form.

448
00:22:43.280 --> 00:22:45.020
That's why using the VLAN is so important.

449
00:22:45.020 --> 00:22:46.570
That's why you have to flag it that way.

450
00:22:46.570 --> 00:22:49.710
When you say this is a remote span VLAN,
it's saying,

451
00:22:49.710 --> 00:22:53.855
when I move a frame onto it,
do not mess with the layer two header.

452
00:22:53.855 --> 00:22:56.100
Normall, your VLANs will
mess up a layer two header.

453
00:22:56.100 --> 00:22:57.420
This stops that.

454
00:22:57.420 --> 00:22:58.390
So, that's why we have that.

455
00:22:58.390 --> 00:23:01.520
And you can filter the VLAN, that'll
work out, you can certainly do that and

456
00:23:01.520 --> 00:23:02.710
make the dedicated interfaces.

457
00:23:03.930 --> 00:23:08.087
If you want something that gives you even
more control, it's not on the exam, but

458
00:23:08.087 --> 00:23:11.110
there's something called a layer 2 tunnel,
L2 tunnel.

459
00:23:12.530 --> 00:23:14.225
Only the higher end Cisco
switches support it.

460
00:23:14.225 --> 00:23:19.820
I'm pretty sure mine don't, but you could
go in, and you could set up an L2 tunnel,

461
00:23:19.820 --> 00:23:24.408
and you can actually tunnel traffic
from one interface to another, or

462
00:23:24.408 --> 00:23:27.675
really across your network
with this tunnel, and

463
00:23:27.675 --> 00:23:31.500
then you can set up that as
the destination for the span.

464
00:23:31.500 --> 00:23:33.630
So a couple of different techniques there.

465
00:23:33.630 --> 00:23:37.280
But the VLAN filtering, that's probably
the easiest, just go on the trunk and

466
00:23:37.280 --> 00:23:39.530
do that, all right.

467
00:23:39.530 --> 00:23:42.970
Rick asked a question about,
did I add VLAN 999 to the trunk or

468
00:23:42.970 --> 00:23:44.490
did that happen automatically?

469
00:23:44.490 --> 00:23:45.980
It happened automatically.

470
00:23:45.980 --> 00:23:48.370
Just because I haven't done any filtering,
right.

471
00:23:48.370 --> 00:23:50.520
So let me bring that back up real quick.

472
00:23:50.520 --> 00:23:55.150
So I still have that VLAN
999 defined right here.

473
00:23:55.150 --> 00:23:59.650
So by default on

474
00:23:59.650 --> 00:24:03.840
CISCO equipment when you create VLAN
it's automatically added to the trunks.

475
00:24:03.840 --> 00:24:06.690
So when you do a show interface trunk,

476
00:24:08.390 --> 00:24:11.290
as you create VLANs they're
automatically added to the trunk.

477
00:24:11.290 --> 00:24:12.640
Now they might not go active.

478
00:24:12.640 --> 00:24:15.980
You have to have at least one port
in the VLAN for it to go active, but

479
00:24:15.980 --> 00:24:19.810
assuming that you do,
then you'll see them active right there.

480
00:24:19.810 --> 00:24:22.910
And so I've got that port 24 as my
trunk it's carrying one through 3999.

481
00:24:22.910 --> 00:24:25.580
That was automatic, right?

482
00:24:25.580 --> 00:24:28.020
If we have filters in place,
it's not automatic and

483
00:24:28.020 --> 00:24:29.540
that's where we have to go and
customize it.

484
00:24:29.540 --> 00:24:30.510
So for

485
00:24:30.510 --> 00:24:34.970
example, doubling back to your earlier
question about having a dedicated one.

486
00:24:34.970 --> 00:24:39.298
I could create another trunk so maybe
like fa0/23 and we could set that up for

487
00:24:39.298 --> 00:24:46.360
that one, we could set it to via trunk.

488
00:24:46.360 --> 00:24:51.410
And we could set up no negotiation,
so it's always a trunk, right?

489
00:24:51.410 --> 00:24:56.627
And then you can say switchboard and
trunk and set the allowed VLANs and

490
00:24:56.627 --> 00:25:00.390
you could specify exactly
what VLAN you want.

491
00:25:00.390 --> 00:25:06.180
So maybe on this one,
I only want VLAN 999,

492
00:25:06.180 --> 00:25:11.524
but then on fa0/24, I might say switch

493
00:25:11.524 --> 00:25:16.580
port trunk allowed VLAN except 999.

494
00:25:16.580 --> 00:25:17.550
Okay?

495
00:25:17.550 --> 00:25:19.670
So now on port 23.

496
00:25:19.670 --> 00:25:24.240
I only have VLAN 999 and
on port 24 I have everything except 999.

497
00:25:24.240 --> 00:25:28.480
So now, I've kinda split those out and
broken them apart.

498
00:25:28.480 --> 00:25:31.220
Now, that interface for
me doesn't have anything plugged into it.

499
00:25:31.220 --> 00:25:35.340
So I don't think that'll actually show for
me in a show interface trunk now.

500
00:25:35.340 --> 00:25:37.800
But it will be in the config.

501
00:25:37.800 --> 00:25:42.440
Let me just jump to that and of course
it's gonna match my security token.

502
00:25:42.440 --> 00:25:43.120
There.

503
00:25:43.120 --> 00:25:45.110
All right.
So now you can see you're on port 23.

504
00:25:45.110 --> 00:25:47.034
See how it's doing just
allowed VLAN 999 and

505
00:25:47.034 --> 00:25:50.320
then here it's doing allowed one
through 998 and then 1000 to 4094.

506
00:25:50.320 --> 00:25:56.878
So that kinda achieves that goal of
a dedicated connection for that VLAN.

507
00:25:56.878 --> 00:25:57.456
>> Great question.

508
00:25:57.456 --> 00:25:58.290
>> Yeah.

509
00:25:58.290 --> 00:26:01.030
All right, well,
that in a nutshell is our spam.

510
00:26:01.030 --> 00:26:04.240
I know I spent a lot longer on that than
I intended to, but it is good stuff.

511
00:26:04.240 --> 00:26:05.860
We saw span in the first episode.

512
00:26:05.860 --> 00:26:07.020
RSPAN in this one.

513
00:26:07.020 --> 00:26:08.060
They're both on the exam.

514
00:26:08.060 --> 00:26:09.930
They're both useful in real life land.

515
00:26:09.930 --> 00:26:11.155
It's just good stuff.

516
00:26:11.155 --> 00:26:14.740
>> RSPAN's great for those lazy admins
out there that don't wanna get up

517
00:26:14.740 --> 00:26:16.340
from their desk, right [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, or

518
00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:18.590
if you just have a really big,
complex network.

519
00:26:18.590 --> 00:26:20.310
Sometimes physical access to the switch

520
00:26:20.310 --> 00:26:21.530
isn't-
>> Practical.

521
00:26:21.530 --> 00:26:22.340
>> Yeah.

522
00:26:22.340 --> 00:26:24.270
>> And in this case I didn't
have to move any cables.

523
00:26:24.270 --> 00:26:27.300
I can just remote into another switch,
capture that traffic,

524
00:26:27.300 --> 00:26:29.500
send it to VLAN 999 and
I start getting it.

525
00:26:29.500 --> 00:26:30.080
>> Awesome.

526
00:26:30.080 --> 00:26:32.820
Well Don is there anything else we need to
talk about this episode before we bring it

527
00:26:32.820 --> 00:26:33.610
to a close?

528
00:26:33.610 --> 00:26:35.460
>> I think that's it for SPAN and RSPAN.

529
00:26:35.460 --> 00:26:38.950
We do have more topics to cover but
we'll save those for another day.

530
00:26:38.950 --> 00:26:40.750
>> All right.
Well excellent demonstrations.

531
00:26:40.750 --> 00:26:41.670
Thanks for that.

532
00:26:41.670 --> 00:26:44.600
Thank for watching today, we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for IT Pro TV.

533
00:26:44.600 --> 00:26:46.550
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

534
00:26:46.550 --> 00:26:47.260
>> And, I'm Don Pezet.

535
00:26:47.260 --> 00:26:49.970
>> And, we'll see you next time.

536
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:54.990
[MUSIC]
