episodes.title: Cisco StackWise
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.171 --> 00:00:10.644
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.644 --> 00:00:13.440
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.440 --> 00:00:17.340
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
we're taking a look at CCNP switch today.

4
00:00:17.340 --> 00:00:20.040
To help us out,
here with us, Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:20.960
How's it going, Don?

6
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:22.020
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

7
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:25.690
Glad to be back on the show and ready to
jump back into the world of CCNP switch.

8
00:00:25.690 --> 00:00:29.250
Today we're gonna be taking a look at
technology that not a lot of people get to

9
00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:33.220
work with, but it's kind of a cool one,
and it's called Cisco StackWise.

10
00:00:33.220 --> 00:00:36.370
Now, I know, actually Ronnie,
you remember we

11
00:00:36.370 --> 00:00:40.660
worked together years ago in a building
where we had a bunch of Cisco switches and

12
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:43.615
we used a technology
called Cisco GigaStack.

13
00:00:43.615 --> 00:00:45.175
>> Right.
>> Do you remember the GigaStack cables?

14
00:00:45.175 --> 00:00:46.335
>> I do remember them.

15
00:00:46.335 --> 00:00:48.130
>> They had a bit of a nickname.

16
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:50.735
>> [LAUGH]
>> They were called GigaStack,

17
00:00:50.735 --> 00:00:52.355
a lot of people called them GigaCrap.

18
00:00:52.355 --> 00:00:52.950
>> Right.

19
00:00:52.950 --> 00:00:55.200
>> [LAUGH] The problem was
they weren't terribly great.

20
00:00:55.200 --> 00:00:58.700
What they allowed you to do was
to take more than one switch and

21
00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:01.960
to run this special cable
in-between each switch

22
00:01:01.960 --> 00:01:04.780
to create kind of a strong
backbone in-between them.

23
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:08.530
And it was a way to get high port
densities in a Cisco environment.

24
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:10.300
Well, the technology wasn't very good and

25
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:13.810
there is a better technology
in Cisco Stackwise.

26
00:01:13.810 --> 00:01:16.280
Now, before we dive into
that let's talk about kinda

27
00:01:16.280 --> 00:01:18.245
the problem that we're
trying to solve here.

28
00:01:18.245 --> 00:01:23.000
Ronnie, if I need to get a 24-port switch,
does Cisco have one for me?

29
00:01:23.000 --> 00:01:26.410
>> Cisco absolutely has a 24-port
switch for you somewhere, and

30
00:01:26.410 --> 00:01:29.700
they'll probably more than likely want
to sell you multiple of them, yeah.

31
00:01:29.700 --> 00:01:31.860
>> Yeah, and if I need 48 ports?

32
00:01:31.860 --> 00:01:34.880
>> They'd love it, they'd love for
you to actually buy a 48 port one, too.

33
00:01:34.880 --> 00:01:37.113
>> What if I need 72 ports?

34
00:01:37.113 --> 00:01:37.941
>> 72 ports?

35
00:01:37.941 --> 00:01:39.044
Yes.
>> [LAUGH]

36
00:01:39.044 --> 00:01:41.450
>> No, no, there's not, there may be,

37
00:01:41.450 --> 00:01:42.005
yeah.

38
00:01:42.005 --> 00:01:43.615
[LAUGH]
>> It starts to get a little iffy, right?

39
00:01:43.615 --> 00:01:46.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what happens is there's something

40
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:48.295
magical that happens at 48 ports.

41
00:01:48.295 --> 00:01:49.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you need up to 48 ports,

42
00:01:49.540 --> 00:01:51.160
you can buy one Cisco switch.

43
00:01:51.160 --> 00:01:53.060
You get it, You got 48 ports,
you're in business.

44
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:55.125
If you need a little bit more, right?

45
00:01:55.125 --> 00:01:58.100
If you needs 72 ports, if you need 100,
200, 300 ports, right?

46
00:01:58.100 --> 00:02:02.535
Well, then you need to move
from what are called fixed

47
00:02:02.535 --> 00:02:07.540
configuration switches to modular
switches, right, chassis-based switches.

48
00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:10.160
And, for Cisco,
those are usually the 4500s and the 6500s.

49
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:14.670
There's a few other specialized switches
they have, but for the CCNP routing and

50
00:02:14.670 --> 00:02:17.990
switching, the 4500s and the 6500s,
those are the ones to remember.

51
00:02:17.990 --> 00:02:20.670
And if you go to Cisco's website and
look for them, what you're buying is,

52
00:02:20.670 --> 00:02:24.610
effectively, a big box,
a big, fat, empty box.

53
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:27.905
And then it has no ports,
no ports that are useful at all.

54
00:02:27.905 --> 00:02:31.835
And you buy cards, modules,
that you slide into the switch so

55
00:02:31.835 --> 00:02:33.605
you get exactly what you want.

56
00:02:33.605 --> 00:02:38.675
If you need 72 ports, you buy
enough blades to give you 72 ports.

57
00:02:38.675 --> 00:02:39.945
Or if you need 224 ports,

58
00:02:39.945 --> 00:02:43.195
or however many, you buy the right
amount of blades for that.

59
00:02:43.195 --> 00:02:48.030
And the cool part about it is,
you can have a 192-port switch, and

60
00:02:48.030 --> 00:02:50.960
it's just one switch,
one thing that you go and configure.

61
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:52.130
And it's got all these ports,

62
00:02:52.130 --> 00:02:56.320
super high port density,
which is great at the access layer.

63
00:02:57.330 --> 00:03:00.470
Except, if your remember Cisco's model,
right, they want your network to have

64
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:03.440
three layers, an access layer,
a distribution layer and a core layer.

65
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:04.470
And at the core,

66
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:07.650
you're just trying to move data as
fast as possible and that's it.

67
00:03:07.650 --> 00:03:10.370
At the distribution layer,
you're doing a lot of logic.

68
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:11.900
You're layer three switching, routing,

69
00:03:11.900 --> 00:03:14.130
things like that's all
happening at distribution.

70
00:03:14.130 --> 00:03:19.480
And at access layer, that's where you're
doing things like port security and

71
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:23.150
protection from exploit, and
then just providing high port density.

72
00:03:23.150 --> 00:03:27.270
Well, the problem with 4500s and
6500s is they're great switches, but

73
00:03:27.270 --> 00:03:29.685
they're pretty expensive, right?

74
00:03:29.685 --> 00:03:32.735
Speced out with gigabit networks,
they can cost tens of thousands,

75
00:03:32.735 --> 00:03:36.101
even hundreds of thousands, of dollars
in some scenarios to get them speced

76
00:03:36.101 --> 00:03:38.854
out exactly the way that you want,
and that's a log of money.

77
00:03:38.854 --> 00:03:42.530
So for a lot of people out there,
they don't go that route.

78
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:46.475
They just buy 3560s or 2960s, and
they start stacking those switches.

79
00:03:46.475 --> 00:03:49.624
But the problem is, if you go out and
buy a 2960 or a 3560,

80
00:03:49.624 --> 00:03:52.170
the maximum ports you're
gonna get is 48 ports.

81
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:56.800
And if you need more than 48 ports,
now you've got two switches, and

82
00:03:56.800 --> 00:03:57.850
what are you gonna do?

83
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:01.795
Well, we saw in earlier episodes that we
could run a trunk cable in-between them,

84
00:04:01.795 --> 00:04:04.460
a trunk VLANs across a single link.

85
00:04:04.460 --> 00:04:06.900
But your single link is gonna be,
what, a gigabit?

86
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:11.560
Maybe a ten gig connection if you buy
the ten gig uplink module for it.

87
00:04:11.560 --> 00:04:14.870
But you could also do things
like EtherChannel, and

88
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:16.650
start bonding interfaces together.

89
00:04:16.650 --> 00:04:20.824
So maybe I have 8 gigabyte interfaces I
bond together to get 8 gigs of bandwidth

90
00:04:20.824 --> 00:04:22.960
on that link in-between two switches.

91
00:04:22.960 --> 00:04:24.170
That's great.

92
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:26.190
But what if I've got five switches.

93
00:04:26.190 --> 00:04:28.659
I'm gonna end up losing a lot
of ports to EtherChannel, right?

94
00:04:28.659 --> 00:04:30.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> And You've seen this, Ronnie.

95
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:31.770
>> Yeah, no doubt.
Once you actually start doing

96
00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:34.400
the EtherChannel, if you start bonding
them together, if you can bond up to

97
00:04:34.400 --> 00:04:38.380
eight, you're actually taking
eight ports away from each switch.

98
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:42.172
So even on a 48-port switch,
all of a sudden it becomes, well, what,

99
00:04:42.172 --> 00:04:43.347
40 ports at the max.

100
00:04:43.347 --> 00:04:44.040
>> Yeah.
>> And

101
00:04:44.040 --> 00:04:46.100
then if you're actually doing trunking for
something else,

102
00:04:46.100 --> 00:04:49.440
and you have some other issues, then you
just kind of realize, you start losing it.

103
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:52.740
And that's why something like what we're
talking about in terms of StackWise

104
00:04:52.740 --> 00:04:55.000
is really a neat technology for us.

105
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:56.372
>> All right, so
let's talk about StackWise.

106
00:04:56.372 --> 00:05:01.200
What StackWise does is it lets you
take a Cisco switch or some routers.

107
00:05:01.200 --> 00:05:06.330
It's really supported on the 3750s, so
if you have 3750, 3750E, 3750G, or 3750X.

108
00:05:06.330 --> 00:05:11.645
Boy, that is harder to
say than it should be.

109
00:05:11.645 --> 00:05:13.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> Any of those four models,

110
00:05:13.630 --> 00:05:18.680
those switches have special StackWise
connectors on the back of them, right?

111
00:05:18.680 --> 00:05:20.170
And there's some routers.

112
00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:22.410
If you have a Cisco 2900 and

113
00:05:22.410 --> 00:05:26.460
3900 series routers, they have switch
modules that you can pop into them, right.

114
00:05:26.460 --> 00:05:27.930
They're called, what are they called?

115
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:29.460
Ethernet switch modules?

116
00:05:29.460 --> 00:05:31.262
They got an actual name for it.

117
00:05:31.262 --> 00:05:32.210
Oh, EtherSwitch.
>> EtherSwitch.

118
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:33.485
>> That's it, EtherSwitch module.

119
00:05:33.485 --> 00:05:37.340
So, the EtherSwitch modules, they also
have gigastacks, I mean, gigastacks,

120
00:05:37.340 --> 00:05:38.068
thinking of the old stuff.

121
00:05:38.068 --> 00:05:40.328
>> [LAUGH]
>> The StackWise connector on them.

122
00:05:40.328 --> 00:05:43.220
And the StackWise connector, if you look
at it, it looks like an old school SCSI

123
00:05:43.220 --> 00:05:48.380
connector, and it allows you to put
a special cable on the back of the device.

124
00:05:48.380 --> 00:05:53.510
And that cable can then connect over to
the other device to create a bonded back

125
00:05:53.510 --> 00:05:54.640
plane, all right?

126
00:05:54.640 --> 00:05:56.410
Now, if you've never seen this,
let me show you.

127
00:05:56.410 --> 00:05:59.270
I've got some kind of Visio
stencils here that Cisco provides.

128
00:05:59.270 --> 00:06:01.580
And here I've got a stack of 3750s, right?

129
00:06:02.820 --> 00:06:04.280
These are 48 port 3750s.

130
00:06:04.280 --> 00:06:08.440

576
00:27:50.480 --> 00:27:53.360
They actually don't let you, or at least
I'm not aware of any way that you can

577
00:27:53.360 --> 00:27:55.810
hard set the MAC address
prior to adding it.

578
00:27:55.810 --> 00:27:58.050
That's why I add
the switches one at a time.

579
00:27:58.050 --> 00:27:58.580
One at a time so

580
00:27:58.580 --> 00:28:02.120
you make sure you know which one is
getting which number, all right.

581
00:28:02.120 --> 00:28:06.380
But once they're added in,
the switch bonds hold these together, and

582
00:28:06.380 --> 00:28:09.570
the ports now show up as
part of your switch, and

583
00:28:09.570 --> 00:28:13.110
it's kind of neat because when
you take a look at a switch.

584
00:28:13.110 --> 00:28:18.538
If I do show IP interface brief, right?

585
00:28:18.538 --> 00:28:23.300
When we take a look at our interface
brief output, I've got my ports 1 slash 0

586
00:28:23.300 --> 00:28:28.180
slash 1, all the way through, is this a 24
port or a 48, tis is a 24 port switch.

587
00:28:28.180 --> 00:28:31.028
So, I see 1 through 24, and
then notice what happened after it.

588
00:28:31.028 --> 00:28:35.240
FA2-0-1 and it's going all

589
00:28:35.240 --> 00:28:41.240
the way through 2-0-24 because I told
it that switch 2 was a 24 port switch.

590
00:28:41.240 --> 00:28:44.780
If I told it I was gonna have a switch 3,
and

591
00:28:44.780 --> 00:28:47.700
I was gonna make it a 48 port switch,
right.

592
00:28:47.700 --> 00:28:50.070
So, we'll just add in a switch 3.

593
00:28:50.070 --> 00:28:52.770
It's gonna update my config
to reflect that, and

594
00:28:52.770 --> 00:28:57.680
I can start doing port configurations,
assigning VLANs, and all of that.

595
00:28:57.680 --> 00:29:01.420
And it's gonna show all these
extra ports available to me even

596
00:29:01.420 --> 00:29:03.290
though that switch is down, right?

597
00:29:03.290 --> 00:29:04.440
And that's kinda how it views it.

598
00:29:04.440 --> 00:29:05.470
Oh, that switch failed.

599
00:29:05.470 --> 00:29:08.440
The ports exist, I need to know them,
but the switch has failed.

600
00:29:08.440 --> 00:29:12.180
And so we're gonna save their
config instead of losing it, and so

601
00:29:12.180 --> 00:29:14.510
there all that is, and we'll see that.

602
00:29:14.510 --> 00:29:16.690
Well it might not show up in the VLANs,
cuz they're all down,

603
00:29:16.690 --> 00:29:18.240
but we'll see if it shows up there.

604
00:29:18.240 --> 00:29:21.060
Yeah, it's not going to show up there yet,
but as soon as I bring those switches

605
00:29:21.060 --> 00:29:24.180
online they'll show up there too,
and we'll be off and going.

606
00:29:24.180 --> 00:29:27.390
And at this point I add in my switches,
right?

607
00:29:27.390 --> 00:29:31.500
I just plug in the stack wise cables and
they bond into the group, and that's it.

608
00:29:31.500 --> 00:29:33.670
And I don't really see
anything different here.

609
00:29:33.670 --> 00:29:37.630
The ports all show up just like normal,
and when I do a show switch,

610
00:29:37.630 --> 00:29:41.390
the only real difference I'll see is these
guys will switch from provision to ready.

611
00:29:41.390 --> 00:29:43.740
And they'll have a Mac address populated.

612
00:29:43.740 --> 00:29:45.940
But from then on,
if I wanna connect to the console,

613
00:29:45.940 --> 00:29:47.580
I connect to the console
of the master switch.

614
00:29:47.580 --> 00:29:49.110
I plug into that.

615
00:29:49.110 --> 00:29:51.530
When I assign an IP address
to the switch stack,

616
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:53.310
the IP address is being
handled by the master.

617
00:29:53.310 --> 00:29:56.390
And if the master fails, well,
the other guys take it over.

618
00:29:56.390 --> 00:29:59.950
I don't even have to configure HSRP or
VRRP or any of that stuff.

619
00:29:59.950 --> 00:30:04.940
If this switch fails, the config is
synchronized across the entire stack.

620
00:30:04.940 --> 00:30:07.680
So any member in the stack can jump in,

621
00:30:07.680 --> 00:30:12.320
and take over, and
that's all because of this ring.

622
00:30:13.430 --> 00:30:17.370
The config is synced across them, if one
guy fails another one can step up and

623
00:30:17.370 --> 00:30:19.330
say, hey, I'm the new master,
I've already got the config,

624
00:30:19.330 --> 00:30:21.450
my ports are configured this way.

625
00:30:21.450 --> 00:30:22.550
We're ready to rock.

626
00:30:22.550 --> 00:30:26.170
So, this is a great replacement for things
like first hop redundancy protocols.

627
00:30:26.170 --> 00:30:30.160
VRRP, GLBP, HSRP.

628
00:30:30.160 --> 00:30:32.780
It's not a perfect replacement for GLBP,

629
00:30:32.780 --> 00:30:36.730
cuz you're not really load balancing,
but you don't necessarily need to,

630
00:30:36.730 --> 00:30:40.080
cuz this is one solid switch there's
nothing to load balance or cross.

631
00:30:40.080 --> 00:30:41.650
It's really a great solution.

632
00:30:41.650 --> 00:30:43.940
>> Now Don,
you had mentioned that some of the cables,

633
00:30:43.940 --> 00:30:46.510
these stackwise cables,
they have logic in them.

634
00:30:46.510 --> 00:30:49.200
Is there a way that we can actually verify
that the cables are functioning the way

635
00:30:49.200 --> 00:30:50.710
that we believe they're supposed to be?

636
00:30:50.710 --> 00:30:52.090
>> Yeah, there's a few extra commands.

637
00:30:52.090 --> 00:30:53.730
I don't know if these will
be on the exam or not,

638
00:30:53.730 --> 00:30:57.800
but it doesn't hurt to kind of see them.

639
00:30:57.800 --> 00:30:59.490
I ran the show switch command, right?

640
00:30:59.490 --> 00:31:03.550
To just look at my overall status but
if you do a ?, you'll see where you can do

641
00:31:03.550 --> 00:31:08.550
a stack ports and stack ring and
you can see some additional information.

642
00:31:08.550 --> 00:31:14.180
Like if I do stack ring, speed,
that'll show me information on my speed.

643
00:31:14.180 --> 00:31:16.920
I can see that I've got a full
ring configuration, right,

644
00:31:16.920 --> 00:31:19.180
cuz if there's a break,
I end up like half duplex, right?

645
00:31:19.180 --> 00:31:21.690
So we end up at a partial.

646
00:31:21.690 --> 00:31:24.240
But I've got a full ring,
it's running stack wise,

647
00:31:24.240 --> 00:31:26.630
and I've got 32 gigs of bandwidth.

648
00:31:26.630 --> 00:31:27.395
That's sweet.

649
00:31:27.395 --> 00:31:29.680
Extra bandwidth that we get right there.

650
00:31:29.680 --> 00:31:31.460
So that's one command to be aware of.

651
00:31:31.460 --> 00:31:35.605
There's also show switch detail,
which is a pretty handy one,

652
00:31:35.605 --> 00:31:39.010
cuz it gives you a little extra
information about the devices.

653
00:31:39.010 --> 00:31:44.090
Now, what I see up here, that's what I
got from show switch, so that's not new.

654
00:31:44.090 --> 00:31:45.560
What's new is down here.

655
00:31:45.560 --> 00:31:47.570
I can see the individual ports.

656
00:31:48.580 --> 00:31:50.030
What's my port status?

657
00:31:50.030 --> 00:31:51.710
What's my neighbor's port status?

658
00:31:51.710 --> 00:31:53.630
Am I connected or what?

659
00:31:53.630 --> 00:31:55.950
I can see that I am connected but
my neighbor is down,

660
00:31:55.950 --> 00:31:59.890
which means either the other end of
the cable is unplugged or the other end is

661
00:31:59.890 --> 00:32:03.740
just not functioning right, so I'm not
seeing my neighbors on Port 1 or Port 2.

662
00:32:03.740 --> 00:32:05.170
But it gives us a chance to see that,

663
00:32:05.170 --> 00:32:08.200
and the cables which
communicating that information.

664
00:32:08.200 --> 00:32:11.700
>> All right, Don, that's a lot of
information just about StackWise.

665
00:32:11.700 --> 00:32:13.910
Any other parting words for us?

666
00:32:13.910 --> 00:32:15.560
>> It's a great technology,

667
00:32:15.560 --> 00:32:19.870
if you're looking at high
port density switches, right?

668
00:32:19.870 --> 00:32:24.450
6500s, they're great switches, especially,
in your core or distribution layer.

669
00:32:24.450 --> 00:32:27.490
But in your access layer if you're looking
for something less expensive that's still

670
00:32:27.490 --> 00:32:32.710
very feature rich, a 3750 cluster combined
with the stack wise cables, it's super

671
00:32:32.710 --> 00:32:36.970
easy to configure, super easy to maintain,
and a lot less expensive than the 6500's.

672
00:32:36.970 --> 00:32:39.079
And I know for small and
medium businesses,

673
00:32:39.079 --> 00:32:42.955
I'll use them even in the core sometimes
because you can get some real power, and

674
00:32:42.955 --> 00:32:45.919
some real bandwidth out of them,
without breaking the bank,

675
00:32:45.919 --> 00:32:48.262
so definitely a technology
you wanna look into.

676
00:32:48.262 --> 00:32:51.539
>> So in this episode, we took a look at
StackWise as a technology for the Cisco

677
00:32:51.539 --> 00:32:54.867
switches, remember that it actually
allows us to be able to aggregate those

678
00:32:54.867 --> 00:32:58.507
switches together, and really treat them
almost like a modular switch, as well,

679
00:32:58.507 --> 00:33:01.965
where we get the functions that we
normally do see there, not every function.

680
00:33:01.965 --> 00:33:03.551
But it is a neat technology for

681
00:33:03.551 --> 00:33:07.994
us where we actually don't have to worry
about things like trunking between them,

682
00:33:07.994 --> 00:33:12.309
as well as, ether channel, but we actually
get the full bandwidth that we need,

683
00:33:12.309 --> 00:33:16.230
allows us to go to manage multiple
switches from one, as well.

684
00:33:16.230 --> 00:33:18.360
So that's a great place for use to end.

685
00:33:18.360 --> 00:33:21.300
>> Signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

686
00:33:21.300 --> 00:33:22.000
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

687
00:33:22.000 --> 00:33:25.185
>> And we'll see you next time.

688
00:33:25.185 --> 00:33:29.780
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to secure a network by employing DHCP Snooping. DHCP Snooping allows you to configure your network to only allow dynamic IP addressing from the ports you specify protecting you from attacks via a rogue DHCP server
episodes.title: Switch Security Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.861 --> 00:00:16.560
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:18.040
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.040 --> 00:00:20.900
Joining with me on the show today,
yet again, Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:20.900 --> 00:00:22.200
How's it going today Don?

6
00:00:22.200 --> 00:00:23.230
>> It is going great Daniel.

7
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:24.790
Glad to be back on the show.

8
00:00:24.790 --> 00:00:27.405
And ready to kick off
a new section on this one.

9
00:00:27.405 --> 00:00:28.740
We're jumping objectives and

10
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:32.600
we're gonna move into some of
the switch security features.

11
00:00:32.600 --> 00:00:36.910
You'd be amazed how many really cool
features are built into Cisco switches,

12
00:00:36.910 --> 00:00:41.990
to help to secure and protect your network
that just aren't turned on by default.

13
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:44.390
If you don't know about them,
you don't think to turn it on, and

14
00:00:44.390 --> 00:00:47.220
your network runs, and
you deal with security issues.

15
00:00:47.220 --> 00:00:50.310
But as it turns out, there's,
I don't know, five or

16
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:54.310
six different things that we can turn on a
switch, that completely eliminate certain

17
00:00:54.310 --> 00:00:58.060
types of attacks that a lot of people
spend a lot of time worrying about.

18
00:00:58.060 --> 00:01:03.530
And on layer two access switches, on your
layer three distribution in core switches,

19
00:01:03.530 --> 00:01:05.440
we can implement these technologies, and

20
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:08.580
we can end up with a really,
really secure network.

21
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:12.050
Now, on our distribution in core, we
normally try to keep things moving as fast

22
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:14.980
as possible and try not to
implement too much crazy logic, so

23
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:19.392
the majority of these we'll use on
our access switches all the time, but

24
00:01:19.392 --> 00:01:21.780
then on our core and
distribution some of the time.

25
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:23.118
So just be aware that as we look through,

26
00:01:23.118 --> 00:01:26.000
you don't necessary want to turn
these on for every single switch.

27
00:01:26.000 --> 00:01:29.130
And the main reason is, you gonna think
about where your attacks come from.

28
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:31.890
Your attacks generally come from clients.

29
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:35.320
When clients plug in, to the access
ports on the switches, right?

30
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:36.550
The access switches.

31
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:38.180
Clients don't plug into distribution.

32
00:01:38.180 --> 00:01:39.840
Clients don't plug into core.

33
00:01:39.840 --> 00:01:41.980
And so
these technologies are the most effective,

34
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:44.830
when implemented on the access switch,
right?

35
00:01:44.830 --> 00:01:50.030
Now, the first type of attack that
I wanna get into is, one that is.

36
00:01:50.030 --> 00:01:53.150
Actually, you'll see several of
these are really easy to pull off.

37
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:56.120
But one of the just super
mega easy ones to pull off.

38
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:58.650
So easy that people do it by accident.

39
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:01.950
It's what called a rogue DHCP server,
all right.

40
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:03.320
I'll give you a great example.

41
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:07.680
There was one day,
where I was at the office, and

42
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:11.520
people started coming to me saying,
Don, I can't get to the Internet.

43
00:02:11.520 --> 00:02:13.000
I think the Internet's down.

44
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:18.300
And I can print, I can access the local
stuff, but I can't get to the Internet.

45
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:19.588
>> You can't print.

46
00:02:19.588 --> 00:02:20.490
[LAUGH]
>> Printing, who can't print?

47
00:02:20.490 --> 00:02:23.804
But I said, well that then, that's odd,
and then, I sat on my laptop and

48
00:02:23.804 --> 00:02:25.210
got right out to the Internet.

49
00:02:26.430 --> 00:02:30.010
Okay, so that's working for
me, and I couldn't print.

50
00:02:30.010 --> 00:02:31.130
Now that's weird.

51
00:02:31.130 --> 00:02:33.070
So I'm getting to the Internet,
things are good for

52
00:02:33.070 --> 00:02:37.760
me, but I can't print, they can't
get to the Internet, they can print.

53
00:02:37.760 --> 00:02:39.900
What the heck is going on here?

54
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:42.690
And so I started to take a look at what
was different between my machine, and

55
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:45.860
theirs and my machine had a static IP,
cuz I did network management,

56
00:02:45.860 --> 00:02:48.730
had a lot of ACL's that were
tied to the IP on my laptop.

57
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:52.370
Their machine was DHCP, and when I looked
at the address that they got on their

58
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:55.590
machine, it wasn't in the right network.

59
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:57.470
It was a completely different network.

60
00:02:57.470 --> 00:03:02.830
We used some 10 dot networks there,
and they had a 192.168 address.

61
00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:04.218
I was like, man where did that come from?

62
00:03:04.218 --> 00:03:07.430
And the DHCP server that was listed
was the server that I didn't know,

63
00:03:07.430 --> 00:03:09.820
because I have a 192 at 168 address.

64
00:03:09.820 --> 00:03:13.350
Somebody had brought up
a rouge DHCP server.

65
00:03:13.350 --> 00:03:16.005
Now an attacker can do this.

66
00:03:16.005 --> 00:03:19.555
Because what happens is,
clients get a DHCP address from them, and

67
00:03:19.555 --> 00:03:21.895
they set themselves as a default gateway,
and

68
00:03:21.895 --> 00:03:25.285
a smart attacker makes it where they then
connect it back into the network, so

69
00:03:25.285 --> 00:03:27.750
you can just pass right through them and
don't even know it.

70
00:03:27.750 --> 00:03:31.280
They can then run a sniffer and capture
all your traffic or manipulate your data,

71
00:03:31.280 --> 00:03:33.500
do man in the middle attacks, and
you know all that great stuff.

72
00:03:33.500 --> 00:03:35.750
Right?
And usually it doesn't even notice it.

73
00:03:35.750 --> 00:03:38.660
But this one, I didn't think was an attack
because you couldn't communicate

74
00:03:38.660 --> 00:03:40.360
through it, it was just too obvious.

75
00:03:40.360 --> 00:03:41.470
And sure enough,

76
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:45.560
what happened is, there was a person
that was actually up in accounting,

77
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:50.400
it wasn't even in IT, where they had gone
to the store during their lunch break.

78
00:03:50.400 --> 00:03:54.140
And they had bought a wireless router for
them to use at home.

79
00:03:54.140 --> 00:03:56.990
And, they brought it into the office,
and they decided, you know what?

80
00:03:56.990 --> 00:04:00.160
I wanna check and see if there's any
updates for it before I take it home.

81
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:02.590
And so they plugged it into our network.

82
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:06.960
And those home routers, those wireless
routers, they're DHCP servers.

83
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:08.510
And it's turned on by default, so

84
00:04:08.510 --> 00:04:12.920
as soon as they plugged it into my
network, it started handing out addresses.

85
00:04:12.920 --> 00:04:16.220
And my clients, that had DHCP addresses,

86
00:04:16.220 --> 00:04:20.570
they'd start getting new leases because
that router was responding faster

87
00:04:20.570 --> 00:04:23.690
than our corporate DHCP server which
was actually on a different subnet.

88
00:04:23.690 --> 00:04:26.140
And so,
they started getting these bad addresses.

89
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:30.085
Now, it was an accident, in this case,
but it caused the denial of service.

90
00:04:30.085 --> 00:04:32.645
My client's couldn't work, right.

91
00:04:32.645 --> 00:04:35.715
But if it was malicious, it could
have been a man in the middle attack.

92
00:04:35.715 --> 00:04:38.895
And that's a rogue DHCP server,
and it's super easy to do,

93
00:04:38.895 --> 00:04:43.555
anybody can fire up DHCP on their laptop,
they can run it in a virtual machine,

94
00:04:43.555 --> 00:04:44.737
they can bring in a router.

95
00:04:44.737 --> 00:04:48.735
There's any number of ways to do it
that don't even cost a penny, and

96
00:04:48.735 --> 00:04:51.460
now you're serving up DHCP
addresses on the network,

97
00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:54.650
and, people aren't able to
get their real addresses.

98
00:04:54.650 --> 00:04:56.170
That's a real problem
that we have on networks.

99
00:04:57.270 --> 00:05:02.450
Now, on Cisco switches, we have this
technology called DHCP snooping.

100
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:04.956
And DHCP snooping,
on most switches these days,

101
00:05:04.956 --> 00:05:08.985
it's actually turned on by default,
but it's not set to do anything.

102
00:05:08.985 --> 00:05:14.055
And what DHCP snooping does is, it watches
the network for DHCP communications.

103
00:05:14.055 --> 00:05:18.380
So your switch is actually monitoring
DHCP, and seeing this stuff happen.

104
00:05:18.380 --> 00:05:20.290
And it just doesn't do anything about it.

105
00:05:20.290 --> 00:05:22.510
But we can get in there and
change the way it works, and

106
00:05:22.510 --> 00:05:28.580
we can tell it to get involved in the DHCP
process to help protect our network.

107
00:05:28.580 --> 00:05:30.610
And it's super simple to turn on.

108
00:05:30.610 --> 00:05:33.220
It doesn't take a lot of
work to get it going.

109
00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:37.220
And it helps eliminate these rogue DHCP
servers, it gives you that control.

00:27:25.870 --> 00:27:28.670

558
00:28:25.570 --> 00:28:29.140
Because each DHCP discover message
has to have a different source MAC.

559
00:28:29.140 --> 00:28:31.180
And so,
if you limit the amount of source MACs,

560
00:28:31.180 --> 00:28:33.820
you've limited the amount of
IPs that one person could get.

561
00:28:33.820 --> 00:28:34.930
Right?
So that's one way to solve it.

562
00:28:34.930 --> 00:28:36.550
We'll see that later.

563
00:28:36.550 --> 00:28:39.120
But, DHCP snooping can do it too.

564
00:28:40.130 --> 00:28:44.560
You can actually set, it's kind of like a
rate limit, like with quality of service.

565
00:28:44.560 --> 00:28:48.381
You can limit the amount of
the DHCP traffic that's allowed

566
00:28:48.381 --> 00:28:52.355
on a particular port and
you can cut that down so that if I try and

567
00:28:52.355 --> 00:28:57.412
do 500 discovers I exceed the rate limit
and it will trim off the extra ones.

568
00:28:57.412 --> 00:29:01.649
So if I rate limit it down to ten,
yeah, I can grab ten addresses.

569
00:29:01.649 --> 00:29:04.690
But I won't be able to get 11.

570
00:29:04.690 --> 00:29:07.700
So we kind of put a limit on how
effective that attack can be.

571
00:29:07.700 --> 00:29:12.390
And the command to do it is pretty
simple here, let me switch back to one

572
00:29:12.390 --> 00:29:16.490
of my core switches and
I'll show you how to do it.

573
00:29:16.490 --> 00:29:18.140
You'll do this on your access ports.

574
00:29:18.140 --> 00:29:20.890
We don't wanna rate limit our DHCP server.

575
00:29:20.890 --> 00:29:22.320
That's not normally a good thing.

576
00:29:22.320 --> 00:29:24.220
So this would normally
be our access ports and

577
00:29:24.220 --> 00:29:29.080
you just want to limit how much
they can issue at any given time.

578
00:29:29.080 --> 00:29:32.990
And so the way we do that is you get into
an interface that a client's plugged into.

579
00:29:32.990 --> 00:29:36.330
So this client for me is plugged into,
what is it plugged into?

580
00:29:36.330 --> 00:29:40.260
Here, we'll find out real quick.

581
00:29:40.260 --> 00:29:42.990
It is plugged into port two.

582
00:29:42.990 --> 00:29:46.490
So I can get into interface fa1/0/2,
all right?

583
00:29:46.490 --> 00:29:50.270
And I can say ip dhcp snooping.

584
00:29:51.460 --> 00:29:53.870
And then if you do a question mark
you'll see there's a limit command.

585
00:29:53.870 --> 00:29:55.500
There it is, limit.

586
00:29:55.500 --> 00:29:59.480
And we can apply limits
to the DHCP requests.

587
00:29:59.480 --> 00:30:02.010
So I can set a rate limit on here.

588
00:30:02.010 --> 00:30:06.392
And I can specify how many requests I
want to allow to go through this port,

589
00:30:06.392 --> 00:30:09.210
through its DHCP snooping interval.

590
00:30:09.210 --> 00:30:11.710
And this will effectively
kill that kind of attack, so

591
00:30:11.710 --> 00:30:13.480
I can throw a ten on here or five.

592
00:30:13.480 --> 00:30:18.140
You can do one, but
if somebody unplugs their laptop and

593
00:30:18.140 --> 00:30:23.410
plugs in another laptop that might
not be enough time to get past it.

594
00:30:23.410 --> 00:30:24.620
So now they can't get an address.

595
00:30:24.620 --> 00:30:27.630
So you normally wanna give a little
bit of leeway on those ports.

596
00:30:27.630 --> 00:30:28.960
So I'll do ten.

597
00:30:28.960 --> 00:30:33.000
And now, if somebody plugs in
that port and starts going crazy.

598
00:30:33.000 --> 00:30:35.840
The first ten work and then they stop.

599
00:30:35.840 --> 00:30:38.870
And that peels that off so
it's not sending out those DHCP discovers.

600
00:30:38.870 --> 00:30:43.620
My MAC address table doesn't fill up,
and my server only wasted ten IPs.

601
00:30:43.620 --> 00:30:46.200
That attack is effectively stopped.

602
00:30:46.200 --> 00:30:47.227
>> Very very cool man.

603
00:30:47.227 --> 00:30:50.720
DHCP snooping is apparently a very
powerful tool for us to enable

604
00:30:50.720 --> 00:30:55.063
on our Cisco switches, tightening that
security down just like we'd like it.

605
00:30:55.063 --> 00:30:57.160
We get all the DHCP hacking stuff.

606
00:30:57.160 --> 00:30:59.920
Stop doing that people and
if you do we can stop you.

607
00:30:59.920 --> 00:31:01.690
>> Yeah, and you said it's powerful.

608
00:31:01.690 --> 00:31:04.530
We're actually going to continue
using DHCP snooping in some of our

609
00:31:04.530 --> 00:31:06.430
other security features.

610
00:31:06.430 --> 00:31:09.300
Because that we've got several security
features that build off of the database

611
00:31:09.300 --> 00:31:10.430
that DHCP snooping builds.

612
00:31:10.430 --> 00:31:14.150
Remember, it's keeping a record of
what MAC addresses got what IPs and

613
00:31:14.150 --> 00:31:16.050
you can use that for
all sorts of additional features.

614
00:31:16.050 --> 00:31:18.740
So we're going to see this
again as the series goes on.

615
00:31:18.740 --> 00:31:19.350
>> Awesome.
Well,

616
00:31:19.350 --> 00:31:22.060
it looks like we're going to have to
make another part to this because

617
00:31:22.060 --> 00:31:24.300
apparently we have a lot
more to talk about.

618
00:31:24.300 --> 00:31:26.730
Don, have we come to
the end of this episode?

619
00:31:26.730 --> 00:31:28.990
Or do we have anything else we
would like to tack on the end?

620
00:31:28.990 --> 00:31:32.240
>> I don't think I can fit anything
else in, in the time that I've got.

621
00:31:32.240 --> 00:31:33.100
So, let's wrap it here.

622
00:31:33.100 --> 00:31:34.040
We will continue on.

623
00:31:34.040 --> 00:31:35.680
This is going to be a multi part series.

624
00:31:35.680 --> 00:31:39.340
What we showed you here was how we could
take two really common attacks, and

625
00:31:39.340 --> 00:31:40.040
just eliminate them.

626
00:31:40.040 --> 00:31:41.900
They're not even valid
on your network anymore.

627
00:31:41.900 --> 00:31:44.360
There's several other attacks,
we're actually going to do the same thing.

628
00:31:44.360 --> 00:31:46.770
So these are prevalent attacks
that are easy to pull off.

629
00:31:46.770 --> 00:31:48.390
This is good stuff to know.

630
00:31:48.390 --> 00:31:51.495
So we'll two or three parts on this
one to make sure we cover them all.

631
00:31:51.495 --> 00:31:53.130
>> Excellent.
Well I'm looking forward to that.

632
00:31:53.130 --> 00:31:54.480
Hopefully you guys are as well.

633
00:31:54.480 --> 00:31:55.850
Thanks for watching today.

634
00:31:55.850 --> 00:31:57.968
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

635
00:31:57.968 --> 00:31:59.084
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

636
00:31:59.084 --> 00:32:00.627
>> And we'll see you next time.

637
00:32:00.627 --> 00:32:07.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue switch security configurations moving into the topics of IP Source Guard and Dynamic ARP Inspection. They explain how you can prevent IP Spoofing attacks using IP Source Guard and for MAC Spoofing or ARP poisoning attacks you can employ Dynamic ARP Inspection.
episodes.title: Switch Security Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.765 --> 00:00:13.781
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.781 --> 00:00:16.650
And wlcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.650 --> 00:00:17.880
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:21.130
Joining me in the studio today is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:22.510
How's it going today, Don?

7
00:00:22.510 --> 00:00:23.490
>> It is going great, Daniel.

8
00:00:23.490 --> 00:00:24.780
Excited to be back on this show and

9
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:30.210
ready to continue our adventure into the
wide world of switch security features.

10
00:00:30.210 --> 00:00:33.730
In part one, we had a chance to
take a look at DHTP snooping, and

11
00:00:33.730 --> 00:00:37.210
how we could use it and
a couple other little technologies to

12
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:39.760
protect our switches from
certain DHCP attacks.

13
00:00:39.760 --> 00:00:43.305
We specifically saw rogue DHCP servers and
DHCP starvation, and

14
00:00:43.305 --> 00:00:45.700
it really wasn't that
hard to get it set up.

15
00:00:45.700 --> 00:00:48.490
And now, you don't have to worry
about those attacks on your network.

16
00:00:48.490 --> 00:00:50.360
It's a thing of the past, right?

17
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:53.850
But, one of the things I said right
at the end of the episode was

18
00:00:53.850 --> 00:00:59.220
remember GHB snooping, because we can
use it for a lot of other stuff, too.

19
00:00:59.220 --> 00:01:02.110
Right, well, in this episode,
we're gonna see some of that other stuff.

20
00:01:02.110 --> 00:01:04.130
What are the other things we
can use that database for?

21
00:01:04.130 --> 00:01:08.631
Because that GHB Database,
remember, it's got IPs and

22
00:01:08.631 --> 00:01:12.021
MAC addresses and what port people are on.

23
00:01:12.021 --> 00:01:14.160
And that's really valuable
information to have.

24
00:01:14.160 --> 00:01:17.480
It goes beyond what the MAC address table
or the ARP table would have by itself and

25
00:01:17.480 --> 00:01:18.630
kind of combines it and

26
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:21.850
gives us a chance to use that for
additional client validation.

27
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:24.770
And so, we're gonna see that here in this
episode and we'll get a chance to kind

28
00:01:24.770 --> 00:01:26.700
of jump in there and
see what we can do with that data.

29
00:01:26.700 --> 00:01:29.450
>> Yeah, when it comes to IP
the first thing I usually think of,

30
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:31.420
Don, is IP spoofing.

31
00:01:31.420 --> 00:01:35.060
It's one of the most common types of
attack because I want to hide myself and

32
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:38.700
IP is a great way to go ahead and
show everyone who I am.

33
00:01:38.700 --> 00:01:40.700
So if I can make that something else,

34
00:01:40.700 --> 00:01:42.830
make it think, well,
maybe I'm a server on your network.

35
00:01:42.830 --> 00:01:44.850
Don't look at me,
I'm over here stealing data.

36
00:01:44.850 --> 00:01:45.600
That's what I wanna do.

37
00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:47.770
So IP spoofing's probably
one of the biggest attacks.

38
00:01:47.770 --> 00:01:50.334
And can DHCP snooping help us with that?

39
00:01:50.334 --> 00:01:51.312
Or spoofing should I say.

40
00:01:51.312 --> 00:01:54.008
Snooping and spoofing,
say that three times fast.

41
00:01:54.008 --> 00:01:56.090
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it absolutely can.

42
00:01:56.090 --> 00:01:56.620
Right?

43
00:01:56.620 --> 00:02:00.850
If you think about IP spoofing, it's
one of the easiest attacks to pull off.

44
00:02:00.850 --> 00:02:03.410
You just change your
computer's IP address.

45
00:02:03.410 --> 00:02:04.120
Problem solved.

46
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:06.920
Right?
So it's not that hard to pull off, and

47
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:08.390
there's plenty of attackers
out there that do it.

48
00:02:08.390 --> 00:02:10.650
So how can we prevent that?

49
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:13.870
Well, if you're using DHCP snooping,
one of the things that's gonna happen is,

50
00:02:13.870 --> 00:02:16.930
a client's going to send out
a broadcast or request an address.

51
00:02:16.930 --> 00:02:20.990
And the DHCP server's gonna respond,
and attach the address to you.

52
00:02:20.990 --> 00:02:24.950
If you're running DHCP snooping
that makes it into the database and

53
00:02:24.950 --> 00:02:28.650
we can then use that
database to ensure security.

54
00:02:28.650 --> 00:02:33.110
We now know that IP address
belongs to that MAC address and

55
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:34.845
we know what port it's on.

56
00:02:34.845 --> 00:02:37.435
And the switch can enforce that.

57
00:02:37.435 --> 00:02:40.145
So if all of the sudden we see the IP
address appear somewhere else with

58
00:02:40.145 --> 00:02:42.645
a different MAC address, that's not right.

59
00:02:42.645 --> 00:02:44.665
And so we stop them from using it.

60
00:02:44.665 --> 00:02:47.645
Or if we see that IP address
appear on a different port

61
00:02:47.645 --> 00:02:50.775
while we still have the other one logged,
that's not right.

62
00:02:50.775 --> 00:02:54.005
And so we know to step in and
deal with that.

63
00:02:54.005 --> 00:02:56.171
So we can use DHCP snooping
to kinda prevent that.

64
00:02:56.171 --> 00:02:59.053
And if you will remember the database,
let me show it to you here real quick.

65
00:02:59.053 --> 00:03:04.034
In the last episode, we took one of
my routers, it was an NYWAN1, right?

66
00:03:04.034 --> 00:03:05.314
So my New York WAN1 router.

67
00:03:05.314 --> 00:03:08.531
And I switched it from
a static IP to DHCP.

68
00:03:08.531 --> 00:03:13.610
And when I did that, it requested
a DHCP server and DHCP snooping

69
00:03:13.610 --> 00:03:18.984
on my system was able to record that and
allow it and pass it through.

70
00:03:18.984 --> 00:03:25.250
If I run show IP DHCP snooping binding.

71
00:03:25.250 --> 00:03:27.975
When I run that,
sorry binding without an s.

72
00:03:27.975 --> 00:03:29.105
There we go.

73
00:03:29.105 --> 00:03:30.355
We can see the database.

74
00:03:30.355 --> 00:03:33.547
And if you look at that database
I've got a MAC address.

75
00:03:33.547 --> 00:03:36.442
7C:0E:CE:5C:FE:C0, right?

76
00:03:36.442 --> 00:03:37.722
There's my MAC address.

77
00:03:37.722 --> 00:03:39.304
Here's the IP I got.

78
00:03:39.304 --> 00:03:46.575
192.168.16.22, I got a lease for,
I don't know whatever 85,000 seconds is.

79
00:03:46.575 --> 00:03:49.307
You'll see DHCP snooping
is how it was learned.

80
00:03:49.307 --> 00:03:54.310
It's on VLAN 1 and
it's on interface FA1/0/2.

81
00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:58.210
So it knows IP, MAC, and port.

82
00:03:58.210 --> 00:04:01.790
And we were just using DHCP snooping
to control where servers were.

83
00:04:01.790 --> 00:04:04.630
But at the same time,
it's recording all this information and

84
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:06.030
sticking it in a database.

85
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:06.660
Right?

86
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:11.270
A normal DHCP database, which you
have on here also, is just MAC to IP.

87
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:13.190
It doesn't track ports.

88
00:04:13.190 --> 00:04:15.590
And your MAC address table is MAC to port.

89
00:04:15.590 --> 00:04:17.760
And your ARC table is IPs to MAC.

90
00:04:17.760 --> 00:04:19.670
None of them have all three components.

91
00:04:19.670 --> 00:04:21.450
DHCP snooping does.

92
00:04:21.450 --> 00:04:25.690
So if I want to prevent IP spoofing,
I can just tell the switch,

93
00:04:25.690 --> 00:04:29.650
hey, pay attention to that DHCP
snooping database and enforce it.

94
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:33.760
If you see somebody on a different port or
a different IP or a different MAC, and

95
00:04:33.760 --> 00:04:36.930
they don't match up right,
block that traffic.

96
00:04:36.930 --> 00:04:38.890
All right.
Now I know what you're thinking is,

97
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:43.110
well, what if I turn my machine off and
I turn somebody else's machine on and

98
00:04:43.110 --> 00:04:44.950
they get the same address as me?

99
00:04:44.950 --> 00:04:48.215
Well that would only happen
if your lease had expired and

100
00:04:48.215 --> 00:04:49.646
it's tracking the lease also.

101
00:04:49.646 --> 00:04:52.870
That's right here, and so
it knows if your lease is expired.

102
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:56.240
No other MAC address should be
able to get this IP while your

103
00:04:56.240 --> 00:04:59.080
lease is still ticking down
unless you release it.

104
00:04:59.080 --> 00:05:00.614
Right?
Like on a Windows machine,

105
00:05:00.614 --> 00:05:04.663
you can do IPConfig/release but
when you do that the switch sees that too.

106
00:05:04.663 --> 00:05:07.019
Remember it's monitoring
all the DHCP traffic, so

107
00:05:07.019 --> 00:05:10.260
it knows that your lease ended and
it removes you from the database.

108
00:05:10.260 --> 00:05:12.180
Right?
It's watching, it's very smart stuff.

109
00:05:12.180 --> 00:05:12.870
Right?

110
00:05:12.870 --> 00:05:14.910
If you turn it on, you gotta turn it on.

111
00:05:14.910 --> 00:05:19.084
But we can use that to enforce it and
now if somebody tries to spoof our IP,

112
00:05:19.084 --> 00:05:22.856
the switch will see it and
it will stop it from happening, right?

113
00:05:22.856 --> 00:05:26.554
Now the key component here,
the thing that I've kind of been banging

114
00:05:26.554 --> 00:05:30.540
into your heads is that it really is
combined with DHCP snooping, right?

115
00:05:30.540 --> 00:05:32.960
That's where the data is coming from,
that's where it gets this,

116
00:05:32.960 --> 00:05:38.350
it kind of learns it and make sure to get
that put it in place and fire it along.

117
00:05:38.350 --> 00:05:42.150
So getting this configured is actually
pretty simple, we just turn it on and

118
00:05:42.150 --> 00:05:44.180
it runs right off of that
DHCP snooping database.

119
00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:51.720
Now, the only time we have a problem with
that is, what if we're not using DHCP.

120
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:53.220
Right?

121
00:05:53.220 --> 00:05:57.050
If you're not using DHCP then you gotta go
some other route, and you got two choices.

122
00:05:57.050 --> 00:05:59.397
One you could do DHCP reservations, which,

123
00:05:59.397 --> 00:06:02.133
depending on your DHCP
server might be pretty good.

124
00:06:02.133 --> 00:06:05.487
And now you reach out,
you get that address and it sees that, and

125
00:06:05.487 --> 00:06:07.244
you always get the same address.

126
00:06:07.244 --> 00:06:08.830
You have the affect of a static IP,

127
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:11.420
but now you're dependent
on your DHCP server, right?

128
00:06:11.420 --> 00:06:15.435
If your DHCP server fails, you might have
a web server or a mail server and it tries

129
00:06:15.435 --> 00:06:19.290
to get an IP that it has a reservation
for, but that server's not available.

130
00:06:19.290 --> 00:06:20.129
You don't get the address, right?

131
00:06:20.129 --> 00:06:21.230
So that'd be a problem.

132
00:06:23.120 --> 00:06:26.630
But if I don't wanna use DHCP at all,
if I just want a static IP.

133
00:06:26.630 --> 00:06:30.760
Well, in that scenario we can
actually do a static binding.

134
00:06:30.760 --> 00:06:34.694
And bind the IP to a MAC, to a port.

135
00:06:34.694 --> 00:06:37.949
And so you can do it without the DHCP
snooping database it's just going to be

136
00:06:37.949 --> 00:06:39.198
a much more manual process.

137
00:06:39.198 --> 00:06:42.560
All right, I'm gonna show you both ways
just so you guys know and you can see it.

138
00:06:42.560 --> 00:06:45.876
So let's jump in here and we'll get a
chance to kind of get this configured and

139
00:06:45.876 --> 00:06:48.697
right now I'm just going to verify
my configuration real quick.

140
00:06:48.697 --> 00:06:51.838
I already know it's working cuz I
see the database right here, but

141
00:06:51.838 --> 00:06:53.475
I just wanna jump back to NY WAN1.

142
00:06:53.475 --> 00:06:58.740
So this is my WAN router right here and
if I do a show IP interface brief,

143
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:05.170
I can look at its IPs, and
I can see that it's got 192.168.16.22.

144
00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:06.990
And it got it from DHCP.

145
00:07:06.990 --> 00:07:11.472
So I know it is using DHCP to get this

00:30:12.870 --> 00:30:15.560
>> [LAUGH] Hey, well we all love
options for security, right?

593
00:30:15.560 --> 00:30:17.500
Anything we can do to help ourselves,

594
00:30:17.500 --> 00:30:19.670
keep ourselves out of the weeds,
I'm all about that.

595
00:30:19.670 --> 00:30:24.479
So I'm looking forward to part three and
maybe even part 4000, knowing Don.

596
00:30:24.479 --> 00:30:25.729
All right Don, well, we'll call it a day.

597
00:30:25.729 --> 00:30:27.271
Thanks for those great demonstrations.

598
00:30:27.271 --> 00:30:28.271
Thank you for watching.

599
00:30:28.271 --> 00:30:30.021
Signing off for ITProTV.

600
00:30:30.021 --> 00:30:31.478
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

601
00:30:31.478 --> 00:30:32.354
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

602
00:30:32.354 --> 00:30:33.979
>> And we'll see you next time.

603
00:30:33.979 --> 00:30:40.200

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue switch security, this time tackling port security for more granular control over what devices can access specific ports and disabling any ports experiencing unauthorized access. They then move into how to recover disabled ports back to working order using Err-Disable Recovery and finishing up with VLAN Access Control Lists.
episodes.title: Switch Security Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:11.924 --> 00:00:16.181
All right, greetings everyone, welcome to
another exciting episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.181 --> 00:00:17.631
I'm your host Daniel Lowry,

4
00:00:17.631 --> 00:00:21.821
joining me on the show today well is a man
that needs no introduction, Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:21.821 --> 00:00:22.740
How's it going today Don?

6
00:00:22.740 --> 00:00:23.920
>> It is going great Daniel,

7
00:00:23.920 --> 00:00:27.330
and back again for part three of our
switch security features episode.

8
00:00:27.330 --> 00:00:30.680
We've seen a lot of bells and
whistles and features and

9
00:00:30.680 --> 00:00:33.950
all sorts of stuff throughout these
two episodes we've done so far.

10
00:00:33.950 --> 00:00:36.036
>> Starting to feel like
a Highlander series or something.

11
00:00:36.036 --> 00:00:39.330
>> [LAUGH] Which episode is the one
we're gonna forget about and

12
00:00:39.330 --> 00:00:40.230
pretend doesn't exist?

13
00:00:40.230 --> 00:00:44.150
So, So in this episode that we're gonna
continue on and take a look at some

14
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:47.180
other security features that are,
again, just built into the switch.

15
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:49.660
We just have to turn them
on if we want to use them.

16
00:00:49.660 --> 00:00:52.770
And I wanna take us down memory lane for
a minute.

17
00:00:52.770 --> 00:00:55.640
We're gonna step back and we're going to
take a look at something we learned about

18
00:00:55.640 --> 00:00:58.570
back in the CC and A level which
we should have learned about,

19
00:00:58.570 --> 00:01:01.910
something called switch port,
port security.

20
00:01:01.910 --> 00:01:02.557
All right,

21
00:01:02.557 --> 00:01:06.660
on a system switch all of your ports
that are configured is a switch board.

22
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:10.260
You can have a level three switch
than can be configured as routers.

23
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:11.030
Right?

24
00:01:11.030 --> 00:01:14.110
But on the ones that
are configured as switchboards,

25
00:01:14.110 --> 00:01:17.920
those guys we can turn on
a technology called port security.

26
00:01:17.920 --> 00:01:21.760
And since this is our security feature
show it makes sense, this one being here,

27
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:26.720
it's a great way that we can do
well one of two things really.

28
00:01:26.720 --> 00:01:31.000
One we can restrict a port
to a particular MAC address,

29
00:01:31.000 --> 00:01:34.990
again another great way to kind
of stop MAC address spoofing.

30
00:01:34.990 --> 00:01:38.256
Or we can limit the number of Mac
addresses that are allowed to be

31
00:01:38.256 --> 00:01:39.673
simultaneously on a port,

32
00:01:39.673 --> 00:01:42.877
which can help prevent people
bringing switches from home and

33
00:01:42.877 --> 00:01:47.055
plugging them in and adding more computers
to your network than what you allow.

34
00:01:47.055 --> 00:01:50.070
Right?
If you've got a voiceover IP phone, and

35
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:52.320
you know it's got two jacks on it,
a in and out.

36
00:01:52.320 --> 00:01:55.080
A lot of them do, so
you can daisy chain your computer off it.

37
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:57.310
But you don't want people
to use that feature.

38
00:01:57.310 --> 00:02:00.440
You could set that port to have
a maximum one MAC address.

39
00:02:00.440 --> 00:02:03.330
And if anybody ever plugged
a second device into that phone,

40
00:02:03.330 --> 00:02:06.270
that would be a second MAC address, and
it wouldn't be allowed to communicate.

41
00:02:06.270 --> 00:02:07.560
It'd be stopped, right?

42
00:02:07.560 --> 00:02:11.780
That's what port security allows us to do,
and it's really effective.

43
00:02:11.780 --> 00:02:15.810
It's just a little cumbersome to get
configured and kind of put in place.

44
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:17.720
So I wanna show you guys that,
kinda how it works,

45
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:21.190
what we can do with it, and you'll see
it's a pretty straightforward practice.

46
00:02:21.190 --> 00:02:24.680
Most of you guys have already seen
this one, so for those of you,

47
00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:26.100
it's more of a refresher.

48
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:28.870
But it's on the exam, so
something we wanna learn.

49
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:32.370
So I'll just take my core switch here and
we'll jump in and kinda see one of those

50
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:36.450
quick configurations If I take
a look at it here, I've got.

51
00:02:36.450 --> 00:02:42.180
We'll target that same router that I've
been messing with this whole series.

52
00:02:42.180 --> 00:02:43.520
On my port fa1/0/2.

53
00:02:43.520 --> 00:02:46.310
That port has a connection to a router.

54
00:02:46.310 --> 00:02:49.370
And that router is up and
running, you know?

55
00:02:49.370 --> 00:02:50.910
It's the one that we were
doing ARP inspection, and

56
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:52.540
all those other things on earlier.

57
00:02:52.540 --> 00:02:56.110
And it's just, it's a regular old system,
it's out there.

58
00:02:56.110 --> 00:02:58.110
It's got an IP address and
it's communicating.

59
00:02:58.110 --> 00:03:00.200
And I wanna make sure that it's
the only one that's there.

60
00:03:00.200 --> 00:03:02.600
Now, we normally configure
this on access ports,

61
00:03:02.600 --> 00:03:04.930
you don't normally do
port security on a trunk.

62
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:07.320
Because a trunk, well it,

63
00:03:07.320 --> 00:03:11.400
a trunk is going to have more than one
MAC that's on it pretty normally, right?

64
00:03:11.400 --> 00:03:12.440
Even an uplink well, right?

65
00:03:12.440 --> 00:03:13.800
You can spot those really easy.

66
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:17.650
If you do a,
show mac address table, right?

67
00:03:17.650 --> 00:03:19.530
When you look at your MAC address table,
you'll see,

68
00:03:19.530 --> 00:03:22.220
well you'll see all the static ones for
the switchboards, right?

69
00:03:22.220 --> 00:03:24.540
But after that, you'll see your dynamics.

70
00:03:24.540 --> 00:03:26.600
And you can spot uplinks really easy.

71
00:03:26.600 --> 00:03:28.950
Because you'll have more than one port.

72
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:32.280
Oh sorry, one port with more than one MAC
address if you are seeing more than one

73
00:03:32.280 --> 00:03:35.510
MAC address what does that mean it usually
means that someone brought a switch or

74
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:39.080
a hub and stuck it on the end and that's
why you are seeing more than one mac

75
00:03:39.080 --> 00:03:41.680
address, but
this is an uplink to one of my switches so

76
00:03:41.680 --> 00:03:43.990
I know that's a trunk
its going to have that.

77
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:46.650
Now, it's not necessarily a trunk,
it could just be an uplink.

78
00:03:46.650 --> 00:03:49.740
The difference is a trunk carries
more than one VLAN, right?

79
00:03:49.740 --> 00:03:53.860
I'm only seeing VLAN1 over here, if I
saw more than one VLAN on the same port,

80
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:54.960
I would know it was a trunk.

81
00:03:54.960 --> 00:03:58.740
That's the only time, you should
see more than one VLAN on a port.

82
00:03:58.740 --> 00:04:03.190
So, if I want to take a port and lock it
down, like fa1/0/2, that's an access port.

83
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:07.620
I've got a router on the other end of it,
but let's just say it's a workstation.

84
00:04:07.620 --> 00:04:11.090
And I only want that one MAC address
to be able to communicate there.

85
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:12.650
Well, I can go in and I can limit it.

86
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:14.640
Or maybe it's not even
about being specific.

87
00:04:14.640 --> 00:04:16.580
I just don't want more
than one MAC address.

88
00:04:16.580 --> 00:04:20.530
I just want it to be held to one system
and it can't plug in a hub, right?

89
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:21.560
Or switch.

90
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:23.000
So, I can jump into my configuration.

91
00:04:23.000 --> 00:04:29.840
I can get into fa1/0/2 and I can come
in here and I can tell it, switchport.

92
00:04:29.840 --> 00:04:31.800
Well, I do need to make sure
it's an access port here.

93
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:35.130
So I'll do a switchboard mode access
just to make sure, it already is.

94
00:04:35.130 --> 00:04:39.074
And then I'll say
switchport port-security.

95
00:04:40.130 --> 00:04:42.780
ANd then how I want to configure
this is kind of up to me.

96
00:04:42.780 --> 00:04:45.830
If I am just trying to stop
people from bringing in switches.

97
00:04:45.830 --> 00:04:47.130
I can just say maximum one.

98
00:04:48.140 --> 00:04:50.960
And that's going to set it so
that this port,

99
00:04:50.960 --> 00:04:56.060
if it ever has more than one MAC address
that's going to create a violation.

100
00:04:56.060 --> 00:04:58.700
And I just need to add a little more
to finish this off before it actually

101
00:04:58.700 --> 00:04:59.440
works, right.

102
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:03.440
I need to say, switchport, port-security,

103
00:05:03.440 --> 00:05:06.900
violation, and
what do I want to do about it, right?

104
00:05:06.900 --> 00:05:09.740
So somebody brings in a switch,
what am I gonna do?

105
00:05:09.740 --> 00:05:11.630
I got a few choices, right?

106
00:05:11.630 --> 00:05:14.650
My choices boil down to,
just down to three, right?

107
00:05:14.650 --> 00:05:15.620
Protect.

108
00:05:15.620 --> 00:05:20.220
Protect means I want to stop
this from happening, right?

109
00:05:20.220 --> 00:05:26.540
So if somebody jumps in and has more than
one MAC address, I want to know about it.

110
00:05:26.540 --> 00:05:29.250
Protect me as I'm gonna get
a little warning about it.

111
00:05:29.250 --> 00:05:32.720
But even though it says protect
it doesn't actually do anything.

112
00:05:32.720 --> 00:05:36.670
It doesn't stop them it still lets
the extra MAC addresses get on there, but

113
00:05:36.670 --> 00:05:39.170
I at least know about it.

114
00:05:39.170 --> 00:05:40.300
All right.
Restrict.

115
00:05:40.300 --> 00:05:45.260
That says I'm gonna let the first
MAC address continue to work, but

116
00:05:45.260 --> 00:05:47.890
the second and third and fourth, and
however many other MAC addresses,

117
00:05:47.890 --> 00:05:50.630
I'm gonna stop them,
I'm actually going to restrict them.

118
00:05:50.630 --> 00:05:52.140
That's a little more aggressive.

119
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:53.490
The original host can still talk but

120
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:56.260
when they put that switch in,
the other host won't be able to.

121
00:05:56.260 --> 00:05:58.590
They get a little more protection.

122
00:05:58.590 --> 00:05:59.750
But my favorite?

123
00:05:59.750 --> 00:06:00.640
Shut down.

124
00:06:00.640 --> 00:06:03.940
So if another MAC address
shows up on this board, or

125
00:06:03.940 --> 00:06:07.250
more than one MAC address in this
case I'm gonna shut that port down,

126
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:09.820
and then it's gonna stay shut down
until I do something about it.

127
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:10.800
That's how I'm gonna configure this one.

128
00:06:10.800 --> 00:06:12.300
I'm just gonna say shutdown.

129
00:06:12.300 --> 00:06:14.850
And so if we get a violation that's it,
and I've got one more command I need to

130
00:06:14.850 --> 00:06:20.500
throw in there, which is switchport
port-security and just press enter.

131
00:06:20.500 --> 00:06:21.330
I forget this one all the time.

132
00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:23.080
This one actually turns the stuff on.

133
00:06:23.080 --> 00:06:24.060
Right?
So, I was

134
00:06:24.060 --> 00:06:26.260
adding configuration options before.

135
00:06:26.260 --> 00:06:30.510
But that last command is what
actually gets it up and running and

136
00:06:30.510 --> 00:06:34.250
at this point that port is now monitoring.

137
00:06:34.250 --> 00:06:38.300
And if it sees more than one MAC address
it's going to take some action and

138
00:06:38.300 --> 00:06:40.590
I don't see a lot of that in my config,
right?

139
00:06:40.590 --> 00:06:41.980
Where'd those commands go?

140
00:06:41.980 --> 00:06:45.300
Well maximum one is the default.

141
00:06:45.300 --> 00:06:47.160
And shutdown is the default and

142
00:06:47.160 --> 00:06:49.570
since they're defaults that's
why they don't show up here.

143
00:06:49.570 --> 00:06:50.928
If I had put the other values they would.

144
00:06:50.928 --> 00:06:52.910
But switchport port-security
to turn it on?

145
00:06:52.910 --> 00:06:56.150
That's not a default, and so
that's why that one stayed.

146
00:06:56.150 --> 00:06:57.520
Port security's now on for this port.

147
00:06:57.520 --> 00:06:59.040
>> Yeah, now, Don,
that sounds really cool.

148
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:01.980
I like the way I've got
something plugged into a port,

149
00:07:01.980 --> 00:07:04.900
I've limited it to one
device on that port.

150
00:07:04.900 --> 00:07:08.100
Once that thing gets learned,
anything else comes in,

151
00:07:08.100 --> 00:07:09.450
tries to give me other stuff.

152
00:07:09.450 --> 00:07:13.650
The access in that port is just gonna
shut it off and that's the way I like it.

153
00:07:13.650 --> 00:07:16.900
But, what if the first thing to to
plug in isn't what I want it to be.

154
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:18.690
What if I accidentally
left something plugged in?

155
00:07:18.690 --> 00:07:22.170
And they're like now it's all shut down,
I got a lot of configuration to do,

156
00:07:22.170 --> 00:07:26.070
how can I make it say this
is the device regardless?

157
00:07:26.070 --> 00:07:26.580
>> Great point.

158
00:07:26.580 --> 00:07:29.610
So the problem with how I've
configured it here is I said

159
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:32.240
it's got to be a maximum of
one MAC address all right?

160
00:07:32.240 --> 00:07:36.640
Well if an attacker comes in and
un-plugs a computer, the port goes down.

161
00:07:36.640 --> 00:07:40.300
And when the port goes down,
the MAC address table entry for

162
00:07:40.300 --> 00:07:41.160
it is immediately cleared.

163
00:07:41.160 --> 00:07:42.060
It doesn't even wait for a timer.

164
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:42.930
It just clears it.

165
00:07:42.930 --> 00:07:43.500
Right?

166
00:07:43.500 --> 00:07:46.800
So, when they plug in their computer,
they're the attacker.

167
00:07:46.800 --> 00:07:48.235
It's just one MAC address.

168
00:07:48.235 --> 00:07:50.865
That's going to pass and
port security is not going to stop them.

169
00:07:50.865 --> 00:07:54.308
But what Daniel was saying was what
if I want it to be one Mac address

170
00:07:54.308 --> 00:07:55.632
specifically, right?

171
00:07:55.632 --> 00:08:00.268
Well, if I know the Mac address I can
come in here and I can punch it in.

172
00:08:00.268 --> 00:08:05.124
So when I looked at my MAC address table,
way back when I got started, here.

173
00:08:05.124 --> 00:08:10.250
On Fa1/0/2, this right here was
the MAC address of that router, right?

174
00:08:10.250 --> 00:08:14.510
So if I have it, or if you haven't pulled
it up, I usually do something like this,

175
00:08:14.510 --> 00:08:17.250
just do a do command,
show mac address table.

176
00:08:19.300 --> 00:08:21.150
And I usually do it
a little more gracefully.

177
00:08:21.150 --> 00:08:26.777
And then I just filter it to include
the 1/0/22, the port that I'm looking for.

178
00:08:26.777 --> 00:08:28.577
Oh sorry, /2.

179
00:08:28.577 --> 00:08:32.350
Oh, shoot, it's gonna get,
how can we stop that?

180
00:08:32.350 --> 00:08:33.813
Oh, we can't.

181
00:08:33.813 --> 00:08:35.158
Well, any how.
You guys can see it right there.

182
00:08:35.158 --> 00:08:37.435
[LAUGH] So we can get that MAC address and
we can pull it up.

183
00:08:37.435 --> 00:08:40.095
Or if I know that it ends in fec0,
I can filter.

184
00:08:40.095 --> 00:08:43.300
You can filter various ways to try and
get just the one that you want.

185
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:44.195
There we go.

186
00:08:44.195 --> 00:08:49.515
And so on the port, I can come in here and
I can say, switchport port-security,

187
00:08:49.515 --> 00:08:52.891
and then you can manually
specify the MAC address.

188
00:08:52.891 --> 00:08:59.033
And so I can say mac-address 7c0e, and
I can go in and I can type it, all right?

189
00:08:59.033 --> 00:09:05.220
And if I manually set it,
I set a maximum of one addresses.

190
00:09:05.220 --> 00:09:09.741
And I'm manually setting that address
right here so I'm already at my maximum.

191
00:09:09.741 --> 00:09:12.643
And if somebody unplugs that cable,
the port goes down,

192
00:09:12.643 --> 00:09:16.830
the MAC address table empties,
this command will still be there.

193
00:09:16.830 --> 00:09:21.010
And so when they plug their computer in,
this MAC address is there, and

194
00:09:21.010 --> 00:09:23.790
now their MAC address is there,
and they're in violation.

195
00:09:23.790 --> 00:09:28.739
So now we know it, it's there,
I just have to finish out this command and

196
00:09:28.739 --> 00:09:30.941
it'll be set in stone, right?

197
00:09:30.941 --> 00:09:34.330
That's the MAC address that's
allowed to talk on that port.

198
00:09:35.710 --> 00:09:39.543
Now, when I ran it, I got found
a duplicate MAC address, Right?

199
00:09:39.543 --> 00:09:40.360
What's that about?

200
00:09:40.360 --> 00:09:43.440
Well it's already learned that
MAC address in this port and

201
00:09:43.440 --> 00:09:46.690
it's dynamic, I'm kind of like
statically defining it here, right?

202
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:50.610
So, I probably need to shut the port down
to clear it, and then put this in and

203
00:09:50.610 --> 00:09:51.920
turn the port back on.

204
00:09:51.920 --> 00:09:54.304
That router has this MAC address,
at least I hope it does, and so

205
00:09:54.304 --> 00:09:57.150
then it should be able to get in there and
communicate.

206
00:09:57.150 --> 00:10:00.070
But this does bring up a good
opportunity to show something else,

207
00:10:00.070 --> 00:10:01.588
one of the neater features.

208
00:10:01.588 --> 00:10:04.850
If you're rolling this out for
just one system it's no big deal, but

209
00:10:04.850 --> 00:10:06.490
where do we really need this feature?

210
00:10:06.490 --> 00:10:08.311
We need it on our access ports.

211
00:10:08.311 --> 00:10:11.190
And in a large environment you might
have thousands of access ports.

212
00:10:11.190 --> 00:10:15.130
You might have tons of computers,

We did route maps in the route show.

437
00:21:52.010 --> 00:21:53.860
But here it's called a VLAN map.

438
00:21:53.860 --> 00:21:57.790
And a VLAN map applies to
traffic within a VLAN.

439
00:21:57.790 --> 00:21:58.380
Not routed.

440
00:21:58.380 --> 00:21:59.830
I mean, it can be routed.

441
00:21:59.830 --> 00:22:03.090
But it, routed or not, it's even local
traffic that it's gonna filter and

442
00:22:03.090 --> 00:22:04.370
allow us to protect.

443
00:22:04.370 --> 00:22:07.990
So let's say I have two hosts that
I absolutely do not want to be able

444
00:22:07.990 --> 00:22:08.990
to communicate.

445
00:22:08.990 --> 00:22:09.530
All right.

446
00:22:09.530 --> 00:22:10.830
And they're both on VLAN one.

447
00:22:10.830 --> 00:22:13.510
In other words,
they're not gonna route, right?

448
00:22:13.510 --> 00:22:17.180
So if I take a look at a ny wan one here,
this guy.

449
00:22:17.180 --> 00:22:18.440
Oh, his port is shutdown.

450
00:22:18.440 --> 00:22:22.230
Let me fix his port real quick, otherwise
he's going to have a really boring day.

451
00:22:22.230 --> 00:22:25.820
So on this guy, I shut him down
with that port security, right?

452
00:22:25.820 --> 00:22:27.930
So I'm gonna go and fix that.

453
00:22:28.990 --> 00:22:31.920
So I'll just do a no port-security.

454
00:22:31.920 --> 00:22:32.880
And switchport, port security.

455
00:22:34.979 --> 00:22:41.920
And if I can get this, there we go.

456
00:22:41.920 --> 00:22:44.030
Okay so I'm gonna turn that port back on.

457
00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:46.760
So that he'll be able to communicate.

458
00:22:46.760 --> 00:22:48.940
And that router was 192.168.16.22, right?

459
00:22:51.060 --> 00:22:54.470
And earlier in the show I was
Ping from it over to another IP,

460
00:22:54.470 --> 00:22:59.270
let me just go verify that that still
works since I'm hosing everything up here.

461
00:22:59.270 --> 00:23:04.690
This guy, if we take a look at
our IP here, let's make sure.

462
00:23:04.690 --> 00:23:09.370
It's using DHCP so I have to give it
