463
00:23:09.370 --> 00:23:11.870
as soon as it has it it
will get 192.168.16.22.

464
00:23:11.870 --> 00:23:16.940
And I was pinging to 192.168.16.1,
and it was successful.

465
00:23:16.940 --> 00:23:18.900
Let's say I wanna block that.

466
00:23:18.900 --> 00:23:22.240
I don't wanna allow the communication
between these two hosts.

467
00:23:22.240 --> 00:23:24.390
I can write an ACL that
identifies that traffic,

468
00:23:24.390 --> 00:23:26.510
and I can use a VLAN map to filter it.

469
00:23:26.510 --> 00:23:27.540
There we go, I got my address.

470
00:23:27.540 --> 00:23:30.830
>> Don, wouldn't it just be easier to
stick the two hosts on different VLANs?

471
00:23:30.830 --> 00:23:35.430
>> You certainly could,
unless you actually need it for

472
00:23:35.430 --> 00:23:37.140
some other reason, right?

473
00:23:37.140 --> 00:23:40.000
There could be times where
maybe you've got something like

474
00:23:40.000 --> 00:23:41.420
a router on the network.

475
00:23:41.420 --> 00:23:44.270
And you want all of your hosts to
be able to talk to the router but

476
00:23:44.270 --> 00:23:46.600
you don't want them to be
able to talk to each other.

477
00:23:46.600 --> 00:23:47.895
You can use a VLAN ACL to do that.

478
00:23:47.895 --> 00:23:51.586
This is something that ISP's do a lot when
they have like Metro E networks to try and

479
00:23:51.586 --> 00:23:55.700
protect clients, this is an easy way to do
it and everybody stays within one VLAN.

480
00:23:55.700 --> 00:23:58.400
Right, so there's different reasons
why you might want to do this.

481
00:23:58.400 --> 00:24:01.684
But if I jump in here and try and ping.

482
00:24:01.684 --> 00:24:06.076
So I'm coming from 192.168.16.22.

483
00:24:06.076 --> 00:24:07.610
And I'm going to 192.168.16.1.

484
00:24:07.610 --> 00:24:10.490
And there we go.

485
00:24:10.490 --> 00:24:13.170
I can see that I am able to do that ping.

486
00:24:13.170 --> 00:24:14.230
But I want to stop that.

487
00:24:14.230 --> 00:24:18.825
I don't want this particular router
to be able to get to that host.

488
00:24:18.825 --> 00:24:23.366
So I can jump over to my core switch, and
I can create an ACL that identifies that.

489
00:24:23.366 --> 00:24:28.624
So I'm just gonna jump in here and
I'm going to say access-list and

490
00:24:28.624 --> 00:24:33.810
you can do a named ACL and extended,
you can do whatever you want.

491
00:24:33.810 --> 00:24:38.780
If we want to do something like a named
ACL, those really aren't that hard to do,

492
00:24:38.780 --> 00:24:40.880
and it's kind of the best
way to go these days.

493
00:24:40.880 --> 00:24:46.657
So, if I want to do that I'll just
come in and say IP access-list.

494
00:24:46.657 --> 00:24:52.574
And then I'm gonna call
this one a acl-vlan1.

495
00:24:52.574 --> 00:24:56.490
That router and the host that
it's pinging are both on vlan1.

496
00:24:56.490 --> 00:24:59.300
And this is an ACL I'm gonna
be applying to vlan1, and so

497
00:24:59.300 --> 00:25:01.570
I just wanna name it in a way that I
can remember what it's purpose is.

498
00:25:01.570 --> 00:25:03.140
So I'll just call it ACL vlan1.

499
00:25:03.140 --> 00:25:07.448
And I'm gonna come in here and
specify traffic I wanna match.

500
00:25:07.448 --> 00:25:12.157
And I wanna match, and use permits
to say that you're matching, right.

501
00:25:12.157 --> 00:25:19.136
So I wanna match when 192.168.16.22

502
00:25:19.136 --> 00:25:24.824
is going to 192.168.16.1.

503
00:25:24.824 --> 00:25:26.880
All right,
when those two hosts are talking.

504
00:25:26.880 --> 00:25:30.910
Now, I could go further and specify
equaling certain ports or whatever,

505
00:25:30.910 --> 00:25:33.880
but I just want to kill these
two hosts altogether, right?

506
00:25:33.880 --> 00:25:38.700
And so I'm gonna permit IP for that, okay.

507
00:25:38.700 --> 00:25:42.460
Now, be careful on this because
sometimes you've got protocols like

508
00:25:42.460 --> 00:25:46.320
ping that fall outside of it and
see how I've got icmp right there?

509
00:25:46.320 --> 00:25:49.100
And so you might need to add
a little bit more to it.

510
00:25:49.100 --> 00:25:52.520
If I just do IP that gets tcp and udp.

511
00:25:52.520 --> 00:25:54.230
But icmp is kind of special,

512
00:25:54.230 --> 00:25:58.590
so I might need to match on that also
if I want to go a little bit further.

513
00:25:58.590 --> 00:26:01.080
But, in my case, I'm really just
trying to match the IP address, so

514
00:26:01.080 --> 00:26:02.270
this will work for me.

515
00:26:02.270 --> 00:26:03.740
>> Looks like it can go
the opposite way as well.

516
00:26:03.740 --> 00:26:06.400
If I just wanted to allow tcp,
I could do that and not udp.

517
00:26:06.400 --> 00:26:08.130
>> Yeah, you can be really specific.

518
00:26:08.130 --> 00:26:11.520
And, you mentioned you're
doing it the other way.

519
00:26:11.520 --> 00:26:14.210
VLAN ACLs are kind of magical,
cuz you're not being routed.

520
00:26:14.210 --> 00:26:17.040
So you don't come from one interface and
go to another interface.

521
00:26:17.040 --> 00:26:20.270
And that means that these ACLs apply
to traffic in both directions.

522
00:26:20.270 --> 00:26:24.330
And so, I need to write
the inverse of what I just did,

523
00:26:24.330 --> 00:26:26.020
to make this actually work.

524
00:26:26.020 --> 00:26:28.990
So I'm gonna add one more line, which it's
really just gonna be the same as the line

525
00:26:28.990 --> 00:26:31.110
above except, I'm gonna flip the IP.

526
00:26:31.110 --> 00:26:35.250
So, this is gonna be dot one,
going to dot 22.

527
00:26:35.250 --> 00:26:38.629
So, on the first one I did,
dot 22 going to dot one, and

528
00:26:38.629 --> 00:26:42.867
on the second line I'm doing the other
way around, dot one to dot 22.

529
00:26:42.867 --> 00:26:45.449
To get both directions of the traffic,
right.

530
00:26:45.449 --> 00:26:48.491
VLAN ACLs apply to both directions so
you gotta write both ways.

531
00:26:48.491 --> 00:26:51.570
That's a lot different then regular ACLs.

532
00:26:51.570 --> 00:26:54.870
So now I'm gonna match that traffic,
all right?

533
00:26:54.870 --> 00:26:58.350
I don't want anybody else to match this,
and so there is a like an implicit deny

534
00:26:58.350 --> 00:27:02.440
all, but you can punch one in if
you want to be on the safe side.

535
00:27:02.440 --> 00:27:04.866
We can just kinda fill
that in if you want.

536
00:27:04.866 --> 00:27:06.779
Usually we do that if you want
to tack logging onto it, or

537
00:27:06.779 --> 00:27:08.260
whatever to get a record of it, all right.

538
00:27:10.250 --> 00:27:11.950
Now I've got an ACL, all right.

539
00:27:11.950 --> 00:27:16.537
And if I do a show access-list, I can
see it and it's just matching those two

540
00:27:16.537 --> 00:27:19.850
communications and
it's not matching anybody else.

541
00:27:20.920 --> 00:27:22.970
I'm not gonna attach this ACL though.

542
00:27:22.970 --> 00:27:26.324
I need to create a map that applies it,
and here's where things get different.

543
00:27:26.324 --> 00:27:31.574
I'm gonna jump in here and
I'm gonna say vlan access-map, all right.

544
00:27:31.574 --> 00:27:32.606
Not an access list,

545
00:27:32.606 --> 00:27:37.242
an access map, right that's the difference
right that's what makes these things work.

546
00:27:37.242 --> 00:27:40.658
And so I'm gonna punch that in here and
I am gonna give it a name, and

547
00:27:40.658 --> 00:27:43.116
I'll just call this map-vlan1, all right.

548
00:27:43.116 --> 00:27:47.310
And like a named ACL, like a route map
they have line numbers that identify them,

549
00:27:47.310 --> 00:27:51.379
and if you just leave it at the default
the first one will be ten, and then 20,

550
00:27:51.379 --> 00:27:52.199
and then 30.

551
00:27:52.199 --> 00:27:54.482
I usually like to type them in
just to be on the safe side, but

552
00:27:54.482 --> 00:27:56.500
that's certainly optional.

553
00:27:56.500 --> 00:27:57.760
Then I can specify what I want to do.

554
00:27:57.760 --> 00:28:00.117
And I want a match based
on that IP address.

555
00:28:00.117 --> 00:28:06.741
And so I'm gonna say,
match IP address acl-vlan1, okay.

556
00:28:06.741 --> 00:28:10.045
So I want to match traffic that's
from that's from that ACL, and

557
00:28:10.045 --> 00:28:11.890
my action is gonna be drop.

558
00:28:11.890 --> 00:28:14.360
I'm gonna drop that traffic, all right?

559
00:28:14.360 --> 00:28:15.450
Then I'm gonna add another line.

560
00:28:15.450 --> 00:28:18.020
If I stop right there,
this one will apply.

561
00:28:18.020 --> 00:28:20.610
It'll drop that traffic, and
there's nothing else to match on.

562
00:28:20.610 --> 00:28:23.640
And so every bit of traffic
will be dropped from then on.

563
00:28:23.640 --> 00:28:25.995
So, I need to add one more line.

564
00:28:25.995 --> 00:28:29.695
So I'll do this vlan
access-map map-vlan1 20.

565
00:28:29.695 --> 00:28:33.215
And on this one,
I'm not gonna do a match statement at all.

566
00:28:33.215 --> 00:28:36.225
And if you don't do a match statement,
it means it matches everything.

567
00:28:36.225 --> 00:28:39.455
And I'll set the action to forward,
all right?

568
00:28:39.455 --> 00:28:41.815
I'm gonna drop traffic
that matches the ACL, so

569
00:28:41.815 --> 00:28:47.225
the traffic between those two hosts,
I'm gonna forward everything else, okay.

570
00:28:47.225 --> 00:28:50.350
So that should be pretty
much all I need there.

571
00:28:50.350 --> 00:28:54.930
The last thing I need to do,
is to attach this to the vlan itself.

572
00:28:54.930 --> 00:28:56.430
I stop here, I'm not done.

573
00:28:56.430 --> 00:28:59.570
So, I need to say, and this is
a command that's completely unique.

574
00:28:59.570 --> 00:29:04.360
We need to say vlan filter,
and then attach that map.

575
00:29:04.360 --> 00:29:08.020
So, I'll say map-vlan1.

576
00:29:08.020 --> 00:29:12.120
And then, you can actually attach
a map to more than one vlan.

577
00:29:12.120 --> 00:29:16.640
So you have to say vlan-list, and
then which vlans this attaches to.

578
00:29:16.640 --> 00:29:18.010
I'm just doing vlan1.

579
00:29:18.010 --> 00:29:20.490
But you can use commas and
hyphens to specify ranges and

580
00:29:20.490 --> 00:29:22.000
apply this to more than one.

581
00:29:22.000 --> 00:29:27.350
And when I attach that, now all
traffic passing through vlan1, whether

582
00:29:27.350 --> 00:29:31.770
it's getting routed or not, even local
traffic is gonna pass through this filter.

583
00:29:31.770 --> 00:29:34.310
And if it matches we're gonna kill it and
stop it, and

584
00:29:34.310 --> 00:29:36.150
that's gonna be the end of it, all right?

585
00:29:36.150 --> 00:29:41.280
So, when this is done, I should no
longer be able to communicate, right?

586
00:29:41.280 --> 00:29:44.210
The traffic shouldn't match up,
and I shouldn't be able to do it.

587
00:29:44.210 --> 00:29:50.630
If I jump over to NYWAN1, this guy who was
successfully pinging just a moment ago,

588
00:29:50.630 --> 00:29:55.110
if I repeat that ping,
its not working, right?

589
00:29:55.110 --> 00:29:59.280
Its not hitting and its because
we've got that vlan filter in place.

590
00:29:59.280 --> 00:30:02.070
So, its neat way to restrict traffic or
permit traffic,

591
00:30:02.070 --> 00:30:05.140
you could permit just certain things and
drop everything else.

592
00:30:05.140 --> 00:30:09.770
You can really get a lot of control here,
even on non-routed traffic.

593
00:30:09.770 --> 00:30:11.280
Now, be careful with this.

594
00:30:11.280 --> 00:30:14.610
Because non-routed traffic
that's all within a vlan,

595
00:30:14.610 --> 00:30:16.500
the switch doesn't normally
get very involved in it.

596
00:30:16.500 --> 00:30:18.630
It looks at the layer two header and
that's it.

597
00:30:18.630 --> 00:30:22.340
Now, I'm having to look at least the layer
three header caused I've matched some IPs.

598
00:30:22.340 --> 00:30:23.990
And if I went even further on ports,

599
00:30:23.990 --> 00:30:25.600
you can start to get some
performance degradation.

600
00:30:25.600 --> 00:30:26.990
So just keep an eye on that.

601
00:30:26.990 --> 00:30:29.090
But otherwise it's a great technology and

602
00:30:29.090 --> 00:30:30.850
another wonderful way
to filter that traffic.

603
00:30:30.850 --> 00:30:32.370
>> Very cool stuff, Don.

Now we've gone through quite a few
different ways in which we can secure our

605
00:30:35.540 --> 00:30:39.590

the switch security that we've looked at.

00:30:39.590 --> 00:30:43.165
We got a little bit more to cover, and

00:30:43.165 --> 00:30:44.190

>> We do thank you for

00:30:44.190 --> 00:30:46.660

being on the show today.

00:30:46.660 --> 00:30:48.050

00:30:48.050 --> 00:30:50.370
Hopefully we'll see you in part four.

611
00:30:50.370 --> 00:30:51.520
As we'll see everybody else.

00:30:51.520 --> 00:30:55.532

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel finish out the switch security series with Private VLANs and Storm Control. Here they explain how you can use Private VLANs to isolate devices that are sharing the same switch without needing to route as in traditional VLANs. Then they finish by explaining how you can use Storm Control to eliminate accidental, or intentional broadcast storms.

are basically broadcast storms anyway.

722
00:35:48.570 --> 00:35:51.830
And so, those types of things
would happen because hubs repeat

723
00:35:51.830 --> 00:35:55.310
everything in a loop on your network and
could drive everything crazy.

724
00:35:55.310 --> 00:35:59.640
In today's modern networks, thanks to
things like spanning tree protocol and

725
00:35:59.640 --> 00:36:01.980
layer three switches and

726
00:36:01.980 --> 00:36:06.040
VLANs we don't normally have
broadcast norms anymore, all right?

727
00:36:06.040 --> 00:36:08.930
But if you're on a network that's poorly
designed, maybe one you adopted and

728
00:36:08.930 --> 00:36:12.030
it's not your fault but
you've got to deal with it and support it.

729
00:36:12.030 --> 00:36:15.800
You can actually configure
special switches to watch out for

730
00:36:15.800 --> 00:36:17.010
excessive broadcasts.

731
00:36:17.010 --> 00:36:20.550
And if it sees excessive broadcasts
it can trim them off and

732
00:36:20.550 --> 00:36:23.910
stop your network from being brought
down when you have a broadcast storm.

733
00:36:23.910 --> 00:36:27.100
They just keep rattling around and around
in your network, building and building and

734
00:36:27.100 --> 00:36:30.960
building, consuming all your
bandwidth until your network falls.

735
00:36:30.960 --> 00:36:33.420
Here we can stop it before
you get to that point.

736
00:36:33.420 --> 00:36:36.470
You still have a problem, its still
something you need to address, but

737
00:36:36.470 --> 00:36:38.680
this will stop it from
downing your network.

738
00:36:38.680 --> 00:36:42.600
Storm control is supported on really
every Cisco switch I've ever touched.

739
00:36:42.600 --> 00:36:44.880
So I haven't run into one
that didn't support it.

740
00:36:44.880 --> 00:36:48.550
And you basically go into an interface,
and you set limits.

741
00:36:48.550 --> 00:36:52.070
And you can define exactly how much
traffic you want to allow, and

742
00:36:52.070 --> 00:36:53.430
there's a few different ways to do it.

743
00:36:53.430 --> 00:36:57.610
Let me show you here on an actual switch,
cuz it's easier to see with the commands.

744
00:36:57.610 --> 00:37:01.360
If I jump into a port, and
it could be a trunk port,

745
00:37:01.360 --> 00:37:05.480
it could be a regular port, just
whatever it is that you wanna work with.

746
00:37:05.480 --> 00:37:08.130
So I'll jump into one of
my random ports here.

747
00:37:08.130 --> 00:37:10.830
And you run storm-control, question mark.

748
00:37:10.830 --> 00:37:15.010
You'll see the different types
of storm control we can do.

749
00:37:15.010 --> 00:37:17.310
And I mentioned broadcast and multicast.

750
00:37:17.310 --> 00:37:20.700
For the most part, those are the two
stories we need to watch out for but

751
00:37:20.700 --> 00:37:22.760
you'll see Unicast is in here also.

752
00:37:22.760 --> 00:37:26.410
Now, if you're having a Unicast storm,
that's almost always an attack,

753
00:37:26.410 --> 00:37:28.350
somebody trying to VLAN hop or whatever.

754
00:37:28.350 --> 00:37:32.620
It's not a good thing but
it has that spore, you can use it.

755
00:37:32.620 --> 00:37:34.330
I've never used that in production.

756
00:37:34.330 --> 00:37:36.810
But Broadcast and
Multicast on the other hand,

757
00:37:36.810 --> 00:37:40.130
those they can storm in it pretty is if
you still have hubs or if your network,

758
00:37:40.130 --> 00:37:44.810
has too many hosts in a single VLAN,
you can end up with problems there.

759
00:37:44.810 --> 00:37:48.680
Or if a Mac address table gets full,
you can start to have problems.

760
00:37:48.680 --> 00:37:52.300
So we can start to enforce that
right here, you set your limits for

761
00:37:52.300 --> 00:37:55.585
broadcast and multicast and
then you set an action.

762
00:37:55.585 --> 00:37:59.535
With storm control you've got a few
options to pick from, shutdown and

763
00:37:59.535 --> 00:38:00.875
trap, all right.

764
00:38:00.875 --> 00:38:05.965
Shutdown says if I start to see
excessive broadcast or Unicast or

765
00:38:05.965 --> 00:38:10.490
whatever I'm gonna shut the port down, and
that's gonna stop your storm, isn't it?

766
00:38:10.490 --> 00:38:11.970
So that's one way to do it.

767
00:38:11.970 --> 00:38:15.730
Now, if you have many switches and
you start shutting a port down,

768
00:38:15.730 --> 00:38:16.980
that's gonna segment your network.

769
00:38:16.980 --> 00:38:20.260
So it's not unnoticed,
people will see that that's happened.

770
00:38:20.260 --> 00:38:22.370
But at least,
you still have some functionality and

771
00:38:22.370 --> 00:38:24.040
the storm has been stopped.

772
00:38:24.040 --> 00:38:27.470
Storm's almost always caused by
an accidental loop in the network and

773
00:38:27.470 --> 00:38:28.820
spanning tree should catch it.

774
00:38:28.820 --> 00:38:30.655
But if spanning tree doesn't
catch it this sure will.

775
00:38:30.655 --> 00:38:32.300
Cuz it will shut that port off and
that loop is gone.

776
00:38:33.910 --> 00:38:37.100
The other option is trap and with trap
it just generates an SNMP trap and

777
00:38:37.100 --> 00:38:38.550
it will send it to a monitoring server.

778
00:38:38.550 --> 00:38:41.630
So you might have something like
Solar Winds Network Performance Monitor.

779
00:38:41.630 --> 00:38:43.290
And it can receive that, and catch it, and

780
00:38:43.290 --> 00:38:46.660
then you get an alert that lets you know,
and you can go and start to address it.

781
00:38:46.660 --> 00:38:51.010
So that's more of like a monitoring
instead of an actual rich.

782
00:38:51.010 --> 00:38:51.510
>> Can you do both?

783
00:38:51.510 --> 00:38:53.560
>> No, it's kind of tied to one or
the other.

784
00:38:53.560 --> 00:38:54.170
>> One or the other.

785
00:38:54.170 --> 00:38:56.132
>> Yes, it depends on how
aggressive you want to be.

786
00:38:56.132 --> 00:38:59.850
You sorta can do both, if you have
something, like I mentioned solar wind.

787
00:38:59.850 --> 00:39:04.110
They have it where if it receives an SNMP
trap, that it can take certain actions.

788
00:39:04.110 --> 00:39:05.980
So you could have it turn around and
do a shut down.

789
00:39:05.980 --> 00:39:09.340
But the reason that they don't do both
is that If you shut the port down,

790
00:39:09.340 --> 00:39:14.840
you might not be able to send the trap and
so it kind of one or the other.

791
00:39:14.840 --> 00:39:18.940
So, I'll just set mine to trap and we'll
put that in place, so if I do have one,

792
00:39:18.940 --> 00:39:19.480
that's what I"ll do.

793
00:39:19.480 --> 00:39:23.950
Or I could just step it over to shut
down and put that one in place.

794
00:39:23.950 --> 00:39:26.960
So, now I need to configure
the actual limits and

795
00:39:26.960 --> 00:39:28.530
all three of these
are configured the same way.

796
00:39:28.530 --> 00:39:31.970
So, you might do all three
limits on one interface.

797
00:39:31.970 --> 00:39:34.170
Or you might wanna do just broadcast and
multicast, but

798
00:39:34.170 --> 00:39:36.100
the syntax is actually the same.

799
00:39:36.100 --> 00:39:39.750
So, what we do is we come in and
we say storm-control.

800
00:39:39.750 --> 00:39:42.940
And then which of these communication
types we wanna protect from,

801
00:39:42.940 --> 00:39:45.200
normally it's broadcast, right.

802
00:39:45.200 --> 00:39:48.040
And then from there,
you specify the level.

803
00:39:48.040 --> 00:39:51.410
Now the level can be one of three things.

804
00:39:51.410 --> 00:39:53.630
It can be a percentage of bandwidth.

805
00:39:53.630 --> 00:39:57.663
If I see that 30% or more of my bandwidth
is a broadcast, that's a storm.

806
00:39:57.663 --> 00:40:00.405
Or 80% of my bandwidth is a broadcast,
that's a storm.

807
00:40:00.405 --> 00:40:02.422
So you can do it just based
on what's called Level.

808
00:40:02.422 --> 00:40:04.380
Level is that percentage of bandwidth.

809
00:40:04.380 --> 00:40:08.600
Or you can do packets per second.

810
00:40:08.600 --> 00:40:13.100
I can say, if I'm receiving more than
1,000 broadcast packets per second,

811
00:40:13.100 --> 00:40:15.270
that's a storm, right.

812
00:40:15.270 --> 00:40:19.079
Or you can do bits per second, right,
measuring the actual bandwidth.

813
00:40:19.079 --> 00:40:24.240
If I see more than 500 bits per second
of broadcast, then that's a storm.

814
00:40:24.240 --> 00:40:25.140
So we define that.

815
00:40:25.140 --> 00:40:29.520
But the very first keyword we have is
level, regardless of what we're doing.

816
00:40:29.520 --> 00:40:32.670
So even if the level is a percentage of
bandwidth, we always start with this one.

817
00:40:32.670 --> 00:40:36.210
But after that,
You can specify the percentage right here.

818
00:40:36.210 --> 00:40:37.200
So, I can say 80.

819
00:40:37.200 --> 00:40:41.050
And if I were to press enter right now,
then

820
00:40:41.050 --> 00:40:45.480
if it sees more than 80% of my bandwidth
as a broadcast, it's a storm, right.

821
00:40:45.480 --> 00:40:47.470
That's probably a little
on the high side there but

822
00:40:47.470 --> 00:40:50.270
some networks do have a high broadcast,
right.

823
00:40:50.270 --> 00:40:54.320
Or I can delete that, and if I say PPS,

824
00:40:54.320 --> 00:40:59.030
now it's packets per second, or
BPS, that's bits per second, right.

825
00:40:59.030 --> 00:41:01.370
So, I can tell it which
one I wanna monitor.

826
00:41:01.370 --> 00:41:05.190
With all three you have what's
called a rising threshold and

827
00:41:05.190 --> 00:41:08.520
a falling threshold, so that the first
number that you specify here,

828
00:41:08.520 --> 00:41:13.380
like if I say 60, right, level 60,
that means if 60% of my bandwidth or

829
00:41:13.380 --> 00:41:16.940
more is a broadcast, then this is
gonna be considered a storm, right.

830
00:41:16.940 --> 00:41:18.250
That's my rising threshold.

831
00:41:18.250 --> 00:41:22.650
As the bandwidth rises to that point,
now we got a storm, okay.

832
00:41:22.650 --> 00:41:27.610
If you just stop right there, the rising
and falling thresholds are set the same.

833
00:41:27.610 --> 00:41:31.390
But I can come back and
specify a falling threshold also.

834
00:41:31.390 --> 00:41:36.390
And if I have the interface set to shut
down, then it can keep kinda monitoring,

835
00:41:36.390 --> 00:41:40.230
well, actually if it was shut down,
it really kinda dies, but if you do SNMP,

836
00:41:40.230 --> 00:41:45.080
we can keep monitoring and it can watch
for when it falls to a certain level.

837
00:41:45.080 --> 00:41:48.310
And if it reaches a certain falling level,
then it can clear the error, right.

838
00:41:48.310 --> 00:41:50.160
It's really useful with SNMP.

839
00:41:50.160 --> 00:41:53.480
Now we don't normally, well,
you can set them to be the same, but

840
00:41:53.480 --> 00:41:58.290
if it's one of those fluctuating, and
it goes, maybe, 58 to 62, down to 58,

841
00:41:58.290 --> 00:42:01.160
up to 62, then you're just
gonna get a ton of messages.

842
00:42:01.160 --> 00:42:05.910
So, I might wanna set a falling
level that is lower than this one.

843
00:42:05.910 --> 00:42:10.030
Don't clear the error until we're
below 40% broadcast, right.

844
00:42:10.030 --> 00:42:12.760
And that gives me a little buffer room
to stop from getting excessive error

845
00:42:12.760 --> 00:42:15.800
messages or
alerts on an SNMP system, right?

846
00:42:15.800 --> 00:42:18.420
So, the rising and falling threshold,
the falling is optional.

847
00:42:18.420 --> 00:42:21.370
The rising is the important one,
cuz that's when the alert is thrown or

848
00:42:21.370 --> 00:42:22.770
the port gets shut down, right.

849
00:42:22.770 --> 00:42:26.350
If the port gets shut down,
are we able to communicate over it?

850
00:42:26.350 --> 00:42:27.458
Not really.

851
00:42:27.458 --> 00:42:31.363
It is error disabled, so technically, the
switch could look at it, but it treats it

852
00:42:31.363 --> 00:42:35.103
as shut down, so it never really clears
the error, unless you have error disable

853
00:42:35.103 --> 00:42:38.571
recovery turned on, which we talked
about in one of the earlier episodes.

854
00:42:38.571 --> 00:42:41.631
And then, every so often,
it'll turn the port back on to try it and

855
00:42:41.631 --> 00:42:45.567
see if it meets our thresholds, and that's
where the following threshold comes in,

856
00:42:45.567 --> 00:42:47.831
if you're using the shut down command,
right.

857
00:42:47.831 --> 00:42:49.971
So, that's how we define that.

858
00:42:49.971 --> 00:42:52.730
And here, I would basically be saying 60%

859
00:42:52.730 --> 00:42:56.250
of my bandwidth is where I
wanna throw up for a broadcast.

860
00:42:56.250 --> 00:43:04.430
I might mix and match these, and say from
multicast, I wanna do, packets per second.

861
00:43:04.430 --> 00:43:10.970
And I'll say, if I get to 1,000 packets
per second, that's a multicast storm.

862
00:43:10.970 --> 00:43:12.690
Or if I set a following one,

863
00:43:12.690 --> 00:43:15.703
right, maybe I set it to 800 packets
per second, is my following, right.

864
00:43:15.703 --> 00:43:20.215
Oops, actually you know what, multicasting
is one of those special ones, isn't it?

865

00:43:22.365 --> 00:43:25.455
Oh, no, I just left off my level

00:43:25.455 --> 00:43:28.429

00:43:33.200 --> 00:43:34.342
There we go.
All right, so

00:43:34.342 --> 00:43:37.606
now I got my multicast set, and
then I might do the same thing for

872
00:43:37.606 --> 00:43:40.701
unicast, right, so can come in and
specify unicast also.

873
00:43:40.701 --> 00:43:44.541
And on this one,
I might do bits per second, and

874
00:43:44.541 --> 00:43:49.437
I've got 100 megabit interface,
and so 100 megabits

875
00:43:49.437 --> 00:43:54.339
in bits is 100 million, so
maybe I say like 95 million.

876
00:43:57.019 --> 00:43:57.950
Is that right?

877
00:43:57.950 --> 00:44:00.880
Is that 95 mega bit?

00:44:00.880 --> 00:44:01.515

>> Is it?

00:44:01.515 --> 00:44:02.140
I'm bad at math.

880
00:44:02.140 --> 00:44:02.640

00:44:03.140 --> 00:44:05.268

00:44:05.268 --> 00:44:07.293
If I'm seeing more than 95 megabit in

00:44:07.293 --> 00:44:09.305

00:44:09.305 --> 00:44:11.825
it may just be that I'm using my network,

00:44:11.825 --> 00:44:14.285
But I can treat that as a unicast storm.

00:44:14.285 --> 00:44:16.983
Like I said, I haven't used

00:44:21.410 --> 00:44:25.200

00:45:09.360 --> 00:45:10.940
Now I'm running storm control.

00:45:10.940 --> 00:45:15.380
And so, if these events happen, it'll take

00:45:15.380 --> 00:45:18.100

00:45:18.100 --> 00:45:19.660

00:45:19.660 --> 00:45:21.110

00:45:21.110 --> 00:45:25.150

00:45:25.150 --> 00:45:26.560
You can turn it on, and
if it's monitoring,

00:45:27.570 --> 00:45:30.430

00:45:30.430 --> 00:45:33.330

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain how you can set up your switch network to survive a failure using the Hot-Standby Redundancy Protocol (HSRP). 00:22:04.420 --> 00:22:06.060

00:22:06.060 --> 00:22:08.720
They did kind of tweak the way

00:22:08.720 --> 00:22:10.770

00:22:10.770 --> 00:22:13.130
So if you support version 2,

00:22:13.130 --> 00:22:16.620
But your not going to see any huge

448
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:20.750
So, that's basically

00:22:20.750 --> 00:22:21.890
getting it kind of put in place.

00:22:22.960 --> 00:22:24.620

00:22:25.910 --> 00:22:30.195

cuz right now it's not

00:22:37.409 --> 00:22:41.668

00:23:37.592 --> 00:23:39.380

00:23:39.380 --> 00:23:40.998

00:23:40.998 --> 00:23:44.701
I'm gonna start talking to the network,
well I'm gonna listen first and

00:23:44.701 --> 00:23:46.082

00:23:46.082 --> 00:23:50.326

00:23:50.326 --> 00:23:51.841
do you guys need a backup?

00:23:51.841 --> 00:23:54.093
And then I should go
into the standby state.

480
00:23:54.093 --> 00:23:57.543
Or if there's already an active and
a standby then I'll just keep speaking and

00:23:57.543 --> 00:23:58.598

482
00:23:58.598 --> 00:24:02.568
So I can see I just went

483
00:24:02.568 --> 00:24:08.064
And if I do a show standby, I can look at

00:24:08.064 --> 00:24:13.420
change, my Virtual IP is 192.168.16.20,

00:24:13.420 --> 00:24:17.800
And if I look down here, I can see

00:24:17.800 --> 00:24:21.240
that's my other switch.

00:24:21.240 --> 00:24:27.741

00:24:27.741 --> 00:24:30.436
So I now have a true cluster.

489
00:24:30.436 --> 00:24:34.543
If one of the other switches, or

00:24:34.543 --> 00:24:36.660
I would take over, okay.

491
00:24:36.660 --> 00:24:38.810
Now, let me show you kinda

492
00:24:38.810 --> 00:24:43.360
If I jump over to my other switch,

493
00:24:43.360 --> 00:24:45.810
Well, it's gonna be one of two things,
right.

494
00:24:45.810 --> 00:24:49.510
If the whole switch were to fail, if I
were to yank the power plug out of it,

495
00:24:49.510 --> 00:24:50.944
right, that's a failure,

496
00:24:50.944 --> 00:24:54.379
that'll cause it to flip over, or
if the VLAN interface goes down.

497
00:24:54.379 --> 00:24:56.140
Now, when's your VLAN
interface gonna go down?

498
00:24:57.480 --> 00:25:00.898
Never really is, right,
if it has no ports active in that VLAN.

499
00:25:00.898 --> 00:25:04.760
But if you've got at least one trunk, it
should always be up so it's not realistic.

500
00:25:04.760 --> 00:25:07.475
But I'm gonna to down the VLAN
interface just to show you guys.

501
00:25:08.545 --> 00:25:11.775
So if I go into int vlan 1 and
do a shutdown,

502
00:25:11.775 --> 00:25:16.305
all right, this guy can't be active
anymore cuz it just lost its interface.

503
00:25:16.305 --> 00:25:18.645
And so you'll see some status
messages coming up and

504
00:25:18.645 --> 00:25:22.960
I can see my Grp 1 state
went from Active to Init.

505
00:25:22.960 --> 00:25:24.711
So I'm now down as the active.

506
00:25:24.711 --> 00:25:29.029
And if I switch back over to my other
switch, I'm gonna switch switches,

507
00:25:29.029 --> 00:25:32.490
you'll see I got a status
message right there.

508
00:25:32.490 --> 00:25:34.470
Grp 1 state went from Standby to Active.

509
00:25:35.580 --> 00:25:37.796
And your work stations,
they don't even know this happened.

510
00:25:37.796 --> 00:25:42.640
Because the virtual IP stays the same,
192.168.16.20.

511
00:25:42.640 --> 00:25:46.340
And the MAC address stays the same cuz
it was a virtual MAC, it hands off.

512
00:25:46.340 --> 00:25:48.780
And so they just start going
to this new destination.

513
00:25:48.780 --> 00:25:50.470
They don't even realize that it happened.

514
00:25:50.470 --> 00:25:54.730
We now have first hop redundancy right
here in the event of a switch failure.

515
00:25:54.730 --> 00:25:58.640
>> Yeah, Don, I've seen this in action and
I think we lost maybe one ping.

516
00:25:58.640 --> 00:26:01.400
It was so quick, super fast,

517
00:26:01.400 --> 00:26:04.770
no workstation knew anything about the
fact that one switch actually went down.

518
00:26:04.770 --> 00:26:06.000
>> Yeah, it's fast.

519
00:26:06.000 --> 00:26:09.500
The part that takes the longest is that
virtual MAC address is moving to other

520
00:26:09.500 --> 00:26:13.130
hardware, and so the switches have

521
00:26:13.130 --> 00:26:15.810
That's really all you're waiting for,
and that happens pretty quick,

522
00:26:15.810 --> 00:26:17.530
so you usually don't notice.

523
00:26:17.530 --> 00:26:21.730
I mean, there's some software out there
like Lotus Domino that'll pick up on that,

524
00:26:21.730 --> 00:26:23.970
but most software won't
even realize it happened.

525
00:26:23.970 --> 00:26:25.520
It's just a smooth transition over.

526
00:26:25.520 --> 00:26:28.890
>> Yeah, now we have some redundancy
if the switch fails, right?

527
00:26:28.890 --> 00:26:31.180
If that goes down, it's not a problem.

528
00:26:31.180 --> 00:26:34.164
Jumps over to our standby switch,
it becomes the active switch, and

529
00:26:34.164 --> 00:26:35.249
we're off to the races.

530
00:26:35.249 --> 00:26:39.476
But Don, one of the more common problems
that we actually have in switches is that

531
00:26:39.476 --> 00:26:42.970
a port fails, and
not necessarily the switch itself.

532
00:26:42.970 --> 00:26:44.030
What can we do if that happens?

533
00:26:44.030 --> 00:26:45.605
Do we have some HSRP for that?

534
00:26:45.605 --> 00:26:46.105
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

535
00:26:46.105 --> 00:26:46.713
>> Yeah so,

536
00:26:46.713 --> 00:26:50.875
you bring up a great point there, right?
If I take a look at my

537
00:26:50.875 --> 00:26:52.785
core switch here, right?

538
00:26:52.785 --> 00:26:55.765
When I downed it, I downed Vlan1,
and that's never gonna happen.

539
00:26:55.765 --> 00:26:58.925
That's not a realistic failure.

540
00:26:58.925 --> 00:27:03.275
So, really all HSRP is set up for
here is if my whole switch fails, and

541
00:27:03.275 --> 00:27:04.627
that's not terribly realistic either.

542
00:27:04.627 --> 00:27:08.420
These things'll run for seven,
ten years and never have a single failure.

543
00:27:08.420 --> 00:27:09.890
You're more likely to
have a power outage or

544
00:27:09.890 --> 00:27:13.070
some other kind of configuration
issue that downs it.

545
00:27:13.070 --> 00:27:15.390
But an individual port failing,
that happens a lot.

546
00:27:15.390 --> 00:27:18.310
Well, I'm tied to Vlan1,
and Vlan1's not gonna fail,

547
00:27:18.310 --> 00:27:21.710
so the port failing here isn't gonna help.

548
00:27:21.710 --> 00:27:24.540
What if I wanna monitor some other port?

549
00:27:24.540 --> 00:27:26.870
Now, if I'm the default gateway,

550
00:27:26.870 --> 00:27:32.440
then I'm typically going to be using some
kind of downstream router as my gateway.

551
00:27:32.440 --> 00:27:33.874
I'll have a gateway of last resort or

552
00:27:33.874 --> 00:27:36.910
some default route that I use
to get people to the Internet.

553
00:27:36.910 --> 00:27:39.810
I might wanna monitor the port
that that's attached to.

554
00:27:39.810 --> 00:27:43.190
I don't wanna put that port in HSRP,
but I wanna monitor that port.

555
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:45.258
So what we can do is we
can use track objects.

556
00:27:45.258 --> 00:27:49.012
If you watched the route show, I spent
some time on that in the IP SLA episodes.

557
00:27:49.012 --> 00:27:52.360
But here, on a switch,
you can do track objects also.

558
00:27:52.360 --> 00:27:56.485
You can track individual interfaces or
you can track routes.

559
00:27:56.485 --> 00:27:58.825
So if you have a default
route in your routing table,

560
00:27:58.825 --> 00:28:00.735
you can just monitor to see if
the default route is there.

561
00:28:00.735 --> 00:28:03.705
And if the default route goes away,
you can take action,

562
00:28:03.705 --> 00:28:05.365
you can cause HSRP to failover.

563
00:28:05.365 --> 00:28:08.415
There's some neat ways to do this and
I wanna show them to you.

564
00:28:08.415 --> 00:28:12.155
So let's just use a quick example here.

565
00:28:12.155 --> 00:28:18.677
Let's say I've got interface fa1/0/1, and
there is a router on the other side of it.

566
00:28:18.677 --> 00:28:23.352
So if I ping to 192.168.16.,

567
00:28:23.352 --> 00:28:28.300
what is that guy's IP, 22 or something.

568
00:28:28.300 --> 00:28:29.260
Wait, let me find out.

569
00:28:29.260 --> 00:28:32.190
If my Edge guy here, this Edge router.

570
00:28:32.190 --> 00:28:35.363
So if I take a look at, or no,
it's not, it's NY WAN, here we go.

571
00:28:35.363 --> 00:28:38.240
NY WAN, this router,
which I apparently didn't power on, so

572
00:28:38.240 --> 00:28:39.885
we'll have to pick somebody else.

573
00:28:39.885 --> 00:28:41.740
[LAUGH] Let's pick this guy here.

574
00:28:41.740 --> 00:28:44.330
I have a number of different devices
to pick from that are actually

575
00:28:44.330 --> 00:28:45.470
already powered on.

576
00:28:45.470 --> 00:28:49.278
So, if I do a show IP int br,
I can look at this guy.

577
00:28:49.278 --> 00:28:53.000
This guy is 192.168.16.1, this is
the guy I duplicated earlier, right?

578
00:28:53.000 --> 00:28:56.460
So there's a nice little overlap for me.

579
00:28:56.460 --> 00:28:59.460
And that's the Gi 0/0
interface on this one.

580
00:28:59.460 --> 00:29:04.090
So if I go to my core switch and I take a
look at how I'm connected to that, right?

581
00:29:04.090 --> 00:29:08.150
So if I look at my cdp nei,
oh, I'm not in config.

582
00:29:09.920 --> 00:29:11.572
And I take a look at my neighbors,

583
00:29:11.572 --> 00:29:14.585
I can see that I'm connected
to NYEDGE1 on Fas 1/0/1.

584
00:29:14.585 --> 00:29:16.650
Good, all right, so
that's the interface that I'm on.

585
00:29:16.650 --> 00:29:18.580
I might wanna monitor that interface, or

586
00:29:18.580 --> 00:29:20.910
I might just wanna monitor
some route that's tied to it.

587
00:29:20.910 --> 00:29:25.720
So for example, I might say ip route, and

588
00:29:25.720 --> 00:29:32.850
have a default route that points to
192.168.16.1, to that guy, okay.

589
00:29:32.850 --> 00:29:37.484
And that route makes it into my routing
table as my gateway of last resort,

590
00:29:37.484 --> 00:29:38.399
right there.

591
00:29:38.399 --> 00:29:41.310
And so I might want to monitor
whether that default route is there.

592
00:29:41.310 --> 00:29:44.050
So I can just create a track
object that monitors those and

593
00:29:44.050 --> 00:29:45.370
then reflects the status.

594
00:29:45.370 --> 00:29:46.980
It's pretty straight forward.

595
00:29:46.980 --> 00:29:49.015
If you've seen the route show,
you already know how to do this.

596
00:29:49.015 --> 00:29:53.338
But if you haven't, the commands to create
a track object, we basically say track,

597
00:29:53.338 --> 00:29:55.070
and then you give it a number.

598
00:29:55.070 --> 00:29:58.110
You can create as many track objects
as you want, well, there is a limit.

599
00:29:58.110 --> 00:30:01.720
Let's see what mine is, 1000, but
I'm not gonna monitor 1000 things.

600
00:30:01.720 --> 00:30:06.580
So I'm just gonna say track 1, and
then you can track all sorts of stuff.

601
00:30:06.580 --> 00:30:08.840
You can track jitter and delay,

602
00:30:08.840 --> 00:30:12.910
you can track, reachability is what
I normally do, can I reach it?

603
00:30:12.910 --> 00:30:14.980
You can track all sorts of crazy stuff.

604
00:30:14.980 --> 00:30:17.545
So it's kinda up to you how
you wanna set this one up.

605
00:30:17.545 --> 00:30:21.294
But in my scenario, I just wanna track,
I'll start with an interface.

606
00:30:21.294 --> 00:30:27.017
So I'm gonna track fa1/0/1 and
what I'm looking for

607
00:30:27.017 --> 00:30:31.640
is line-protocol, the physical port.

608
00:30:31.640 --> 00:30:35.200
If that physical port goes down,
this track object will go down.

609
00:30:36.290 --> 00:30:39.170
So it gives me a way to kind
of monitor that physical port.

610
00:30:39.170 --> 00:30:42.742
If I'm monitoring a route,
I could say, I'll do track 2 here.

611
00:30:42.742 --> 00:30:44.801
I do track 2, and then I come in and

612
00:30:44.801 --> 00:30:48.000
I specify that I'm wanting
to monitor a route.

613
00:30:48.000 --> 00:30:50.560
And if you do a question mark you'll see
the different things you can monitor.

614
00:30:50.560 --> 00:30:52.390
I guess route's tucked under IP.

615
00:30:52.390 --> 00:30:57.980
But we can say ip route, and you can
specify the route you wanna monitor.

616
00:30:57.980 --> 00:31:00.630
And then just add the key word,
reachability,

617
00:31:01.650 --> 00:31:05.410
which means look at my routing table and
see if you can find a route.

618
00:31:05.410 --> 00:31:08.050
And by doing all 0s
that's the default route.

619
00:31:08.050 --> 00:31:12.811
So track object 1 is monitoring
a physical interface,

620
00:31:12.811 --> 00:31:16.165
track object 2 is monitoring a route.

621
00:31:16.165 --> 00:31:19.120
And the commands,
let me just bring those back up again.

622
00:31:20.240 --> 00:31:22.060
The commands are pretty simple too.

623
00:31:22.060 --> 00:31:23.570
If you go jump over to the route show and

624
00:31:23.570 --> 00:31:27.810
check out the IP SLA episode, I show where
you can set up schedules and timers.

625
00:31:27.810 --> 00:31:30.670
You can set up all sorts of
crazy things here to monitor and

626
00:31:30.670 --> 00:31:32.790
influence how often it pings and
all of that.

627
00:31:32.790 --> 00:31:34.580
There's a lot more to them.

628
00:31:34.580 --> 00:31:38.660
But for this, these two commands
right here really kinda tackle it.

629
00:31:38.660 --> 00:31:41.450
One monitors a physical interface,
one monitors a route.

630
00:31:41.450 --> 00:31:44.036
If either one goes down,
the track object fails.

631
00:31:44.036 --> 00:31:47.356
And we can tie that track object to HSRP.

632
00:31:47.356 --> 00:31:53.208
So I can jump into HSRP, well here,
let me show you a track object fail first.

633
00:31:53.208 --> 00:31:57.341
So if I say Show track 1,
it says that it's up, right?

634
00:31:57.341 --> 00:31:58.827
That interface is up.

635
00:31:58.827 --> 00:32:02.671
If I get into interface fa1/0/1,
and I shut it down,

636
00:32:02.671 --> 00:32:07.450
the interface goes down,
the track object will go down, all right.

637
00:32:07.450 --> 00:32:11.893
So I get one extra line there during
a failure letting me know the track object

638
00:32:11.893 --> 00:32:16.348
went down, and if I do a show track 1,
I can see that status is down, right?

639
00:32:16.348 --> 00:32:19.970
So another way to kind of monitor that,
and

640
00:32:19.970 --> 00:32:24.295
I can jump into the HSRP
configuration on VLAN 1 and

641
00:32:24.295 --> 00:32:29.927
what you do is you say standby 1,
and then if you look at your help,

642
00:32:29.927 --> 00:32:34.025
you've got the track command right there.

643
00:32:34.025 --> 00:32:38.425
And we can track, if I say track 1,
I'm gonna track that physical interface,

644
00:32:38.425 --> 00:32:40.455
if I say track 2,
I'm gonna track my default route, right?

645
00:32:40.455 --> 00:32:43.557
So you can track kind of
whatever you want, right?

646
00:32:43.557 --> 00:32:47.517
Now when we track an object,
you need to say what to do about it,

647
00:32:47.517 --> 00:32:49.477
and there's two options here.

648
00:32:49.477 --> 00:32:51.487
A lot of times you just want it shut down.

649
00:32:51.487 --> 00:32:52.717
Hey, if I can't get to that port,

650
00:32:52.717 --> 00:32:55.540
people don't need to come to me,
shut this one down, right?

651
00:32:55.540 --> 00:32:58.100
And I don't mean shut the router down and
turn it off.

652
00:32:58.100 --> 00:33:00.240
I mean shut down the HSRP group,

653
00:33:00.240 --> 00:33:03.180
which is gonna cause the other
router to go active, right?

654
00:33:03.180 --> 00:33:04.510
The problem with shutting it down,

655
00:33:04.510 --> 00:33:07.850
though, is it kind of has a hard
time coming back up, right?

656
00:33:07.850 --> 00:33:11.400
So another option we can do is
called a decrement, all right?

657
00:33:11.400 --> 00:33:14.670
Every router in our HSRP
cluster has a priority,

658
00:33:14.670 --> 00:33:18.300
and the priority determines who's
going to be the active router.

659
00:33:18.300 --> 00:33:20.480
And by default they all
have a priority of 100.

660
00:33:20.480 --> 00:33:23.970
You can set it so
that when the track object fails,

661
00:33:23.970 --> 00:33:28.210
instead of shutting it down,
it can lower the priority.

662
00:33:28.210 --> 00:33:31.630
A higher priority number's gonna become
active, a lower priority number won't.

663
00:33:31.630 --> 00:33:35.990
So, we can say, lower my priority so
somebody else can become active, and

664
00:33:35.990 --> 00:33:38.550
let them jump in and take over, all right?

665
00:33:38.550 --> 00:33:42.880
And if that happens, now we're up,
and we're happy, and we're running.

666
00:33:42.880 --> 00:33:45.510
But we wanna pay attention to
how we do our decrements, right?

667
00:33:45.510 --> 00:33:49.360
Cuz you might be tracking more than
one object, so you might wanna have

668
00:33:49.360 --> 00:33:52.350
two things fail, or three things fail
before you actually fail over, and

669
00:33:52.350 --> 00:33:54.220
you can use decrements to figure that out.

670
00:33:54.220 --> 00:33:58.710
So I can say decrement ten,
if that interface goes down,

671
00:33:58.710 --> 00:34:00.359
I'm gonna reduce my priority by ten.

672
00:34:01.650 --> 00:34:06.370
My default priority is 100, that'll
take me down to 90, and I'm in business.

673
00:34:06.370 --> 00:34:12.000
Well, I could also come in and
say, like, standby 1 priority and

674
00:34:12.000 --> 00:34:16.920
redefine my priority to something higher,
so maybe I am the root.

675
00:34:16.920 --> 00:34:21.210
I want this one to be the active router,
and so, I set my priority to 110.

676
00:34:21.210 --> 00:34:23.360
Everybody else is 100, so
I'll become the active, right?

677
00:34:23.360 --> 00:34:28.890
My priority is 110, and when I fail that
track object, it's gonna decrement it

678
00:34:28.890 --> 00:34:32.190
by 10, that'll put me to 100 just in line
with everybody else, I'll stay active.

679
00:34:32.190 --> 00:34:34.940
But, if bump that to 11,
It'll take me down to 99,

680
00:34:34.940 --> 00:34:37.950
and everybody else will be better
than me and then they can take over.

681
00:34:37.950 --> 00:34:40.150
So, you gotta kinda pay
attention to that stuff.

682
00:34:40.150 --> 00:34:41.680
So, by setting my priority to 110,

683
00:34:41.680 --> 00:34:46.540
I will become active and
the other guys won't, they'll go standby.

684
00:34:46.540 --> 00:34:47.914
And then, if a failure happens,

685
00:34:47.914 --> 00:34:50.475
I'll drop down to 99 and
somebody else will become active.

686
00:34:50.475 --> 00:34:52.752
Now, if my priority is
higher than everybody else,

687
00:34:52.752 --> 00:34:54.760
I should be active right now, shouldn't I?

688
00:34:54.760 --> 00:35:00.870
Well, by default, HSRP will not
override the currently active master.

689
00:35:00.870 --> 00:35:05.500
So if I do a show standby and I look
at what's in there I can see where my

690
00:35:05.500 --> 00:35:11.290
priority is 110 right there, and
if I look at the active router, it doesn't

691
00:35:11.290 --> 00:35:13.830
say it here, but I didn't configure it on
the other router, so you know it's 100.

692
00:35:13.830 --> 00:35:15.860
I'm not the active.

693
00:35:15.860 --> 00:35:17.390
Why not?

694
00:35:17.390 --> 00:35:19.440
And that's because we're
not overriding it.

695
00:35:19.440 --> 00:35:24.064
If you want overrides, you need to
type standby and your group number,

696
00:35:24.064 --> 00:35:25.820
preempt, all right?

697
00:35:25.820 --> 00:35:27.310
It's called preemption, and

698
00:35:27.310 --> 00:35:31.270
it basically says if I've got a better
priority, I want to be the active.

699
00:35:31.270 --> 00:35:33.720
And when I turned on that preemption,
you'll see, there we go,

700
00:35:33.720 --> 00:35:34.890
we went and turned active.

701
00:35:34.890 --> 00:35:38.440
So if you have one router or one switch
that you want to be the active one and

702
00:35:38.440 --> 00:35:41.820
you give it a higher priority, it's a good
idea to turn on preemption there too.

703
00:35:41.820 --> 00:35:44.670
That way if there's a failure,
somebody else can take over, but

704
00:35:44.670 --> 00:35:45.810
when the failure is gone and

705
00:35:45.810 --> 00:35:50.972
this switch comes back to normal, it'll
take back over and become the primary.

706
00:35:50.972 --> 00:35:53.284
All right, and
that's what just happened for me.

707
00:35:53.284 --> 00:35:58.123
So I'm now active and if I get into
fa1/0/1, and I shut that, well,

708
00:35:58.123 --> 00:36:01.479
before I do it here let me
just do a show standby, and

709
00:36:01.479 --> 00:36:05.290
we saw that my priority was 110, right?

710
00:36:05.290 --> 00:36:08.150
So right here I can see
my priority is 110.

711
00:36:08.150 --> 00:36:13.170
And the standby router is the other switch
and it's got a priority of 100, right?

712
00:36:13.170 --> 00:36:14.850
I can see its priority now.

713
00:36:14.850 --> 00:36:19.590
If shut this interface down,
my track object

714
00:36:19.590 --> 00:36:23.950
fails which is gonna
lower my priority to 99,

715
00:36:23.950 --> 00:36:27.740
and I should give up my role
as the active HSRP router.

716
00:36:28.845 --> 00:36:30.260
I should.

717
00:36:30.260 --> 00:36:32.510
Well, I'm waiting and it's not happening.

718
00:36:32.510 --> 00:36:33.940
So what's going on there?

719
00:36:33.940 --> 00:36:36.120
Well, if I look at my show standby output,

720
00:36:37.145 --> 00:36:41.285
I can see that my track object has
caused me to decrement down to 99.

721
00:36:41.285 --> 00:36:42.245
It worked like I expected.

722
00:36:42.245 --> 00:36:44.915
And the standby has a priority of 100.

723
00:36:44.915 --> 00:36:47.145
Why didn't the standby take over?

724
00:36:47.145 --> 00:36:50.530
Because it's not gonna preempt me,
I'm the active router.

725
00:36:50.530 --> 00:36:52.980
I need to turn on preemption on it, too.

726
00:36:52.980 --> 00:36:54.820
And then it would have taken over and
kicked in.

727
00:36:55.960 --> 00:36:58.780
If we had left it at
the default function of hey,

728
00:36:58.780 --> 00:37:00.750
track this object and if the object fails,

729
00:37:00.750 --> 00:37:04.040
just shut down, then this would have
worked and that would have been it.

730
00:37:04.040 --> 00:37:07.270
But because I did a decrement, I need to
make sure preemption is turned on, so

731
00:37:07.270 --> 00:37:09.670
the other guys will kick in and
do their work.

732
00:37:09.670 --> 00:37:13.800
So, if I were to jump over
to the other switch and

733
00:37:13.800 --> 00:37:19.355
jump back in to my configuration and
get in to VLAN1 and

734
00:37:19.355 --> 00:37:23.980
set its standby with preemption,

735
00:37:23.980 --> 00:37:29.090
it's got a priority of 100, I've got a
priority of 99 and so it should take over.

736
00:37:29.090 --> 00:37:30.260
And, I see that it just did.

737
00:37:30.260 --> 00:37:34.660
So, it just took over,
it's now the head honcho, it's active.

738
00:37:34.660 --> 00:37:38.530
And if I go back to core one,
and I fix my problem, right?

739
00:37:38.530 --> 00:37:44.110
So if I fix the issue with my system,
I can get into that interface and fix it.

740
00:37:45.500 --> 00:37:50.630
My priority will go back to 110,
I'm set to preempt, I'll become active.

741
00:37:50.630 --> 00:37:54.130
And so
it's kind of tucked away right there,

742
00:37:54.130 --> 00:37:56.050
I just went from standby to active, right?

743
00:37:56.050 --> 00:38:01.480
So now I'm in business, and that's really
all there is to it to configuring HSRP.

744
00:38:01.480 --> 00:38:07.260
Technically, I was done 25 minutes
ago when I issued standby one IP and

745
00:38:07.260 --> 00:38:09.380
IP address, I was done right there.

746
00:38:09.380 --> 00:38:12.710
But all these other things
are ways that we can tweak

747
00:38:12.710 --> 00:38:16.000
the configuration to get it to
behave the way that we want, right?

748
00:38:16.000 --> 00:38:18.110
There's a lot of stuff
that you can adjust, and

749
00:38:18.110 --> 00:38:21.840
even then it really just boils down
to a handful of commands, right?

750
00:38:21.840 --> 00:38:26.010
So these standby commands that,
these five and the track objects,

751
00:38:26.010 --> 00:38:29.580
between those you get a pretty
well-rounded clustering solution.

752
00:38:29.580 --> 00:38:32.350
>> Yeah, it's nice to be able
to use that preemption to

753
00:38:32.350 --> 00:38:35.810
enable some consistency in your network
because the switch goes down, and

754
00:38:35.810 --> 00:38:37.910
you're not just gonna leave it down and
go, oh well, what are we gonna do?

755
00:38:37.910 --> 00:38:39.050
You're gonna get fixed,

756
00:38:39.050 --> 00:38:43.740
you're gonna replace it with another
switch, and you want that consistency.

757
00:38:43.740 --> 00:38:47.820
I expect that to be that,
not the standby, right,

758
00:38:47.820 --> 00:38:50.050
but the active, or the active switch.

759
00:38:50.050 --> 00:38:52.280
I want that to be there all the time.

760
00:38:52.280 --> 00:38:54.600
And when this one has to take over,
it does, that's great, but

761
00:38:54.600 --> 00:38:57.220
when I get everything back to
the way I like it, let's use

762
00:38:57.220 --> 00:39:00.690
that preemption to make sure it comes back
to the way we actually want it to work.

763
00:39:00.690 --> 00:39:02.040
>> Yeah, absolutely.

764
00:39:02.040 --> 00:39:04.240
Now Daniel, I only got through HSRP.

765
00:39:04.240 --> 00:39:05.560
>> You only got there.

766
00:39:05.560 --> 00:39:09.025
>> I had two more to talk about,
VRRP and GLBP.

767
00:39:09.025 --> 00:39:11.171
Their configurations are almost identical,
so

768
00:39:11.171 --> 00:39:14.583
the work that we just did right there is
basically the same with the other two.

769
00:39:14.583 --> 00:39:17.018
But there are important,
they do behave a little differently, so

770
00:39:17.018 --> 00:39:18.270
I wanna talk about them.

771
00:39:18.270 --> 00:39:21.965
But let's do a part two so we can tackle
those other guys and get them knocked out.

772
00:39:21.965 --> 00:39:23.975
They are important,
you do wanna know them.

773
00:39:23.975 --> 00:39:26.775
There are times where the other
protocols are preferred, but

774
00:39:26.775 --> 00:39:30.095
HSRP is built into darn near
all Cisco equipment these days.

775
00:39:30.095 --> 00:39:32.575
It works on routers,
it works on switches, great technology,

776
00:39:32.575 --> 00:39:37.517
it's pretty flexible, and it's good stuff,
unless you have third party equipment,

777
00:39:37.517 --> 00:39:38.797
and then you're kinda out of luck.

778
00:39:38.797 --> 00:39:40.837
So, we'll talk about
that more in part two.

779
00:39:40.837 --> 00:39:42.937
>> Hey, some of our best work
is in part twos, right Don?

780
00:39:42.937 --> 00:39:44.607
So, I'm looking forward to that.

781
00:39:44.607 --> 00:39:46.857
We'll go ahead and thank you, Don,
for those great demonstrations.

782
00:39:46.857 --> 00:39:49.313
Thank you guys for watching,
we're gonna go ahead and call it a show.

783
00:39:49.313 --> 00:39:52.703
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

784
00:39:52.703 --> 00:39:53.439
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

785
00:39:53.439 --> 00:39:54.979
>> And we'll see you next time.

786
00:39:54.979 --> 00:40:00.002
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue exploring redundancy protocols found on Cisco switches, this time covering the Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol or VRRP. Just like HSRP, VRRP allows you to set up standby switches to take over in the case of a failure with the main switch. Also, they go over the topic of load balancing using the Gateway Load Balancing Protocol(GLBP).
episodes.title: First-Hop Redundancy Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.641 --> 00:00:13.351
Alright, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.351 --> 00:00:16.250
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.250 --> 00:00:17.520
I am your host Daniel Lowry,

5
00:00:17.520 --> 00:00:20.160
joining me in the studio today is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:22.080
How is it going today Don?

7
00:00:22.080 --> 00:00:24.110
>> It is going great Daniel
glad to be back on the show and

8
00:00:24.110 --> 00:00:27.630
ready to jump back into
the world of Cisco switching.

9
00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:31.360
In particular we're going to be taking
a look at first hop redundancy and

10
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:33.680
this is part two to first hop redundancy.

11
00:00:33.680 --> 00:00:35.930
So if you haven't caught
the first episode check that out.

12
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:39.050
Because what we've tackled there,
which HSRP, right?

13
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:43.020
The hot standby routing protocol,
or redundancy protocol, and

14
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:46.520
it was a great chance to see how to take
a couple of Cisco switches or routers, for

15
00:00:46.520 --> 00:00:50.600
that matter, and effectively
cluster them together, where one is

16
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:54.820
handling the routing, and if it fails,
another one takes over and runs that role.

17
00:00:54.820 --> 00:00:59.740
Now, you'll remember from an episode,
hopefully you'll remember, That HSRP was

18
00:00:59.740 --> 00:01:06.020
Cisco proprietary, and it worked really
well, but it is Cisco proprietary.

19
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:08.330
So that's kind of it's
limitation that it has.

20
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:11.490
There's actually a few other limitations
that, if you've only worked with HSRP you

21
00:01:11.490 --> 00:01:15.620
might not notice, cuz HSRP does a really
good job of creating that redundancy.

22
00:01:15.620 --> 00:01:18.290
If one device fails,
the other takes over, it's really fast.

23
00:01:18.290 --> 00:01:20.250
Works great, right?

24
00:01:20.250 --> 00:01:23.240
But there are other options, and that's
what we're gonna look at in this episode.

25
00:01:23.240 --> 00:01:27.980
We have two other redundancy options in
Cisco equipment that are available to us.

26
00:01:27.980 --> 00:01:33.770
Now HSRP is supported on darn near all
Cisco equipment, routers, and switches.

27
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:36.790
Firewalls not so much,
firewalls do different stuff.

28
00:01:36.790 --> 00:01:39.330
But on the routing and switching
side you have HSRP built into it,

29
00:01:39.330 --> 00:01:40.990
into almost all of the equipment.

30
00:01:40.990 --> 00:01:44.090
So you can jump in and configure it and
get it up and going pretty easily.

31
00:01:44.090 --> 00:01:48.100
But if you have third party equipment,
maybe you've got some Cisco switches and

32
00:01:48.100 --> 00:01:52.690
some HP Pro curves, or you've got some
Cisco routers and some Juniper routers.

33
00:01:52.690 --> 00:01:54.800
And you want to have
redundancy between them,

34
00:01:54.800 --> 00:01:58.960
then it becomes a little more challenging,
you can't use HSRP anymore right?

35
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:03.090
So instead we have VRRP right?

36
00:02:03.090 --> 00:02:07.350
VRRP is
the Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol and

37
00:02:07.350 --> 00:02:12.970
It's an IEEE standard, it's basically
a standards alternative to HSRP.

38
00:02:12.970 --> 00:02:16.540
And Cisco is involved in
the standardization of the VRRP.

39
00:02:16.540 --> 00:02:20.850
So it's not like Cisco really cares which
one you use, so it's kind of up to you,

40
00:02:20.850 --> 00:02:25.680
and you'll see when we go and configure it
the VRRP and HSRP are almost identical.

41
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:27.930
So in real life land.

42
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:31.140
It doesn't really matter
which one you use, right.

43
00:02:31.140 --> 00:02:33.820
It's kind of which one makes
best sense in your environment.

44
00:02:33.820 --> 00:02:38.170
If you're all Cisco, you might choose
to go HSRP, just because you can, but

45
00:02:38.170 --> 00:02:40.290
if you're mixing vendors or
even if you are all Cisco,

46
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:44.110
you might choose to go VRRP anyway,
just because it is the standard.

47
00:02:44.110 --> 00:02:45.630
And that's kinda how I am.

48
00:02:45.630 --> 00:02:50.130
Even in the earlier days with trunking,
where you could choose between ISL and

49
00:02:50.130 --> 00:02:51.740
802.1q, I would always go 802.1q.

50
00:02:51.740 --> 00:02:54.790
Because, I knew if I had all
Cisco equipment I was fine,

51
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:58.260
but if I wanted to bring third party
stuff in later I could still use it.

52
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:00.188
That's how I am with VRRP and HSRP.

53
00:03:00.188 --> 00:03:08.170
But, I said HSRP is supported on darn
near all Cisco equipment, VRRP isn't,

54
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:11.240
so you'll need to check your IOS to
make sure it's part of the feature set.

55
00:03:11.240 --> 00:03:15.270
Some feature sets don't include VRVP,
but we're doing HSRP.

56
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:17.800
It's getting to be a smaller and smaller
amount of devices that are like that.

57
00:03:17.800 --> 00:03:20.530
But be on the lookout for
that for your equipment.

58
00:03:20.530 --> 00:03:25.560
>> So Don, when it comes to VRRP,
it's basically an identical type of thing

59
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:30.060
as HSRP, which we love, it's a fantastic
little item we have available for us.

60
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:31.420
But if I'm remembering correctly,

61
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:34.590
I think there is some, is there
terminology that's kind of different?

62
00:03:34.590 --> 00:03:35.490
>> Yeah.
>> When it comes

63
00:03:35.490 --> 00:03:36.760
to configuring it and stuff.

64
00:03:36.760 --> 00:03:39.440
>> They use some slightly different
words in the descriptions and

65
00:03:39.440 --> 00:03:41.030
there is some slightly different behavior.

66
00:03:41.030 --> 00:03:43.620
So let's touch on those
kind of key points.

67
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:49.370
With HSRP you have one active router,
one stand-by router,

68
00:03:49.370 --> 00:03:53.200
and, everybody else is
just called an other.

69
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:54.420
Right?
They're not active or standby,

70
00:03:54.420 --> 00:03:56.820
they're just kind of waiting in the folds,
there.

71
00:03:56.820 --> 00:04:00.190
And, so, you really just have one router
that's up and going, one that's standby.

72
00:04:00.190 --> 00:04:01.788
Everybody else is just kind of parked.

73
00:04:01.788 --> 00:04:03.086
Right.

74
00:04:03.086 --> 00:04:07.770
In VRRP instead of the active router
you have what's called the master, so

75
00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:09.970
you have a master router, right?

76
00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:14.660
And if the master router fails, then it
flips over to what's called its backup.

77
00:04:14.660 --> 00:04:18.320
So instead of active and standby,
you have master and backup.

78
00:04:18.320 --> 00:04:20.240
Right?
So that's the difference in terminology.

79
00:04:20.240 --> 00:04:22.640
But there's also differences in behavior.

80
00:04:22.640 --> 00:04:27.070
So, in HSRP, you have an active and a
standby, everybody else is parked, right?

81
00:04:27.070 --> 00:04:30.790
They're all kind of stuck in that speak
phase, but they're not active or standby.

82
00:04:30.790 --> 00:04:35.910
Well, in VRRP,
all the other routers are backups.

83
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:39.610
You have one master, and
everybody else is a backup.

84
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:43.770
And any one of those backups could step up
to become the master at a moment's notice,

85
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:46.930
if they have the right priority,
if they beat the other people out, or

86
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:48.990
first come first serve,
whoever gets there, right?

87
00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:51.690
They're all eligible to become the master.

88
00:04:51.690 --> 00:04:56.170
So, you have one master and
all the others are backups.

89
00:04:56.170 --> 00:04:58.630
Now, in HSRP because you
just had an active and

90
00:04:58.630 --> 00:05:02.530
a standby,
when I ran the show standby command.

91
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:05.970
If I was on the active router I saw
the IP address of the backup, and

92
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:07.930
if I was on the backup router, standby.

93
00:05:07.930 --> 00:05:12.170
If I was on the standby router
I could do a show standby and

94
00:05:12.170 --> 00:05:13.240
see who the active router was.

95

00:05:31.670 --> 00:05:35.970

00:11:50.052 --> 00:11:51.730

00:11:51.730 --> 00:11:55.720
So by default, yes, VRRP is faster,

00:11:55.720 --> 00:12:00.710

00:19:13.340 --> 00:19:17.530
First off, GLBP is gonna take us back

00:19:17.530 --> 00:19:20.000

00:19:20.000 --> 00:19:21.470

00:19:22.540 --> 00:19:27.690
But what GOBP does that's different,

VRRP you have an active or

00:19:32.820 --> 00:19:35.600
That's the router that's doing the work,

00:20:17.907 --> 00:20:20.187

It's a hard sell.

00:20:25.087 --> 00:20:28.947
And there's a lot of CIOs out there

00:20:28.947 --> 00:20:31.890

00:20:31.890 --> 00:20:35.070
what if we put that old switch over

00:20:35.070 --> 00:20:39.020
I've been there, so you want to try and

00:20:39.020 --> 00:20:45.500
So GLBP says, all right, let's just not

398
00:20:45.500 --> 00:20:49.977
Let's get multiple switches, or

00:20:49.977 --> 00:20:54.390
on that first hop IP, and

00:20:54.390 --> 00:20:57.070
And that way you're actually

00:20:57.070 --> 00:21:01.460
And if one fails, the other one

00:21:01.460 --> 00:21:04.900

00:21:08.460 --> 00:21:10.810

00:21:10.810 --> 00:21:13.800

00:21:13.800 --> 00:21:16.590
And load balancing across all of them.

00:21:16.590 --> 00:21:18.780
And as one failed, or

00:21:18.780 --> 00:21:20.390
people would just shift

00:21:20.390 --> 00:21:22.310

00:21:22.310 --> 00:21:25.970
But it takes a lot of

00:21:25.970 --> 00:21:28.220

00:21:28.220 --> 00:21:32.130
And that doesn't happen with HSRP and

00:21:32.130 --> 00:21:34.640
the system because they're just

00:21:34.640 --> 00:21:36.600
They do that all the time, right.

00:21:36.600 --> 00:21:40.150
But with GLBP they've gotta actually look

00:21:40.150 --> 00:21:44.630
as a result,
M=most Cisco switches do not support GLBP.

00:21:45.690 --> 00:21:51.580
So for example, here in my lab,

00:21:51.580 --> 00:21:55.810

00:23:25.650 --> 00:23:27.500
Now, the way GLBP works,

00:23:27.500 --> 00:23:31.590
the configuration's actually
remarkably similar to HSRP VRRP, right?

00:23:31.590 --> 00:23:34.160
All three of these configure

448
00:23:34.160 --> 00:23:41.120
The difference is you do have

00:23:41.120 --> 00:23:44.560
What they do, they call it an AVG.

00:23:44.560 --> 00:23:48.760
So the active virtual gateway, right?

00:23:48.760 --> 00:23:51.540
So the AVG,

00:23:51.540 --> 00:23:54.024
So the first switch you configure, or

00:23:54.024 --> 00:23:58.920

00:23:58.920 --> 00:24:01.914
And then after that, every other switch or

00:24:01.914 --> 00:24:05.580
every other router that you

00:24:05.580 --> 00:24:09.680
Becomes what's called an AVF
an active virtual forwarder.

00:24:09.680 --> 00:24:11.580

00:24:11.580 --> 00:24:14.270
Active virtual gateway,

00:24:14.270 --> 00:24:16.820

00:24:16.820 --> 00:24:22.410
The only difference is the AVG is the one

00:24:22.410 --> 00:24:26.100

00:24:26.100 --> 00:24:28.640

00:24:28.640 --> 00:24:30.500
They're all moving it along, right?

00:24:30.500 --> 00:24:35.810
And if the AVG fails, one of the other

00:24:35.810 --> 00:24:38.880
And traffic continues flowing like normal,

00:24:38.880 --> 00:24:42.120

00:24:42.120 --> 00:24:44.610
And when I say how we're gonna load

00:24:44.610 --> 00:24:47.900
when you load balance

00:24:47.900 --> 00:24:52.070
You can pick how you wanna do it, there's

00:24:52.070 --> 00:24:55.270
And the default mode is

00:24:55.270 --> 00:24:58.290

00:24:58.290 --> 00:25:01.580

00:25:01.580 --> 00:25:03.540
the traffic, it distributes that way.

00:25:03.540 --> 00:25:07.170
But you can switch to other modes and

00:25:07.170 --> 00:25:09.170
It's up to you how you wanna do that.

00:25:09.170 --> 00:25:11.680
A few different ways to go about that.

00:25:11.680 --> 00:25:14.150
That's why we have to have that one AVG.

00:25:14.150 --> 00:25:16.950

00:25:16.950 --> 00:25:18.320
They could all just be forwarding.

00:25:18.320 --> 00:25:21.360
And if somebody drops, there's extra

481
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:22.810
And they grab it and they move on.

482
00:25:22.810 --> 00:25:25.200
Right.
So pretty neat the way that works,

483
00:25:25.200 --> 00:25:28.370
everybody's up and running,

484
00:25:28.370 --> 00:25:31.870

Now the way these guys work

00:25:31.870 --> 00:25:34.800
is they listen for all traffic.

486
00:25:34.800 --> 00:25:40.170
So we have a virtual IP, and our host
are all pointing to this virtual IP and

00:25:40.170 --> 00:25:42.830
the AVG and all the AVFs,
they all listen for that traffic.

488
00:25:42.830 --> 00:25:48.360
Okay, but based on the load balancing,
when a client sends out an ARP request,

489
00:25:48.360 --> 00:25:52.420
right, so the first time my laptop goes
to hit that IP request, all right.

490
00:25:52.420 --> 00:25:53.580
I send out an ARP request.

491
00:25:53.580 --> 00:25:55.960
And I say, all right,
my default gateway is 192.160.0.1.

492
00:25:55.960 --> 00:26:01.120
Can somebody tell me what the MAC
address of that system is?

493
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:05.460
And the router with 192.168.0.1, here's
that arp request, and it replies back and

494
00:26:05.460 --> 00:26:07.610
says, hey, that's me,
here's my Mac address.

495
00:26:07.610 --> 00:26:12.130
Well, with GLBP all the forwarders,
the ABG and

496
00:26:12.130 --> 00:26:16.560
the ABFs, they all listen and
they all hear that ARP request.

497
00:26:16.560 --> 00:26:21.400
And then based on load balancing,
one of them responds back and says hey,

498
00:26:21.400 --> 00:26:24.340
that's me, here's my MAC address.

499
00:26:24.340 --> 00:26:31.000
So unlike HSRP and VRRP where they all
share a virtual MAC address, GLBP doesn't.

500
00:26:31.000 --> 00:26:37.280
Each forwarder the ABG and the ABFs,
they have all have their own MAC address.

501
00:26:37.280 --> 00:26:39.960
And that way the clients are using
that MAC address to get to

502
00:26:39.960 --> 00:26:43.380
an individual node inside
of the GLBP cluster.

503
00:26:43.380 --> 00:26:46.080
So it's a shared layer three IP.

504
00:26:47.240 --> 00:26:50.590
And a unique layer two MAC.

505
00:26:50.590 --> 00:26:53.710
>> All right Don, so
we've got active forwarding.

506
00:26:53.710 --> 00:26:55.630
Everybody's forwarding,
everybody's doing something.

507
00:26:55.630 --> 00:26:58.340
They're trying to load balance,
obviously it's the whole point here.

508
00:26:58.340 --> 00:27:00.550
But there's only one IP address.

509
00:27:00.550 --> 00:27:04.950
How do the devices know which
device to actually forward through?

510
00:27:04.950 --> 00:27:09.720
Yeah, great question, because with
HSRP and VRRP, it's really simple.

511
00:27:09.720 --> 00:27:12.930
There's a MAC address and
an IP address, right?

512
00:27:12.930 --> 00:27:17.330
Layer two and layer three,
that actually move from router to router,

513
00:27:17.330 --> 00:27:21.075
switch to switch, so
the clients move along with it, right?

514
00:27:21.075 --> 00:27:24.635
They've already got it in their ARC cache
that says where they're gonna go, right?

515
00:27:24.635 --> 00:27:28.085
You know, for a laptop,
the first time I plug into a network and

516
00:27:28.085 --> 00:27:29.525
I go to contact my default gateway.

517
00:27:29.525 --> 00:27:32.150
I wanna get to the Internet or
some other network.

518
00:27:32.150 --> 00:27:35.410
I know my default gateway is
let's say it's 192.168.0.1.

519
00:27:35.410 --> 00:27:37.200
I know that's my default gateway.

520
00:27:38.240 --> 00:27:40.490
I type that in, or
I get it from a DHCP server.

521
00:27:40.490 --> 00:27:43.090
But the first time I talk to it,
I have to send out an ARP broadcast.

522
00:27:43.090 --> 00:27:44.430
And I send out that ARP broadcast and

523
00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:48.380
I say, hey, what's the MAC address for
192.168.0.1?

524
00:27:48.380 --> 00:27:50.980
And that gateway receives it and
responds back.

525
00:27:50.980 --> 00:27:54.380
And in HSRP or VRRP, it's just
whoever's controlling it right then.

526
00:27:54.380 --> 00:27:58.730
They respond back and I add their
fake cluster IP to my ARP cache and

527
00:27:58.730 --> 00:28:00.080
now I can talk to the gateway.

528
00:28:00.080 --> 00:28:00.930
Right?

529
00:28:00.930 --> 00:28:04.460
If a failure happens, the IP and
the MAC move to the other system.

530
00:28:04.460 --> 00:28:06.990
So my ARP cache stays current and
I keep communicating.

531
00:28:06.990 --> 00:28:08.510
Right?
Very simple.

532
00:28:08.510 --> 00:28:10.520
With GLBP it's different.

533
00:28:10.520 --> 00:28:14.650
With GOBP, you have a shared IP address.

534
00:28:14.650 --> 00:28:19.580
One IP that's shared across
all your AVFs and the AVG.

535
00:28:19.580 --> 00:28:22.640
But each one maintains
its own MAC address.

536
00:28:22.640 --> 00:28:23.790
They each have a unique MAC address.

537
00:28:24.920 --> 00:28:30.090
And that way when I send out my ARP
broadcast, everybody that the AVG and

538
00:28:30.090 --> 00:28:32.890
all the AVF's are listening for
that broadcast.

539
00:28:32.890 --> 00:28:35.530
They hear it, right,
they hear that come in.

540
00:28:35.530 --> 00:28:39.270
And then, based on load balancing right,

00:33:32.210 --> 00:33:36.409

00:34:17.910 --> 00:34:21.830

00:34:21.830 --> 00:34:24.360

00:34:31.380 --> 00:34:34.820

00:34:34.820 --> 00:34:36.930

00:34:36.930 --> 00:34:39.300

It balances people out, because typically,

00:35:18.420 --> 00:35:20.450

You buy two 6500s, and
