766
00:39:34.380 --> 00:39:40.820
And if I jump over to edge two, I can take
this guy and repeat that same process.

767
00:39:41.990 --> 00:39:49.227
So, I'll just come in here and
say GLBP 1 and IP 192.168.16.1.

768
00:39:49.227 --> 00:39:50.410
All right?

769
00:39:50.410 --> 00:39:51.620
And, I'll leave his priority at 100.

770
00:39:51.620 --> 00:39:54.980
The other guy's got a higher priority,
so he'll stay the AVG.

771
00:39:54.980 --> 00:39:59.320
But this one will come up, and
it will become an active forwarder.

772
00:39:59.320 --> 00:40:02.006
Right?
An AVF, and we should see that here,

773
00:40:02.006 --> 00:40:02.700
shortly.

774
00:40:02.700 --> 00:40:07.080
Now, if I get impatient, and I don't see
the communication, again, we might have to

775
00:40:07.080 --> 00:40:10.980
make sure we've got connectivity between
the two systems, and there we go.

776
00:40:10.980 --> 00:40:13.514
I see that I do.
It just kind of transitioned And

777
00:40:13.514 --> 00:40:18.990
I can see that interface transition
from state Listen to Active.

778
00:40:18.990 --> 00:40:23.850
And now it's forwarding and if I do a show
glbp, I can jump in here and look at it.

779
00:40:23.850 --> 00:40:27.190
And I can see information about that avg,
and I can see myself.

780
00:40:27.190 --> 00:40:30.560
And so here's the two nodes that
are involved in this environment.

781
00:40:30.560 --> 00:40:33.810
And then down here,
I can see the MAC address that I'm using.

782
00:40:33.810 --> 00:40:36.940
And see how it says that I
learned that MAC address, right?

783
00:40:36.940 --> 00:40:38.300
I learned it from the other one.

784
00:40:38.300 --> 00:40:40.870
This is the MAC address for the group.

785
00:40:40.870 --> 00:40:46.230
But I'm gonna respond to clients
with this address, my owner address.

786
00:40:46.230 --> 00:40:47.230
That's that unique address.

787
00:40:47.230 --> 00:40:49.750
That's why we've got two MAC
addresses that are inside here that

788
00:40:49.750 --> 00:40:50.710
are tied to that.

789
00:40:50.710 --> 00:40:54.520
And so now, we're configured,
we're up, and we're in business.

790
00:40:54.520 --> 00:40:57.080
And so now we're running GLBP,
it's that easy.

791
00:40:57.080 --> 00:41:00.720
>> It's that simple, ladies and
gentlemen, GLBP coming to the rescue.

792
00:41:00.720 --> 00:41:05.760
When we've spent multi, multi thousands
of dollars on awesome hardware but

793
00:41:05.760 --> 00:41:06.940
we want to get the most of that.

794
00:41:06.940 --> 00:41:10.680
Now you can go to your CIO or
whoever is coming to you going,

795
00:41:10.680 --> 00:41:14.620
what is that extra switch sitting
in there doing nothing for?

796
00:41:14.620 --> 00:41:16.400
You can go,
well it's not doing nothing anymore.

797
00:41:16.400 --> 00:41:20.270
I made sure we're utilizing that hardware
until we do have a full-on failover.

798
00:41:20.270 --> 00:41:22.907
>> Yep,
now I do want to show one more thing.

799
00:41:22.907 --> 00:41:24.927
Let me jump back over to EDGE1.

800
00:41:24.927 --> 00:41:30.266
So I was running the show glbp command,
right?

801
00:41:30.266 --> 00:41:33.744
If you do, show glbp brief, you're
gonna see something that's a little bit

802
00:41:33.744 --> 00:41:36.310
different than what we've seen before,
okay?

803
00:41:36.310 --> 00:41:41.185
When you look at this,
notice how I've got two entries for,

804
00:41:41.185 --> 00:41:45.155
or really three entries here for my
interface on this router, on this switch.

805
00:41:45.155 --> 00:41:48.395
So when I look at this, I can see
that I've got group 1 configured, and

806
00:41:48.395 --> 00:41:51.220
under forwarding,
I've got somebody who's not forwarding.

807
00:41:51.220 --> 00:41:54.330
And then I've got two that are forwarding,
okay.

808
00:41:54.330 --> 00:42:00.090
What you're seeing here is an entry for
the AVG and an entry for the AVF.

809
00:42:00.090 --> 00:42:05.386
But the AVG shows up as a AVF also,
so it shows up twice.

810
00:42:05.386 --> 00:42:07.630
And so that's why I have
something not forwarding.

811
00:42:07.630 --> 00:42:10.910
And that not forwarding is 192.168.16.1,

812
00:42:10.910 --> 00:42:13.830
that's the IP that we
assigned to this group.

813
00:42:15.030 --> 00:42:18.640
And if I look at the address,

814
00:42:18.640 --> 00:42:22.540
it's 192.168.0.1, but right beneath it,
here's those fake MAC addresses.

815
00:42:22.540 --> 00:42:26.985
And notice how there's two different ones,

816
00:42:26.985 --> 00:42:29.420
0007.b400.0101 and
the other one is 0102, okay?

817
00:42:30.710 --> 00:42:33.430
So, I've got two different MAC addresses.

818
00:42:33.430 --> 00:42:35.481
Those are the unique MAC
addresses that we hand out so

819
00:42:35.481 --> 00:42:37.957
that clients to know to connect to us,
and so you'll see that.

820
00:42:37.957 --> 00:42:40.360
But don't be surprised when you have one
entry in here that's not forwarding.

821
00:42:40.360 --> 00:42:46.470
That doesn't mean that you need to jump in
and fix something, bhat's just the AVG.

822
00:42:46.470 --> 00:42:52.320
And the AVG is currently local,
that's the active, and it has a standby.

823
00:42:52.320 --> 00:42:55.300
But notice how the forwarders
don't have a standby.

824
00:42:55.300 --> 00:42:57.170
Right, they just have a dash over here.

825
00:42:57.170 --> 00:42:58.980
Cuz a forwarder doesn't need a standby,
right?

826
00:42:58.980 --> 00:43:00.000
They're just forwarding.

827
00:43:00.000 --> 00:43:01.798
So it's really treated as
two different entities.

828
00:43:01.798 --> 00:43:04.155
Your AVG kinda has split personalities.

829
00:43:04.155 --> 00:43:07.634
Right, because it's an AVG and an AVF,
everybody else is just an AVF.

830
00:43:07.634 --> 00:43:08.737
So that output's a little bit weird.

831
00:43:08.737 --> 00:43:10.271
>> Our favorite schizophrenic protocol.

832
00:43:10.271 --> 00:43:12.751
[LAUGH]
>> That's it, it's really powerful,

833
00:43:12.751 --> 00:43:13.910
it's a great protocol.

834
00:43:13.910 --> 00:43:17.252
It's one people really wanna use,
you just have to have the hardware for it.

835
00:43:17.252 --> 00:43:21.440
You gotta pay some dough to get
GLBP in your environment, but

836
00:43:21.440 --> 00:43:22.950
it does a great job, it really works well.

837
00:43:22.950 --> 00:43:23.730
>> Awesome.
Well, Don,

838
00:43:23.730 --> 00:43:27.200
is there anything else we need to let
these good people know about when it comes

839
00:43:27.200 --> 00:43:29.980
to these redundancy and
load balancing protocols?

840
00:43:29.980 --> 00:43:31.390
>> That's about it.

841
00:43:31.390 --> 00:43:33.190
Just, real high level, just for

842
00:43:33.190 --> 00:43:36.200
your own memory,
the commands are real simple, right?

843
00:43:36.200 --> 00:43:39.920
Because they're really pretty much the
same commands for all three, VRRP, HSRP,

844
00:43:39.920 --> 00:43:41.420
and GLBP.

845
00:43:41.420 --> 00:43:45.960
The other thing you need to remember is
that HSRP and GLBP are Cisco proprietary,

846
00:43:45.960 --> 00:43:47.990
VRRP is an open standard.

847
00:43:47.990 --> 00:43:51.780
So third parties can support it
just as well as anybody else.

848
00:43:51.780 --> 00:43:55.475
So be aware of those differences,
be aware of how to configure them and

849
00:43:55.475 --> 00:43:59.590
kinda the key differences between
each one, and you'll do well.

850
00:43:59.590 --> 00:44:02.350
>> All right, well Don, thank you so
much for those demonstrations.

851
00:44:02.350 --> 00:44:03.410
Thank you for watching.

852
00:44:03.410 --> 00:44:05.250
Hopefully we'll see you
next time on ITProTV.

853
00:44:05.250 --> 00:44:07.250
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

854
00:44:07.250 --> 00:44:08.820
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

855
00:44:08.820 --> 00:44:09.415
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

856
00:44:09.415 --> 00:44:11.518
>> And we'll see you next time.

857
00:44:11.518 --> 00:44:18.100
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at some of the benefits and features of Layer 3 switches. Â They also discuss the limitations of using Layer 3 switches. Â The guys also show a basic inter-vlan configuration on a Layer 3 switch.
episodes.title: Layer 3 Switching
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.261
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.261 --> 00:00:12.881
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.881 --> 00:00:14.890
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:18.720
we're taking away a CCMP switch today,
and to help us out, Mr. Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.720 --> 00:00:19.560
How's it going?

6
00:00:19.560 --> 00:00:21.180
>> It is going great, Ronnie.

7
00:00:21.180 --> 00:00:24.290
Ready to jump into one of the cooler
topics that we get to see inside of

8
00:00:24.290 --> 00:00:25.710
the CCMP switch world.

9
00:00:25.710 --> 00:00:30.590
Now, for the switch exam, we're normally
talking about layer two topics, right?

10
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:32.150
Switches are layer two devices,

11
00:00:32.150 --> 00:00:35.160
we're trying to move frames
from one port to another.

12
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:38.930
But in this episode,
we're gonna look at layer three switching,

13
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:42.350
which is kind of a contradiction
to terms there, right?

14
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:44.610
Switch is layer two and
I'm talking about layer three.

15
00:00:44.610 --> 00:00:48.010
>> Yeah, Don, I know from the OSI model
that layer two, we have switches and

16
00:00:48.010 --> 00:00:49.840
layer three we have routers.

17
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:52.980
But you're talking about a layer three
switch that really is a contradiction to

18
00:00:52.980 --> 00:00:54.220
what we're normally seeing.

19
00:00:54.220 --> 00:00:56.900
>> Yeah, and it's a technology
that's evolved quite a bit and

20
00:00:56.900 --> 00:00:58.310
I'll tell you when I.

21
00:00:58.310 --> 00:01:01.930
The first layer three switch
that I worked on was in, oh,

22
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:06.460
shoot it would've been 1999 or
2000 and back then what you did,

23
00:01:06.460 --> 00:01:10.650
is you would get a Sysco switch
like those big 5500's back then.

24
00:01:10.650 --> 00:01:14.480
And you would actually
buy a router module.

25
00:01:14.480 --> 00:01:16.050
And you'd stick it into the switch,

26
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:20.760
you are effectively taking a physical
router and sticking it in your switch, so

27
00:01:20.760 --> 00:01:24.880
that the switch can do routing
right there inside of the device.

28
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:27.000
In today's world,
you still have that, right?

29
00:01:27.000 --> 00:01:31.400
If you get a 6500 series switch,
the really big one, you can put

30
00:01:31.400 --> 00:01:35.530
a supervisor module in there and it can
do the routing right there on the switch.

31
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:39.898
But even the lower end
switches like the 3560's,

32
00:01:39.898 --> 00:01:44.550
the 3750's, even the 2960's
can do it to a limited degree.

33
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:49.430
They can perform routing just right
there in software on the switch.

34
00:01:49.430 --> 00:01:50.400
And it's pretty neat, right?

35
00:01:50.400 --> 00:01:54.390
Let's start off with something
that's kindaimportant.

36
00:01:54.390 --> 00:01:56.530
Why would we bother doing this
in the first place, right?

37
00:01:56.530 --> 00:01:58.320
If you got routers that
are perfectly good at routing,

38
00:01:58.320 --> 00:02:02.120
and you got switches that are perfectly
good at switching, why mix the two?

39
00:02:02.120 --> 00:02:03.920
We're not talking about chocolate and
peanut butter here.

40
00:02:03.920 --> 00:02:05.870
It's not gonna be that perfect mixture.

41
00:02:05.870 --> 00:02:10.230
So, the main reason we do it is bandwidth,
right?

42
00:02:10.230 --> 00:02:12.500
When you go and buy a router,

43
00:02:12.500 --> 00:02:17.440
are you gonna be able to find a router
with ten gigs of bandwidth on it?

44
00:02:17.440 --> 00:02:18.410
You can they make them.

45
00:02:18.410 --> 00:02:20.110
They're expensive, right?

46
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:23.820
Most of the routers that you buy
today are only gonna be gigabit.

47
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:24.360
Right?

48
00:02:24.360 --> 00:02:27.700
So, if you have 2 gigabit
interfaces I could link to

49
00:02:27.700 --> 00:02:31.200
gigabit networks that have a gigabit of
bandwidth through them, and that's great.

50
00:02:31.200 --> 00:02:34.070
But if I want ten gig, now,
I got a bit of a problem.

51
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:35.640
I gotta find a router that has it.

52
00:02:35.640 --> 00:02:38.130
Or, if I need even more than ten gigs,

53
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:40.780
then we really start talking
about getting expensive.

54
00:02:40.780 --> 00:02:44.030
So, there's problem number
one is bandwidth and

55
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:45.820
problem number two is port density.

56
00:02:45.820 --> 00:02:48.450
When you go and buy a router how
many interfaces does it have?

57
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:49.600
>> Two or three?

58
00:02:49.600 --> 00:02:51.790
Most routers just have two or
three, right?

59
00:02:51.790 --> 00:02:54.760
And as you start to get into the higher
end routers, when you get to the 3900's,

60
00:02:54.760 --> 00:02:58.100
you can get modules and
it's pretty easy to throw in 12,

61
00:02:58.100 --> 00:03:02.795
even 24 ports on a 3900 if
you really kinda press it.

62
00:03:02.795 --> 00:03:06.995
If you start getting into the 7200's
you can get even more ports, but

63
00:03:06.995 --> 00:03:08.865
what if I need 100 ports?

64
00:03:08.865 --> 00:03:11.955
Well, now, it's pretty tough to
find a router that can do that,

65
00:03:11.955 --> 00:03:16.525
it's easy to find a switch with 100 ports,
it's harder to find a router.

66
00:03:16.525 --> 00:03:18.685
And especially,
a router that has the throughput,

67
00:03:18.685 --> 00:03:22.745
the ability to move enough data
through it to maintain high bandwidth.

68
00:03:22.745 --> 00:03:25.595
So, on wide area networks
that's not a problem right?

69
00:03:25.595 --> 00:03:30.340
On a WAN, when we're talking about
T1 lines and MPLS frame relay,

70
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:31.720
those types of connectivity,

71
00:03:31.720 --> 00:03:35.340
we're not usually talking about gigs
of bandwidth, and it's not a big deal.

72
00:03:35.340 --> 00:03:38.520
We're also not usually talking
about hundreds of interfaces.

73
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:41.440
So it's not a big deal,
routers can handle it just fine.

74
00:03:41.440 --> 00:03:46.390
But on a Local Area Network,
on a LAN, you might have many VLANs.

75
00:03:46.390 --> 00:03:50.990
And you need to route between those VLANs,
and finding a router

76
00:03:50.990 --> 00:03:55.150
with enough interfaces to do one
interface per VLAN is pretty hard to do.

77
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:59.118
It gets pretty expensive and creates this
massive single point of failure right

78
00:03:59.118 --> 00:04:02.075
there on your In your network, so
that's a pretty big challenge there.

79
00:04:02.075 --> 00:04:03.270
Right?

80
00:04:03.270 --> 00:04:06.370
Now, over the years, there have been
different solutions to this, and

81
00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:07.600
one solution was router on a stick.

82
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:09.030
>> Ronnie,
you remember router on a stick, right?

83
00:04:09.030 --> 00:04:11.930
>> Yeah, with router on a stick, what we
do is we, of course, connect the actual

84
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:17.220
layer two switch to a layer three router
and even between VLANs, we'd actually

85
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:21.040
have to take traffic from one VLAN,
shuffle it out to, of course, the router.

86
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:24.970
The router would then route it out on
that same length into the separate VLAN.

87
00:04:24.970 --> 00:04:28.800
So, being able to do router on a stick
was actually a great configuration

88
00:04:28.800 --> 00:04:30.600
on a fairly small network.

89
00:04:30.600 --> 00:04:33.740
But then again, you're still having
that one gig port, normally.

90
00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:37.390
And so you do have a lot of VLANs or if
you're actually doing something like VTP

91
00:04:37.390 --> 00:04:41.520
between multiple switches, it can get
a little bit more hefty at that point.

92
00:04:41.520 --> 00:04:44.660
So, even though the solution is not
the greatest solution, if you really need

93
00:04:44.660 --> 00:04:48.740
that high speed traffic that we normally
do need between different networks.

94
00:04:48.740 --> 00:04:51.240
>> Yeah, and if you've never done
router on a stick, first off,

95
00:04:51.240 --> 00:04:54.610
I don't blame you,
it was a great solution.

96
00:04:54.610 --> 00:04:57.860
It was the only thing we had for a while,
where you basically configured a trunk

97
00:04:57.860 --> 00:05:02.090
port, right, so a VLAN trunk port
between your switch and your router.

98
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:05.010
And then on your router,
you could create virtual sub interfaces.

99
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:07.970
In fact, let me, yeah, I'll show you guys
real quick, just if you haven't seen it

100
00:05:07.970 --> 00:05:11.430
before, so I've got this router here and
it's a 2900 right?

101
00:05:11.430 --> 00:05:16.080
If I look at my version output here,
so it's not a great router, but

102
00:05:16.080 --> 00:05:19.620
it's good enough and it's got
a couple of gig ports on it right?

103
00:05:19.620 --> 00:05:25.470
So it's got three gigabit Ethernet
interfaces on it that I can use here and

104
00:05:25.470 --> 00:05:27.730
those interfaces that kind of limits us.

105
00:05:27.730 --> 00:05:30.410
I can connect to three VLANs,
I have three interfaces.

106
00:05:30.410 --> 00:05:32.205
But what if I have five or ten VLANs.

107
00:05:32.205 --> 00:05:34.510
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can take one of those interfaces and

108
00:05:34.510 --> 00:05:38.410
break it up to have virtual
sub-interfaces, and

109
00:05:38.410 --> 00:05:40.950
I can use those as a trunk to my network.

110
00:05:40.950 --> 00:05:45.610
So, if I take a look at the configuration
of one of those interfaces,

111
00:05:45.610 --> 00:05:46.325
I'll take gi0/0, right?

112
00:05:46.325 --> 00:05:50.127
So it's 192.168.16.2 and that's it.

113
00:05:50.127 --> 00:05:51.218
It's up and it's running.

114
00:05:51.218 --> 00:05:56.449
Now, it has no knowledge of VLANs because
this is just an access port on the switch,

115
00:05:56.449 --> 00:05:56.990
right?

116
00:05:56.990 --> 00:05:59.180
The switch is putting us on VLAN one and

117
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:04.190
that's what that one is, right, but
if I had VLANs two, three, four, and five.

118
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:08.070
I could come in and start to add those
in here as virtual sub-interfaces.

119
00:06:08.070 --> 00:06:12.754
So, in my configuration I could
jump in and I could say interface

120
00:06:12.754 --> 00:06:17.950
gi0/0.2 like that, and
I'm creating a sub-interface.

121
00:06:17.950 --> 00:06:21.530
And when you do that, you have to tell it
the encapsulation that you're using and

122
00:06:21.530 --> 00:06:23.830
I'm gonna tell it, encapsulation.1q so,

123
00:06:23.830 --> 00:06:26.460
it knows that I'm gonna be
building an 802.1q trunk and

124
00:06:26.460 --> 00:06:30.270
it got mad at me cuz I didn't follow
it up with what VLAN it was gonna be.

125
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:33.800
You have to tell it all right,
this one's gonna be on VLAN 2 and

126
00:06:33.800 --> 00:06:38.720
then I can give it an IP address of
whatever it is that I want it to have or

127
00:06:38.720 --> 00:06:40.390
I'll just give it a fake one.

128
00:06:40.390 --> 00:06:45.020
And I could continue doing that for

00:06:45.020 --> 00:06:49.490
So, maybe I've got VLAN 3 out there,

00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:52.650
And I just keep going,
adding in each of my different networks.

131
00:06:52.650 --> 00:06:57.280
Now, the cool part about this
is that I have one interface

00:06:57.280 --> 00:07:01.220
that I've now got set up for

133
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:06.620
So, if I take a look at my config for
that, you'll see

134
00:07:06.620 --> 00:07:13.180
where I've got the 0/0 interface and then

00:07:13.180 --> 00:07:16.840
And I can continue adding more
sub-interfaces as I needed them

136
00:07:16.840 --> 00:07:20.610
to finally get to where I've
got all my VLANs represented.

137
00:07:20.610 --> 00:07:25.770
And when I do a show IP route, they just
show up in here as connected routes.

138
00:07:25.770 --> 00:07:28.910
So, I'm connected to 192.168.16.17.18,

139
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:31.930
So, this is the old solution.

140
00:07:31.930 --> 00:07:33.450
If I wanted to route between these VLANs,

141
00:07:33.450 --> 00:07:36.740
I could take one router,
set it up as a trunk.

142
00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:39.620
The port that I'm plugged into on
the switch, I'd need to configure that as

143
00:07:39.620 --> 00:07:44.150
a trunk so that I'm carrying VLANs 2,
3 and 4, and off we go, right?

144
00:07:44.150 --> 00:07:45.980
Well, there's one problem.

145
00:07:45.980 --> 00:07:48.260
Right, first of all, I mean,
that all works,it works great.

146
00:07:48.260 --> 00:07:50.670
But the problem is, it's one line.

147
00:07:50.670 --> 00:07:52.720
And like Ronnie said,
it's a gig leak, right?

148
00:07:52.720 --> 00:07:54.470
But it's not even just that.

149
00:07:54.470 --> 00:07:58.234
My traffic, if I'm routing
something from VLAN 2 to VLAN 3.

150
00:07:58.234 --> 00:08:02.274
I had to send the traffic up
the gig link to the router.

151
00:08:02.274 --> 00:08:04.614
The router moves it over the VLAN 3 and

152
00:08:04.614 --> 00:08:08.500
then it's gonna come down
the same link on the other VLAN.

153
00:08:08.500 --> 00:08:11.990
So I'm using send and receive bandwidth.

154
00:08:11.990 --> 00:08:14.880
Now, gig links like this
one are full duplex.

155
00:08:14.880 --> 00:08:17.230
So I can send and receive at the same
time, that's should be okay but

156
00:08:17.230 --> 00:08:18.780
everybody else is doing the same thing.

157
00:08:18.780 --> 00:08:22.710
Everybody else is going up and
down that same line.

158
00:08:22.710 --> 00:08:26.910
I've created a bottleneck on my network,
and that's the bad part.

159
00:08:26.910 --> 00:08:32.700
So if we could take this router and
stick it inside of the switch,

160
00:08:32.700 --> 00:08:35.510
now I don't have a link that I've
gotta go up and come back down.

161
00:08:35.510 --> 00:08:40.600
I don't have this bandwidth contention or
whatever, it's all inside of the switch.

162
00:08:40.600 --> 00:08:45.400
And so that solves one problem and we get
another really cool benefit along with it.

163
00:08:45.400 --> 00:08:49.725
The router that's inside of the switch
can be directly wired in to the back

164
00:08:49.725 --> 00:08:51.510
plane of the switch.

165
00:08:51.510 --> 00:08:56.440
And that means you can
route packets at speeds

166
00:08:56.440 --> 00:09:01.090
that aren't realizable on a normal router,
on a traditional, affordable router.

167
00:09:01.090 --> 00:09:07.290
So for example, when I look at this router
here, it's a 2900 and it has gig boards.

168
00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:10.510
So I can't move more than a gig
of data in any direction, right?

169
00:09:10.510 --> 00:09:14.080
I can be sending a gig or receiving
a gig or doing both at the same time.

170
00:09:14.080 --> 00:09:17.230
But I can never get more than a gigabit of
bandwidth on this because that's what I'm

171
00:09:17.230 --> 00:09:18.710
tied to right?

172
00:09:18.710 --> 00:09:21.580
But on a Cisco switch,
you have a back plane.

173
00:09:21.580 --> 00:09:25.070
And the back plane is
usually significantly higher

174
00:09:25.070 --> 00:09:27.875
than whatever the speed of
the ports happen to be,all right.

175
00:09:27.875 --> 00:09:30.840
Because Cisco switches
operate on this principle of,

176
00:09:30.840 --> 00:09:33.710
well they call it subscription and
over subscription,

177
00:09:33.710 --> 00:09:38.920
that if I get a 48 port and
they're 48, one gig

178
00:09:38.920 --> 00:09:44.590
ports I could potentially be generating
48 gigs of traffic in either direction.

179
00:09:44.590 --> 00:09:45.670
Right?

180
00:09:45.670 --> 00:09:48.070
But the back plane of the switch
is probably not 48 gigs.

181
00:09:48.070 --> 00:09:52.270
Because Cisco knows that not every
port is talking to each other.

182
00:09:52.270 --> 00:09:55.970
So it's normally gonna be
something like 16 gigs or 32 gigs.

183
00:09:55.970 --> 00:09:57.500
And ports are sharing.

184
00:09:57.500 --> 00:09:58.070
Right?
So

185
00:09:58.070 --> 00:10:00.600
you're over subscribing your back plane.

186
00:10:00.600 --> 00:10:03.940
Potentially I could have more port traffic
then what's available in the back plain.

187
00:10:03.940 --> 00:10:08.405
But even at 32 gigs if I'm over
subscribed, I still have more bandwidth

188
00:10:08.405 --> 00:10:11.050
than this router's gonna
have with a single gig link.

189
00:10:11.050 --> 00:10:13.790
So when you buy a Cisco switch,
if you get the cheap ones, right.

190
00:10:13.790 --> 00:10:14.750
You get a 2960.

191
00:10:14.750 --> 00:10:18.720
It's usually,
eight ports assuming it's gig,

192
00:10:18.720 --> 00:10:22.260
it's usually eight ports sharing a one
gig connection to the back plane.

193
00:10:22.260 --> 00:10:23.490
So if you look at the front of the switch,

194
00:10:23.490 --> 00:10:26.140
you'll actually see these little
yellow boxes drawn around ports.

195
00:10:26.140 --> 00:10:28.630
That are showing you
the clusters that they create.

196
00:10:28.630 --> 00:10:31.102
So these eight ports
share a gig connection.

197
00:10:31.102 --> 00:10:32.182
These eight ports share a gig.

198
00:10:32.182 --> 00:10:33.401
These eight ports share a gig.

199
00:10:33.401 --> 00:10:34.850
Right?

200
00:10:34.850 --> 00:10:37.076
And on a higher end switch, like a 3750,

201
00:10:37.076 --> 00:10:39.426
which is what I've been
using most of the show.

202
00:10:39.426 --> 00:10:42.701
This 3750s,
they don't over subscribe, and so

203
00:10:42.701 --> 00:10:47.395
if you've got a 24 port 3750,
it's got a 24 gig back plane.

204
00:10:47.395 --> 00:10:50.105
Usually more because of
the uplink ports that are on it.

205
00:10:50.105 --> 00:10:54.375
And so these switches cost more, but
there's a reason for that, right?

206
00:10:54.375 --> 00:10:57.875
Because they're able to handle all
the bandwidth that you shove at them.

207
00:10:57.875 --> 00:11:02.065
Now unfortunately there's not a great
way to see what your bandwidth is

208
00:11:02.065 --> 00:11:04.340
right here on the switch itself.

209
00:11:04.340 --> 00:11:06.700
You've really gotta go to
Cisco's documentation.

210
00:11:06.700 --> 00:11:08.792
If you go an dig up Cisco's documentation,

211
00:11:08.792 --> 00:11:11.740
like here's I've the 6500s
kinda pulled up.

212
00:11:11.740 --> 00:11:14.100
When you go and
start reading on the switches,

213
00:11:14.100 --> 00:11:18.190
it'll tell you about the back plane,
right?

214
00:11:18.190 --> 00:11:19.640
When you buy that switch,

215
00:11:19.640 --> 00:11:23.060
it's comes in different models that have
different amounts of back plane bandwidth.

216
00:11:23.060 --> 00:11:28.604
And so you'll see down here like if
we have a Cisco 6500 with the SFM2,

217
00:11:28.604 --> 00:11:33.105
you can get up to 256 gigabit
of bandwidth on that switch.

218
00:11:33.105 --> 00:11:38.312
That might be a little bit of overkill for
us but if I have a virtual router floating

219
00:11:38.312 --> 00:11:43.700
on the back plane, that means the router
can be routing 256 gigs of data at once.

220
00:11:43.700 --> 00:11:46.875
Now it's not normally that bad because of
the way you have your separate control

221
00:11:46.875 --> 00:11:47.470
plane and all that.

222
00:11:47.470 --> 00:11:52.180
So you're never truly routing a full 256,
but you could be doing that, and

223
00:11:52.180 --> 00:11:54.690
you'll see they have models that
go all the way up to 720 gigabits.

224
00:11:54.690 --> 00:11:57.610
You can get huge amounts of bandwidth.

225
00:11:57.610 --> 00:11:59.339
Even on your cheaper switches.

226
00:11:59.339 --> 00:12:01.010
I shouldn't say cheaper here.

227
00:12:01.010 --> 00:12:02.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Less expensive switches,

228
00:12:02.870 --> 00:12:07.060
even on like a 3560, The back plane
on those is still pretty significant.

229
00:12:07.060 --> 00:12:08.560
You can move a lot more
data than a router.

230
00:12:08.560 --> 00:12:09.650
All right?

231
00:12:09.650 --> 00:12:13.110
So that's the main reason why we might
choose to do layer three switching,

232
00:12:13.110 --> 00:12:16.440
is we could get way better
bandwidth out of this

00:12:16.440 --> 00:12:19.070
than we would by doing
it on a router itself.

234
00:12:19.070 --> 00:12:19.880
All right?

00:12:19.880 --> 00:12:22.010
But it's not all sunshine and rainbows.

00:12:22.010 --> 00:12:25.040
When you switch this,
there's certain things that you give up.

237
00:12:25.040 --> 00:12:30.080
Certain things that you can do on
a router but you can't do on a switch.

238
00:12:30.080 --> 00:12:31.230
All right?

239
00:12:31.230 --> 00:12:32.890
The number one thing?

00:12:32.890 --> 00:12:34.870
If I take a look at my interfaces, right?

00:12:34.870 --> 00:12:37.420
Or here, even in the show version,

00:12:37.420 --> 00:12:40.010
When I take a look at
the interfaces on my switch,

00:12:40.010 --> 00:12:42.270
what kind of interfaces am I gonna have?

00:12:42.270 --> 00:12:45.810
Well on this one,

On this one what you'll see is

Right.

I've got 24 fast Ethernet interfaces.

I've got two gigabit Ethernet interfaces.

How many serial ports do I have?

>> None.
>> None.

00:12:58.290 --> 00:12:59.720
You know, that's the thing.

00:12:59.720 --> 00:13:03.060
On a switch it is really switching for
Ethernet networks.

00:13:03.060 --> 00:13:04.940
What if I need MPLS?

00:13:04.940 --> 00:13:06.700
What if I need frame relay?

00:13:06.700 --> 00:13:09.430
What if I have a T1 that's

00:13:11.060 --> 00:13:12.190
Switches don't do that.

257
00:13:12.190 --> 00:13:13.650
Switches are LAN devices.

258
00:13:13.650 --> 00:13:15.290
Local area networks not
wide area networks.

259
00:13:15.290 --> 00:13:16.910
They are not going to do that, right?

00:13:16.910 --> 00:13:18.230
There are some switches that will do it.

261
00:13:18.230 --> 00:13:22.280
When you start getting in to

262
00:13:22.280 --> 00:13:25.600
But on your mid-tier and low-end switches

263
00:13:25.600 --> 00:13:28.300
On a router if I need a T1 interface,
no big deal.

264
00:13:28.300 --> 00:13:31.540
You just buy a serial HWIC and
pop it in there and you're in business.

265
00:13:31.540 --> 00:13:34.420
Or a module you throw in there and
you got it.

266
00:13:34.420 --> 00:13:35.740
On a switch, you don't have that.

00:13:35.740 --> 00:13:37.710
That's the first thing we give up.

00:13:37.710 --> 00:13:41.090
The other thing we give up

269
00:13:41.090 --> 00:13:44.140
There's certain protocols that
work just fine on a router but

00:13:44.140 --> 00:13:45.320
don't work on a switch.

271
00:13:45.320 --> 00:13:49.460
A great example of that would be NAT,

00:13:49.460 --> 00:13:54.480
If I'm on a switch, so well,
just kinda first rule of layer three

00:13:54.480 --> 00:13:57.550

So I'm just gonna issue an IP routing

00:14:00.225 --> 00:14:01.520
right.

00:14:01.520 --> 00:14:06.250
And if I do a show ip nat translations,

00:14:09.750 --> 00:14:10.330
Right?

00:14:10.330 --> 00:14:12.280
But, if I take a look at show ip nat and

00:14:12.280 --> 00:14:14.800
do a question mark,

00:14:14.800 --> 00:14:16.314
Right?
They're there, so

00:14:16.314 --> 00:14:18.530

00:14:18.530 --> 00:14:22.860
Well, what you'll find is this is one

00:14:26.440 --> 00:14:30.600

00:14:30.600 --> 00:14:36.350
If I were to try to get into interface

00:14:37.570 --> 00:14:39.010
It didn't work, right.

00:14:39.010 --> 00:14:41.620
So I can't actually enable NAT.

00:14:41.620 --> 00:14:43.953
So the fact that the show commands
are there doesn't really help me, right.

290
00:14:43.953 --> 00:14:45.056
I'm giving that up.

291
00:14:45.056 --> 00:14:49.440
Same thing with some routing protocols,
you'll find that, even if you have a layer

00:14:49.440 --> 00:14:53.780
three switch, you might have support for

00:14:53.780 --> 00:14:58.230
So I might say, router RIP,

00:14:58.230 --> 00:15:00.510
But sometimes they won't be there.

00:15:00.510 --> 00:15:03.160
So notice I've got like router BGP,

00:15:03.160 --> 00:15:05.780
Most layer three switches

00:15:05.780 --> 00:15:08.100

00:15:08.100 --> 00:15:11.150
You don't need BGP when you're

00:15:11.150 --> 00:15:12.750

00:15:12.750 --> 00:15:14.410
Some of them will, some won't.

Some might do OSPF but not do RIP.

00:15:17.360 --> 00:15:20.670
So understand that not all your

00:15:20.670 --> 00:15:22.380
Even though they show up in the commands,

00:15:22.380 --> 00:15:25.750
sometimes you go to enable them and

00:15:25.750 --> 00:15:28.207
Well, in this case this

306
00:15:28.207 --> 00:15:29.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> So this one has it,

00:15:29.560 --> 00:15:30.410
not every switch does.

308
00:15:30.410 --> 00:15:33.800
Just be aware that you are giving up

00:15:33.800 --> 00:15:36.160
So it's not that we don't

00:15:36.160 --> 00:15:38.780
routers still serve a very specific place.

00:15:38.780 --> 00:15:41.820
It's just sometimes we can use

00:15:41.820 --> 00:15:46.100
>> Now,Don, is there any advantage,

with the way that the A6 work in

>> Well, it depends on the switch.

00:15:51.070 --> 00:15:53.818
So, when you have a router,
a router has hardware.

00:15:53.818 --> 00:15:54.987
Ronnie mentioned ASIC's, right?

00:15:54.987 --> 00:15:58.312
Application specific integrated
circuits It's microchips that

Now we're making you do something

Well, on a low end switch or

00:16:11.340 --> 00:16:14.260
on some of the mid tiers,

00:16:14.260 --> 00:16:16.320
And so they're doing it in software,

00:16:16.320 --> 00:16:20.090
So, if you have a complex network,

00:16:20.090 --> 00:16:23.800
policy based routing, the switches

00:16:23.800 --> 00:16:25.244
Routers do a great job of that.

00:16:25.244 --> 00:16:29.708
But when you start getting into the higher

00:16:34.443 --> 00:16:37.992
They've got the hardware for the router

00:16:37.992 --> 00:16:41.985
supervisor module that you pop into it,

00:16:41.985 --> 00:16:45.685
So there is a difference between whether

00:16:45.685 --> 00:16:47.415
in software, all right?

00:16:47.415 --> 00:16:51.085
And let's build on that hardware and

00:16:51.085 --> 00:16:54.650
So, on a router,

00:16:54.650 --> 00:16:57.010
to each network that you're

00:16:57.010 --> 00:16:58.440
On a switch you don't, right?

00:16:58.440 --> 00:17:00.260
And let's take a look at my switch here.

00:17:00.260 --> 00:17:05.156
So, I've got this switch, and
it's a 3750, I think 24 ports, and

00:17:05.156 --> 00:17:09.216
if I take a look at the interfaces
that are available, right?

00:17:09.216 --> 00:17:14.080
I've got FA 1/0/1, and on it goes, right?

00:17:14.080 --> 00:17:16.790
But notice how I don't have IP

None of these interfaces have an IP.

00:17:19.110 --> 00:17:23.150
Because it's on a router that we

00:17:23.150 --> 00:17:26.610
On a switch,

00:17:26.610 --> 00:17:29.710
And so you can see I've got

00:17:29.710 --> 00:17:33.040
A virtual interface, you might be

Technically, it is, yes.

But it's software that the switch

00:17:37.250 --> 00:17:41.630
So it's got this interface that has an IP,

00:17:41.630 --> 00:17:43.470
I can add ports to it.

And now they're a part of that network and

Switches do support doing

00:17:49.850 --> 00:17:51.873
I could assign a physical

00:17:51.873 --> 00:17:55.606
Maybe I wanna take,
I'll take port number 12 over here and
